Homemaking Development Through Homemaking Education— Woman's Role in Family Preparedness Preview of Discussions—1969-70 Celestia J. Taylor From the very beginning of this dispensation of the restoration of the gospel, our Church leaders have never ceased to admonish and advise us to maintain and provide for our families, not only in times of prosperity and plenty, but also in times of need and emergency. With the world in a turmoil of uncertainty and confusion, it is of greater importance than ever before that we heed the counsel of our leaders and prepare our homes so that our families will be provided for in any emergency which might, and very well could, arise. For this reason, the following course of study has been worked out for our homemaking discussions. Discussion 1—''She Looketh Well to the Ways of Her Household.'' (Prov. 31:27.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 Objective: To show the need for family preparedness and the role of the Latter-day Saint woman in achieving it. Discussion 2—"'She Perceiveth That Her Merchandise Is Good: Her Candle Goeth Not Out By Night." (Prov. 31:18.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, November 1969 Southern Hemisphere: April 1970 Objective: To show that buying wisely and saving regularly are basic to good money management. 471 June 1969 Discussion 3—''The Heart of Her Husband Doth Safely Trust in Her, So That He Shall Have No Need For Spoil.'' (Prov. 31:11.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, December 1969 Southern Hemisphere: May 1970 Objective: To recognize that debt must be controlled to insure family happiness and financial security. Discussion 4—''She Considereth a Field and Buyeth It: With the Fruit of Her Hands She Planteth a Vineyard." (Prov. 31:16.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 Objective: To point out the woman's responsibility in planning and managing a successful family budget. Discussion 5—''She... Worketh Willingly With Her Hands." (Prov. 31:13.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 Objective: To alert the Latter-day Saint woman to the wisdom of preparing for family security through home storage of foods. Discussion 6—''She Is Not Afraid of the Snow for Her Household: For All Her Household Are Clothed With Scarlet. (Prov. 31:21.) Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 Objective: To alert the Latter-day Saint woman to the wisdom of preparing for family security through home storage of basic items other than food. NOTE: A demonstration would be given in July and August and recipes furnished. A SOCIAL RELATIONS Immortality and Eternal Life Preview of Lessons 1969-70 Alberta H. Christensen As we approach the 1969-70 social relations lessons, based again upon the writings of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., we recall the words of Lord Byron: But words are things; and a small drop of ink, Falling like dew, upon a thought, produces That which makes thousands, perhaps millions, think. During the coming year we shall be concerned with words—motivating, thought-evoking words which may inspire thousands of Latter-day Saint women throughout the world. During the years of President Clark's membership in the First Presidency of the Church, April 1933-October 1961, he delivered numerous addresses to graduating university students, to Church auxiliary organizations, at general Church conferences and elsewhere. In these addresses many principles of the gospel were impressively clarified and truths fundamental in constructive, righteous living became beckoning roads for the listeners to follow. Some of these addresses preserved in written form constitute the Melchizedek Priesthood course of study for 1969-70. The companion Relief Society lessons will again correlate with a number of them. Ques- 473 June 1969 tions important as the following are among those to be considered in the social relations lessons: Is restraint really the road to freedom? How are our everyday activities influenced by the immutable laws of the universe? How important is work in achieving personal happiness? How does the role of woman relating to the eternal plan of creation place her in a position of honor? How may a mother's knowledge of the ultimate destiny of the family unit influence her attitude toward what otherwise might seem merely housewife routine? What would be included in the inherent upward reach of man? In some cases the correlation with the Melchizedek Priesthood course of study will be very close and the words of President Clark will be quoted frequently. This will give the Relief Society women an opportunity to feel the spirit and individuality of President Clark's writings. In other cases significant statements made by President Clark will form the basis for a lesson channeled more specifically to a woman's everyday world. The emphasis thus will be on a woman's relationship to her Father in heaven, to herself, and to her family, with some consideration of neighborhood situations. We remind class leaders that. The introduction to each lesson should be a helpful guide in their lesson preparation. They are urged also to make full use of the involvement suggestions so that class members will be motivated to think and to participate actively in the discussion of gospel principles and human behavior situations being considered. Lesson 1—Restraint—Road to Freedom, Part 1 Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 Objective: To point out a mother's opportunity to teach the need and benefits of complying with the restraints of the immutable laws of the universe. Lesson 2—Restraint—Road to Freedom, Part 2 Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, November 1969 Southern Hemisphere: April 1970 Objective: To point out that understanding the difference between immutable spiritual and physical laws and the regulations which apply to them, may influence one's attitude toward the regulations. Lesson 3—The Upward Reach > Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, December 1969 Southern Hemisphere: May 1970 Objective: To illustrate that all may enjoy man's material progress but our spiritual achievements must be individually attained. Lesson 4—Work—A Road to Personal Fulfillment Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 Objective: To emphasize the value of work in meeting the requirements of happiness and of divine admonition. 474 Lesson Previews Lesson 5—Be of Good Cheer Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 Objective: To remind the Latter-day Saint woman that the gospel of Christ brings a message of gladness to her home. Lesson 6—A Position of Honor Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 Objective: To point out that the role of woman is essential to the eternal plan of creation and that she therefore occupies a position of honor. Lesson 7—Purpose and Reward Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, April 1970 Southern Hemisphere: September 1970 Objective: To point out that if a Latter-day Saint woman will keep the ultimate destiny of the family unit constantly in mind, she may be purposefully motivated in her daily living. Lesson 8—''Whither Goest Thou?" Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, May 1970 Southern Hemisphere: October 1970 Objective: To reemphasize some of the truths in the writings of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., which may influence for good the behavior patterns of our lives. Cultural Refinement Ideals of Womanhood in Relation to Home and the Family Preview of Lessons for 1969-70 Bruce B. Clark (Textbook: Out of the Best Books, Volume 5: Community Responsibility, by Bruce B. Clark and Robert K. Thomas.) The Cultural Refinement program of lessons using Out of the Best Books as a basic text has now functioned for five years in the Relief Society organization. Volume 5, to be used during 1969-70, will complete the sixth year of what was planned from the beginning as a six-year program. Volume 1, used in 1964-65 and 1965-66, stressed the individual and human values as seen through literature and the related arts. Volumes 2 and 3, used in 1966-67 and 1967-68, widened the horizon, emphasizing ideals and problems in marriage, parenthood, and family relationships. Now the closing two years of the program, Volume 4 for 1968-69 and Volume 5 for 1969-70, widen the scope still further, stressinga woman's activities andresponsibilitiesin community life and the world in which she lives. 475 June 1969 As pointed out a year ago, no individual or family can exist in isolation. In many significant ways a woman's first responsibility is to herself and to her family, but she also needs to function meaningfully with other people—as a friend and neighbor, as a Church worker, and as a citizen of the community, the nation, and the world. Moreover, in all of these things she needs to find a happy balance between work, recreation, relaxation, spirituality, and cultural fulfillment. Each lesson in the Cultural Refinement program for this year will focus upon community involvement that is meaningful, wholesome, and well balanced. As in former years, each section of the text will include more material than can easily be covered in a single lesson. This is done intentionally so that each class leader may choose those selections that she responds to with enthusiasm and that she feels are especially appropriate to her group. It is far better to cover one or two selections thoroughly and in such a way that they really touch the lives of the women than it is to cover all of the selections hastily and superficially. Any selections not used in the Relief Society lessons are still available for excellent enrichment readings within the home. The year ahead will be the fourth year in which music and painting are used to supplement the literature in each lesson. Once again we encourage class leaders to harmonize the music and art as fully as possible into the lesson goals for each month rather than use them merely as decoration. We know that this is difficult, but the challenge can be met with careful advance planning, i. E., by careful allocation of time, by using them either as introductory or concluding material, or by using them as special assignments. Once again we also urge class leaders to get as many Relief Society sisters as possible personally involved in each lesson. If the lesson is simply a monthly presentation by the teacher to women who have not read the material and do not participate in experiencing it, the lesson probably will not be very meaningful. All Relief Society sisters should be encouraged to read the selections in advance, participate in presenting them or at least in discussing them, and then take them home to their husbands and children for family enrichment. With this approach each lesson can be deeply meaningful and permanently useful. The overall theme for the year is "Woman's fulfillment through service to others and involvement in the lives of others" and the outline of individual lessons is as follows: Lesson 1—The Meaning of Freedom "My soul standeth fast in that liberty in the which God hath made us free.''—Book of Mormon (Al. 61:9.) The Cover: Frontispiece: Art Layout: INustrations: = BY HANDCART CAME They knew how far it was By measured longings for a home. Exulting as they went, their cart wheels spun Into the garnet-studded West. Children of the evening, they? No, of the noon. The scars of the night were washed away, The Zion of their days begun. A thousand miles and pull a cart! They, of avalanche and stone, Of fiords and crags, Of bounties of the sea and shore. Possessions now, were millstones gone. The throated burning in their breasts Enough to feed upon. They knew how far it was, The lingering distance stalked with death. With spider strength, dragged Carcasses of bed and skillet, Flour and salt, through grass of June, July's scorched lips, then to lay their burdens down Upon November's sod. Ground so hallowed, pray Walk....... Unshod. —Hazel Loomis Meeting of Desert and Mountains, Southern Utah Transparency by Lucien Bown Lithographed in Full Color by Deseret News Press Handcart in the West Photograph by Dorothy J. Doxey Professor of Scripture Brigham Young University [Editorial Note: The concluding year of the study of the Doctrine and Covenants will begin in October 1969 in the Northern Hemisphere and in March 1970 in the Southern Hemisphere. ] ws I assume that it would be a little easier if I were to address myself to the subject: "When Did I Begin to Study the Gospel of Jesus Christ?" instead of "How I Became Involved in The Doctrine and Covenants,' because the Doctrine and Covenants _ gives us the gospel. In fact, if we were to analyze its doctrines, I do not believe it could be surpassed by any of the other three books of scripture accepted by the Latter-day Saints. Furthermore, we would learn that it is the repository of many doctrines of salvation which are only mentioned or inferred in those other books. Formative Years in the Priesthood As far as I am concerned, my interest in the study of the gospel began when I became a deacon in the Aaronic Priesthood. Il believe that because I was 484 given responsibility at that time my interest in the gospel was heightened. It was the practice of the counselor in the bishopric who had charge of the quorum to give assignments to the quorum members to participate in giving parts of the lesson. As an ordained teacher, I became the teacher of the quorum under the direction of a member of the ward bishopric. This practice continued in the priest's quorum; consequently, my interest in the gospel became very great during those formative years in the priesthood. This foundation proved very helpful in preparation for a mission, so much that when I was called to be a missionary at the age of twenty-two, I felt that I was prepared to teach the gospel when I arrived in the mission field. My interest in the gospel was theological; consequently, I learned the doctrines of the Church from all of the standard works, especially with an emphasis upon the Bible since I knew I would use it as the ip ven Lon Lon Lon Xoo Kon Koo) ' ¢ OV CRONO: 5 O1R0. It wasn't until some years later, except for the use of many pas- - sages in the Doctrine and Covenants which provided clear explanations of particular. Doctrines, that I really studied the Doctrine and Covenants in depth. The True Concept of God Among many other fundamental doctrines, the missionary teaches the investigator the true concept of God. Of all the doctrines of the gospel this one stands out as one of the most important for people to know since it is life eternal to know God. (John 17:3.) One of the difficulties a nonmember may have in accepting the concept that God is personal, having a body of flesh and bones, is God's attribute of omnipresence. The apostate "Christian" world believes that God is a spirit without form; whereas the Lord has revealed to his prophets, ancient and modern, that he has a body. He may be said, however, to be a spirit the same as "man is spirit;" that is, he, as well as. Man, has always been a spirit, from eternity to eternity though in earth-life and the resurrected state the personal spirit is associated with a body. (D&C 93: 33; 130:22.) If God has a tangible body, and he is not a spirit only, then how can he be omnipresent, or everywhere? The "Light of Christ" or spirit of the Lord emanates from God to fill all space. (Acts 17:27-28; D&C 88:12.) Because of this omnipresent power, God has communication with all of his creations, and thus he is everywhere, as the scriptures aver. Salient Principles of Doctrine and Covenants The Doctrine and Covenant is different from the other three standard works of the Church because it is a little more difficult to maintain interest in sustained reading unless one has a definite objective in his reading, such as theological. There is relatively no narrative in the Doctrine and Covenants. The exception to this is Section 135, the historical account of the martyrdom of the Prophet Joseph Smith and his brother Hyrum 'at Carthage Jail 125 years ago. I presume that it would not be amiss to suggest an exaggerated comparison of the Doctrine and Covenants and reading the dictionary—in both, there is statement after statement of truths not always connected with the preceding information. This fact, however, has its advantages. One does not have to look very far to find rich, inspiring thoughts. Also, one must concentrate on his reading in order not to miss salient principles. Years ago I realized that many members of the Church might find difficulty in keeping up their interest in reading the Doctrine and Covenants, so I conceived the idea that this book could be enjoyed more and learned better, perhaps, through the commentaries of the prophets, seers, and revelators of the dispensation. With this and other purposes in mind, I set out to compile such a work, using the sermons and writings of the members of the First Presidencies, Twelve Apostles, and the Patriarchs to the Church to explain 485 July 1969 the Doctrine and Covenants. For well over five years I labored on this project which culminated in the four volumes of The Latter-Day Prophets and the Doctrine and Covenants, published from 1963 to 1965. I have known young as well as old people who have shown unusual interest in the Doctrine and Covenants through the use of these volumes. Writings of Elder B. H. Roberts In the years when I was learning the teachings of the Church, I was impressed with the writings of Elder B. H. Roberts of the First Council of Seventy. I remember his quoting a passage from George Rawlinson's Historical Evidences of the Truth of the Scripture Records, as follows:. Of this we may be sure, that if any new forms of evidence should hereafter be needed, to meet any new forms of unbelief, and authenticate afresh the word of truth, they will be found deposited somewhere, waiting for the fulness of time; and God will bring them forth in their season, from the dark hieroglyphics, or the desert sands, or the dusty manuscripts, to confound the adversaries of his word, and to magnify it above all his name. (Quoted in New Witness for God, Volume II, Forewords.) Under the caption of "The World's Hunger For Knowledge of The Christ," President Roberts quoted the following from the Life of the Master by Rev. John Watson: Were a parchment discovered in an Egyptian mound, six inches square, containing fifty words which were certainly spoken by Jesus, this utterance would count more than all the books which have been published since the first century. (Ibid.) 486 Although Elder Roberts used these quotations to support the Book of Mormon, I came early in life to know that we do have the words of Christ in the Doctrine and Covenants, in fact, hundreds and hundreds of them spoken to his Prophet, Joseph Smith. The introduction to the revelations in this book of scripture reveals the author as the Savior. Examples are: Hearken, O ye people of my church— 1:1. Ae to the voice of Jesus Christ, your Lord, your God, and your Redeemer... (27:1.) Behold, thus saith the Lord, even Alpha and Omega... (54:1.) A Witness for the Savior The Lord declared, however, that the revelations were given after the manner of the Prophet's language. (D&C 1:24.) The Doctrine and Covenants stands as a witness for Jesus that he is the Savior of those who want to be saved. The doctrine that salvation comes only to those who accept him and thus he saves only them, is taught plainly. (D&C 42:1; 29:17.) In truth, the Doctrine and Covenants is an answer to the present thought among some theologians that God is dead, a notion that has received wide publicity. The modern scriptures declare plainly that God lives! Two important accounts of the appearance of the Savior in this generation are given in the Doctrine and Covenants: (1) the stirring description by the Prophet Joseph Smith and Sidney Rigdon is a testimony to this fact. And now after the many testimonies which have been given of him, this is the testimony, last of all, which we How | Became Involved in the Doctrine and Covenants give of him: That he lives! For we saw him, even on the right hand of God; and we heard the voice bearing record that he is the Only Begotten of the Father— That by him, and through him, and of him, the worlds are and were created, and the inhabitants thereof are beand daughters unto God. Thousands of people have had their faith restored and also increased in the credibility of the Bible through their acceptance of the fulness of the gospel of Jesus Christ. The trek of our pioneer forefathers over long miles of plains bears solemn testimony to their faith built upon modern revelation. President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. Caught the sacrifice and toil of these hardy, faithful men and women as he described in a general conference later published in a book "To Them of the Last Wagon," this magnificent accomplishment, as follows: That evening was the last of the great trek, the mightiest trek that history records since Israel's flight from Egypt, and as the sun sank below the mountain peaks... 'Zion, Zion, lovely Zion, Beautiful Zion, Zion, City of our God." They knew there was a God, for only he could have brought them triumphant, militant, through all the scorn, the ridicule, the slander, the tarrings and featherings, the whippings, the burnings, the plunderings, the murderings, the ravishing of wives and daughters, that had been their lot, the lot of their people since Joseph visioned the Father and the Son. (Conference Report, October 1947, page 158.) 488 Words of the Lord to This Generation How did I become involved in the study of the Doctrine and Covenants? You will have observed by now that my interest came about as a youth because I needed the Doctrine and Covenants to clarify many Bible doctrines in my preparation for the mission field. Also, I came to know that this book of scripture is a witness for the divinity of the Savior. In addition, I saw in the Doctrine and Covenants the words of the Lord Jesus Christ to the people of this generation. This last fact was apparent, for it is a modern book intended to guide people on the road to salvation in the present world. In the Bible there are many prophecies regarding the last days. My interest was aroused in the Doctrine and Covenants because it is a "voice of warning" to the people of our times, just as the Bible was intended to "warn" the people of the generations about which it speaks, and at the same time, in prophecy, it spoke of our dispensation. In other words, to have the Creator of the earth inform us of what is to happen to this world and its inhabitants today even more clearly than the information on this subject in the Bible, is a stimulus for the members of the Church to become involved in the Doctrine and Covenants. For example, the very conditions which we see today—extreme wickedness, disbelief in God, people becoming laws 'unto themselves—were foreknown. Of interest to all of us are world events. The political unrest among the nations, the How | Became Involved in the Doctrine and Covenants extent of rumors of wars and actual conflict, together with the great amount of sickness and natural calamities, all signify that the times prophesied are with us. Unless extreme apa- | thy has taken hold of us, it is difficult to understand why a Latter-day Saint would not want to understand the signs preceding the second coming of Christ. We should look forward to his coming. (D&C 45:39-42.) The Purpose of Life I doubt that there is a person who at some time in his life, if not many times, has not wondered about the purpose of this life and especially the important question as to what lies beyond the grave. This ever-present question is revealed in the Doctrine and Covenants, especially the future existence following the spirit world. The truth is taught that man had a premortal state and that the earth was created for man. (D&C 92:23-29; 49:16-17.) Man is spirit and body to be wed eventually by the resurrection. (Ibid., 88:15-16.) The doctrine of the resurrection is revealed plainly, and evidence to support belief in the resurrection is given in accounts of resurrected beings communing with mortals. Such examples are: John the Baptist, Peter and James, Elijah, Moses and other prophets. (I[bid., 27:5-14; 128:21.) One of the most distinctive doctrines taught in the modern revelations that has found unusual interest and profit is the one regarding the various kingdoms following the resurrection. Who has not thrilled with this "transcript from the eternal world," as he has come to understand the magnanimity, mercy, and justice of God in this divine plan? How wonderful it is to have one's eyes opened to understand the opportunity to receive exaltation—all that the Father hath? Early in life I learned this great truth, and I came to love it because it was congenial to my soul. I believe that this doctrine motivates one to serve the Lord with all his heart, might, mind, and strength. As one comes to love one teaching after another, his whole being takes on new life and new purpose. The visions of the prophets become his visions and. His goals. The same spirit that revealed the teachings of the fulness of the gospel of Jesus Christ to the prophets also reveals these truths to the one who becomes involved in the Doctrine and Covenants. He loves the Lord because he knows that the Lord loves him. He understands what it means when the Lord said: That which is of God is light; and he that receiveth light, and continueth in God, receiveth more light; and that - light groweth brighter and brighter until the perfect day. (D&C 50:24.) How to Become Involved in the Doctrine and Covenants. If someone were to ask me what he or she could do to become involved in this wonderful book of scripture, I would offer the following: 1. She could undertake an assignment to teach this book. 2. If this opportunity were not available in the classroom, she could assume that someday she would need the teachings of the Doctrine and 489 July 1969 490 Covenants to help her as a teacher, administrator in the Church, to assume the responsibilities of a parent, to abide by the charge of "every member a missionary,' and above all for her own salvation. She could ask herself a series of questions about the doctrines of the Church periodically and then endeavor to learn the answers to these questions from the Doctrine and Covenants by the use of the index, concordance, commentaries, and other means. She could resolve to set aside ten or fifteen minutes each day to read the revelations. If there were times when she found it hard to follow this practice she could remember the advice of President Brigham Young concerning prayer: If you do not feel like praying then get down on your knees, then stay there until you get the spirit of prayer. (Journal of Discourses 7:164.) So also, she could be as persistent until she became the victor. No doubt other means might be employed of accomplishing the same purpose. In any case, I bear testimony that a knowledge of the teachings of the Doctrine and Covenants is necessary to attain the heights of performance required to receive eternal life. The revelations are true, Joseph Smith is a prophet, and his successors enjoy the same calling. All of this means that Jesus Christ is our Savior in every sense of the word; he lives, this I know by the testimony of the Spirit. = HIS GIFT They say Six thousand of them perished as they came this way. Fairbairn y, Announcement of Winners Mary R. Decker Safsten The General Board of Relief Society is happy to announce the names of the winners in the first annual Relief Society Song Writing Contest. The first prize of sixty dollars for the music and forty dollars for the lyrics is awarded to the song-writing team of Mary D. Safsten and Ranghild L. Safsten for a lovely hymn, "Lo, Thou Art Near." Mary D. Safsten wrote the music, and the lyrics were penned by her mother-in-law. Both women are members of the Bellingham Ward, Cascade Stake, in Washington. The second prize of seventy-five dollars is awarded to Ruth B. Lehenbauer of Logan, Utah, for her hymn "My Cup of Joy." The prize-winning songs are the property of the General Board of Relief Society, and will be programmed for performance by Singing Mother choruses. The General Board is very pleased with the response to this first contest. There were 222 songs submitted to a committee of eminently qualified judges. The winners are to be congratulated for their very fine abilities. The caliber of the songs submitted was very high, showing the great talent of Latter-day Saint women in the musical field. The General Board once again congratulates these sisters and all others who entered the contest on their accomplishments and encourages even more widespread participation in future competition. 492 Mary R. Decker Safsten began her study of music at a very early age and has participated extensively in Church and school musical activities. She was reared in Mesa, Arizona. She was graduated from Brigham Young University with an undergraduate and graduate major in music. In 1957, she married Robert Safsten and they are the parents of seven children. She has given organ recitals in Washington, Utah, and Arizona, and accompanied the Cascade—Vancouver Stakes - Singing Mothers concert, and _ participated with the Singing Mothers from the Northwest at General Conference two years ago. Safsten and they are parents of four children and have seventeen grandchildren. She has taught Sunday School, and served as Relief Society president, counselor, and homemaking leader. She recently served a stake mission. She enjoys sewing, handicraft, cooking, and of course, writing poetry. Ruth Benson Lehenbauer was born in Washington D. C. And spent most of her youth in Silver Spring, Maryland. She acquired the majority of her college education in Utah. After serving a mission to West Germany, she was married to Ottomar Lehenbauer and they have three children. She is presently serving as MIA chorister in her ward, and is a part-time instructor of languages at Utah State University, Logan, Utah, teaching French and German. Ruth Benson Lehenbauer 493 Goal, Understanding, and Technique Jean Larsen, Instructor in Child Development and Family Relationships at. Brigham Young University @ The answer to the question, "Should there be discipline?" comes through loud and clear, "Yes, there must be discipline!" But the what, the why, and the how of discipline and guidance are not so clearly spelled out. Not knowing what is expected on either end of the guidance situation provides some frustrating experiences for all concerned. We recall the story: Bobby had been playing by the duck pond for several minutes when Father called for him to come in the house. Bobby approached his father slowly, looking down at muddy feet and wet pant legs. When Bobby's father saw the mud and the wet, he said in a stern voice, "Well, Bobby, how many times must you be told to stay out of the mud and water? Go get mea willow, maybe a 'willowing' will help you remember." Bobby was gone for several minutes before he slowly approached his father again— this time with his hands behind him. His father's voice was again stern as he said, "Well, I'm waiting, give me the willow." Bobby 494 drew both hands around and produced not a willow but several rocks in each hand. Then he said in a meek little voice, "T couldn't find a willow, but here are some rocks to throw at me." GOAL As adults being responsible for guiding the child we are concerned about his behavior and ways of altering, controlling, or instigating certain behaviors. Guidance can become a battle of wills between adults and children. But, as in all battles, someone must be the victor. Should it be the adult at the expense of the child's curiosity, spontaneous expression, and self-esteem, or should the child be the winner because of his ability to display compulsive, negative, and violent behavior? Power struggles are a risk to any relationship and should be avoided. The goal of guidance is to let the child know what is expected of him, and then provide experiences which will help him to develop self-discipline or control from within. UNDERSTANDING Why do children do what they do and when will they change? There is a reason why children do what they do. Sometimes adults don't take time or don't try to understand what is behind the behavior. How many times have you heard a parent say to a child, "Now stop crying or [ll really give you something to cry for," assuming that there is not a reason for the child to cry in the first place. Some behavior, although unacceptable to adults, is normal for the child of a given age and may very well pass on like the seasons. Temper tantrums are a normal reaction to frustration for the toddler age. Getting into things, finding out what possibility an object or material has for manipulation, is a_ force pushing the child from within. Most parents have the same concerns. "Why can't my child be quiet in Church?" or "Just when I want him to behave, he really acts up." A new situation or one that does not necessarily accommodate to the child usually produces child behavior that the adult does not approve of. The most difficult time in many households is the dinner hour. Mother may be intent on preparing the meal, younger children are tired and hungry, and Father and the older children need a listening ear after their day away from home. Tension runs high in such a situation. Keys to Child Guidance Sometimes children do what they do because they do not know what is expected of them. TECHNIQUE Guidance involves evaluation of and reaction to behaviors. Because each of us is an individual dealing with another unique individual, successful techniques will vary. There are some guidelines which may serve as a basis for dealing with behavior in general. First, punishment does not teach or show the child the type of behavior you want exemplified. It may cut off the behavior or traumatize the child about that which he should not do, but punishment does not establish what the child should do. Toddlers are notorious for using primitive social techniques. Usually, if another child has something they want they will bite, poke, pull or hit in order to gain possession. Many parents see this behavior and become very anxious. Usually, someone will suggest that the way to teach them not to bite is for you to bite them back. Will your biting the child teach him what you want him to do? Second, it is not wise to try to cut off a child's curiosity. This is like trying to stop his growth. Foster his asking questions and trying things out. If the _ behavior is caused because of a growing curiosity, then tolerate or channel, but be very selective when you stop this kind of behavior. Water play is one of the most soothing types of play a child of most young ages can engage in. However, water play and 495 July 1969 other related sensory types of play need to be channeled. A mother might respond, "No, I can't have you pouring water from container to container here on the kitchen floor, but outside (or a protected area inside) you may do so." Third, try looking at things from the child's point of view. Rather than expecting the child to come all the way in an intolerable situation, see what you can do to make it easier for him. Sincere praise for just being himself can modify a_ child's behavior. Some adults feel compliments are not for children, but if there is a basis for them, they should be used. There was a five-year-old in the nursery school who seemed to be overflowing with good ideas. The teacher in the nursery group would frequently comment to this child, "John, you are clever!" One day a parent said to the teacher, "Why. Are you always telling that. Child he's clever? Don't you think he'll-. Become egocentric?" The teacher replied that she. Felt children's behavior was greatly influenced by the way others reacted to them both by words and deeds. Sometime later John was watching a disgruntled repairman fixing a plugged up sink in the nursery school. As the repairman took off the gooseneck and found it filled with sand, it appeared he was going to explode. John, who had been watching the operation, looked up at the man's angry face and said, "My, you're clever to be able to fix that sink." The repairman's anger turned into a friendly smile as he said, "Well, I guess I am clever at that." 496 A fourth guide would be to feed into the child love, warmth, gentleness, and self-worth. Children learn what they live. A child who has _ received has something to give back. A fifth and concluding guide deals with letting the child know what is expected of him. Teach the child what to do rather than what not to do. Help the child see reasons, outcomes, and responsibilities. This is the opposite from threats and retaliations. Provide experiences whereby the child can develop innercontrol through understanding rather than control through fear. Mary had been cutting and pasting at the art table. When she was nearly finished with her picture she noticed how easily her scissors snipped off small corners and pieces of the paper. Mary snipped and watched the small pieces flutter to the floor. Soon it looked like snow and soon the floor looked like a real storm had hit. The teacher came to Mary and said, "When Mr. Bob, our custodian, comes in to clean tonight, he'll wonder what has been happening in this room." Mary thought for a moment and then replied, "I'll need to get this mess cleaned up, would you hold the dustpan while I sweep?" Make teaching your discipline and take the initiative to discuss, explain, interpret, and demonstrate desirable behavior. If your guidance relationship is constant and you are accepting of the fact that each experience will not be a successful one—it takes a long time to learn—eventually you will reach the goal of establishing self-worth and controls from within the child. m Lenora Peterson had hurriedly glanced at the clock as _ she popped the frozen peas into the steaming pot of chicken and noodles. Time had more than caught up with her, and the missionaries would be coming to dinner in about twenty minutes. She always tried to have the meal ready exactly when the elders arrived as time was so precious to them. Today had been unusually busy. At Relief Society that morning Sister Lemmon, the president, had asked her to stop by Sister Slack's home and pick up some ironing. After a few days home from the hospital with another new baby, Sister Slack had suffered a set-back and was ordered to bed by her doctor for a week or more. The Relief Society sisters were assisting the family with the work, food, and the small children. Lenora had spent most of the day ironing, so she could return it to Sister Slack later on tonight. I do wish Maida would get home soon, she thought as she added a bit more salt to the noodles, she's such a big help when time is pressing. Maida had announced her intention of being a little late today, as it was the final tryouts for the high school musical. Of 497! / the ten who had competed for the coveted part, she was one of July 1969 the three finalists. She had been an "almoster" the past three years, and had come so close to getting parts in the school productions that this last chance in her senior year was, at the moment, the most important thing in her life. | enora turned the flame down on the noodles and started buttering the French bread. As the knife smoothed the soft spread over the slices she smiled faintly, her eyes watered a bit, and her mind shifted in reverse to more than a decade ago. No matter how many times she prepared dinner for the missionaries, this backward glance was a mental ritual with her—a way of giving thanks for a second chance. Life had been so different and wonderful when she and George had moved from southeastern Idaho. Even though Church membership was large here on the West Coast, the saints were still a minority in this teeming metropolis, but the missionaries had found this a fruitful field. George had immediately befriended the missionaries and shared his own experiences with them. Knowing what a _ real home-cooked meal meant to a young missionary far away from home, he wanted to invite them to dinner, and Lenora had agreed wholeheartedly. She wanted it to be a very special meal. These young men so valiantly serving the Lord deserved the very best. For days she planned the meal, shifted the food budget, in order to buy the choicest steaks, and put an all-out effort into the occasion. Every minute of that first day that the elders came to 498 dinner was spent in cleaning every corner, making a table arrangement that resembled a page from Home Lovely, and preparing food fit for the most critical gourmet. It was worth it though —the way those hungry boys devoured every morsel, the praise they heaped on her, George's look of satisfaction. She had fed the children early, sent them to their rooms, and planned an after-dinner relaxation period around the fireplace with hot buttered popcorn, crisp apples, happy conversation, and a background of soft nostalgic stereo music. Her plans were shattered, though, as the elders had to eat and run in order to make an early evening appointment. It was some time before they were invited again. Such a meal played havoc with her grocery budget, and she expended so much time and energy in preparing it that she needed a couple of months' rest between invitations. Lenora put as much dedication into the second meal as she had the first, and the new elders praised her highly. She felt especially happy, and after bidding the young men goodbye, she went to check on the children. As she neared the bedroom she noticed the door was slightly open, and heard the children talking. Maida had a play telephone to her ear, and the first words Lenora caught were, "Yes, were having missionaries to dinner tonight." Lenora paused and_ smiled with deep satisfaction. How sweet she thought, children usu- ally imitate their parents in play. Having the missionaries to dinner is evidently making an impression on her. She stood outside unnoticed as Maida's conversation continued. "I'm sorry your baby suddenly got sick, Sister Nelson, but I can't take your Primary class today. The missionaries are coming to dinner.... No, I can't tend your children while you go visiting teaching, Sister Gregerson. We're having the missionjn, aries tonight." aw Tn a eee mel KR? The pleased look drained from Missionaries to Dinner Lenora's face. Somehow the replay of her own words sounded different from the original. "T don't wanna' go on a mission, 'cause when people ask missionaries to dinner, then the mother's not nice, and she can't do anything else to help anybody, and all she cares about is a clean house and fancy food, and the children have to eat sandwiches and then go to their room... And I just don't like it." Lenora's first reaction was to plunge into the room, and give her son a good tongue lashing for his failure to recognize her tireless efforts to serve the missionaries who were in turn serving the 499 July 1969 Lord. Instead, she dazedly foand her way back to the living room and sat at the foot of the reclining chair where George was reading the evening paper. George listened thoughtfully; then in his usual quiet manner commented, "Well, I guess we'll just have to make a few changes." "T know, dear, I would like to have the elders over again, but 'if this is the effect it's having on the children, we just won't be able to." "That's not exactly the type of change I had in mind. As I recall, some of my most pleasant meals in the mission field were when we took potluck with some of the members or investigators. That hash or watered-down soup tasted as good as if it had been served at the Waldorf-Astoria, because it was served in a homey atmosphere with warmth and love." "But, George, I've tried to serve the missionaries with warmth and love." "Of course you have, dear. You've probably tried so hard it's been a burden on you, and you didn't have enough energy left to be considerate to the children or your friends. How about trying it again soon, and see what can be done about changing the children's 'I-hatethe-missionaries-to-dinner' attitude to 'we-love-them-to-dinner' image." "Well, okay, George, I guess I'm willing to try." Lenora was a little skeptical, though. It had always been so important to her to have the 500 house spotless and the food superior when she entertained guests. "The ensuing days saw Lenora conducting a lot of self-analysis. Was she having the missionaries to dinner as a sincere gesture of love, or was she eager to show off an immaculate house and receive a shower of compliments for her superb cooking? Was she like the Pharisees who paid tithes, yet omitted the more important things of the law? Was she a bit guilty of swallowing the camel and straining at the gnat? She realized that in her narrow effort to perform one benevolent act, she had shunned the opportunity to perform many. Lenora knew it wouldn't be a fast or easy change, but she resolved to try. The next time missionaries were invited she planned it very carefully. She let the children decide on the menu, though she didn't mention guests were coming. How she hoped the elders could tolerate hot dogs on a stick and French fries. She cleaned the house the day before and arose extra early on the appointed day to add the finishing touches. All day she tried especially hard to be pleasant to the children. Though nervous and tense on the inside, she put on a good front before them. She let Vernon and Maida invite some of their neighborhood friends over to make cookies. This would create a happy experience for them and also provide dessert for dinner. All was going well. The children were blissfully up to their elbows in cooky dough, and the first try had been taken from the oven. Just as she had passed around the first samples and observed the looks of pleasure and accomplishment on their faces, the telephone rang. It was Annie next door. Her toddler had fallen and slashed his cheek on the table's edge. The cut looked deep, and Annie was sure stitches would be needed, so she needed Lenora to drive her to the doctor. Annie had a car at home. Why couldn't she drive to the doctor herself? Instinctively, Lenora said, "Oh, I'm sorry, Annie, but..." then caught herself. Quickly she shelved her uncharitable thoughts and realized a mother with a crying, bleeding baby would be in no condition to do any driving.. "I'm sorry, Annie," she repeated, "but... It will take at least a minute before I can leave." She removed the sheet of halfbaked cookies from the oven, hurried the children to the car, and met Annie on the driveway. In a couple of hours they were back home with the injured baby repaired almost as good as new. Time was of the essence now. Lenora flew around her kitchen so fast she even surprised herself. But now the doorbell rang. It was Annie, beaming with gratitude. "Here, Lenora, I thought you might like these radishes for dinner. It's my first experience growing vegetables. I'm as proud as punch over them, and I want to share them with you." "Oh, Annie, how sweet of you. They'll be perfect in the salad. We're having two missionaries from our Church to dinner toMissionaries to Dinner night. They'll so appreciate home-grown radishes." "Oh, Lenora, why didn't you tell me before, and I could have had someone else drive us to the doctor?" Annie paused. "When I have guests for dinner I don't let anything else interfere. You're a real jewel." Lenora had to fight the pangs of self-righteousness after that compliment. She then seized the opportunity to tell her neighbor a bit about the missionary system of the Church. Somehow or other, dinner was ready on time. She had the children set the table and instructed them to set two extra places for the missionaries. Even though the silver was on the wrong side, she didn't have time to worry about it. As they devoured the hot dogs, the rest of the cookies were baking in the oven. How the elders exclaimed over the hot cookies and cold _ bottled peaches! And during the meal Maida spilled her milk and baby Paul tossed his food, but Lenora tried to take it calmly. WWhile the children helped with the dishes, there were comments. "Those were the best dogs and fries... This has sure been a neat day." After a few more well-planned "'missionaries-to-dinner". Experiences, the children began remarking, "When are they coming again? Let's have them real soon." Gradually, then, Lenora began really to believe Mr. Emerson's philosophy—that persistence in doing increases one's capacity for that job. Soon the weighty tenseness of company to dinner 501 July 1969 disappeared, and it became a relaxed, enjoyable experience for herself, her family, and guests. She was amazed that a one-dish missionary meal, cooked in the oven while she taught a Primary class, could taste nearly as good as an all-day preparation of turkey and the trimmings. She was further amazed how on extra busy days when she had the missionaries to dinner, a fifteenminute cleaning on 'the front rooms could look almost like the two-hour job. Yes, Lenora had changed over the years, and how grateful she was for that opportunity of evesdropping on her children so long ago. The sudden slamming of the front door quickly brought Lenora back to the present. "Mom! Mom! I got the part. I really made it this time." Lenora ran through the hall, embraced her daughter. Their squeals of delight resembled a couple of pre-schoolers. "I'm sorry 'm late, Mom... I know we're having the elders to dinner, but they took so long making a decision... What can I do to help with dinner?" "How about getting out the greens from the crisper and making a quick salad?" "I wonder," reflected Maida as she chopped the celery, "what my big brother will be having for dinner tonight." _ "Well," replied Lenora, "about right now Vernon is sleeping, but in a few hours he'll probably be eating Ris Grot and perhaps a side order of fish." "Or how about peanut butter sandwiches?" Just as Maida placed the salad on the table, the five short and two long buzzes on the doorbell gave the signal that the elders had arrived. As the young girl headed for the door she paused at her mother's side, hugged her gently, and exclaimed, "Oh, Mom, I just love the whole world tonight. I love the judges who gave me the part... I love you... I love my missionary brother... And I especially love having missionaries to dinner." v. Dyd SUMMER NIGHT And now in gentleness, the sun goes down. Cannon Jessie Evans Smith, wife of President Joseph Fielding Smith of the First Presidency of the Church, has been honored by many student organizations and other groups of young people. A noted singer and beloved exemplary woman, her addresses and her singing have delighted collegiate and Church audiences. In April 1969, she was given a citation as an ''Ideal Woman' by the Latter-day Saint co-eds at Utah State University, Logan, Utah. The subject of the meeting was ''The Eternal Quest of Womanhood," and Sister Smith addressed the young women, sang a solo, and participated in the music presented by a special chorus. Also, in April, Sister Smith was honored by Weber State College in the tabernacle, Ogden, Utah. President E. Lamar Buckner said that her visit was the highlight of the year, and that her singing thrilled everyone present. "We are so grateful for your spirit of dedication," he said. ''We want you to know that you hold a spot in our hearts, and we shail always be grateful to you for being with us." Sister Smith spoke of the young women as diamonds in a diadem of crown jewels, advising them to make a careful selection of the jewels for their crowns. Mrs. Evelyn LeTourneau, sixty-eight, of Longview, Texas, wife of industrialist-inventor Robert LeTourneau and mother of four sons and one daughter, was named American Mother of the Year in Los Angeles, California, last May. She was chosen, in part, because she lovingly extended her role of motherhood to students: the Winona Bible Camp groups she established in seven boys' ranches across the country and the student body of the LeTourneau Institute of Technology in Longview. Mrs. Elizabeth Peterson McKay, a seventy-two-year-old Latter-day Saint woman from Ogden, became Utah's Mother of the Year. She was left a widow with four sons and four daughters from one to sixteen years of age and through the heroic efforts of all, the children received excellent educations and have become distinguished members of Church and community. She is a woman of talents, sterling character, and refinement. Mrs. Edna C. Karlinsey, wife of Curtlee J. Karlinsey, Tacoma, Washington, a schoolteacher and mother of seven children, represented the State of Washington as Mother of the Year. An active Latter-day Saint, she has encouraged and assisted her children in attending college and serving missions for the Church. Her talents in teaching, oil painting, and homemaking are outstanding. Mrs. Jessie Lamb Stewart of Las Vegas, Nevada Mother of the Year, now a widow, reared four motherless children in addition to her own eight sons and daughters. A devoted Latter-day Saint, she has held numerous offices and teaching assignments in Relief Society. She assisted her husband in managing a large ranch and in raising cattle and thoroughbred horses. She is active in community affairs and in politics. A chorus of Singing Mothers from the Los Angeles area, directed by Ellen N. Barnes of the General Board of Relief Society, provided music for the Awards Luncheon on May 12th. Many of the 1969 Mothers visited Salt Lake City following the convention in California and were entertained by the Church and by Relief Society. President Belle S. Spafford is second vice-president of the American Mothers Association. 503 EDITORIAL / TO EACH IS GIVEN A GIFT For all have not every gift given unto them; for there are many gifts, and to every man is given a gift by the Spirit of God. (D&C 46:11.) (Italics added.) ma in his loving-kindness God allows each person to come into the world possessing in his soul embryo gifts to be used and developed as one's free agency determines. While man's mind is veiled from a remembrance of his pre-mortal life, some of the seeds of his accomplishments there are born into mortality with him. The Father expects life to bring joy to his children. He prepares them for such joy by giving them the gifts with which to acquire it. One of the essential requirements of the Giver of Gifts is that the gift be used for the benefit of others ''that all may be profited thereby."' (D&C 46:12.) The use of these precious gifts selfishly, for personal gain alone is not the purpose for which they are given. The intention of the Lord is that gifts be magnified for the building of the kingdom. The rewards of such increase are that the gifts will be added upon. No one, we are told, lives to his fullest potential. Always there are greater goals to conquer. Efforts to reach that potential are crowned with the increased desire to do more and progress further. Gifts are to be sought. The prophets exhort the people to ''covet earnestly the best gifts.'' (I Cor. 12:31.) The blessings of spiritual growth are contingent upon asking in faith for one or more of the gifts. Proficiency is to be gained by personal effort and constant prayer to God to bless those efforts. Gifts are many and varied. They encompass gifts of knowledge and understanding of gospel doctrine given by the Holy Ghost to talents in culture areas. Talents are given in music, literature, and art, in Volume 56 July 1969 Number 7 Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Mittenberger, Acting Secretary-Treasurer 504 the realms of medicine, in aptitudes in educational pursuits, in the fields of engineering, and agriculture. The gifts are as diverse as the ability to love all of God's creations, a cheerful spirit, friendliness. To some is given the gift of leadership, to others the gift of following, not blindly but understandingly. Some are the lawgivers, the wise and sagacious, others are the workers who uncover the secrets of nature. Some possess gifts that even they do not suspect until they are brought to light by obedience to commandments. Some gifts are never discovered because they are not sought. There are those who resist the disciplines the development of a talent requires. They will not accept the responsibility bestowed with the gift to work toward its fulfillment. The potential for greatness is there but as a fallow field lies unused and dormant, idle in the sun, its potential for growth and production curtailed, so lie buried talents the owners fail to enlarge. These are the unprofitable servants of the parable of the talents whose condemnation is greater than the loss of the talent. Their condemnation is greater than they would have received had they not been given the gift. There are those who reject the gifts so willingly given by a loving Father, those whose self-afflicted blindness, whose spiritual unawareness prevent their accepting a glorious opportunity to use the gift in perfecting themselves and in helping build the kingdom of God. Relief Society is a marvelous gift given by our Heavenly Father to his daughters which some of the unseeing women of the Church have not yet accepted. The loss to themselves is great and to their families, husband, and children, but the loss to the building of the kingdom of God on earth is equally great. Failure to accept the God-given gifts results in failure to live most abundantly. Each gift is spiritual if used to elevate, to build, to make the world better. No gift is a small one. Its size is determined by the receiver. All gifts are given that each might contribute to the work of the Lord. —L. W. M. Verda F. Burton Myrtle R. Olson Elna P. Haymond Mary R. Young Celestia J.
