Haycock 505 GENERAL BOARD:: Is Not Veiled Marian Gardner Nielson @® When the three sisters, Gwen, Mary, and Maggie made the final decision, they knew there were still problems to be solved. Getting Gwen's three lively boys settled at Maggie's would entail planning and cajoling. Telephoning Mary's husband in New York about the change of plans was going to take some diplomacy. The real problem was getting their mother out of the hospital and then getting her comfortably and_ safely back home. The plan was simple on the surface. Gwen would go to Cedar Mesa on the plane with their mother. Maggie would keep Gwen's children, and Mary would drive down by car first to get the home ready for the mother's homecoming. 506 Gwen was washing the boys' play clothes, mending overalls, and folding and packing their Sunday clothes. She had a batch of bread in the oven. The baby's bed would be taken to Maggie's later. The trip would probably take four or five days, so she must leave plenty of clothes for the children. Gwen hoped she could get a batch of cookies made to take to Maggie. It would be the hardest on Maggie—what with four youngsters of her own—and she did look a little peaked lately. Gwen had wanted to get a baby sitter but Maggie had insisted on having the three little boys come to her place. Maggie had begun to carry out necessary plans, too. She had made room for Gwen's baby bed in the family room. Hy could set up two army cots in the boys' room. She would move her own baby bed into their bedroom. That way, everyone would be comfortable. She would make stew for the boys and maybe set some jello for dessert. Even thinking about food made her squeamish. You'd think after four babies.... She hadn't told her sisters about her pregnancy. She knew what Gwen would say, "Well, that settles it! I am going to get Jane to come over." Mary was not looking forward to these eight hours of steady driving to Cedar Mesa. It had been nearly ten years since she had driven down that road—ten years of a successful career, and, she admitted wryly to herself, ten years of unsuccessful marriage. And the telephone conversation with James last night had not helped. She knew she had been too brisk, too impersonal on the phone, but habit was hard to break. "James, Mother is well enough to leave the hospital... Oh, she's fine. She said to tell you hello and she would like to see you... QOh. Yes. Well, Gwen will go down with Mother on the plane. Maggie will keep Gwen's children, and I am leaving in the morning for Cedar Mesa to get the house ready.... Why? Well, I have no ties to keep me home.". When James asked "Mary, are you coming back here?" she had answered, "I don't know, James." His "Well, suit yourself" was as cold as her "Goodbye, James." Mary's hands tightened on the wheel. She had not let herself think of the marriage. That is, Love Is Not Veiled not until she had accepted the position with the publishing company. James had not objected, then. As she became successful in her work and spent more time at it, James became resentful. He objected when she spent the summer in Europe for the firm. Why couldn't he accept her success? The house was fine and the cook served better meals than Mary could prepare. She had tried to get close to James again, to get their marriage on an even keel. But now it was a cool neutrality. She was not sure that she wanted to go back to New York—especially since she had stayed in Gwen's comfortably furnished home with its confusion and love. And in the shabby, bulging home where Maggie was a lovely and beloved wife and mother. It was not until Mary came to the Colorado River that she threw off her unhappy mood and began to notice the spectacular scenery. She still missed the narrow, colorful, trestle bridge which had spanned the river when she was a girl, however the sheer red cliffs were still blazing in the sun, their dark shadows darker still because of the intense sun-glare of their lacquered surfaces. She slowed down to catch glimpses of her favorite places. Here was the famous fault that her geology professor had told the class about. There was the little meadow where the five quaking aspens grew—and there they were! But they were taller, with their golden leaves twinkling in the sunlight. She glanced at the familiar 507 July 1969 Horsehead on the Blue Mountain. She slowed down at Devil Canyon and again thrilled to the blaze of scarlet maples warming the dark long-leaf pines. She stopped when she came out on top and gazed at the blue hazelocked horizon. On the flat mesa directly below, yellow cottonwood trees brought Cedar Mesa into sharp focus. The sight filled her heart, mellowed the bitterness and sadness in her soul. She knew she was returning home. Mary drove into the small town marveling at the growth of the community. She almost became excited as she started down the hill toward the house with its big tree in front and its spacious lawns, green in the late afternoon sun. As she stopped in the driveway, Mary shook her head in bewilderment. Why did seeing this childhood home bring tears to her eyes? She had been entertained in palaces in Europe, in ostentatious apartments in New York, in ultra-modern homes throughout the Eastern States. But only this rambling livedin-looking house humbled her, made her feel like a young girl again. It was the flower garden west of the house that caused the tears to fall—freely this time. That was her mother's garden, the one she worried about in the hospital. There were the earlybloomingchrysanthemumsmulticolored against the green lawn. The aspen tree Kent brought from Elk Mountain so many years ago was now a beautiful, white column, flaunting its golden leaves. Tucked in under a scarlet-tipped sumach, Mary saw one 508 lone defiant buttercup peering brazenly from its matted foliage. Suddenly she stopped and examined the ground _Closely. It was still damp from a recent watering! Mary also realized that there were no weeds among the plants. The foliage was all fresh and green—the asters, petunias, and late-blooming zinnias standing straight and tall. Uncle Zeke? It had to be. She stood up and looked around. Across the street at Aunt Gen's, a curtain fell into place. | Mary smiled. So—the neighborhood knew she was home. It was a good feeling to know you were being watched—with neighborliness and friendliness. The house had weathered a little more in the past ten years. The trees were a little 'taller, the shrubs a little thicker. She stopped under the big English elm and looked up into the lightlanced branches where the remnants of the tree house still hung precariously. Once she had fallen from there, had broken her leg, but that pain was nothing like the pain she felt now with her marriage breaking up. Inside, she pulled the drapes, opened windows, and aired out each room as she went from one to the other. What happy hours were spent in this middle bedroom giggling with Gwen and Maggie. How cold it was in the north bedroom in the wintertime, when the boys snuggled under the warm, tied wool quilts! The long table in the dining room was still scarred where the table tennis net had been screwed on too tightly. The big, sunny kitchen still echoed with the sounds of a noisy family popping corn, pulling honey candy, and sitting down to Mother's cooked dinners. She had stepped quietly into the corner bedroom and had felt the presence of her father and mother still there. It was a good house. It was a good feeling Mary had as she went through it. She touched the familiar pictures, ran her fingers along the faded and broken piano keys. Even in the daylight she switched on the lights in the living room to see if she could catch the rainbows in the prisms of the chandelier the whole family loved.... She still wondered why her father had never bought a dishwasher. It would have saved her mother so many hours. Well, if she was going to get to the Merc before closing time, she'd better go. She decided to walk the three blocks to the store. She was stiff from driving and the walk would do her good. Besides —she might see some of her old friends or her mother's friends. Too, she would have to pass Aunt Irene's. Perhaps she would be working among her roses where she was usually seen. It had been difficult to explain to James' friends that all her "Aunts" were really not Aunts at all, but were the older women she knew and loved. Everyone called these dear friends "Aunts." Call them "Mrs Galbraith" or "Mrs. Taylor'? That was too formal for Cedar Mesa folk. It had sounded a little provincial, later, when she thought about it. But home again at Cedar Mesa it sounded all right to talk about "Aunt Irene" and "Aunt Hattie" and all the rest. They seemed closer to you, that way. Aunt Irene wasn't in her roLove {s Not Veiled ses when Mary passed her house. She stopped at the telephone office and asked to have her mother's phone connected. She walked into the Merc, took a basket and selected the groceries she would need. The clerks were all strangers, the few people in the store busy with their own buying. When she paid the bill she felt distinctly let down. Old Home Town, indeed! On the corner near home she met Ruth Murphy—Ruth Layman she was now—the tall wearylooking woman informed her. But Ruth was in a hurry to get supper for her large family so she spent little time talking. "I'm so glad your mother is coming home. We've all missed her—and worried about her." "She had a rough time, Ruth, but the doctor says she will be all right. She's coming in a day or so. I']l stay until she is up and around and can do for herself." "Well, we must get the old crowd together while you're here. I'll give you a ring. See you later, Mary." Ruth hurried down the street to her small trailer house. The feeling of not belonging persisted. Mary was tired. She wanted to get right home, take a shower and get into her bed. She hoped she wouldn't see anyone else now; she didn't feel like talking. She saw Johnny Jones, her father's old friend, hobble out of his lot to intercept her, but she pretended not to see him and hurried along faster. But the minute she stepped into the house, serenity returned and Mary became receptive to the enfolding arms of the dear home. She fixed a sandwich and 509 July 1969 a glass of milk and went into the living room to eat it. She picked up an open book from the table, Collection of Great Poems, and leafed through its pages. It was a favorite book of her mother's and the penned comments on the page margins brought the beloved voice into focus reading to the children in the evenings. Whren she finally closed the volume and placed it almost reverently on the table, she was ready for bed. She was going to plan her work for the next day, but dropped off to sleep immediately. It was a bright hushed morning when she awoke. For amoment she felt as she did years before when she was waking in that same room—a sense of anticipation, a surge of interest, a feeling of expectancy. A knock on the door brought her to her feet. "I'm coming," she called. "just a minute." "Oh, Mary, it's just your old Aunt Gen. I'm already in." She peered around the door. "How good to see you. You haven't -changed a bit... Still the prettiest girl in town!" She planted a quick kiss on Mary's surprised face. "So your mother's coming home tomorrow! We've been keeping in touch with Gwen. It will be so wonderful to have her back. You know," Aunt Gen spoke tenderly, "you look more like her than any of the girls." Quick tears stung Mary's eyes as she held the frail woman close. "That's the nicest thing anyone has said to me for years. Come and sit down Aunt Gen, and 510 what do you have under that napkin?" "Just a few cinnamon rolls for your breakfast. I knew you wouldn't stop to cook anything." She surveyed Mary with bright black eyes. "You're too thin. And your eyes tell me you are not happy. What's the matter?" Mary laughed. "Oh, Aunt Gen, you always did say my eyes gave me away. You're wrong. I'm —fine. And now that I'm home, I'm beginning to be myself again." Aunt Gen noticed the slight hesitation, but she changed the subject. "You see, I have on my working apron. I am going to stay and help you get this house all ready for your mother's return. Oh, I know," she shook her head, "you think you can do it alone. Well, maybe you can, but we're going to help." "Wile,. "Certainly... Irene, Lydie, Addie, and Natalie. Do you think we girls would let your mother down? After sixty years of being as close as we are? Not for one minute! Now eat your rolls, child." Mary sat down and helplessly watched Aunt Gen take over— as she always did. The cinnamon rolls were warm and sweet and she ate the three without even once thinking of her diet. Aunt Irene brought a casserole and greeted Mary with love and a few happy tears. Aunt Lydie and Aunt Addie came in talking a blue streak... Not expecting Mary to answer. Aunt Natalie was late, but her warm greeting and her gentle manner made Mary realize why her mother loved Natalie so much. It was a lovely day. Actually, Mary didn't accomplish much. Every time she started to dust or vacuum or wash windows one of the aunts firmly pushed her aside. Mostly, she listened to the familiar stories, laughed at the same anecdotes, and hummed the same nostalgic songs. Just as the sun stepped behind the Bear's Ears and flung its painted shafts at the drowsy sky, the women finished their work. Gwen called later that night to say that the plane would land at the airport at Cedar Mesa at four-thirty the next afternoon. Mary called Aunt Irene who said she would tell the others. "Don't cook your roast, Mary, save it for another day. I am bringing chicken a la Maryland that your mother likes so well." "But, Aunt Irene...." "Now, Mary! I'm in a hurry. Goodbye." The next morning Mary rose early. She went out to the strawberry patch and picked a bowl of the plump sweet berries. As she washed them she thought how her mother liked them and how proud she was of her berry » patch. All morning neighbors came in and greeted her with familiar affection. They were all so happy that her mother was coming home. Shy Mrs. Sanchez, who helped with the ironing, brought a basket of peppers—huge green bell peppers, round orange-red pimentos, long, pale-green mild ones and slim, dark-green hot ones. Becky brought a big apple pie, freshly baked. The little schoolteacher's wife, whom her mother had befriended, slipped her choice casserole into the Love Is Not Veiled oven. Aunt Gladys brought a loaf of her stone ground brown bread. There were bottles of sour cherry jelly, Doris' pretty pickles, a ground raisin cake, and a tin of rolls almost ready for the oven. Mary could only thank the people, her voice choking on inadequate words. How hospitable they were! How could she have forgotten her mother's lovely friends? Yes, and hers, too. How could she have cast aside these cherished customs? The first thing her mother saw when she got home from the airport were the fresh flowers. The house was full of them: roses in tall vases; late velvety clematis in a low crystal bowl; zinnias, asters, petunias, and a pottery jar filled with brown-hearted sunflowers. Mary gasped in surprise. 511 July 1969 "The Garden Club!. How they must have worked to get them all here, fresh and smiling," her mother exclaimed. She wandered slowly through the shiny rooms smelling the fragrant bouquets, noting gleaming windows and crisp curtains. At last she settled down in her own room. "How good to be home. How wonderful to be in my own room again. God has been good to me. He sent love to make me happy. He sent comfort to me when I was sorrowful. Children and all of my friends to sustain me in my illness. I am so grateful for his sharing these 'things with me." She-looked up at Mary, her He sent you words tender, meaningful. "Sharing is a part of life, Mary. You have to be able to receive, by knowing how to give." Mary nodded. She took Gwen's hand and the two sisters left, their. Mother's understanding smile blessing them. It was late that night that Mary made up her mind. She put in the call to James in New York, her hand unsteady on the receiver. When he answered she could hardly bring herself to speak. Then, humbly, sincerely, with sweet tones of love, she said, "James, do you really want me to come home?" And the sudden radiance in her face lighted up the whole room. AD THE INFINITE COMPOSER The great composer sat within his room, And wrote a part for every instrument, He blended wondrous: themes into a whole Most beautiful, and yet: so quickly spent. But there is one whose genius is more great, His: work is far more beautiful to see, He blended all live things, all natural sounds Into an everlasting symphony. He took the mighty ocean's angry roar And tempered it with plaintive cries of gulls, The calls of cormorants. And guillemots, Which fly for shelter till the great storm lulls. He shaped the rolling uplands, and the plains With March wind whispering through the waving grass, With shyest creatures swiftly burrow bound As human steps approach, and gently pass. He sent the speeding comet on its course That each might have free passage on its flight, Then massed the myriad-stars of Milky Way Into a highway of celestial light. His orchestra is heard throughout the world, In jungle, mountain, desert plain, and fjord, His music is eternal, and his skill Is absolute, he is our gracious Lord. §12 —Gillian G. Brown-Lee Worcester, Worcs., England Photograph by Willard Lur _—Maxine R. Jennings inside and out Mama Counted Flavor—Not Calories Edythe K. Watson, Member, General Board of Relief Society ws Mama left a legacy of happy memories for her family. Our friends and relatives young and old loved to come to her gracious, hospitable home. Some who knew Mama best said it was because she was generous, kind, and witty, with a penchant for making every guest feel special and welcome. To this I wholeheartedly agree, but Mama had something else which drew people to her. Mama was an excellent cook. She liked nothing better than to share her cuisine with those she loved. ' Unfortunately for her daughters, Mama never used a recipe. All of her dishes were concocted by feel, consistency, or taste. A pinch of this or a handful of that. Mama didn't even own measuring cups or spoons. One of the happiest memories Mama left her children was our annual trip to "the Lakes." Mama prepared for several days for this special event. I can close my eyes now and it seems as though I can almost taste some of her special goodies. As the tantalizing aroma from Mama's preparatory baking permeated the air, it appeared that it touched off the appetite alarms of all the youngsters in our neighborhood and those children who came to our kitchen door never went away hungry. For the long drive to "the Lakes," our outing site, Mama usually brought a lunch of milk, cinnamon buns, or slices of raisin and nut bread spread with freshly churned butter. She would pack them in the folds of snowy white dish cloths to keep them fresh, since wax paper or plastic wrap had never been heard of in our town. There 514 Mamma Counted Flavor—Not Calories was always just enough food to appease our hunger but not too much to spoil our appetites for the picnic to follow. And what a picnic! Our favorite food was Mama's baked beans. Their cooking was an all-day process. How we loved the smell of the molasses and brown sugar, mustard, and the salt pork nestled cozily among the brown beans. Combined, they produced a flavor that was delectable. Homemade root beer was a must. This was an exciting change from milk or the ever-popular lemonade. Mama's root beer had a special tang. We all loved the bottling process and as we put the corks into the bottle tops and tied them securely to the bottle with string, we would beg Mama to put our mark on just one bottle reserved especially for each of us. In our home town, most everyone had at least a small garden. Fresh vegetables were common fare. Mama said they were good for us and so she used them in every possible way. Happily, Mama had the knack for giving even the lowliest variety a special flavor. Pickled cucumbers were our special favorites so Mama always included them as part of our picnic menu. Wheat was indeed the staff of life in our home. Mama used it in a variety of ways. From a breakfast food which she simmered for hours on the back of our coal range, to hot cakes, baking powder biscuits, buns, scones, to wonderful crusty homemade bread. We loved to spread fat slices of this bread with cream skimmed from the milk pan and flavored with sugar, or covered and dripping with honey or syrup. Long loaves of what we now call French bread were our favorite for an outing. What is so delightful as homemade ice cream? No picnic or outing was complete in our family without it. Since Mama never counted calories, her ice cream was rich and delicious. The best and sweetest part was that which some lucky individual would lick from the dasher. Mama made many flavors and each kind we would avow to be our favorite. Try a delicious peach variety for your family. A dripper cake, usually Mama's special fudge cake recipe, completed our lunch. Even though we had eaten our fill we could never resist this special treat. Papa always concluded our picnics by arising to his feet and proclaiming that this picnic was the best ever. His only complaint being that he had eaten too much. Why did she make everything taste so good? Then, one by one, each one of Mama's children in his own way would echo Papa's words. Many of you, like Mama's children, have treasured memories. Many of you, as we do, long for "Mama's" cooking. Why not plan a family outing and try these recipes or those you and your family enjoyed and remember so well? Add 1 beaten egg and 1% to 2 cups powdered sugar and beat vigorously. 517 A Brace of Horses x nN Helen Hinckley Jones as g Papa had agreed to appraise a farm out in Snowville, and, since our Grant car was one day new, all the family went along for the adventure. This was a long time ago and the road was nothing more than a lane with a well-traveled center strip and two wide, bumpy shoulders. Mile after mile we jounced along on the shoulder. "Sam," Mama begged, "try the middle of the road. This is shaking our new car to pieces. The bottom of those wheel tracks looks smooth to me." Papa shook his head. "Ida, if I once get into those ruts, it will take a brace of horses to pull us out." So Papa avoided "getting into a rut," and every time I hear that trite old phrase I remember the dry, sunny day, the deeply rutted road, and our highwheeled, high-bodied new Grant. Perhaps that is what has led me to wonder continuously if I am getting into a rut, and, if I am, will I find a brace of horses to help me out. Getting into a rut is a dangerous and deadly thing. One of the basic needs of man is something to look forward to, some change, some growth, some different experience. Indicated, too, is that the road upward is not marked out by wheel tracks of the crowd. Perhaps you have seen the ruts on the road ahead of you, and recognizing the danger, have stayed out of them; but maybe you have blundered in, and the brace of horses to pull you out has not turned up. Do you ever feel stuck? You do have the brace of horses available: Resolution and Effort. Surveys show that one rut—and a deep one—is mental inertia. Some people haven't read a book in a year, or participated in a stimulating conversation since they can remember. Is this your rut? Perhaps you aren't keeping up with world events. If you don't know what is happening on the earth and above and below it, resolve to read the front and editorial pages of your newspaper each day or a good news magazine once a week. Resolve and then do it. Books are even more vital. One day a little ant climbed a blade of grass and, looking around him, said happily, "From here I can see the world!" and began happily to describe it. Writers of books are like that ant. They can see only the part of the world that is around them, but by reading you can see many such areas. Books can tell you of the scientific developments that are impinging upon our everyday lives. They can take you to faraway places and make you feel a part of all humanity. They can share with you the thoughts of great minds and the actions of noble men. And don't think that you can't 518 A Brace of Horses learn from fiction. Biography is the story of one man, fiction offers an account of mankind. Resolve to read a good book each month or even each week. Then make the effort to live up to your resolve. "Picking the brains" of others sounds almost unpardonable, but that is what the mentally alert do every day of their lives. If you meet a ceramic artist, learn about ceramics. If you meet an old-timer, learn more about your community. If you meet a scout-explorer, learn more about mountaineering. Reach out for these opportunities. A group of seventy-five adults living near the Huntington library where rare book exhibits are always open free to the public, was asked how often each of the group visited the library. Some had never been there. Some had been only when taking out-of-town guests. Only three visited with each change of exhibit. If there are libraries, museums, art galleries in your area, you may decide to grow mentally through visiting these places. Perhaps you want to pull out of your rut in a really big way. Plan to attend some adult education or college extension classes. Even go back to school if there is an opportunity in your area. The really tragic thing is to get into a spiritual rut. "For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?" (Matt. 16:26.) Have you grown careless and substituted routine Church activity for real spirituality? Church attendance is excellent, but unless it is an evidence of a "hunger and thirst after righteousness," you will still find yourself in a rut. Don't go to Church only to have your body counted. Perhaps you no longer take time to prepare yourself to pray. To really commune with God and hear his answers to our prayers we must close everything else out of our minds. Our minds must be open to receive the help and the solace that prayer can bring. You can find spiritual experience in reading the scriptures. Why don't you try reading any of the scriptures straight through with a good commentary at your elbow? You will find it a rich experience. Ruts are dangerous not only for a low-centered car on a high-centered road, but for any man or woman, boy or girl, who has ever read the commandment, "Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect." (Matt. 5:48.) Remember that it takes just a brace of horses whose names are Resolution and Effort to free you and set you high on the shoulder again. CPD GRANDMA'S COOKIES No one could make the cookies just like she could, Some were soft and spicy, raisin filled, Others were real crunchy, topped with sugar, At making brownies she was highly skilled. For holidays she used her special cutters, Hearts, and stars, and chubby boys and girls, Ginger, butterscotch, and plain vanilla, Baked and trimmed with little frosting swirls. Her cookie jar was very seldom empty, She always seemed delighted when we'd come, And what was best of all about her cookies, She invited one and all to, 'Please try some." —Ruth G. Rothe 519 July 1969 = Mama took a crocheted pot holder off the hook on the wall and opened the hot oven door of our big coal and wood range. Reaching in, she carefully pulled out the large dripper that was filled with eight evenly shaped loaves of golden brown bread. The delicious aroma that penetrated the room made me ever so glad I had a nose, and I inhaled deeply, again and again. Mama reached for another pot holder, lifted the big pan, and carried it to the pantry, where she emptied the luscious contents on a bread board that had previously been covered with a clean white cloth. Coming back into the kitchen, she went again to the stove, removed the lid from a pot of beans that had been slowly cooking since early morning, and taking a spoon, stirred them thoroughly. I was sitting half-on-half-off a chair, watching her every move with the wholehearted interest of a hungry nine-year-old youngster. "When are we going to eat?" I asked her as she went into the dining room and took a coin from the sugar bowl in the china closet. Mama smiled. "Just as soon as you get back," she answered, handing me the coin along witha scarf to tie around my head. "I want you to take this money and go up to Sister Carey's for a pound of butter." I slid off the chair and took the money quickly, for I thought of how the yellow butter would melt when it touched the hot bread, and how good it all would taste. "Hurry now, and be very careful not to lose the quarter," she 520 cautioned as I tied the scarf under my chin and left the house. I squeezed the money tightly in one hand, and guided my bicycle up the road with the other one. The later afternoon air was chilly, and low-hanging rain clouds made me pump faster than I usually did. As I rode along, I remembered the hot bread in the pantry and the good beans on the back of the stove. In spite of the cold weather I felt warm all over. Sister Carey was on the back porch and called, "Come in," when I knocked on the screen door. "I'm just now churning," she said when I told her why I was there. "Do you want to wait or come back later?" "T'll wait," I said as I sat down and watched her turn the handle 'of Butter Lena Mae Hansen of the big wooden churn. Round and round went the paddles inside, and I could hear the sour cream closh back and forth as I imagined little pieces of butter beginning to form. Soon Sister Carey removed the lid and paddles from the churn, and taking a long spoon, she gathered the clusters of butter, and placed them in a large bowl. With a broad wooden paddle she worked the butter back and forth, stopping once in awhile to empty the liquid that oozed out as she pressed the yellow spread against the bowl. I watched intently while she poured cold water on and off the butter to wash away any remaining sour liquid. After salting it, she worked it again as she had before. Finally, she spooned a pound portion into an oblong wooden mold and carefully pushed it out on a piece of parchment paper. Folding the sides and ends of the paper to cover the butter neatly, she found a_ small cardboard to place it on so it would be easier for me to hold. I gave her the money and hurried outside thinking that Mama might be a little upset because I had been gone so long. Very carefully, I laid the cardboard and butter in the small wire basket that was hooked securely to the handle bars of my bike. As I started back down the road, the summer rain clouds darkened, and soft sprinkles of water began to dampen the earth. I was glad I had a bicycle, and I hurried as fast as my young legs could pedal me. I held on to the handle bars tightly as I rode the four blocks toward home, for I didn't want anything to happen to the soft, precious contents in the wire basket. But happen it did, without any warning, and only a half block away from my destination. It all came about so quickly I don't know exactly how it took place. I guess the front tire hit a rock in the slippery road because all of a sudden the wheel turned sharply, the bike swerved dizzily, and the butter flew into the air as I tried frantically to regain control of the handle bars. But the bars wouldn't be controlled and we fell with a crash—me on the bottom and the bike on top. I skinned my knee as I slid along the ground, and tiny particles 521 July 1969 of blood were standing on the bruise as if it was a big decision as to whether they should stay on the surface or trickle down my leg. I was on the verge of tears when, suddenly, I saw the parchment paper, its contents splattered every which way in a mass of yellow ruin. The tears that had gathered close to my eyelids flowed over the edge and down my face. "Good old expensive stuff," I cried, as I saw that only a small amount of butter remained on the paper. I picked it up ever so carefully and hoped with all my heart that it would be enough for supper. "It's doubtful," I murmured to myself as I pushed the bike the remaining distance home. "I'm sure this isn't enough for nine of us to share." I parked the bicycle and walked slowly to the house wish- -ing I was someone else's little girl, so I wouldn't have to go inside. But I wasn't someone else's, I was our own little girl, and I opened up the door and stepped into the kitchen. The table was set, and our 522 family was starting to sit down; so no one noticed me for a minute. "Here's the butter," I said in a sad, weak voice. Mama was at the stove pouring the beans into a bowl. "What kept you so long?" she asked, not looking around. I walked over to her and stretched out my arm. The paper and butter, on the palm of my hand, were very close to her face. She stepped back to avoid being smeared, and a trace of a frown appeared on her forehead as she raised one eyebrow slightly. Then looking at me, all tearstained and skinned, she said with the real concern of a loving mother, "You've had an accident." She began immediately to examine my knee. "It isn't too bad—go and wash up," and she gave me a hug as she took the butter. "Will there be enough for supper?" I asked anxiously as I dried my hands. Mama looked at the contents on the parchment. It appeared to be clean, so she carefully scraped it into the butter dish. "Yes, I'm sure there is enough," she reassured me, kindly, and going to the table, she set the dish by the bread. I slipped quietly into my place as Mama sat down on her chair. "There are plenty of beans, cool milk, fresh warm bread, and a jar of strawberry jam," she said after we had said the blessing on the food, "so there will be no need for any of us to use more than just a dab of butter tonight." Everyone smiled, and I was ever so glad that I wasn't someone else's little girl. Her Hobby W> Writing @® Bertha Anderson Kleinman, Mesa, Arizona, has brought distinction to herself, to her State, and to the Church through her well-developed and useful hobby of writing. Her verbal architecture encompasses many fields, from prose and poetry to hymn lyrics and pageants. Her childhood home was situated on the rim of the north bench adjacent to City Creek Canyon in Salt Lake City. On this commanding location, her father erected a pretentious home for those times. Here Bertha grew to womanhood among orchards of fruitful and beautiful trees, lilac hedges, shrubbery, and_ terraced lawns. She watched the sun rise over the magnificent rugged Wasatch Range and watched it set in splendor over the great inland sea to the west. The ever-changing beauties of the Rockies lent color and majesty to her poetic nature and _ influenced her writing of the glowing tributes to the great western empire of which she is so much a part. About her writing, Sister Kleinman says: "If anything that I have written can help someone else, that is my favorite." Primary children love to sing her well-known "I Have Two Little Hands." Soon after her marriage to Orson Kleinman, she moved to Arizona and became one of the most prominent literary women of that area. She has been described as an outstanding citizen and Church member. In 1957, the Governor of Arizona _proclaimed November 3d as Bertha Kleinman day in recognition of her many published works regarding the State of Arizona. She earned the title '"'Poet Laureate of Arizona." She received the David O. McKay Humanities award at commencement exercises at Brigham Young University in 1958, largely in honor of the pageant "The Message of the Ages," a literary memorial to 100 years of Mormonism, perhaps the best known of her works. She updated the text in 1947 to include the pioneers coming into the valley. This pageant was produced every night for six weeks in the Tabernacle on Temple Square. Sister Kleinman was honored by the King of Denmark for her writings about the land of her ancestry. Her writings have appeared many times in The Relief Society Magazine, and in the other Church publications, and she has had a book of poetry published which is now sought after as a collector's item. At the age of ninety-three, she continues to write lovely and moving poetry. Her six children and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren revere her and are proud of the rich heritage of her written words. Always a devoted Relief Society worker, she was recently honored by the Relief Society of the East Mesa Stake for her untiring service and dedication. 523 e ye es =~ AANA AAACOAAN BUDGET DECORATING The Tapestry Touch i AAA (v f\ ad U ' 4 i Af uy j al The age-old tapestry touch is created inexpensively with a colorfully patterned terry bath mat and enhanced by a matching rose tree of bright plastic flowers. Fruit and HEART ROOM FOR HOME Alice Morrey Bailey Chapter 2 SYNOPSIS: Mary Ann and Kim Freeman take Kim's father from his home in Mayville, Utah, to their home in Los Angeles to care for him after an accident, in which his hip has been broken. His coming will constitute an upheaval in their way of living, as Mary Ann will have to break her contract as a teacher in order to care for him. This will halve their income at the crucial time when their last two unmarried children are dependent on it—Tommy for his last year in college and Rosemary for her wedding, both events the following June. It is now October. The parents are apprehensive about Rosemary's reaction, especially, as she has a demanding personality. @ Rosemary was her charming best throughout the slow process of the dinner after they had made her grandfather comfortable—and he sparkled under her attention. "Grandfather, is my little grotto still there?" "Yes, honey. The grandchildren play there by the hour." 526 "But you made it for me, didn't you? Chisled it out of pure rock." "Indeed I did, but the water had done most of it. It was yours before it was anybody else's." Rosemary dimpled with pleasure. "You know when they had those adorable, ugly troll dolls? My college friends couldn't imagine why I collected them. It was so I could take them there and put them in their own setting, and someday I mean to." It was Tommy who voluntered his room for his grandfather, as Mary Ann hoped he would. "Because it is closest to the bathroom," and moved his things to the one vacated by Robert, which they had used as a guest room since, while Rosemary made the bed ready for her grandfather. "Such willing hands!" said their grandfather. "I feel as if I had dropped into a bed of roses. Everybody is so nice to me, and I don't know why—a useless old man." "Grandpa!" Tommy and Rosemary protested in unison. "You could be useless forty years and not live up your credit,' Tommy went on. "How I loved my summers with you in Mayville!" "That's real nice of you children to say," said Father Freeman, "but mind you, stop me if I get to repeating myself. I've taken to reminiscing and I forget things, tell things over and over, can't remember what I've done and haven't done. I have to keep a list, I'm so old." "Dad, I do the same things," put in Kim. "Well, you're not so young yourself," said his father, looking at him astutely. "This doddering of the mind is a terrible trial to the young." How long is he going to stay?" She was looking at her father. He looked at Mary Ann. Here it was! "I'm going to take care of him," said Mary Ann. "How can you, with your job?" "TI have to break my contract. Monday." "Just like that?" "There wasn't any other way out, Rosemary." "Couldn't Aunt Emily or Aunt Francine have taken Grandfather? At least until summer?" "They thought otherwise," said Kim. "They wanted to sell the place and put your grandfather in a rest home." "Sell the place!" said Rosemary and Tommy im unison. This reaction, so like their own, was at least heartwarming to -Kim and Mary Ann. "T often describe Grandfather's set-up in class, an almost totally self-containmg unit—the. Cows, the chickens and garden feed the table and the table feeds the pigs. The pigs and extra produce go to market. One blissful round of living." 529 July 1969 "In the older days," said Kim, "you added a few sheep and got your clothing and bedding out of it, with rabbit brush, indigo, and madder root for dyes." "Somebody ought to write all that down," said Rosemary. "I love old things." "I remember!" said Tommy, his eyes sparkling. "Grandmother washed the wool, picked the burrs out of it, carded it into bats and made quilts. She even made her own soap—with lye and old fat." "Her mother made her own lye, out of leached wood ashes. The early pioneers didn't have to buy a thing. They grew cane and made their own molasses, spun the fleece into yarn, and wove their own homespun, even grew cotton, and raised silk worms and made silk. I've seen samples in the museums." "How long is Grandfather going to stay?" repeated Rosemary stubbornly. "We don't know," said her father. "Your grandfather thinks he will be well enough to go home by spring, but you can see...." "What about my wedding?" pursued Rosemary. "And Tommy's thesis quarter?" "Let me worry about my own affairs, Sis," said Tommy. "I wasn't thinking of the changes it would make in our lives when I invited your grandfather—or the burden it would put on your mother," Kim said. "Neither was I," said Mary Ann. "If you had been there, Rosemary, if you had seen your grandfather, with all of us talking as if he wasn't there, the 530 tears coming down his face in spite of his efforts not to show his weakness—his physical weakness. He is proud and independent. I was proud of your father when he told him the place would never be sold—not in Grandfather's lifetime, and not in ours." "And I was glad to hear from your mother her true feelings about her job. I had felt all along she was just saying she liked it to make us feel better about her working." "That's all very fine," said Rosemary somewhat bluntly. "But now what about my wedding? Obviously, both of you forgot about that." Rosemary was right. They had forgotten their children in the emotion-charged scene. The full brunt of their impulsive invitation had not hit them until later. Right now, as a matter of fact, Tommy had depended on his mother for his tuition and books, no small matter at this point in his education, and Rosemary had every reason to expect a lovely wedding, on the basis of their combined income. "Well, honey, we'll out," Kim said vaguely. Mary Ann realized now that she had shielded Kim in the matter of money, rushing forth with her funds whenever something above his ability to provide was needed. How could he realize the difference her salary had made in their plane of living? All the fringe items not officially listed with utilities, groceries, and house payments, the deluxe station wagon which had come into use bringmake ing his father home, the luxuries of finer clothes, a bigger fourbedroom home, including the swimming pool, extra gas and expense money for all of them. "We just have to play it by ear," he finished lamely. "T don't like ear music," said Rosemary succinctly. "Or hadn't you noticed? I like to play it as it's written—and it wasn't written this way. It is obvious that my wedding is not important to you." She went into her room and closed the door with a definite bang. Mary Ann rose to follow her. "Don't go, Mother," advised Tommy. "She has to think this thing through," but Mary Ann went anyway, entering Rosemary's room after a slight, unanswered knock. Rosemary was on her stomach on the bed. "Rosemary dear! If you'd been there! If you had seen how it ell Went ace ea deh was, with your aunts determined to sell the place and put the old dear into a rest home. He had been in a nursing home for a month after the hospital, and he couldn't bear it. 'Old people!' he said. 'Nothing but old people! And spaghetti one day, macaroni the next!' Your father and I couldn't bear to see your wonderful grandfather shunted off in his old age, to force him to sell life." his home—his whole "T'd really rather be alone," said Rosemary, without turning over. "T have some retirement coming, Rosemary. Not a great deal, but you can have that for your wedding." "What, exactly do you take me for?" demanded Rosemary, sitting up. "Your retirement is for your own old age! Now, really, Mother. I'd like to be alone."
