Doxey (Reading Assignment: Doctrine and Covenants, Sections 131:1-4; 132.) Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 OBJECTIVE: The Latter-day Saint woman should understand the truth that a marriage to endure after this life must be performed in a house of the Lord, and seek to attain an eternal marriage. INTRODUCTION In conversation with Elder William Clayton, the Prophet Joseph Smith told him what is now recorded in verses 1 through 4 of Section 131 of the Doctrine and Covenants pertaining to marriage. Section 132 is the revelation on celestial marriage, which includes plural marriage as well as eternal marriage. It is believed that the revelation on plural marriage was received as early as 1831, but Section 132 was committed to writing on July 12, 1843. (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 5, p. Xxxi [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereafter referred to as DHC].) Inasmuch as the Lord by revelation has withdrawn the prac- 540 tice of plural marriage, it is only necessary to mention the principle in this lesson. (The Discourses of Wilford Woodruff, pp. 213-18.) It is well to remember that this practice is proper only when the Lord commands it. (D&C 49:15- 17; Joseph Fielding Smith, Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, pp. 323-24; Jac. 2:27-30.) The penalty for practicing plural marriage by a member of the Church today is excommunication, the same as for others who commit adultery. (Joseph F. Smith, Gospel Doctrine, p. 280.) © Exaltation in the celestial kingdom requires eternal marriage but does not require plural marriage. In the revelation regarding eternal marriage, the expression "if a man marry a wife," expression 26 IN THE BEGINNING Marriage ig or Is 2: 18, 29. Lesson Department PURPOSE OF MARRIAGE There are some Churches Which Maintain that celibacy IS sanctioned by God. Ne of these Churches a 4¥S of the Shou] Latter-day Saint young m Or wo Marry SOMeone Who js ota Member of July 1969 The chances for conversion and the consequent happiness in marriage are far greater if the conversion is made before marriage. (Harold B. Lee, Youth and the Church, p. 132.) The Lord has said that parents should teach their children correct principles to shape their lives for happiness. (D&C 68:25- 28.) The mother has a wonderful opportunity in the home to impress upon her children the importance of Tt within the Church. Class Discussion How and when should a mother prepare her children for temple marriage? PURPOSE OF LIFE To work out one's salvation in this life and in the life to come is the paramount purpose of the earth life. This means that the purpose of God in creating man is to grant to him, through obedience, the greatest measure of salvation—eternal life. (Moses 1:39.) As man is the child of God, so also man may, by obedience to law, become as the Father. (D&C 132:20-22.) The blessing of eternal life comes to those who fulfill all the laws and commandments. OBEDIENCE TO THE GOSPEL The gospel of Jesus Christ provides the way whereby the sons: t and daughters of God may return. To his presence in the celestial kingdom. Baptism is the gate to that kingdom. (D&C 76:50-53.) There are degrees in the celestial kingdom, therefore, members of his Church should seek for the highest degree. 542 In the celestial glory there are three heavens or degrees; And in order to obtain the highest, a man must enter into this order or priesthood [meaning the new and everlasting covenant of marriage]; And if he does not, he cannot obtain it. He may enter into the other, but that is the end of his kingdom; he cannot have an increase. (D&C 131:1-4.) The new and everlasting covenant is the gospel of Jesus Christ. There are many covenants within the gospel and marriage for eternity is one of them. To be fully obedient to the gospel involves full discipleship. ETERNAL MARRIAGE After a couple have received the higher ordinances of the priesthood endowment in the temple, they are qualified to receive eternal marriage. Only by the keys of the priesthood held by the President of the Church, who delegates these powers to others, may this union be solemnized. (D&C 132:7.) The blessings available to those who marry for eternity are these:.. They shall pass by the angels, and the gods, which are set there, to their exaltation and glory in all things, as hath been sealed upon their heads, which glory shall be a fulness and a continuation of the seeds forever and ever. (D&C 132:19.) ETERNAL INCREASE In Section 131 and in Section 132, verse 19, the Lord has told us that if faithful to the eternal marriage vows, the blessing of "increase," and "a continuation of the seeds forever and ever" will be received. The Prophet Joseph Smith gave the following information on this subject: The children born to an exalted man and woman after the resurrection are spirit beings. The parents are tangible, resurrected persons referred to in the Scriptures as having spiritual bodies; that is, with spirit element in their veins rather than blood as in mortal bodies. (D&C 88:27; Al. 11:45; Brigham Young, Discourses of Brigham Young, p. 374.) THE DEATHS When resurrected beings are exalted they receive "eternal lives," the power of eternal increase, which is the Opposite of the "deaths," or the lack of such power. (D&C 132:24-25,) Only exalted beings will be Married in the future life because they proved themselves while on the earth in being faithful to all things required of them. (D&C 132:12.) In the following verses the conditions in the world to come are explained, having reference to those who receive marriage for eternity and to others who did not subscribe to the full law: Therefore, if a man marry him a wife in the world, and he marry her not by me nor by my word, and he covenant with her so long as he is in the world and she with him, their covenant and Marriage are not of force when they are dead, and when they are out of the world; therefore, they are not bound Lesson Department by any law when they are out of the world. Therefore, when they are out of the world they neither marry nor are given in marriage; but are appointed angels in heaven, which angels are ministering Servants, to minister for those who are worthy of a far more, and an exceeding, and an eternal weight of glory. For these angels did not abide my law; therefore, they cannot be enlarged, but remain Separately and Singly, without exaltation, in their saved condition, to all eternity; and from henceforth are not gods, but are angels of God forever and ever. (D&C 132:15-17.) If there are some who may believe that their Marriage is in effect beyond the grave, although not solemnized by God's priesthood in the temple, the following verse corrects this belief: And again, verily | Say unto you, if a man marry a wife, and make a covenant with her for time and for all eternity, if that covenant Is not by me or by received there, because the angels and the gods are apwhom they cannot pass; they cannot, therefore, inherit my glory; for my house is a house of order, saith the Lord God. (D&C 132:18.) Class Discussion How does our desire to project our family relationship into eternity motivate our desire to attain the celestial kingdom? MARRIAGE IN THE RESURRECTION In reference to a question concerning Marriage of a woman to that "in the neither marry, resurrection they nor are given in 543 July 1969 marriage, but are as the angels of God in heaven." (Matt. 22:30.) What did the Lord mean when he said that there was no marrying in the resurrection? He was speaking of the Sadducees who had rejected the gospel and its teachings about eternal marriage. As far as they were concerned, there was no Matrying or giving in marriage in heaven. But if the persons are worthy to be married for eternity, and the opportunity does not come while on the earth, the opportunity for this blessing will come in the world ahead. The necessary ordinances may, for instance, be performed on the earth in a temple by proxy. What of Latter-day Saint daughters who have died without being sealed to a man in the temple? Elder Melvin J. Ballard gave this counsel: Now, then, what of your daughters who have died and have not been sealed to some man? Unless it is made known to you, let their case rest. They will make known to you the agreements and contracts they have mutually entered into. The sealing power shall be forever and ever with this Church, and provisions will be made for them. We cannot run faster than the Lord has provided the way. Their blessings and privileges will come to them in due time. In the meantime, they are safe. (Bryant S. Hinckley, Sermons and Missionary Services of Melvin J. Ballard, p. 260.) Elder Ballard also gives an answer to the same question concerning little children who, of course, did not receive the sealing ordinance of marriage: I lost a son six years of age, and I saw him a man in the spirit world after his death, and I saw how he had exercised his own freedom of choice and would obtain of his own will and volition a companionship, and in due time to him, and all those who are worthy of it, shall 544 come all of the blessings and sealing privileges of the house of the Lord. Do not worry over it. They are safe; they are all right. (Ibid.) What about young men and women who die without the opportunity for marriage in the temple? Elder Harold B. Lee has said: You young women advancing in years who have not yet accepted a proposal of marriage, if you make yourselves worthy and ready to go to the house of the Lord and have faith in this sacred principle, even though the privilege of marriage does not come to you now, the Lord will reward you in due time and no blessing will be denied you. You are not under obligation to accept a proposal from someone unworthy of you for fear you will fail of your blessings. Likewise you young men who may lose your lives in a terrible conflict before you have had an opportunity for marriage, the Lord knows the intents of your hearts and in his own time will reward you with opportunities made possible through temple ordinances instituted in the Church for that purpose. (Harold B. Lee, Youth and the Church, p. 132.) Many women join the Church although their husbands may not. What of them? Salvation is an individual matter. If one party to the marriage remains true to the covenant of baptism and the opportunity for eternal marriage is not possible, then the righteous desires of that person's heart will eventually be realized. Class Discussion In view of the foregoing discussion, why do you think the gospel of Jesus Christ is just? BLESSINGS OF TEMPLE MARRIAGE -Experience has shown that those who marry in the temple generally find success in their marriage. Elder John A. Widtsoe gave the following nine reasons for a temple marriage: 1. It is the Lord's desire and will. 2. It is in harmony with the sacred nature of the marriage covenant. 3. It tends to insure marital happiness. 4. It permits the association of husband - and wife for time and for all eternity. 5. It provides the eternal possession of children and family relationship. 6. It acts as a restraint against evil. 7. It furnishes the opportunity for endless [eternal] progression. 8. It. Places the: family under the. Protection of the power of the priesthood. 9. It provides a God-like destiny for human beings. (John A. Widtsoe, Evidences and Reconciliations, pp. 231-36.) HAPPY HOMES The performance of the marrlage ceremony in the temple is not sufficient in itself to make a happy home. President David O. McKay has given six elements which lie at the basis of true home building: 1. Let us substitute the present tendency toward a low view of marriage with the lofty view which God gives RO woe. 2. Teach the young of both sexes in the responsibilities and ideals of marriage so that they may realize that * marriage involves obligation and is not an arrangement to be_ terminated at pleasure.... 3. Instruct young girls in the fundamental arts of housekeeping, so that when responsibilities of wifehood come, they may be free from the difficulties and _ perplexities which arise from ignorance and inexperience. 4. Marriages should be solemnized, as far as possible, in the house of God.... 5. Keep religion in home life.... 6. Teach the young that the foundations of a happy home are laid before even the bride and bridegroom kneel at the marriage altar. (David O. McKay, Gospel Ideals, pp. 478-79.) Lesson Department IMPLEMENTATION In the premortal world the plan of salvation was formed whereby the spirit sons and daughters of God could receive an earth life necessary for eternal progression. The relationship between God and his children was a parent-child relationship because his spint children were born of a Heavenly Father and Heavenly Mother. (Harold B. Lee, Youth and the Church, pp.. 126-27.) The eternal round of spirit children being born to exalted beings and the opportunity to reach the heights of exaltation by an earth life require marriage for eternity by mortals. Faithfulness to eternal marriage covenants is a means of proving oneself as a part of the eternal plan. Marriage was instituted by God for the purpose of bringing to earth life his spirit children for this probationary state. Exaltation is possible only to male and female together. (Joseph F. Smith, Gospel Doctrine, p. 276.) Marriage is so essential to salvation in the highest sense that provision is made in the gospel that those who do not have the opportunity in life for eternal marriage may have the blessing of temple ordinances by proxy. Latter-day Saint parents have the responsibility of teaching their children the principles of the gospel in order that they may be prepared for marriage in the temple. They know that success in marriage is enhanced greatly by eternal marriage and that only when sealed by the priesthood of God can contracts remain unbroken when men are dead. (D&C 132:13-14.) 545 VISITING TEACHER MESSAGE — Truths to Live By (Correlated With the Family Home Evening Manual, 1968-69) Message 1—In the Service of Your Fellow Men Alice Colton Smith Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 OBJECTIVE: To realize that when we serve our fellow beings, we are in the service of our God. A few years ago a group was discussing the meaning of service. One said, "I'm a business man. Everything I manufacture and sell is to help others have a better life." A teacher said, "My whole day is devoted to helping others develop." A mother said, "I gave birth and thus life to a number of people and I serve them." A lawyer said, "A public servant is well named. An elected official serves others." Centuries before this, King Benjamin called all his people together to teach them the will of God. In his memorable address he said: And behold, I tell you these things that ye may learn wisdom; that ye may learn that when ye are in the service of your fellow beings ye are only in the service of your God. (Mosiah 2:17.) What was he saying about service in this verse and the following verses of his speech? Did he mean what the businessman, the teacher, the lawyer, even the mother did, or was he speaking of something beyond the general goodness that people 546 may extend to. One another and for which they often receive remuneration and other earthly rewards? Jesus said: Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father who is in heaven. Many will say to me in that day: Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name, and in thy name have cast out devils, and in thy name done many wonderful works? (italics added.) And then will I profess unto them: I never knew you... 3 Ne. 14:21-23.) And again Jesus said, "For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? Do not even the publicans the same?" (Matt. 5:46.) In these teachings is God -not calling us to a more profound meaning of loving service? Is it enough just to take care of others we love? Do not sinners do the same? In his early instructions to the Relief Society, Joseph Smith said that one of the purposes of the society was in "... Searching after objects of charity and in administering to their wants.... (History of Relief Society, 1842-1966, p. 18.) Moreover, Jesus taught it was to be done so "That thine alms may be in secret...." (Matt. 6:4.) Again Joseph Smith - said, ".. Relief Society is not only to relieve the poor, but to save souls." (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 5, p. 25 [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereafter referred to as DHC}.) Our service to our fellow men, then, has special meanings. It is to be a part of serving God with our "whole souls" (Mosiah 2:21), to follow Jesus into total Lesson Department righteousness, and do the "... Will of my [our] Father which is in heaven." (Matt. 7:21.) We should love and serve our enemies. We should search out those in need. We are not only to attend to their physical needs but to help them find the kingdom of God, to keep his commandments "... That they might rejoice and be filled with love towards God and all men." (Mosiah 2:4.) We are to help them lift their lives to greater goodness, to help them achieve salvation. As we serve our fellow men, then, with these added dimensions, we are in the service of our God helping to bring about his multiple, great purposes. HOMEMAKING—Development Through Homemaking Education Woman's Role in Family Preparedness Discussion 1—''She Looketh Well to the Ways of Her Household." (Prov. 31:27) Celestia J. Taylor Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 OBJECTIVE: To show the need for family preparedness and the role of the Latter-day Saint woman in achieving it. INTRODUCTION Have any of us ever known a period of time when our leaders have not counseled, advised, and even urged us to prepare our homes and families that we might be self-sustaining in a time of need? The answer would certainly have to be in the negative. Why, then, are many of us so reluctant or so indifferent, or even so negligent that we fail to heed this counsel? Is it because we have lulled ourselves into a state of false security by using excuses—excuses which 547 July 1969 we can usually find if we are looking for them? WHAT ARE OUR EXCUSES? 1. That we are not converted. Can we justify ourselves when we accept some of the teachings of our leaders and reject others? 2. That we hear the counsel but we are not ready to heed it. Can we attain salvation without working for it? 3. That there is no immediate need. Illness, accident, strikes, destructive weather (earthquakes, tornadoes, etc.), and other disasters could occur at any time. 4. That we are protected by the Church storehouses. These supplies are only designed to meet needs that go beyond what the family is able to do for itself. 5. That we have inadequate storage space. If there is a will, there is a way to overcome this problem. 6. That spoilage of stored food results in a waste of money and effort. Do we criticize the program rather than the method when unwise planning and improper storing are responsible for our losses? 7. That we cannot afford the extra expense. Careful planning and _ wise manipulation of income will overcome this difficulty. WHY SHOULD WE BE PREPARED? If there were no other reason than that our Church leaders have so counseled us, it would be the best reason in the world for obeying. In a talk given at a Brigham Young University Leadership Week, Elder Harold B. Lee made the following statement: The only safety and security there is in this Church is in listening to the words that come from the prophets of the Lord, as if from the mouth of the Lord himself. And they have spoken; they have told us to prepare, and it is not for us to argue whether we should or whether 548 we should not. We have the prophets today telling us what our responsibility is here and now.... God help us not to turn deaf ears, but go out while the harvest is yet possible and build on a foundation such that when the rains descend, and the floods come, and the winds blow and beat on the house, our house will have stone walls. (BYU Leadership Week, June 16, 1953.) President Tanner told of a conversation he had with a member of the Church regarding the importance of family preparedness. This person said "Well, you know, if I knew that this was going to happen next year, if that is when the emergency is going to take place, I would get mine in" —meaning the year's supply. President Tanner replied, "If I were you I would wait for the emergency.... You remind me of the man who was complaining that he had been paying fire insurance for the last twenty years and he had never got anything out of it." (Welfare Conference, October 1, 1966.) We pay fire insurance, certainly not hoping that some day our houses will burn down. We pay insurance on our lives hoping that we will long. Outlive the maturing of the _ policies. We take other precautions which we hope will insure us a happy and profitable life here on earth, and then we endanger it all by not heeding the warnings and counsel of our leaders regarding this most important phase of our living—preparedness. President J. Reuben Clark gave us some wise and sound advice when he said: First, and above and beyond everything else, let us live righteously, fearing God and keeping his commandments.... [Second,] Let us avoid debt as we would a plague.... Let us straightly and strictly lve within our incomes, and save a little. Let every head of every household see to it that he has on hand enough food and clothing, and, where possible, fuel also, for at least a year ahead. (Conference Report, April 1937, p. 26.) WHAT IS THE LATTER-DAY SAINT WOMAN'S ROLE? In some instances women manage most of the family expenditures. Home management has become a business in itself. This intensifies our responsibility as Latter-day Saint wives and mothers in this important preparedness program. We need, first of all, to be entirely converted to it, and then we should —if we have not already done Lesson Department so—proceed in a systematic and orderly way tomake the necessary preparation, as our incomes will permit, without borrowing or going into debt. CONCLUSION An increased sense of security and a deep feeling of peace fill our hearts when we know that we are obeying the counsel of the prophets of the Lord and when we know that by doing so we can take care of those we love in any emergency. Few of us have known an extremity of want or suffering, but those who have experienced even minor emergencies recognize the wisdom of being prepared. SOCIAL RELATIONS—Immortality and Eternal Life Lesson 1—Restraint—Road to Freedom, Part 1 Alberta H. Christensen (Reference: Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, Selections from the Writings and Messages of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Melchizedek Priesthood Course of Study. 1969-70, Lessons 6-7.) Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 OBJECTIVE: To point out a mother's opportunity to teach the need and benefits of complying with the restraints of the immutable laws of the universe. INTRODUCTION If I were asked to name what I considered to be the most outstanding trend of modern life, particularly among the young people, I think I would say it is the rebellion against the restraints and conventions of our present life, whether those restraints and conventions affect our physical, intellectual, or spiritual activities and being. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 6.) 549 July 1969 These words of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., spoken as early as 1933, reveal a situation which has become increasingly evident through succeeding years and is a vivid reality today. They lead us into the general discussion theme of this _ lesson, which will quote liberally from lessons 6 and 7 of the current Melchizedek Priesthood course of study. This companion lesson will discuss restraints as they relate to the individual, emphasizing the need for restraints in society and in one's personal relationships. UNREST AND OPPOSITION The attitude of unrest and opposition to established institutions, referred to by President Clark and so apparent throughout the world today, is giving parents, educators, and civic leaders much concern. They are considering probable causes and searching for remedies. Existing conditions convince us_ that no easy answer is available and that no generalization is adequate for the complex condition involving so many aspects. President Clark states: Some may say this rebellion shows merely a wish for greater liberty; others may consider it a destructive demand for complete license. As frequently happens, neither extreme view seems wholly right. The truth probably lies somewhere between. ([bid.) A list of probable factors related to this attitude of revolt follows. President Clark has suggested the first three, others have been added, and still others may be suggested. Our concern in 550 this discussion -is to discover some areas where the home may be abdicating important responsibilities. Question for Discussion In your opinion, which of the following probable factors seem most likely to be responsible for this _personal revolt? Discuss as time permits. 1. A general desire for more liberty. 2. A destructive demand for complete license—freedom from restraint. 3. A personal weakness which may cause an individual to want others to become as he is or to share his point of view. 4. A lack of constructive objectives that give purpose to life. A desire to be different. A wish to escape responsibility. A basic lack of understanding of the value of law and order and of the need for personal restraint even in situations where changes and dissent may be justified. 8. A sincere mistrust by many idealistic young people of what they consider to be the hypocrisy and artificiality of accepted standards. Revolt for this reason, if recognized for the idealism it is and properly channeled, can be transformed into a force for good. NA Points to Consider In the search for cause and cure, may we not justly turn the searchlight upon the homes from which these individuals —these restless resisters of law—have come? We may ask such pertinent questions as these:; 1. Is it possible that restrictive demands within the home have been excessive, or has there been a complete lack of restraint? 2. Is it possible that an understanding acceptance within the home has been lacking so self-esteem has not been developed? 3. Have parents set the example of restraint by having definite life objectives? Have they motivated the children to do likewise? A. Have the children been given freedoms in those areas where individuality is commendable? b. Have they been guided so as to be able to distinguish between that which is merely "different" and that which is fundamental? 4. Have the parents done too much for the children, thus depriving them of the strength and growth that responsibility develops? 5. Has the home neglected to teach the need for law and the fact that obedience to law and order brings freedom? 6. Have faith in God and general religious training been absent in the home? RESTRAINTS—WHY? Certain familiar virtues, when developed and exercised, make us good citizens and dependable, upright individuals. These virtues are basic to constructive private life and have been found to be essential to an orderly society as a whole. We may enumerate some of them in such affirmative terms as_ honesty, respect for life and property of others, or in the negatively expressed commandments of the Decalogue, such as, thou shalt not kill, nor steal, nor commit adultery. President Clark states: These virtues are named _ because, looking at mankind as a whole and at the Christian nations particularly, these characteristics seem to be basic to their civilization. They seem to be equally basic to any form of orderly society of which we can conceive. For if every person murdered and robbed and lied and loafed and caroused, if there were an indiscriminate association of the sexes, no ordered society could exist; and without such society we have scant ground for hoping and no ground for believing, that humanity could escape becoming merely animal. ([bid.) Discussion Statements If the foregoing statements are sound, organized society must esLesson Department tablish some restraints and some conventions to assist in the enforcement of the restraints. President Clark states: Certainly some conventions and restraints must be retained; it is equally certain that others might be changed or abolished. The restraint which forbids murder may not be safely abandoned; the convention which prescribes the difference between dinner jacket and full evening dress might be forgotten. ([bid.) RESTRAINTS—WHEN AND HOW MUCH? How much restraint and what type of conventions needed for an orderly social unit to persist may depend upon (1) the persons or group of people affected, (2) the state of their civilization and righteousness. President Clark declares: The greater the civilization and righteousness which a person or a_ people shall possess, the less will be the need of restraint and convention. (Ibid.) Implementation 1. Relate the foregoing statement of President Clark with the following occasion and statement: When the Prophet Joseph Smith was asked how he governed the thousands of converts into the Church, he replied, ".. I teach the people correct principles and they govern themselves...." (Cited by John Taylor, Journal of Discourses, Vol. 10, pp. 57-58 {hereinafter referred to as JD]).) 2. Relate this principle to parental training within the home, answering this question: Can children, generally, be expected to perform better than their teaching or their knowledge? INHERENT IN ALL CREATION Speaking of universal laws, President Clark states:. The great laws governing the universe—physical, intellectual, and 551 July 1969 spiritual—are coexistent with that universe as known to us: they are self-executory, that is, they enforce themselves, no one needs to enforce them; they operate independently of man's will, consent, or desire; they operate impartially and universally; every creature, human or animal, every other created thing, is subject to the applicable law. It follows that whether we wish or whether we do not wish restraint, yet restraint is inherent in all creation.. Efforts to ignore restraint, or to evade it, or to destroy it, will meet with failure. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 7.) The physical world is fully controlled by law; if it were not, it could not and would not exist. Heat, light, electricity, what we call matter—air, water, earth— all are subject to and controlled by law. Our bodies being matter are equally subject to great physical laws from none of which is there any escape. (Jbid., lesson 6.) Question How can a mother make use of her knowledge of these immutable laws in the training of small children? President Clark suggests some practical. Illustration for the operation of these physical laws. He continues: If we walk off a cliff, we fall. It is immaterial whether we know the cliff is there, or whether we know we will fall if we walk off, or whether we desire to fall, or whether we step off the cliff by one foot or jump off by five feet; the result is the same and inevitable. If we touch a hot stove, we are burned; ignorance of its heat, or an accidental touching, or our own preferences, or our lack of knowledge that hot stoves burn—all are immaterial. If we lay hold of a copper wire, heavily charged with electricity, we are killed; again neither ignorance nor accident nor preference will avail us. Acid burns our flesh, water drowns us, poison gas kills us. These results all come from the operation of laws which are immutable; they execute themselves; they do not depend either upon our knowledge of their existence, or upon our consent to their operation, or upon our desire that they 552 manifest themselves; the penalty inevitably follows the violation. (Ibid.) Discussion Questions How may the relationship between the mother and child be affected if the mother (a) merely gives a _ negative command, (b) explains that a certain action will bring a certain result? Give examples. ' How would you answer the older child who asks: "But is there no exception? Does one always have to experience the penalty for violating the law?" One mother's reply: There is no exception unless some other law intervenes to. Soften or eliminate the penalty. For example, if a person wears asbestos gloves, he may be spared the burning effect of the hot stove. If a person steps off the cliff in a parachute, he may land safely upon the ground. The child, thus, gradually learns through experience and the verbal guidance of parent or other persons to walk freely and safely through many of the hazards of the physical world. He must, however, also learn—that this is a gradual process—that the effects of many physical laws must not be learned through personal experience, if he is to survive physically. He must not shoot himself to learn that a bullet shot from a gun can kill. From his close associates, especially the mother, the small child learns of many laws vicariously. He later may seek other authoritative sources. Question How can the mother establish a relationship that will build confidence in her judgment and admonition? Discuss briefly. THE IMMEDIATE VERSUS THE DELAYED PENALTY The penalty for violation of the immutable laws may be immediate, as in the foregoing examples, or they may be delayed for months or even many years. It is not difficult for adults to know and to understand why this is so. It is, however, not always easy for them to keep the effects sufficiently in mind that they are willing to heed the warning effects of the law. It is far easier to comply with the restraints of the law when the penalty is in immediate sight. Would many persons yield to the habit of smoking if the possible cancer result were always an immediate penalty? For children, it is even more difficult to maintain interest in a far-away penalty. Discussion Statement The more mature a person becomes, the more willing he is to comply with the restraints of physical laws where the results are not immediate. There are innumerable laws in the physical world about which we know very little at present. It is to discover these laws and their effects that research science is making such great effort today, in extensive areas of life. Muchhasbeen discovered already. We have centered our discussion, thus far, upon the immutable laws which affect our physical beings. "... It is inconceivable," LIFE'S AFTERNOON Lesson Department states President Clark, "that affairs of the mind and spirit of men, embracing the moral and spiritual world, are not also controlled by law." (Ibid.) (This aspect of the laws which affect our lives will be treated more fully in the succeeding lesson.) We also have focused our discussion, thus far, upon the effects of violating specific natural laws. We must not overlook the truth that obedience to the law brings affirmative rewards. President Clark phrases this idea beautifully in the following paragraph: On the other hand the law operates just as certainly in its blessings as in its penalties. If we avoid the cliff, we do not fall; if we do not touch the stove, we are not burned; if we leave the charged electric wire alone, we are not injured. So in intellectual and spiritual matters: if we do not offend, we suffer no injury. But in intellectual and spiritual matters, obedience to law brings' not only the blessings of mere absence - of penalty, but it brings also, in every case, increased power and strength, it brings growth and development, it brings us nearer to the ultimate goal pronounced by the Master: "Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect." [Matt. 5:48.] And this truth is the wonder and the glory of our intellectual and spiritual lives. (Ibid, lesson 7.) For Home Doing Make opportunities to remind yourself and to teach your children that obeying the restraining laws of the universe is to walk the road of freedom—free from the penalties that violation brings, free to enjoy the rich blessings of obedience. No afternoon of life is colorless; All the brilliance of the setting sun Reflects the golden memories of youth, And gilds the pathway toward the evening. —Grace B. Thomas "My soul standeth fast in that liberty in the which God hath made us free.'' _The Book of Mormon (Al. 61:9.) Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting, October 1969 Southern Hemisphere: March 1970 OBJECTIVE: To make clear that the free agency of man—his right to choose—is at the base of all meaningful liberty. MUSIC uBianik" from Ma Viast (My Fatherland) by Bedrich Smetana (1824-1884) Commentary on musical selection by Clawson Cannon, Assistant Dean of College of Fine Arts, Brigham Young University. " Through the ages as men have striven to be "... Free forever, knowing good from evil; to act for themselves and not to be acted upon...." (2 Ne. 3:26) they have yearned for personal and political freedoms. In the great nationalistic movements of the 19th century, artists, writers, and musicians did not really reflect the conditions of their time as much as they wrote on what they wished conditions were to be. Bedrich Smetana, in his later life, composed a series of six tone poems that beautifully expressed his love and hopes for his country. "The Moldau" is the best known of the six. It is a musical description of the mighty river by that name which flows through the land. "Blanik" is the final poem of the series, it paints the hill located in the mid-southern region of Bohemia around which an old legend is built—a legend that tells of sleeping knights that will awaken to serve the country in time of need. Smetana has used as a theme for this work the old Hussite hymn, Ye Are the Warriors of God. He wrote, "On the basis of this melody will develop the resurrection of the Czech people, its future happiness and glory." 554 INTRODUCTION TO LITERATURE LESSON At its most basic level, man's freedom to choose, his "agency" is fundamental to all that he does. We are told in 2 Ne. 2:26 that the redemption of Christ makes men ". Free forever, knowing good from evil; to act for themselves and not to be acted upon...." The selections which we are considering this month help us appreciate the range of choices we can exercise in establishing meaningful concepts of liberty. "THE HIND AND THE PANTHER" John Dryden's lines from his long poem entitled "The Hind and the Panther" emphasize the danger of trying to coerce others into a belief which matches our own: The Hind and the Panther Of all the tyrannies of human kind The worst is that which persecutes the mind. Let us but weigh at what offence we strike, "Tis but because we cannot think alike. In punishing of this we overthrow The laws of nations and of nature too. Beasts are the subjects of tyrannic sway, When still the stronger on the weaker prey; Man only of a softer mould is made, Not for his fellows' ruin but their aid; Created kind, beneficent and free, The noble image of the Deity. The final line of this excerpt— with its echo of Genesis 1:27— is intended to make explicit what has already been hinted at throughout the poem: only that man who remembers in whose image he is made can be expected to understand that Lesson Department coerced freedom of conscience is neither necessary nor beneficial. John Dryden (1631-1700) was one of the most versatile of English poets. He seemed to be at home in dramatic, satiric, narrative, and didactic poetry. He was also one of the greatest of English translators and one of the most accomplished writers of English prose. In 1686 Dryden was converted to Roman Catholicism and "The Hind and the Panther," his most famous religious poem, is a defense of his new faith. The Hind apparently represents the Roman Catholic Church, while the Panther stands for the Church of England. Discussion Question If most of us know that man "convinced against his will is of the same opinion still," why do we still try to force conformity? "THE INDISPENSABLE OPPOSITION" Walter Lippmann (1889) was a member of the famous Class of 1910 at Harvard University. Since his graduation, he has had a distinguished career as a journalist, editor, and author. For members of the Church, Mr. Lippmann's insistence on the necessity of opposition strikes an immediately responsive chord. In the second chapter of 2 Nephi we find the following lines: For it must needs be, that there is an opposition in all things. If not so... Righteousness could not be brought to pass, neither wickedness, neither holiness nor misery, neither good nor bad. (2 Ne. 2:11.) In reading Lippman's "The Indispensable Opposition" we 555 July 1969 must distinguish at once between that opposition which stems from mere contentiousness and that opposition which is creative. The Book of Mormon warns us against contention in the eleventh chapter of 3 Nephi, verse 29: For verily, verily I say unto you, he that hath the spirit of contention is not of me, but is of the devil, who is the father of contention, and he stirreth up the hearts of men to contend with anger, one with another. One of the cues as to what is essentially wrong with contention is given in the phrase "with anger." Too often our opposition is expressed in emotional, exaggerated charges and counter-charges. In such a statewe are not receptive to the whisperings of the Spirit. The Holy Ghost is not able to penetrate the wall of strong feeling which we have erected. We haven't ears to hear the truth. A dispute is not even a detour toward truth; it becomes an end in itself, a dead end. We quickly become less concerned with finding answers than we are in winning arguments. How rarely anyone is listening in an argument. We wait impatiently while our opponent speaks so we can stun him with our side as soon as he finishes. The opposition Mr. Lippmann finds "indispensable" has little to do with mere disputation. Rather, it is the presentation and consideration of alternatives that test and refine our own beliefs. Truth has nothing to fear from error and _ since the very word "definition" suggests pointing out that something is not as well as what it is, we can focus and sharpen 556 our perceptions by contrast as well as comparison. It must be remembered, however, that Mr. Lippmann is talking primarily about secular truth. That to which the Spirit has testified to us is not illuminated by error. Discussion Question How can we usually tell when a fruitful discussion is turning into a fruitless disputation? "WHAT IS LIBERTY?" Woodrow Wilson, twentyseventh President of the United States, in his essay "What is Liberty" presents an attractive picture of a harmonious society in which each part is adjusted to and balanced against every other one. It is important to remember, in reacting positively to such a concept, that such an adjustment might be temporarily attained where the basis for the social group is almost wholly evil, that' is, men are mere cogs in a machine. "ANIMAL FARM" George Orwell's "Animal Farm" is a convincing and devastating satire on a communist attempt to make "all animals equal." There are few endings in English fiction as effective as the concluding paragraph of this novel. What is most heartrending is that, to the exploited animals who are gazing in astonishment at the violent argument going on between the pigs and men, whatever the outcome of the arguments, they are the TO RELIEF SOCIETY AND OTHER CHORISTERS: Certainly, you are well advised to Strive to raise the cultural tevel of your group by using the songs of Schubert, Brahms, or others of the Masters whenever you can. Discussion Question What is the basic difference between the harmony and adjustment we seek in an organization such as the Relief Society and that sought after in the grouping described in "Animal Farm'? OTHER POEMS Poems by Henry David Thoreau and James Oppenheim stress the importance of peace of mind and personal integrity in the Meaning we can individually give to liberty. Of course we must understand that the Latter-day Saint definition of liberty is in accord with the Lord's definition of liberty. Thoreau's "Independence" is as follows: My life more civil is and free Than any civil polity. Ye Princes, keep your realms and circumscribed power, Not wide as are my dreams, Nor rich as is this hour. What can ye give which I have not? What can ye take which I have got? Can ye defend the dangerless? Can ye inherit nakedness? To all true wants Time's ear is deaf, Penurious States lend no relief Out of their pelf: But a_ free soul—thank God— Can help itself. Be sure your fate Doth keep apart its state,— Not linked with any band, Even the noblest in the land,— In tended fields with cloth of gold No place doth hold. But is more chivalrous than they and sigheth for a nobler war; are, A finer strain its trumpet rings, A brighter gleam its armour flings. The life that I aspire to live, No man proposeth me; 557, July 1969 No trade upon the street Wears its emblazonry. Along with his friend and mentor Ralph Waldo Emerson, Thoreau believed strongly in a self-reliance which was, _ ultimately, a reliance upon God. The fervor of Thoreau in this poem seems out of place if we do not remember this. It is a little unfair to think of Thoreau as the great rebel in American literature and it is even more unfair to believe that the group of which Thoreau and Emerson were a part — the Transcendentalists — were characterized by personal eccentricity and harsh independence. What all the Transcendentalists insisted upon was the necessity for each person to find out for himself what he believed in. They were sure that men of faith and good will would finally come to essential agreement, since God is the author of all truth but they felt strongly that each person must come to that unity in his own way. In this poem Thoreau tries to reject all the crutches which men have tried to use to avoid facing the truth and establishing a personal liberty based on that truth. James Oppenheim's "The Slave" is equally committed to the necessity for each man to free himself before he can conceive the meaning of liberty. Discussion Question According to the gospel, what is freedom and when is man free? "THE BRIDE COMES TO YELLOW SKY" This selection by Stephen Crane has been praised as an im- 558 plicit satire on an idealized West, as a major example of literary realism; or as simply a memorable story. Crane himself felt it was a "daisy" of a story. It is surely all of these but, in addition, few narratives equal its sensitive probing of the nature of freedom. In Walter Lippmann's article we see the part played by opposition in clarifying liberty. In "The Bride Comes to Yellow Sky" we are helped to understand the necessary connection between freedom and responsibility. There is no talk of freedom in this tale. The characters we meet are not given to philosophizing, but their instinct is sure. Even Scratchy Wilson, blurred by whiskey and unfaltered rage, is sobered and calmed by Jack Potter's announcement that he is now married. It is an indication of the refining influence of women in the development of the rugged west. Under the press of responsibility we are tempted to equate freedom with lack of obligations. Children, however, know better. How anxious they are to leave the circumscribed sphere of childhood for the choices of an adult world. If we lose some of a child's careless zest in growing up, we trade it gladly for the enlarged positions of husband, wife, father, mother. As Lehi reminds us, a Garden of Eden universe is static. (2 Ne. 2:22-23.) In the right to choose we prepare ourselves for eternal liberty. Discussion Question Too much responsibility may not prove compatible with freedom. How can we establish the proper balance? BRIGHT ECHO | watched a gull fly low Across the sky, Just where the sunset, Mirrored in the lake, Caused all its beauty To intensify. Alone, where rosy ripples Raced to break, Its bright wings echoed In the lake's reply, Flew its reflected self, In splendor's wake, And seemed the mystic Flight to glorify. —Nona H. Salt Lake City, Utah CLIMATE FOR LILIES There is a climate for lilies—in the tomorrows, In a plain, in the fertile loams of the future, In the gray bestowal of rain and intermittent sun, Lavish on the plain. There will be the pale burgundy of buds, The bloom with its trilogy of petals, Its triumvirate of gold. There is that next of summers, With trine of dreams and gold of hopes, And pale, pure satin Spilling gold from heart of gold. Though wind is a wall between, listen... A plea on the prairie strives Over wood fences weathered to pewter, Along the sea with its green, curling leaf of wave: After the winter of want There is a climate for lilies In tomorrow with its tool in hand And a long road leading there. —Dorothy J. The Magazine is not responsible for unsolicited manuscripts. 563 Law of Tithing Elder LeGrand Richards Of the Council of The Twelve Apostles Dear Relief Society Sisters: I have been asked to discuss with you the Lord's law of tithing and in doing so, I want to bear my testimony to the truth of this principle. Having served as a branch prestident, three times as a ward bishop, once as a stake president, twice as a mission president, and fourteen years as the Presiding Bishop of the Church, I have had much to do with tithing records, and I am. Convinced that the Lord has not forgotten his promise that if his people would return unto him, he would return unto them. THE LORD'S LAW OF FINANCE | It seems that the Lord had two major objectives in mind in giving to his Church the law of tithing in these Latter-days: First: The most equitable manner of financing his Church, for the burden is distributed according to one's ability to pay, the penny of the widow being equal to the gold piece of the rich man. Second: To test the faith of his people, obedience to the law of tithing being accompanied by a promised blessing. Hence, it is the Lord's law of blessing his people. The Lord gave to the Prophet Joseph Smith this revelation at Far West, Missouri, July 8, 1838, in answer to his supplication: 564 O Lord, show unto thy servants how much thou requirest of the properties of thy people for a tithing: Verily, thus saith the Lord, I require all their surplus property to be put into the hands of the bishop of my Church in Zion,; For the building of mine house, and for the laying of the foundation of Zion and for the priesthood, and for the debts of the Presidency of my Church. And this shall be the beginning of the tithing of my people. And after that, those who have thus been tithed shall pay one-tenth of all their interest annually; and this shall be a standing law unto them forever, for my holy priesthood, saith the Lord. Verily I say unto you, it shall come to pass that all those who gather unto the land of Zion shall be tithed of their surplus properties, and shall observe this law, or they shall not be found worthy to abide among you. And I say unto you, if my people observe not this law, to keep it holy, and by this law sanctify the land of Zion unto me, that my statutes and my judgments may be kept thereon, that it may be most holy, behold, verily I say unto you, it shall not be a land of Zion unto you. And this shall be an ensample unto all the stakes of Zion. Even so. Amen. (D&C Section 119.) THE PURPOSE AND USE OF TITHING While the Saints were attempting to establish Zion in the land of Missouri, they followed this requirement as given by the Lord and placed all their surplus property in the hands of the bishop of his Church in Zion. Since that time they have endeavored to comply with the "standing law" given "unto them forever." And after that, those who have thus been tithed shall pay one-tenth of all their interest annually; and this shall be a standing law unto them forever, for my holy priesthood, saith the Lord. (D&C 119:4.) In this revelation, the Lord indicated the purpose for which the tithing shall be used: For the building of mine house, and for the laying of the foundation of Zion and for the priesthood, and for the debts of the Presidency of my Church. (D&C 119:2.) The Lord further directed who _ Shall be responsible to dispose of the tithing:... It [tithing] shall be disposed of by a council, composed of the First Presidency of my Church, and of the bishop and his council, and by my high council; and by mine own voice unto them, saith the Lord.... (D&C Section 120.) The Law of Tithing In a revelation given to the Prophet Joseph Smith at Kirtland Ohio, September 11, 1831, the Lord made very plain the importance of observing the law of tithing: Behold, now it is called today until the coming of the Son of Man, and verily it is a day of sacrifice, and a day for the tithing of my people; for he that is tithed shall not be burned at his coming. (D&C 64:23.) How could one's conscience help but burn within him upon the "coming of the Son of Man," if he realized that he had made no contribution to the expense of establishing God's kingdom in the earth, especially when he came to a realization that all he has he obtained from the Lord, for he created the earth and the fulness thereof, and gave us our lives and our being upon this earth, with a promise that we might "inherit the earth" eternally, if we are faithful. Should we, then, not be willing to pay something for such an inheritance? It is not uncommon for a man in this life to pay money for ten to twenty-five years to purchase a small plot of ground for his use while he lives upon the earth. Should he be less interested in acquiring an eternal inheritance? PAYMENT OF TITHING DEVELOPS FAITH The Lord has always understood that to ask one to surrender, as evidence of religious faith, part of what he has acquired of this world's goods, requires a great measure of faith in obedience. Therefore, in order to develop and test the faith of his 565 August 1969 children, the law of sacrifice has been given unto them even when the Lord did not require their gift for the financing of his Church. Take, for example, Cain and Abel—to them was given the law of sacrifice:... Cain brought of the fruit of the ground an offering unto the Lord. And Abel, he also brought of the firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof. And the Lord had respect unto Abel and to his offering: But unto Cain and to his offering he had not respect. And Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell. And the Lord said unto Cain, Why art thou wroth? And why is thy countenance fallen? If thou doest well, shalt thou not be accepted? And if thou doest not well, sin lieth at the door.... (Gen. 4:3-7.) The Lord did not need the fruit of Cain's land or the firstlings of Abel's flock, for they were 'burned as an offering unto the Lord, but Cain and Abel needed to make this sacrifice to prove their love of God and their faith in him. A careful reading of this text will indicate that Abel's heart was right so he brought "the firstlings of his flock, and the fat thereof," while Cain's offering was made as Satan commanded. (See P. Of G. P., Moses 5:18.) Hence, "the Lord had respect unto Abel and to his offering: But unto Cain and to his offering he had not respect. And Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell,' and darkness entered his heart, and he slew his brother, Abel. Let us now consider Jesus' experience with the rich. Young man: 566 And behold, one came and said unto him, Good Master, what good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life. And he said unto him, Why callest thou me good? There is none good but one, that is, God: but if thou wilt enter into life keep the commandments. He saith unto him, Which?... (Matt. 19:16-18.) Then Jesus enumerated most of the Ten Commandments, to which the young man replied:... All these things have I kept from my youth up: what lack I yet? Jesus said unto him, /[f thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come and follow me. But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions. (Matt. 19: 20-22.) It should be noted that the rich young man asked: "What good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life?" Then it was that Jesus told him to keep the commandments. When the young man informed him that he had done this from his youth, Mark tells us that "Jesus beholding him loved him." (Mark 10:21.) How wonderful! Jesus loves every man who keeps the commandments, but Jesus tried to teach him the law of perfection, so in answer to the young man's further question: "What lack I yet?" Jesus said unto him, If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come and follow me. But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions. (Matt. 19:22.) In this experience, the Savior taught the rich young man that he should be ready to sacrifice all he had, including his time, and follow Jesus in order to obtain perfection. The gospel of Jesus Christ, as restored to the earth in these latter-days, would not be perfect did it not provide all the requirements for our Father's children to reach perfection, for this is what Jesus taught: Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect. (Matt. 5:48.) Our consideration of the experience of the rich young man will better enable us to understand this teaching of the Master: No man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon. (Matt. 6:24.) Abel chose to serve the Lord, "and the Lord had respect unto Abel and to his offering." Cain apparently, in his heart, had greater feeling for Mammon, and his offering was not accepted. The rich young man could not part with his earthly possessions, thus exercising his right of choice, and "he went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions," thus evidencing the fact that he chose to serve Mammon rather than God, thereby proving that he could not live the law of perfection which Jesus attempted to teach him. The Church of Jesus Christ provides an opportunity for all men to express their choice. Jesus made this plain: The Law of Tithing Therefore take no thought, saying, What shall we eat? Or, What shall we drink? Or, Wherewith shall we be clothed? (For after all these things do the Gentiles seek:) for your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things. But seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you. (Matt. 6:31-33.) THE LAW OF TITHING IN ANCIENT ISRAEL The law of tithing was observed by the prophets of Israel. Abraham paid tithing to Melchizedek: For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most high God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him; To whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of all; first being by interpretation King of righteousness, and after that also King of Salem, which is, King of peace;. Now consider how great this man was, unto whom even the patriarch Abraham gave the tenth of the spoils. (Heb. 7:1-2, 4.) The Lord gave this commandment to the children of Israel on Mount Sinai: And all the tithe of the land, whether of the seed of the land, or of the fruit of the tree, is the Lord's: it is holy unto the Lord. (Lev. 27:30.) Thou shalt truly tithe all the increase of thy seed, that the field bringeth forth year by year. And thou shalt eat before the Lord thy God, in the place which he shall choose to place his name there, the tithe of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil, and the firstlings of thy herds and of thy flocks; that thou mayest learn to fear the Lord thy God always. (Deut. 14:22-23.) 567 August 1969 Thus the purpose was then as it is now: "that thou mayest learn to fear the Lord thy God always." And as soon as the commandment came abroad, the children of Israel brought in abundance the firstfruits of corn, wine, and oil, and honey, and of all the increase of the field; and the tithe of all things brought they in abundantly. (II Chron. 31:5.) Honour the Lord with thy substance, and with the firstfruits of all thine increase. (Prov. 3:9.) Jacob promised a tenth of all the Lord gave him: And this stone, which I have set for a pillar, shall be God's house: and of all that thou shalt give me I will surely give the tenth unto thee. (Gen. 28:22.) The sons of Levi were appointed to receive the tithes: And verily they that are of the sons of Levi, who receive the office of the priesthood, have a commandment to take tithes of the people according to the law, that is, of their brethren, though they come out of the loins of Abraham. (Heb. 7:5.) OPPOSITION TO THE LAW OF TITHING IN MODERN TIMES When the Latter-day Saints first taught the law of tithing as a part of the gospel of Jesus Christ, they were opposed by clergy and laity alike, on the grounds that tithing belonged to the law of Moses, which was fulfilled in Christ, but that it was not a part of the teachings of the New Testament. It is clear, however, that Jesus taught that they should not neglect the payment of their tithes: Woe unto you, scribes and Phanisees, hypocrites! For ye pay tithe of mint and anise and cummin, and have omitted the weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy and faith: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone. (Matt. 23:23; see also Luke 11:42.) Opposition, however, has now ceased and many of the churches have attempted to adopt the law of tithing with questionable results. We know that tithing belongs to the gospel of Jesus Christ, for, as we have already indicated, the Lord gave this principle unto his Church by revelation to his prophet of this dispensation, to "be a standing law unto them forever." ESS MOUNTAIN NAMES For mountain flowers, trees, and birds We need the world's most lovely words. Brodiaea, lilies, gentians, clover Are like a song to linger over. Tamarack, fir, and cedar... These Are sounds that label snow-line trees. Flickers, warblers, chickadees, And jays have winged names that please. For mountain flowers, trees, and birds We need the world's most lovely words. 568 —Vesta N. Espond, interpret—and Literary Contest Announcements 1969 The Relief Society Poem Contest and the Relief Society Short Story Contest are conducted annually by the General Board of Relief Society to stimulate creative writing among Latter-day Saint women and to encourage high standards of work. Latter-day Saint women who qualify under the rules of the respective contests are invited to enter their work in either or both contests. The General Board will be pleased to receive entries from the outlying stakes and missions of the Church as well as from those in and near Utah. Since the two contests are entirely separate, requiring different writing skills, the winning of an award in one of them in no way precludes winning in the other. The Relief Society Poem Contest The Relief Society Poem Contest opens with this announcement and closes November 15, 1969. Prizes will be awarded as follows: Minst prize -------.---__2 $40 Second prize - - ---------- $30 Third prize - ------------ - $20 Prize poems will be published in the April 1970 issue of The Relief Society Magazine. Prize-winning poems become the property of the Relief Society General Board and may not be published by others except upon written permission from the General Board. The General Board reserves the right to publish any of the other poems submitted, paying for them at the time of publication at the regular Magazine rates. Rules for the contest: 1. This contest is open to all Latterday Saint women, exclusive of members of the Relief Society General Board and employees of the Relief Society General Board. 570 2. Only one poem may be submitted by each contestant. 3. The poem must not exceed fifty lines and should be typewritten, if possible. Where this cannot be done, it should be legibly written. Only one side of the paper is to be used. (A duplicate copy of the poem should be retained by contestants to insure against loss.) 4. The sheet on which the poem is written is to be without signature or other identifying marks. 5. No explanatory material or picture is to accompany a poem. 6. Each poem is to be accompanied by a stamped envelope on which is written the contestant's name and address. Nom de plumes are not to be used. 7. A signed statement is to accompany the poem submitted certifying: a. That the author is a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. B. That the poem (state title) is the contestant's. Original work. That it hasnever been published. That it is not in the hands of an editor or other person with a view to publication. E. That it will not be published nor submitted elsewhere for publication until the contest is decided. > 8. A writer who has received the first prize for two consecutive years must wait two years before she is again eligible to enter the contest. 9. The judges shall consist of one member of the General Board, one person from the English department of an educational institution, and one person who is a recognized writer. In case of complete disagreement among the judges, _ all poems selected for a place by the various judges will be submitted to a specially selected committee for final decision. SZ ROADSIDE MOMENT, SUMMER Direr the artist etched the growing world As few have paused to see it... Once, Halted by a roadside, | looked out level and deep into his summer world—at blade, stem, blossom, pod, leaf, Whorled and curved, planed and shaped, Divided, yet intricately twined and curled, (Each one an entity individually rising) Diversity in a random plat So myriad, the eye seeking thought by thought For reason, was dazzled by the shades Of light given back from so subtle a variance Of delicate greens. —And these were weeds! Never, no never before had | seen Such wonders springing in so small a space... Great Moses once, in a burning bush, Saw God... | too have looked, and marveled In my small way, at his gifts of grace! 572 —Katherine F. Larsen IDENTITY Who You Are Lillian Y. Bradshaw mt @ At the circus, the lithe tightrope walker gracefully climbed the pole. With breathless excitement we watched him test the wire. A hush fell upon every lip as with slippered feet he glided along the wire—one cautious step after another—his balance measured by every thought and movement of his body. A slip here, a slip there, a quick bend of the body far to the left and then quickly to the right—we gasped with relief as he regained his balance once again to move — swiftly forward. And though we sat taut on the bench below, inside we were keenly aware we were taking every step with him. Now the goal but a few steps more—joyfully and with obvious relief we all exclaimed "Hurrah!" as the platform on the other side was reached in safety. And so it is with children.... Some seem to be thus blessed as they enter in on this tightrope life—well slippered, testing each step, seemingly gifted with a balance all their own. And though they slip to one side or the other and we hold our breath, they always seem to know how to right themselves. It is with excited joy and anticipation we see them perform. And many are the hurrahs. — And then there are _ those children who enter as though wearing hiking boots, and act as the clown who performs clumsily—slipping, sliding, arms and * aK ve fe legs askew. We are at times caused to laugh, yet when we see this young one lose his balance our hearts reach out and achingly we ask ourselves "Oh, what can I do?" "What can I say?" "How can I help, don't you know how important you are?" And then he falls into the net of life and walks about with each step sinking in that net to 573 Pee PR A Se Seca ee August 1969 the height it was before the step was taken—not knowing quite how to get out. And few are the hurrahs. Again, we are caused to ask searchingly of ourselves "What could I have done to prevent the fall?" And then I imagine myself having a rod to hold out for him and others to take hold of until they find firm ground again. While my older children were yet quite young, I taught many Mutual Improvement Association classes and became aware of the fact that those young people whose step seemed so sure seemed always to carry the balance rod with the words emblazoned on it: I know where I came from! I know who I am! I know where I'm going! And I marveled. Otten these young people were either converts or children of recent converts to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day -Saints. And it often puzzled me and caused me to ponder "How, when my children are born under the covenant—how can I instill in them this same strength?" And a prayer would be uttered in my heart. "Oh, Father in heaven, what can I say now while my children are yet pliable and young that will emblazon on their rods who they are and how important they are to themselves and that what they do really counts." They must learn from mistakes, I know, but what can I do now that will give them that innate sense of balance that will help them right themselves as 574 they slip and slide along the tightrope of life? Many years have passed since that prayer was answered. Enough years that in looking back I can now see how it was answered—so subtly and yet with such wisdom. That I am caused to marvel at the simplicity. It all began in sacrament meeting as the speaker—a young woman—told of her conversion to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and of the great joy she felt, while relating the loss of family, friends, and home—all that had been dear to her before. We felt tears sting our eyes and wondered if we really appreciated being born into the Church. How could we be so lucky? Lucky? Was it luck or had someone paid such a price for us once?. We determined as a family to trace back all our genealogical lines and find the one in each line to whom the gospel had been preached first. What had it cost each one to accept the truth? Was it difficult? What an adventure! We divided into four teams—each team determined to trace one of their grandparent's lines. I had most of the histories put away—somewhere.... Others we found through grandparents and relatives. I purchased a large Multigeneration Pedigree Chart, and we began writing in all the progenitor names and the dates we could find. The sheet was large enough (25 x 20 inches) so that all names could be seen at once. Here we did something quite by chance but which made all the difference to the entire evening. We left the first line unnamed —Blair's name was on line 2 and mine on line 3. The evening of July 24th, the anniversary of our pioneers coming into the Valley was the date 'we set aside as a family to disclose what we had found. The interest was as high as if we had been working on a Sherlock Holmes mystery. I can remember the evening we gathered to disclose all we had found. We placed the pedigree chart in the middle of the floor and then as story after story was told a hush descended upon the room. With interest each watched the red check placed by that particular person's name on the chart. We found that most of the red checks appeared under the heading "second greatgrandparents" some four lines away from that first unnamed line. But whose name would be put on that first line they kept wondering? "Many were the stories told of bravery before mobs, trials of faith of families who had had to part because of lack of money so some could travel to Zion and then had worked hard so those left behind could follow and all be together again. Stories of the youngster left alone when his parents died crossing the plains, stories of the mother keeping a family together as the husband went on his mission. And then it all became very real as they heard the story of Sarah Jane Richards—a young girl just about their age. The story told how she and her girl friend went to a Latter-day Saint Identity—Who You Are meeting in Carmarthen, South Wales, about 1848 with the intent of making fun. As they listened to the two missionaries, Sarah Jane believed what was said. After a few more meetings, she told her father she wanted to be baptized. He became very angry and tried many ways to get her to give up the new religion. But she could not—she knew it was true. Her friends threw rocks at her. With tears and heartbreak she was finally forced to leave home without money, clothes, or any other belongings except what she was wearing. She walked eighty miles to a coal mining town where two married sisters lived. When she got there her shoes were worn off of her feet and her feet were bleeding. Ore of the sisters took her in and she started to work in the coal mines, where girls were employed to shovel the coal. While working there, her hand was crushed in an accident. It was so seriously injured that the local doctor advised amputating it. She begged him to delay the operation and he granted one day. She had complete faith she could be healed if the elders could be found, and so prayed constantly for them to come. That night they came, telling her she literally prayed them there. They administered to her and their combined faith was so efficacious that when the doctor arrived expecting to operate, he marveled at the change and decided the operation was unnecessary. After working hard and saving every possible penny, she sailed alone for America. This was only the By/2) August 1969 beginning. With joy she gave her testimony of the truthfulness of the gospel as she had been led to it. Now there came a feeling over the whole room. A soft, warm, penetrating feeling. Our belonging to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints one of luck? No! It had been hard earned by someone who was willing to be lonely, by many who had sacrificed all they had for the precious gift of the gospel. This then led to many more stories of great-grandparents, and grandparents, and their struggles to remain faithful—enduring heartache and disappointments. And then we as parents bore testimony of times of spirit when we had had to decide which path to take. Ever the stories brought the lifeline closer to that first empty line. 576 And now they knew that each one of them would place his own name at the head of the entire sheet. Each generation had remained faithful and now they were the link to keep it unbroken. "Now," we said, as we took our youngest daughter by the hand, "Sue, as you look at this sheet pretend that another sheet just like it is extending into the future on the other side to the left. Here you are as the one with lines spreading from you not only from the past but also to the future—you alone hold both lines. Someday you will be the mother with children and then the grandma. Will your children look back on just such a sheet and have pride and gratitude in their hearts as you have right now for them, because you made the right decisions? They, too, will bless you because you chose to marry in the temple so they could be born under the covenant. Now you know who you are. You know how important you are. You know that what you do now is important." One by one, we took each child through the same route, mentioning perhaps different areas in which they might have to make a major decision—always repeating at the end the same, "Now you know who you are." They stood alone and they felt responsibility weigh importantly heavy upon their own actions. No longer were they to go off and claim it didn't matter what they did. They held hands with the eternities—past and future—and became the link between where they had come from and where they were going. Now they knew, and we knew they knew who they are, and it gave purpose to them to seek out why they are here. Looking only to the past to the deeds accomplished by ancestors can bring a shallow, dangerous false pride. But when they see themselves as a definite part of the future, it brings to immediate focus their own responsibility now. Major decisions—such as the use of drugs or whether going on a mission is important, or what to do with free time in the service of our country, or whom to marry—do not come in one great decision. Such decisions are festered or cured with that cautious tested step forward one at at a time. It is the small slips to the right or the quick one to the Identity—Who You Are left—the decisions which would unbalance my tightrope walker— that I want to reinforce and reinforce again so as to keep that line taut as he carries his own balance rod. With a slack line there can be no sure footing. It has been only within recent years I have been made aware how that prayer was answered. For now my children are old enough that by its fruits it has been tested. Time and time again I have used it and have seen it work on young and old. A subtle way to help them strengthen their own decisions when temptation would seem so _ powerful as to make them sway. When, with small voice or crying out inside, they ask _ themselves, What does it matter? Who cares? It's my life! SS SARAH | had not much to give to her | loved Save love itself, And that was borne in trailing clouds of sand And dust that followed in our stormy way Behind the ceaseless, toiling caravan Wherein she bore her son in winter's years. Celestia J. Taylor Not to Be pwn eneral Board of Relief Society Happy! M Happiness is an abstract quality difficult to define because it has sO many Meanings; paradoxical in nature because it is present in the least expected places and absent where it appears most likely to be found; elusivé because, like the butterfly, it alights wherever it so inclines, but escapes the grasp of those who seek to capture it. It is 4 quality much to be desired, the easiest, yet the most difficult to attain. One of the expressions familiar to us and, therefore, often quoted: "Men are that they might have joy," contains both the secret and the key to the attainment of this most precious commodity. Just being here on this earth does not guarantee us happiness, but it offers us the possibility of attaining it. Its possession, as that of any other worthwhile goal, is dependent upon the laws which govern it, and wherever there is a law there is a responsibility. This is the secret. The key lies in the fulfillment of whatever that responsibility may be. How shall we define this responsibility? Certainly not by listing set rules and forms or by quoting high-sounding platitudes, which, though well-meaning, bear little or no relation to reality. Responsibility can only be defined in terms of the individual, for no one person's situation is the same as that of any other. There are certain positive things, however, that we can know or learn which are applicable under any and all conditions. We should know that forgetfulness of self in the service of others is conducive to serenity of spirit, to peace of mind, and to other qualities which are vital prerequisites to happiness. Finally, we should know that the pattern of life set by our Savior leads to happiness and that our acceptance of and adherence to that way of life is our only hope of attaining it.
