Cannon Lilly Peter, a past-seventy poet, photographer, anc fulltime farmer, recently mortgaged 4,000 acres of her Arkansas plantation to bring the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, with Eugene Ormandy, to play for Little Rock's one hundred and fiftieth celebration of Arkansas' territorial status. She wanted her fellow citizens to hear the best in music, paying $60,000 for this privilege, "Miss Lilly' commissioned, for $8,000, the Pulitzer-prize-winning 'Homage to Haydn" which the orchestra premiered. - It also played selections from Wagner, Debussy, and Brahms. When Baroque concertos for harpsichord are included, Miss Belgeri serves as soloist. 579 EDITORIAL / Leisure for Oneself ® To some the words ''relaxation'' and ''leisure'' may contain derogatory undertones, but the meanings in the dictionary give one pause for thought. ''Relaxation'' is stated as ''relief of bodily or mental _ effort.'' Leisure time is ''the condition of having one's time free from the demands of work or duty.'' What a precious commodity these are for a mother with many young children, or a woman burdened with exacting household duties, including that of constant nursing. One woman confided, ''| have been pressuring myself too much. | am beginning to realize that some of my waking moments need to be spent in doing something | want to do. | need to let down and take or make the time to do something to relax myself."' Advertisements of modern appliances sometimes tell of the additional time released to a busy homemaker. Too often the claim reminds the homemaker of the holes she used to make as a child at the seashore which instantly filled up with water and the holes disappeared. Two women were speaking of joys experienced in earlier days of going visiting. One explained, ''Where could you ever find the time today to go visiting, and if you did, what kind of a welcome would you have in the home where every minute seems to be scheduled fully? I'd feel guilty expecting a friend to sit down and take up her time."' Yet Samuel Johnson said, ''All intellectual improvement arises from leisure."' If this is true, or even partly true, depending on one's interpretation of what he meant, should not every woman seek to capture some leisure when she may pursue her own desires? And how Volume 56 August 1969 Number 8 Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Miltenberger, Acting Secretary-Treasurer — 580 should it be spent? In doing something which will bring her a release from tension, a feeling of fulfillment, the building of her own entity. She may wish to take a walk, to garden, do genealogical research, play or listen to music, study and admire reproductions of paintings, sculptures, study a foreign language, read for pleasure, do crewel work, knit, visit a sick friend, telephone a friend, bake a cake for a neighbor, or just sit still and dream. Others find release and rejuvenation in physical exercise, in tennis, golf, bowling, swimming, or hiking. Sometimes a trip to a lovely store is very satisfying. If one is not too weary, the time before one goes to sleep may be used for relaxing. Perhaps time can be found for reading the scriptures, and even with one's eyes shut, a happy or fond experience can be relived in memory. If no one else is disturbed it is pleasing to sing some songs or recite poetry or scriptures. It is a time to evaluate one's progress and review pleasant events so it will be a time of leisure and relaxation. It is not a proper time to lament one's shortcomings of the day, but rather do that when one is actively pursuing one's work. Sometimes a movie on television will be a source of relaxation. There is no rule that says what one should do with leisure time. It will vary with the individual's need, but every woman needs to enjoy some leisure time, and everyone will do well to rearrange her daily activities, if necessary, so that early or late she can devote some time to herself alone and to view her life as an individual for which life she is accountable. —M. Miltenberger Appointed Acting SecretaryTreasurer The General Presidency of Relief Society is pleased to announc the appointment of Mayola Rogers Miltenberger, member of the General Board, as acting Secretary-Treasurer, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of former Secretary-Treasurer Evon W. Peterson. - Sister Miltenberger was appointed to the General Board in October 1968. (See The Relief Society Magazine, January 1969, p. 16.) She will continue as the administrative supervisor of the Relief Society Social Service programs in Salt Lake City, Arizona, Nevada, and Idaho, while devoting a major part of her time as SecretaryTreasurer. Sister Miltenberger has great executive abilities and an abiding love for Relief Society. She desires to serve in any capacity to which she is called and will render valuable service for Relief Society at this time in her new assignment. She has a deep interest in the work of the sisterhood throughout the Church. They will enjoy their association with her. Irene Cannon Lloyd Resigns From the General Board General Board members and sisters throughout the Church will regret the resignation of Irene Cannon Lloyd from the General Board, as of June 4, 1969. She has served on the board since November 1, 1961 during which time she has rendered devoted and important service to Relief Society. While serving on the General Board, Sister Lloyd has rendered capable service on various committees including the Spiritual Living, General Conference, Homemaking, and Music Committees, along with many others. She has also fulfilled conference-speaking assignments both at home and abroad, and her sincere spirituality has enriched the lives of many sisters. Sister Lloyd came to the General Board after serving Relief Society in various executive positions, including that of a stake Relief Society president. In her home she has carried forth a heritage of deep devotion to the gospel, and her family carry this heritage proudly. The united love of the board goes with Sister Lloyd. Her devotion to Relief Society and her faithful service will remain as a tribute to her in all she does. On behalf of Relief Society sisters throughout the world, love and appreciation are extended to Sister Lloyd. May her health improve and may she find much happiness in her future endeavors. Relief Society will continue to be an enjoyment and a fulfilling part of her life. 582 , Notes to the Field The Relief Society Annual General Conference The Relief Society Annual General Conference will be held Wednesday and Thursday, October 1 and 2, 1969. Dee Applegate | a & a j U wet? If Aa Aj: we ¢ @ Thesounds of the radio banged into Cally's ears as she tried to remember what came next in her pancake recipe. The baby was crying to be picked up, and her husband was calling for a clean towel. The rain beat a heavy tempo against the window; gray clouds pressed a damper on any cheerful thoughts that might have entered her mind. Over the din she heard the radio announcer presenting the local weatherman for his report and forecast. "Tt's a beautiful day in Fremont County!" he began. "At 7:00 this morning, 45 hundredths of an inch of precipitation...." Click! Cally couldn't bear hearing anyone being cheerful about this muggy weather. "He must be some kind of nut," she muttered. At least now with the radio off there was less competition for her attention. She finally got her husband out the door, the 584 baby fed, the dishes done, and the bed made. She had an awful temptation to climb back into bed, but wisdom and good sense beat back her heavy eyelids, and she smoothed the bedspread over the pillows. "A beautiful day indeed!" she muttered as she settled into her daily routine. The phone rang. "Ts this the Glen MacMillan residence?" a man's voice asked. "Yes — this is Cally MacMillan." "Mrs. MacMillan, your husband has been in an automobile accident and has been injured. The ambulance is taking him to City Memorial Hospital now. Can you meet us there?" Cally's heart fell to her feet and she frozein shock. "Mrs. MacMillan?" The man's voice seemed twenty miles away. Cally had visions of her husband strapped on a stretcher in a whining ambulance. The man's voice reached her again: "If you have no transportation, a squad car can pick you up." Reality flooded over Cally in a wave of nausea. "Oh — yes — please — Glen was driving our car — is he seriously injured? Is he all right? Please tell me!" Cally's panic spread to her voice. The man sounded more quiet and understanding than before. "I'm sorry, I don't know. The driver of the other car has only some cuts and bruises. A child ran in front of the other man, he swerved and struck the driver's door of your car. Your husband had immediate medical attention, so he's in good hands. We'll pick you up in about ten minutes." Click. Cally fell back against the wall.. She felt like crying but the tears wouldn't come. Her mouth was dry and her feet felt like lead. Her jumbled thoughts even included regrets of ever having married—it would have prevented so much pain, sorrow, and difficulty. The baby's wail penetrated the shocked trance and brought her back to the cold truth of reality. Cally lifted the receiver again and shakily dialed the number of her neighbor. "Hello, Miriam? This is Cally. Listen, Miriam, I need help. Could you take the baby for awhile? Glen's been in an accident and I've got to go. Oh, thanks—she's in bed and should sleep soon... No, they're coming to get me, but thanks. See you in a minute. Bye." Cally was surprised at her calm as she assembled baby food and dishes so Miriam would have no difficulty finding something The Weather Report for the baby's meals. Miriam and the police car arrived simultaneously, so Cally grabbed her raincoat, gave a brave smile to her friend's encouraging embrace, and stumbled into the rain. The typical hospital odor brought back to Cally's mind that her husband was _ lying somewhere within, unconscious, maybe dying. Panic once again overwhelmed her. She had hoped to be allowed to be with him, but he was in the emergency room. She was shown to what would be his room. The second hand on the clock seemed to take at least five minutes to complete each cycle around the clock. A doctor leaned into the room and glanced around. "Are you Mrs. MacMillan?" "Yes." "Please come with me." Cally followed him to a small office. "Mrs. MacMillan, your husband has been seriously injured. It is imperative that he undergo immediate surgery in order to save his life. We need your permission to perform this surgery." He took a form from a drawer and pushed it toward her. "If you'll sign this standard form, we'll proceed immediately. This explains that we have your permission to do what we feel is necessary even though this action might result in the death of your husband." "Death?" Cally didn't want her husband to die—and Cally's dulled reasoning abilities heard this man asking her permission to do something to Glen which might result in his death. "Mrs. MacMillan your husband has very little chance of living if we do not operate. This is just a legal precaution to pro- 585 August 1969 tect the hospital and doctors. Please sign it." She took the pen and signed her name. The printing was hazy through her tears as her emotions finally found vent. There were no violent sobs or cries—only one or two tears sliding down her cheeks. The doctor was gentle as he touched her shoulder, signaling that they must hurry. He escorted her back to Glen's empty room, then hurried away. | ally stood at the window and watched the rain continue to pelt the earth. It was the kind of drizzle that could—and probably would—go on all day. The gray ceiling of clouds seemed oppressively low. The doctor had told her that it would be at least an hour and a half before she could have any word. She walked over and closed the door. She didn't like the sounds of people walking and talking as if nothing was wrong. The helplessness of her situation weighed heavily upon her. Cally could only sit and stare at the rain. When the door opened again, Cally didn't hear it, because she was asleep. Glen's bed was rolled in, accompanied by nurses and aides who also wheeled in the standard, bearing life-sustaining blood, liquids, and nourishment. Glen's eyes were closed, too. His head and one hand were bandaged. You couldn't see his chest where broken ribs were held in place with adhesive bandages. There were no other visible cuts or bruises—one wouldn't have thought this man had been near death. Finally, the room was left quiet with only three occupants: one stood and watched; 586 one slept in exhaustive fear, the other in drugged and mercifully painless sleep. Cally, in her subconscious, sensed someone in the room. Her eyes opened, though she couldn't quite place where she was or why. 'She saw the clock—then remembered. And it had been nearly three hours since Glen had been taken to surgery. She panicked, then saw the nurse standing near the bed. "Oh! How is he?" Cally hurried to the bed and felt relief to see that Glen looked all right. "We don't know yet, Mrs. MacMillan. We won't really know for twelve to eighteen hours or more. Everything indicates that the surgery was successful, but we'll have to wait and see." "But what's wrong—where and how badly was he hurt?" "He was apparently hit almost directly. His ribs have been set and will be fine. Our worry is that brain damage might have resulted from the pressure of the blows on the top and side of his head. There may be some paralysis and speech impairment. But he is out of danger, though his condition is listed as_ serious. The doctor said that he should sleep for another four or five hours. So you may go home if you wish and return around seven this evening. You may see him then, though other visitors should be discouraged." The cold efficiency of the nurse's recitation helped Cally to keep the tears under control. She put on her coat and left the room, feeling a little dazed at what she had just been told. When she reached the exit, she realized she had no transportation. She went to the desk and waited for the receptionist to notice her. As she waited, Bishop Dale came down the corridor. "Well, hello Cally. Baby sick?" Apparently he didn't know about Glen. "Oh, bishop, Glen's hurt. The baby's home with Miriam. 1... I...." and Cally fell into his arms and sobbed. He led her to a chair and helped her down. She finally controlled her sobs and tried to wipe her nose with her sleeve. Bishop Dale handed her a handkerchief and sat on the chair next to hers. "Can I help, Cally? Do you need a ride?" "Please—yes. And...." Cally began to have some thoughts she realized she should have had hours earlier. "... Could you— would you administer to Glen?" she almost whispered her request. "Of course, Cally, I'll get another of the brethren and we'll come right up. Come on. I'll take you home." "T can't come back until seven. Could you come then?" Bishop Dale said he could. Cally spent the next long hours at home, waiting. Miriam had taken the baby out, so the house was empty. Too empty. Too quiet. She turned on the radio. The 5:00 news was just finishing, and the weather report was beginning. "It's a beautiful day in Fremont County!" Then click! Cally couldn't stand it. Anyone could see it was raining. The man must not have looked outside. It was a terribly miserable day. At ten minutes before seven, Cally, Bishop Dale, and Brother The Weather Report Arlin met at the hospital.. A call to the hospital that afternoon had cleared the bishop and his companion for a_ short visit. Glen was awake but still under too much sedation to respond to his visitors. The brethren administered to Glen. Cally could feel the Spirit of the Lord present and felt strangely at ease. After they left, she knelt by Glen's bed and offered a tearful prayer of her own. | | ear Father in heaven, please help Glen to recover. Please don't let him be crippled or unable to think. Please restore his health. Thou knowest the love we share—of our efforts to live in accordance with thy will. Please, please remember his faithfulness and bless him with complete recovery. If they be thy will, I pray for these things in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen." Cally continued to kneel and watch Glen, her face close to his. She took his uninjured hand in both of hers. She felt her heart tug as she realized how much she loved him. A nurse opened the door and asked Cally to step outside to see the doctor. Once again she sat in the cramped little office. Afraid of hearing the worst, Cally asked no questions. She waited for the doctor to turn to her. "Mrs. MacMillan," he shuffled some folders on his desk to find the right one, "your husband shows good signs of complete recovery. He's been too heavily sedated to make accurate tests, so we won't really know for awhile. He has about a seventy per cent chance of complete recovery." 587 August 1969 "Doctor," Cally interrupted him before he could go on, "if Glen doesn't recover, will he — uh — well, what will be wrong with him?" Cally's fear was obvious in her voice and face. She twisted the handkerchief in her hands. "Possible brain damage which could impair sight, speech, hearing and, to a limited degree, intelligence. More complete tests can be made after we see how he has responded to surgery. I don't want to raise any false hopes, so I'll just tell you that if he recognizes people and asks or answers questions coherently, then that's a good sign. You may visit him again around ten tomorrow morning. We_ should know by then. Cally waited for further information but apparently the doctor had terminated the interview. The bishop, having remembered that Cally had no transportation, was waiting for her in the lobby. She gratefully accepted a ride. Ten o'clock tomorrow morning and she would know. How does one go about reorganizing one's life overnight? Cally slept fitfully, grateful at least that the baby was still at Miriam's. Bless her, Miriam had offered her car for tomorrow. Friends were surely wonderful. In fear and anxiety, Cally cried herself to sleep. She arrived at the hospital before ten—the morning had gone far too slowly. It was gray and raining again. The radio had been no help either: there was news of wars and rumors of wars and tornados and earthquakes in diverse places. The 588 weatherman was there with his usual "It's a beautiful day in Fremont County!" Cally failed to see the beauty of it. Glen's door was closed, but the nurse told Cally she could go in. The curtains were open, but it was dark in the room, reflecting the weather outside. Cally closed the door behind her; she feared the moments to come, and she wanted to be alone with her husband. How would he be? Glen was asleep, so Cally brought her chair close to the bed and watched him. His breathing was regular and his color good. The sound of the steady drizzle outside made Cally oblivious of passing time as she waited the verdict on the life of her husband. Though not verbalized, a prayer hung in her heart, and she waited. Glen stirred and his eyelids fluttered. His glance darted around the unfamiliar surroundings. Bewilderment showed on his face, and fear gripped at Cally's throat. "Oh, please, God!" she gasped. The sound from Cally drew his attention toward her, and his eyes focused slowly on her face. The world seemed to stand still as Cally waited and hoped that he would recognize her. His eyes closed for a moment, and with some effort he cleared his throat. He was obviously very weak and groggy. Then as he looked at her again, a shadow of a smile crept over his usually jovial face. Cally clutched his hand and tears flooded her eyes. Glen returned the pressure on her hand and tried to speak. "What..." he tried again to clear his throat, hoarse from disuse, and rested a moment with his eyes closed. Cally couldn't breathe in fear and anticipation. His voice finally came to her in a coarse whisper. "What—kind of day is it?" The gloom of the rainy day, the sound of the dismal drizzle, and the rumble of distant thunder penetrated the small hospital room as understanding flooded Cally's mind. She knelt beside his bed in prayerful thanksgiving. "Tt's a beautiful day, Glen," she cried in a choked whisper. "Just beautiful!" She had told me they would laugh at her. It was the biggest event of the year: an all-night party in the canyon on Memorial Day holiday, after the parade and the game and the dance— In the Way They Should Go an important affair, the last big party of the season. Only the very elite of the school were invited. She was the cheerleader. She couldn't miss it—not without looking like a nincompoop. John was going and he wanted her to go. The evening would be chaperoned by Rick Johnson's college brother and his gang of alumni friends in town from State for the summer. My voice was somewhere so far back in my throat that I could not seem to make it audible. "Kim..." She guessed my next words. "Just because Valerie Martin's mother will let her go is no reason that I should go. Is that what you're going to say, Mother?" She looked up toward me. The soft light in the room was strong enough to reveal the shimmering streak of tears across her cheek. "Well, I'm not asking that you let me go because Valerie Martin's mother will let her go. I'm asking that you trust me. I'm asking that you will have faith in me." She leaned close to me. "I'm asking you to respect me as your daughter." There was a brief silent moment that did not seem silent at all, but noisy with the furor of my blood rushing against my brain. "Mother... Can't you trust me? Can't you respect and trust me? Can't you?" I could not speak. "Well, can't you?" I had answered all these questions a hundred times. Now there was a flood of tears. "Mama, I don't think you know what you're doing to me. I'll have to go to that party, Mama. Do you want me to go without your permis- 591 August 1969 sion?" She stood now, her hands wringing. "Kimberly, you wouldn't...." Suddenly I sat up and leaned forward. "Kim, please, I know... I know how important this is to you. I've told you a hundred times. I do trust you. I do trust the young people. It's not them I mistrust, but the situation. We just don't do that kind of thing. It's not..." But my words were a volley of meaningless jargon that grew dim to her ears as she turned and streaked out of the door into the hall, and then into her room. I threw my legs over the side of the bed and sat for a moment staring at the shadows of leaves on the carpet. I could hear the mute, mufHled sobbing from her pillows, and my heart leaped inside my ribs. Could I have been wrong? The indecision of that moment tore my soul into frazzled shreds. What was I doing to her and to myself — if she should decide to go against my decision — my better judgment? What would that mean? For her, for me? In that moment I might have gone to Kimberly, put my arms around her shoulders and told her I was sorry; I was wrong, and she should go to this all-night canyon party. But I could not do it. The tears started again. Somebody understood me. "You've got to live with yourself first," Olga smiled and leaned forward across her salad plate. "The one to fear, Margaret, is not Kimberly, but God. I saw her turn into a flurry of arms and legs when she lost her four-year-old temper at bedtime. I saw her shaking with sobs when I left her with the baby sitter one important evening. There were many times we had come to grips with one another. And each time we had lost a little, yet gained so much more. We had learned that there were some things we must do, or must not do or have, no matter how much our wants or needs were in opposition. And we had learned that each crisis passes. Watson Member, General Board of Relief Society @ Summer picnics can be great fun, whether you and your family take to the canyon, the woods, or the beach, or whether you prefer just to relax and enjoy a cookout in your own back yard. What could be more satisfying on a warm summer day than a delicious thirst-quenching cold drink or a slice of cooled melon? But how to keep the melons and the drinks cold is the question. For this practical purpose, and for aesthetic appeal, as well, the washtub in the picture was painted and decorated. Such colorful tubs, when not in use for keeping foods cold, can serve, also, as containers for special arrangements of flowers and greenery for enhancing the attractiveness of the outdoor rest and recreation area. The project of decorating washtubs proved to be one of the most exciting and rewarding homemaking projects sponsored by the Relief Society sisters of the Parley's Sixth Ward, Salt Lake City, Utah. Even those with no acknowledged creativity found real satisfaction in wielding a paint brush with such delightful results. Originality was the key word. White, black or red paint was used to cover the tubs, with a variety of colors and designs used for trim. Sisters with some artistic talent painted original, free-hand designs, such as the one shown in the picture. The more timid ones used decals, stencils, or tracings. Some sisters even discovered artistic talents they were not aware they possessed. All who participated were amazed with the beauty and utility they had brought to the 598 lowly washtub. Some coal buckets were also painted in a like manner for those who wanted something a little smaller. These were later used at their bazaar as containers for popcorn balls, apples, and the like. EQUIPMENT NEEDED Tub—these can usually be found in hardware stores. Round bottom tubs are easier to handle. Rust inhibiting paint Enamel paint in the color of your choice Additional enamel paints for trimming— small cans of enamel are available in many colors Clear varnish—exterior, interior, or marine 1 or 1%-inch bristie brush Decals or stencils—available variety stores Small artist paint brushes for trimming and designs in' most PAINTING THE TUB Clean the tub thoroughly. Apply an undercoat of rust inhibiting paint on the outside and down about six inches (to the estimated water line of the tub when in use). When dry, apply a good quality enamel paint. White was used on the tub in the accompanying picture, but almost any color would be attractive. Use one coat of enamel, or more, for adequate coverage. Allow to dry thoroughly, then cover the entire exterior of the tub with clear varnish for protection and durability. APPLYING DECORATIVE DESIGNS When the varnish on the outside is thoroughly dry, apply decals, stencils, or free-hand painting. Interesting designs can be found in children's picture books, magazines, or in wallpaper prints. These can be traced and Photo by Dorothy J. Roberts + * Palm nas Baez ey Aythy ae then filled in with paint, or they can be glued to the tub and covered with one or two coats of clear varnish. Fill the decorated tub with favorite drinks, fruit juice, milk, homemade rootbeer, lemonade, or melons. Pack with ice, and a large part of the picnic preparations have been completed. Lemon rind, minced 3 egg whites, beaten stiff YY \ — tem Chapter 3 HEART ROOM FOR HOME Alice Morrey Bailey SYNOPSIS: Rosemary Freemian has stormed out of the living room of their Los Angeles home after a scene about her wedding, planned for the coming June, which she had expected her mother to finance. Her parents, Kim and Mary Ann Freeman, have brought her aged grandfather, convalescing from a broken hip, home to care for him, rather than sell his home in Mayville, Utah, and put him in a nursing home. His home is beloved by all the family. Rosemary's mother must give up her job of teaching in order to take on this new responsibility, and it will cut the family income in two. @® There was nothing for Mary Ann to do but leave, but she was near tears when she came out of Rosemary's room, not only at the rebuff, but at her inability to reach Rosemary and at her own question. Kim came to meet her, to put his arm around her. She avoided him, because it did not seem fair to accept comfort for herself when Rosemary had none. "IT told you not to go in," reminded Tommy. "But she's right. Rosemary's right. What are we going to do for her wedding? Isn't a parent's first duty to the children?" Kim was silent under Mary Ann's rebuff, taking it, she knew, as a criticism of him. "It wasn't that," she said later, and explained to him. "Kim, I'm sorry. I love you very much." "Do you, dear? And I love you. Now don't worry about Rosemary. She has a good mind. Give her Sunday to mull it over." There were responsibilities on Sunday—Rosemary with her Sunday Schoo] class, Tommy with his priesthood class, he and his father off early to priesthood meeting, and Mary Ann playing righthand man to everybody's needs. Neither Tommy nor Rosemary opened the subject, busy 603 August 1969 as they were with their teaching assignments, but reverted to their usual Sunday morning activities. Of course, Mary Ann could not go. "Please make my apologies to the class leader," she said. She was president of the gospel doctrine class. "T wonder how soon I'll be able to go?" asked Father Freeman, looking after the men with longing. "Next Sunday, Dad," assured Mary Ann. "We'll be more organized by then. There's no reason you can't go everywhere with two strong men to lift you and a wheelchair to ride in." "That's good," he said. "Beginning tomorrow I am going to start a definite program of exercises. Pretty soon I'll be able to' walk, and then I won't be such a burden on you." It was useless to assure him he was no burden; he could see otherwise. "Kim will help you with your bath when he comes home," she told him, "while I get dinner on the table. And, Dad, we are very glad to have you with us. The children will all be here for dinner. I hope it will not be too much for you." "Just like it was at home when she was alive," Father Freeman said with satisfaction, "the gathering of the clan." He was immaculate, his snowy hair sparkling, when the first contingent arrived—Jennifer and Dick and their pretty little family, three girls and two scrubbed, freckle-faced little boys. | = | ight on their heels came Cary, demanding to know if they _ had any tall, skinny red-heads 604 around, kissing Rosemary unabashedly before them all. "Tiss me, too, Tary," said Jennifer's youngest, Becky, pursing her little red lips. Cary complied, lifting her high. He was courtly, meeting Rosemary's grandfather. "How do you do, sir? I want to hear about that fabulous home Rosemary has been telling me about. How was your trip?" "Here comes Aunt Barbara and Uncle Hank," piped Dennis. "Now we can eat." Barbara's five children were dark-eyed and_ serious, wellmannered and quiet, in contrast to Jennifer's sandy-red and vociferous brood. It was the usual, happy babble at the elongated table, with a dozen conversations going on, interspersed with requests for food and the admonishings of parents as to manners and spilling. "Grandpa, is my little castle still there?" asked Barbara. "T think," said her grandfather, "that a couple of mountain squirrels have taken up housekeeping, but the walls are unhurt." "Your castle?" echoed Tommy. "T'll have you know I fought the battle of Hastings from that castle, and dubbed every knight of King Arthur's Round Table. The moat was real and the drawbridge actually came down, chiseled out of sheer rock, the whole thing!" "Now, Mr. Freeman," put in Cary. "Everybody knows at last why I'm marrying Rosemary —so I can get to your place and revert to my boyhood for all the things I missed." "Tt'satrap,' said Hank. "That's why I married Barbara, and it didn't work. I never get there." "He's right!" abetted Dick. "Tt was part of the deal that I get to fish in Jennifer's grandfather's pond, but it never came through. She keeps my nose to the grindstone just like Rosemary will yours." "T'll tell you what!" said Rosemary, suddenly excited. "Let's go there for our honeymoon—instead of Hawaii. Would it be all right, Grandfather? Oh, please say yes!" "Certainly," said her grandfather, flushing with pleasure. "Of course you may go there for your honeymoon. I'll ask Victor and Emma to make it ready for 39 you. Mi ary Ann caught her breath and looked at Kim. He was remembering, too. It was to that house Kim had brought Mary Ann proudly to meet his parents in their courting days, the pretty new teacher from the Heber Valley, come to Mayville to teach. "The Marriage Bureau," Kim had laughed. "Never a schoolteacher escapes this town. That's why we have such a high rate of culture here. The mothers are all school marms." It was there he had brought her temporarily as a bride and they had been given the whole upstairs in which to set up their new little housekeeping, Rachel generously contributing everything from bedding to bottled fruit, but never intruding on their privacy. That sweet privacy among the treetops, where they could look from their bedroom window into the nests of birds, Heart Room For Home into the petaled hearts of apple blossoms. The beginning cycles of nature had seemed symbols of their own beginnings, and to this day the songs of early robins reminded her of Kim when he was a slim young man, earnest and blonde, when they were newly in love. That house held the Eden days of their early marriage, and it was a fitting honeymoon house for any young couple, secluded as it was between towns, in the mouth of a canyon, its own little entity, and Rosemary's first suggestion brought cries of appreciation from Barbara and Tommy. "T'd like that," said Cary simply, his eyes shining. "Now you're talking sense, sis," Tommy congratulated. "Be a lot easier on the budget, too, than Hawaii." "When are you planning to be married, Rosemary?" Kim's father asked when the excitement died down. "June the third," said Rosemary. Mary Ann sensed Father Freeman's unease and could see him mulling the date in his mind. By his calculations he would be home long since by the first of June. Spring started for him in April or in May, but he said nothing. Any honeymoon should not include an aged grandfather. "They set it for then, Grandfather, so they wouldn't break into my studies, and I could still make it to the wedding. I should be all through with my requirements by then, to graduate a week later." "Oh! Tommy, that's not true!" protested Rosemary. "We set it for ourselves, didn't we, Cary? 605 August 1969 I always wanted a June wedding." "T don't," said Cary, with proper gallantry. "I wanted it the day I asked Rosemary, or the next day—no later." "Cary!" said Rosemary. "You know we can't be ready until June—all the things I want for my wedding. I have it on a timetable, month by month, day by day. It can't be before June." Wasn't Rosemary going to scale down her wedding, in view of their conversation last night? Mary Ann's eyes sought Kim's. "You will be here for it, won't you, Grandfather? And _ well enough to go with us to the Los Angeles Temple?" "You bet I will, darling," her grandfather assured her, but Mary Ann noticed a false heartiness in his voice, and her heart ached. Kim, always sensitive to her thoughts, noticed it, too. Later that night with the day behind them and the children all dispersed to go to their respective wards when Kim's father was resting, Kim brought it up. "It doesn't seem quite honest of us to not tell Dad he can't possibly get back home by spring, no matter what his condition of recovery. We can't let him go back alone, and we ought not to hold out hope." "T think he's coming to the realization by degrees," said Mary Ann, "and it's better that way. Maybe we can wean him gradually to California living." "T hope so," said Kim without conviction. "I wonder' what Rosemary meant, the things she wants for her wedding. Can't she see that now she will have to plan for less?" "Spring is a long way off," 606 said Mary Ann. "As you say, Kim, we'll just have to play it by ear." "What about tomorrow?" "Barbara will come while I get over to school and talk to the principal." Kim fell asleep easily, but Mary Ann was afraid to sleep too soundly, for fear his father might need something during the night. She awakened feeling tired and apprehensive about breaking her contract. "How does it feel to be leaving for work the last time?" asked Barbara when she came. "T'll tell you later," said Mary Ann as she joined Rosemary in the waiting car, because, of course, Rosemary would have to go on substituting until she was replaced. Just now she felt the loss of her job was cataclysmic. How were they going to go on without her salary? It was Rosemary who opened the tender subject as she drove along the boulevard toward San Gabriel School. "You know, Mother, they paid us Friday. The first real pay check I ever had! It's rather a good feeling." "Rosemary, dear, I'm so sorry about your having to scale down your wedding." "Don't be," said Rosemary serenely. "I don't intend to scale it down. I've been thinking. There's no reason why I can't get a job and earn the things I want myself. Do you think they will let me have your class? Or do they have a backlog of teachers just aching to take over?" "If they had they would certainly not have let you substitute for me in the first place, but we can ask," replied Mary Ann, her spirits rising. "T think part of my reluctance to work was fear that I couldn't do it, but this little interval has given me confidence." This was a new facet of Rosemary, who had always seemed so self-sufficient, if not self-satisfied and somewhat supercilious, even critical of the methods of her mother. "T had no idea!" Mary Ann said now, looking at her daughter with new fondness. "It always seemed you were born knowing how to do everything." "Mother! Is that how I really seem to you? That's how you always appeared to me—capable of anything. I've been thinking it over, since I have this experience— oh, student teaching is so supervised—and I have come to the conclusion I was chipping away at you to bring you down to my level." "Could that be true?" Mary Ann asked. "How honest of you to say so!" Rosemary was noted in the family for her analytical mind. When the car pulled into the parking lot of the school the children of the fourth grade swarmed about it. "Hello, Mrs Freeman," they said respectfully to her, but she was astonished to see the little girls vying for the privilege of ( Heart Room For Home holding Rosemary's hand as they walked to the building, their adoring eyes taking in every detail of Rosemary's pretty, flowered dress and accessories. Rosemary dressed immaculately and daintily, with an eye to color combinations. "You held her hand yesterday. It's my turn today," said one. SZ i ~ Vi reereyl | "Via lap! Yesterday." The little boys turned handsprings, their eyes seeking Rosemary's approval. We weren't here 607 August 1969 "Freddie, how nice you look with your glasses!" Mary Ann complimented. "She got them for me, and now I can see everything on the board," said Freddie, but his shy smile was all for Rosemary. Although this was somewhat of a blow to Mary Ann's ego, it gave her courage to face her principal, something she had dreaded, she found now. A contract was a contract; her rating as a teacher was high, and the school board might rightfully hold her to it. "Well, Mrs. Freeman. This is unusual, but I can see your problem. Needless to say, we will not want to lose you. Breaking your contract is not a matter for me to decide, however, as you probably know, and we will need time for the proper replacement." "My daughter, Rosemary, who is substituting for me, would like to continue in my place," Mary Ann replied diffidently. "Really? Her attitude so far has been that she did not want to teach school. I have watched her with interest, and like her work, but she has let it be known she is not interested in a contract. Unless...." "Why don't you talk to her?" "Tl do that. In the meantime you may fill out these forms for resignation. Perhaps we can send her application in with it, along with my recommendation to the school board. It was astute of her to discover little Freddie Williams' eye trouble and initiate his getting glasses. It is this kind of personal involvement we like in our teachers. I see no reason why she can't continue substituting for you until we hear from the school board on your release at any rate." "T don't know whether to feel relieved or deflated," she told the family at dinner that night. "I think they should have put up a token fight at least to spare my ego. And Rosemary! What did you do to get them eating out of your hand like they do—the children, I mean?" "Nothing, Mother. Maybe it is my pretty clothes, or my red hair. I certainly am strict with them, but I try to be just, and I certainly do love them, every one. Do you think Ill get that class? I really do want it." "T hope so, dear," Mary Ann replied. "Mr. Waverly was most impressed and that's half the battle." A few days later twin letters came from the board of education, one addressed to Mary Ann, a gracious release from her contract "in view of the circumstances," and thanking her for her past high-ranking performance, the other to Rosemary. It was all Mary Ann could do to refrain from opening Rosemary's letter.
