She feels there is a great need for children's literature, which must be of equal literary excellence to the best of adult literature. 661 EDITORIAL / TURN TO THE FATHERS "And he shall plant in the hearts of the children the promises made to the fathers, and the hearts of the children shall turn to their fathers."" (D&C 2:2.) @ A well-loved poem speaks of the enduring influence and the continuing blessings that illuminate the world from the deeds and the words and the faithfulness of the fathers—''... For there was grandeur where the fathers stood."' When the hearts of the children turn to the fathers—whether or not the ''children'' are far beyond childhood—and whether or not the fathers still live upon the earth—there are memories and impressions and abiding direction which the fathers have given. Their strength, their leadership, their unselfish efforts, the blessings of their priesthood, are often vividly recalled. And superimposed upon the children forever from the past are those deep and subtle influences which, over the years, still protect and bless them. One woman still remembers and feels the sunlight and warmth of a summer day when she stood with her father in the doorway of an adobe ranch house, looking northward to a far expanse of wheatfields in a time of harvest. The father said, ''There is your college education.'' The father then remarked that he knew little about the courses of studies offered in the universities, but he had heard that the learning and the development were good, and therefore necessary for his children. They would be sent to a university where spiritual enlightment would be a lamp for the years to come. His words were expressed in a moment of time, but the moment became forever in the memory of the daughter—love and sacrifice and strength and a plan for the future all joined together and made into a lasting commitment. Another woman who was devoted to genealogical research and who found great joy in the patterns of the generations, wrote for her family and for the future families of her children the record of Volume 56 September 1969 Number 9 Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Miitenberger, Acting Secretary-Treasurer i' 662 the fathers back along the years—the decisive events in their lives and the teachings that guided them ''in every wilderness.'' The grandfather, who had lived as a boy in the river city of Nauvoo, had seen almost daily the Prophet Joseph Smith and had heard inspired doctrine and direction ''in the grove.'' The father of this grandfather, in the green hills of Vermont, had seen an early copy of The Book of Mormon, and had read it over and over by candlelight—the history of the long-ago fathers in the Western Hemisphere. From the book he learned much wisdom and instructed his family in the eternal verities of faith and righteousness. Then he told them of his own ancestors in Plymouth, England, and how one of them was captain on ''the ship of destiny'' as he called the Mayflower, the ship that helped to part the waters for a journey to the promised land where the gospel would be restored. The families of the fathers, reaching back into the early centuries, have become known to the families of the people who dwell in the 'fulness of times'' and who look forward to a reunion of those related by the flesh and sealed together by the Spirit. It has been said in olden time and continues to this day ''... They judge not the fatherless'' (Isaiah 1:23), expressing the deprivation and limitations which those bereft in early years of an earthly father encounter. It is then that the written record of the father in his time gives comfort, and all the forebears stand as a legion for the years that one must walk with no visible father to smooth the way and offer protection. The arm of faith, also, is extended to the fatherless upon the earth, and the Father in heaven ''keepeth well' the loved ones, for ''Have we not all one Father? Hath not one God created us?" As women of the Church, blessed with the heritage of our fathers, considering their counsel and the line of their authority, it is now a time for us to rejoice in the ''ordinances of heaven." —V. P. Skidmore 663 IN MEMORIAM Mildred Bennion Eyring May 23, 1896—June 25, 1969 Mildred Bennion Eyring, member of the General Board of Relief Society, passed away June 25, 1969 in Salt Lake City, Utah. Sister Eyring had served on the General Board for nineteen years, being appointed in 1950. While serving on the General Board Sister Eyring endeared herself to thousands of Relief Society sisters throughout the world. She was an excellent speaker, and devoted her talents to the needs of the General Board, giving service to education and other committees _as well as to the work of conferences in the stakes. Sister Eyring was born in Granger, Utah. She was the daughter of Marcus and Lucy Smith Bennion. She married Dr. Henry Eyring, noted educator and physicist, August 25, 1928. They are the parents of three sons. There are six grandchildren. Sister Eyring was educated in the Granite School District in Salt Lake City. She was graduated from the University of Utah, where she headed the physical education department for women. She also did graduate work at the University of Wisconsin where she met her husband. She has been a member of the Sunday School General Board and has served loyally in ward organizations and sung in the choirs. She and her husband taught a Sunday School class which was especially appreciated and had a large attendance. At the time of her call to the General Board of Relief Society she was a counselor in the Monument Park Ward Relief Society. She was always devoted to Relief Society and has attended the meetings regularly, giving spiritual encouragement and the blessings of her inspirational companionship to all the women in the ward. The General Board of Relief Society and members throughout the Church who knew and admired Sister Eyring extend heartfelt sympathy to her loved ones at her passing. Mary Ann has submitted her resignation as a teacher in the grade school. This will cut their income in half at the time of their children Rosemary's wedding, and Tommy's graduation. ® Rosemary was ecstatic when she opened her letter from the board of education. "I got it! I got the class!" she said, racing to kiss her mother, hug her father, and lay her cheek against that of her grandfather, who responded with a squeeze of her other cheek. "I draw the line at you, Tommy," she said, stopping in front of her brother in mock rejection. "This can't be the family clinging vine who only last week still insisted she didn't want to work," jeered Tommy. "Clinging vine! Look who's talking!" accused Rosemary. "I was just waiting for all the chatter to calm down before I told my big news. I accepted the scholarship my dean has been trying to thrust upon me for the last two quarters, on the basis of need." "Ha!" said Rosemary. "What if you hadn't had that to fall back on when Mother withdrew her support? What then?" "I'd have gone out and borrowed the money," replied Tommy calmly. "I didn't know you had a scholarship in the offing," said Kim in surprise. Tommy turned his beautiful, blonde giant look on his father. "I turned: it down so some 665 September 1969 less fortunate fellow could use it, but there were no takers." Mary Ann smothered an ejaculation. It was obvious' she had spoiled her children by rushing to their aid whenever they needed money—Tommy for books and _ tuition, and Rosemary for the lavish wedding she had planned. And Tommy could have had a _ scholarship all along! "What will it pay?" she asked. "Books and tuition and a small stipend, which will pay my gas and date bills," said Tommy. "I could have taken a part-time job, but it would cut me out of my study time, just like too many dates would, so I'm cutting out dating for the duration. Period. It's the nose to the _ grindstone—not that it hasn't been there. Of course, I could have borrowed against my degree and paid it back later with no sweat. There is a student loan fund—forgivable loans, at that." Kim looked at Mary Ann and she read his mind. It was simply too easy for young folks! High time they were thrust onto their own resources! "Congratulations on your new positions," Grandfather Freeman offered in his courtly way. "She would have liked to hear that news." He was referring to his departed wife, of course. "Rosemary can thank you for that new job of hers, Grandpa, and I can thank you for my scholarship." "Oh, no! Not me," replied his grandfather. "You are a very fine scholar to merit a scholarship, and Rosemary earned her position with her own initiative. 666 Helping out that little boy with his glasses—I had nothing to do with it." "Didn't you? Now look, Grandfather. Would either one of them have happened if you hadn't come to live with us? Already three sweeping changes have been made. Mother has quit her job, Rosemary has a position to teach, and I have taken myself off the welfare state— family speaking, that is. To say nothing of my resolve not to fall in love with some girl and get married." "I can hardly wait, Tommy Freeman, for you to begin eating your own words." Tommy ignored Rosemary. "See what an impact you have had already on this family, Grandfather?" "I didn't want—I _ didn't mean...." his grandfather began in great agitation. "Grandpa! This is good. Can't you see how important this is —sociologically speaking—how we all needed you?" "If you say so," his grandfather said uncertainly. "We all say so, Dad," said Kim. "Why, you should have heard the men at the shop today, when I told them I had brought you home to _ stay awhile with us. One of the men said that is exactly what he would like to do with his father, but his wife wouldn't hear of it." "Did you tell him it is only till spring?" asked his father. "I told him you expected to go home in the spring," said Kim evasively.; "Spring?" said Rosemary, suddenly interested. ""What time in the spring? Not before we have our honeymoon in your sweet house? Cary and I. We really do mean it, Grandfather." "Summer," amended her grandfather. "Not until you are through with the place, of course." Neither Rosemary nor Tommy seemed to notice the little slump of despair in their grandfather's shoulders, but their parents did. Mary Ann wished the conversation had _ never taken place. "IT must exercise more," was all Kim's father said. Tommy was right. His grandfather's coming had made an impact on their family. Repercussions were felt almost immediately in the budget department. Kim's check exactly covered the house payment, the utilities, and the food, just as it always had, with a little left over for the upkeep of the car and his Church obligations. There was nothing for the one-hundredand-one items never counted in any budget, and Mary Ann was left immediately without a car—Rosemary drove _ the little car to work, Tommy dropped his father off in the station wagon, and drove on to school. Not that Mary Ann needed a car during the day, as she was tied close with Kim's father. It was the little things —a new pair of stockings, cosmetics, reading matter, medicines, and drugs. Mary Ann_ began planning ways to save in her cooking and sewing. "This is something!" Tommy said appreciatively the first time he came home to find her pulling new-baked bread from the Heart Room For Home oven, and forthwith demolished the better part of a loaf with melted butter, milk, and jam. "When I marry—if I marry— I will pick a wife with all the homey virtues." "I can just see it," chided Rosemary, "healthy and docile, like the women the earlier settlers sent for—home-raised girls." "She was the most beautiful one of them all," remembered Father Freeman. "But she was the best cook, the best seamstress, and she used the best grammar." Mary Ann found time now to do many things at homemaking she had been unable to do as a working woman, to sew some of the material she had been tempted into buying in her more lucrative days. "Mother, I didn't know you were such a wonderful seamstress," Rosemary exclaimed when she modeled her first dress. "How about making some of my trousseau?" Mary Ann was thrilled at this invitation, and they huddled over patterns and materials, while Kim and his father worked at genealogy, a project Kim had long wanted to do. With his father's wonderful memory and tendency to reminisce, he was able to fill in many details hitherto missing, and it was a joy to them both. "You'll have to rest during the day, Dad, and we'll take in some evening sessions at the temple, get some of these names taken care of." "Yd like that," said Kim's father, and redoubled his exercise time in the walker. He refused all help at getting about 667 September 1969 and did his own small errands about the house. By Thanksgiving he was spending much of his time on his feet. Thanksgiving was another "Gathering of the Clan," this time with the boys, Robert and Heidi and their three, James and Carol and their four, present, making a total of twenty-four at the long dining table, which had been augmented by folding sections. The weather was so lovely it was possible to eat on the patio, a novelty to Grandfather Freeman. "That's nothing," assured Kim. "We quite often eat Christmas dinner out here, too, with the poinsettias and the calla lilies bordering the path, all in bloom." His father, later, painstakingly wrote the details of this wonderful dinner to Francine and Emily, and received a contrite note from Francine in return: Dad, I am so ashamed to have wanted you to sell your house and put you in a rest home. I can tell it is wonderful for you there, but we could have managed if you had stayed here. Melanie had her baby the next week after you left, a little girl, and if we had only thought of it, she and her husband could have kept our house and Jack and I could have moved in with you until you were better. Emily was so sure it was right to sell the place, that it seemed right to me at the time. We're taking good care of everything. Absent from her letter was any offerto makesuch an arrangement now, but Mary Ann and Kim were content. It was "working out" as Kim had prophesied, not without adjustment pains. Their course was plainly to make life so pleasant for Kim's father that he would relinquish his 668 desire to return to his home and resign himself to a new way of living. They took him driving and showed him the ocean, seeing it again through his eyes, because he was profoundly moved by the sight of so much water when he had fought to keep the water on his land among the mountains. They took him to Palomar to see the Bethlehem Star show as a prelude to Christmas, and he was excited as a child at the wondrous knowledge and ability of men to reproduce such a point in history. They took him to Marineland, and he was reminded of the beasts at home by the animals of the water. "That whale was as proud of her performance as our race mare, Star. Remember how she arched her neck and _ pranced when she won the race at the county fair?" Kim and Tommy took him to priesthood meeting on Sunday mornings, and he came home appreciative of the gospel and their efforts to get him there. Kim and Mary Ann managed a weekly session at the temple, wheeling him through in his chair and he was nearly overcome with pleasure. It was working out, they told each other, and Kim was appreciative of all Mary Ann's efforts to make it so. As for himself, Kim took on a new air of confidence and authority Mary Ann had missed _ before. As a man who was filling his obligation to his father, Kim felt a glow of happiness, and as the total wage earner he felt new strength as the head of the house. When Mary Ann tried to put it into words in the pnvacy of their room, he said, "I feel different, somehow. I always felt a little ashamed before, as if I was not filling my complete place. It is a man's work to furnish the money, to be the provider. You don't know what it did for me when you said you would be glad to quit work, that you didn't really like your job. It was something I felt all along." This was a wrong premise. Mary Ann had liked her job, and the freedom of her own income, but she kept this reservation to herself in order to preserve this new feeling in Kim. She had to admit it was unpleasant to contemplate consulting Kim on every small purchase, after, of course, taking a close look at the budget. Under the joint pressure of her diminished reserve and the coming of Christmas, wasn't it possible, © even inevitable that she should develop self-pity, come to consider herself the family martyr, the unpaid family servant? It was all right for Kim and the children to feel the new power of their independence and to be in the ascendency, but what about her, now in the descendency of importance? (To be continued) 669 r) Yieas Wail we Jean A. Jensen @ "All roads lead to Rome!" Rome—the Eternal City, Rome —built on seven hills. Rome— the ancient city — the ultramodern city. Rome — the pagan city, the Christian city! Rome —the sculpture center of the world, the adopted city of Michelangelo. We visited Venice, the fabulous city of the merchants which is slowly sinking into the sea, and bustling Naples, before Rome. We were stranded in Naples because of a general railroad strike. An unforgettable memory is the pandemonium of the bus station with peoples of many countries worrying, gesticulating and shouting. We were finally put aboard a chartered bus full of girl students late at night. We all slept fitfully after our strenuous day and, as a street clock struck midnight, we gratefully arrived in Rome and registered to take four comprehensive tours of the city in the next two days. We surely fell into the category of the typical Americans who 670 race through Europe spending only a few days when they should be spending at least a week in each place, or better still, a month. The first thing we recognized was the oldest thing in Rome, there long before Rome was built—the "golden" Tiber River, still serenely winding its way through the city as it has done for centuries. The legendladen Tiber flows like molten gold toward the setting sun. We knew if it could speak it would tell us the history of. Rome. The French once offered to divert its channel so that its depths could be explored for treasures but the authorities of Rome, fearing an increase of malaria from such a_ procedure, would not give their consent. The Aqua Marcia built in 140 B. C. And restored in 1869, brings water from the Sabine Mountains, a distance of about fifty-six miles. Although the water is strongly impregnated with lime, it is pure and excellent. Ay ny The panoramic view of Rome from Pincian Hill helped _ to orient us, and the Borghese Gardens which are now turned over to the city for a public promenade, fascinated us as we saw avenues of white marble busts of the great men of Rome as they stood out against a background of dark pines and cypresses. The Vatican Palace, with over a thousand rooms, was of great interest as we toured its museums, the apartment of Pope Julius the Second, which was designed by Raphael, and a few main galleries filled with art treasures. The Vatican Library, with its 350,000 volumes and 50,000 manuscripts, was impressive. The highlight of the tour was the visit to the Sistine Chapel. I will never forget what they said was Michelangelo's self-portrait as a grotesque bag hanging in the fresco of "The Last Judgment." It depicted his feeling at having to lie on his back on high scaffolds with paint dripping into his eyes for four years in the cold dampness of this chapel, as he painted this masterpiece of a ceiling depicting God, the Twelve Apostles, and other Biblical characters, while he longed to be working as a sculptor with his beloved marble. We learned that the Vatican City has its own separate government and its coins and stamps, so we purchased stamps for cards. The second tour of the day included the summer residence of Cardinal Borghese which is now a museum featuring masterpieces by Bernini. Then we Rome went to Janiculum Hill, the highest of the seven hills of Rome, and saw the great monument, one section of which shows Romulus and Remus being suckled by a she-wolf and we recalled the legend of the origin of Rome, founded 750 years before the birth of Christ. We wandered around in the - ruins of the Roman Forum and the old Roman senate building and remembered that here was the cradle of government and that many laws we have today had their origin amid this group of ancient ruins. It is like a sunken square—holding columns, arches, pedestals, and crumbling walls. We stood in awe as memories of the past swept over us and we realized that we were seeing the spot which for centuries had been the heart of the Roman Empire, the stage on which the great dramas of Roman history were performed—the stabbing to the death of Julius Caesar and the resulting speech by Mark Antony being to us the best known. The great white marble monument to Victor Emmanuel, the Bismarck of Italy, is two hundred feet high. The columns, raised figures, and Victor Emmanuel, unifier of Italy in the center sitting astride a_ horse, fascinated us as did the Venetian Palace which had served as headquarters for Mussolini. We had glimpses of the palaces of Rome or "palazzos" and saw galleries and gardens which have been decorated with the most precious works of antiquity. In spite of great sheets of rain we got out of the bus to see the gorgeous fountain of Trevi 671 September 1969 (of "Three Coins in a Fountain" fame) and threw our pennies into the water and made our wishes. Then, while the rain beat down, we entered the Church of St. Peter in Chains where we saw Michelangelo's great statue of "Moses" and marveled again at the wonder of the figures which Michelangelo could see in a block of marble and release with his skill. The next day we saw the Piazza Navona (Navona Square), an ancient square with an ornate fountain and an obelisk, one of a group brought from Egypt. Then we went into the Pantheon whose porch was built in 27 B. C. The Pantheon, with a dome in the center which lets the rain and sunlight in, dates back to the time of Hadrian in 125 A. D. It contains the first unsupported dome ever built and the model for all domes that have capped public building ever since. One of the most beautiful sights was the Marble Stadium, a stadium surrounded by white marble figures depicting some thirty sports. In the period of Rome's glory it was said that the number of Rome's statues equalled that of her inhabitants. We learned about the ancient wellbuilt sewer system which is still used and the Golden Milestone erected by Augustus, from which distances were reckoned to every province of the Roman Empire, and roads were built which joined them in swift, sure communication. We saw the Arch of Titus, erected to commemorate the conquest of Jerusalem and saw, in imagina- 672 tion, long triumphal processions as they passed under this arch. Now the moment had come when we were to visit St. Peter's basilica, the crowning work of Michelangelo, Antonio Sangallo the younger, Peruzzi Bramante, Raphael, Guido Reni, Domenichino, and many other geniuses. We were instructed not to stray or lose our guide or we could easily become lost in this huge structure. We: kept together as we walked toward the reputed tomb of St. Peter which is directly under the great dome which Michelangelo planned. We were told three ordinary churches, spires and all, could be placed side by side beneath the dome alone, with two hundred feet to spare between the tops of the spires and the keystone of the arch. We drove along the Appian Way and saw many ruined sepulchres. It was the fashionable burial place of ancient Rome and the statues and other treasures have long since _ been stolen. We recalled reading "Quo Vadis" and the visits of Peter and Paul to Rome. It is said that from the Appian Way Paul first gained a view of Rome. We visited one of the fortyfive groups of catacombs along the Appian Way. As we entered into their eerie darkness, there was a priest to light the way with a lamp into some of the maze of labyrinths in which the early Christians had found refuge from their persecutions and had also used as their burial grounds. I was impressed as he pointed out to us the Christian sign of a "fish" carved upon a wall. Cutler Transparencies by the author > ~ ~- Liberty Park, Salt Lake City, Utah, from a painting by John Hafen Swiftly the changing lights reached the level of our top window, where the cutglass prisms were. A cheerful grate fire crackled in the open fireplace and music from our old phonograph played a soft accompaniment. This was the moment I waited for: the hour of sunset when our living rooms glowed and the original oil paintings on the walls were pools of light. Red, blue, and gold shafts of sunlight filtered through the diamond panes. Urgently, I cried, "Mother, come quickly or you will miss it." A voice came from the kitchen, "Just a minute, dear, the pies have to be taken out of the oven first." I ran over to the corner of the room, to change the record on the phonograph,. Hurrying back to the settee. "Hurry, hurry, now, Mother, the lights are on the rocks now." This was the crucial moment because to wait much longer, one would miss the whole show. Soon Mother came running in, apron flying, trailing spicy odors of black-currant pies fresh from the oven. She sat by me, wiping her hands on the towel in her lap, and, together, we watched a miracle of light play on the many original paintings, following one after another with liquid sunshine. From the red rocks on down with the setting sun, blue and gold lights sparkled into the open sea, making it truly a sea of gold. This was my favorite painting, the one of Gunnison Island, Great Salt Lake, in a storm, by Alfred Lambourne, Utah artist and writer, who lived in a little house on this lonely island in certain seasons of the year and painted its many moods. Uncle Fred was mother's brother. She was the heroine "Plet" in his epic tale of the Wasatch Mountains, the year of the big avalanche. 676 Gunnison Island, Great Salt Lake, from a painting by Alfred Lambourne The shadows grew longer now and the colors deepened, "Mother, just look at that gold-dust on the desert!" A large desert oil by John Hafen filled one end of the living room, an authentic scene of covered wagons trailing gold dust at the end of day. The setting sun shone blood-red on the strange sculpture of Monument Valley. We looked with anticipation around the room, as every evening was a different experience, changing with the seasons and weather. In the corner, a small landscape by George Ottinger, a pastel of Liberty Park by Hafen, and on the opposite wall, an oil of my grandfather, John C. Cutler when he was Governor of the State of Utah. As the sunrays reached his eyes, we exclaimed "Doesn't he look as if he could speak to us?" We watched with awe as his blue eyes sparkled and smiled a little. Imagination can run riot at such times, later to become inspiration for expression or just priceless memories. - A few moments now and it would be all over; the red sun dropped quickly behind the dark filigree of trees in front of our home. The soft wind blowing the lace curtains seemed like a whispered goodnight. Little did I realize the same principle would apply in later years to my own paintings in my little home. Vivid memories return as I frequently walk through the modern galleries and museums of San Francisco and experience the avant-garde art of psychedelic light. It seems as if a stage had been set for the art of tomorrow. Through centuries of painting, true artists worked endlessly, seeking the mystical quality of light. One of the great masters, William Turner (1775-1851) became fa- 677 mous for his insight and genius in depicting pure light. As one views his retrospective exhibition in the Tate Gallery, London, the impact of an inner light on one after another of his great works (filling three galleries) was like an unknown spiritual source. The French Impressionists later attained light more than any other school and will live forever. The early Utah painter, Lee Greene Richards studied this school of painting in Europe and was greatly influenced by it. One day Mother took me to his studio to show him my first little watercolors. It was a beautiful studio with windows facing South Temple and a real skylight. He showed me his fine paintings. (Continued on page 692) 678 Look to November from a painting by Grayce E. Roberts A BENCH FOR THE HALL Recently, my husband built a dining-library room on our house leaving our hall, which had previously been filled with books, looking empty and colorless. As our hall is small we decided on the amount of space we could devote to a bench without interfering with the passageway. We then cut a pine board that size and stained it walnut. We stapled on a piece of foam in the middle of the board, being sure to tuck the top edge of the foam underneath to give it a tufted look. Then it was covered with upholstery material and tacked down with brass upholstery tacks. Painting chains black to match our black wrought iron rails on our stairs, we fastened them to the stubs in the wall and to the front of the board. Underneath the board small braces were attached so that the bench was serviceable as well as attractive. This stayed within our budget, costing $6. THE ANIMALS ENTER THE ARK Model, Marguerite Mower Covering another piece of masonite with burlap, we made a background with a felt ark for Noah, his wife, and stuffed animals that were sold at a Relief Society bazaar. The animals were so attractive, I wanted to show them off, yet at the same time allow the children to play with them. I sewed a large snap on each animal and small holes were drilled through the masonite for wiring on the counterpart of the snap, allowing for the animals to be played with and then snapped back on the picture. The white dove is beautiful on blue burlap sky, and the orange and yellow ark seems ready for its long voyage upon the waters; the striped zebra, the bearded lion, the pink pig, the mottled snakes, in curves of grandeur, a blue elephant and a pink elephant, and the wooly sheep, with the flapping ears, seem real enough to enter into the ark and make a safe return trip without being lost. Our own handicraft has given us pleasure in the planning and the doing and now offers continued enjoyment for the whole family. 680 Models, Megan and Michael Mower RHYMES AND STORIES AND CASTLES My mother read to my sisters and me from a lovely old nursery rhyme book. When I began reading to my children from this same book the pages were worn and beginning to tear. Loving the characters from the book and wanting my children to enjoy them as I had, I made a picture of these characters drawing them on paper and then cutting them out of felt. My husband covered a masonite board with burlap on which the felt pictures had been sewed. Among the colorful characters which now appear in the picture, which occupies a place of interest on the nursery wall, are Simple Simon, the Old Woman Who Lived in a Shoe, Mistress Mary, Wee Willie Winkle, and others of the cherished people loved by generations of children. They are now giving continued pleasure to Megan, Michael, and Marguerite who greet their storybook friends each day, and sometimes tell them goodnight. i La co. A la te u eal an ~ee The Hawaiian booth was a delight—colorful and inviting. A Bazaar Designed Especially for Children Helen M. Dall, President, Kearns North Stake Relief Society Karen Sorensen, President, Seventeenth Ward Relief Society ® Our whole Bazaar was especially focused on items of interest for children and this plan turned out to be a great success. A special booth was prepared to illustrate helps for Family Home Evening. Assignment charts, flannel boards, plaques, lap boards, and activity sheets were prepared. Items for children were attractively displayed. The items for sale in the varous displays were all donated. Sister Sharon Seamons was chairman. She had made up a sample item and then assigned several sisters to make the desired number of each item. Over thirty sisters were involved in one single booth, and all seemed willing to help. Roberts MATERIALS NEEDED Scraps of cotton material (printed, plaid, or plain) Nylon or wool yarn Large darning needle Melted canning wax Ice tongs A pattern may be made by marking a circle with a saucer (about six inches in diameter). A bowl or drinking glass (about 3 inches in diameter) can be used for the smaller inner circle. Cut the material from the larger circle and mark the smaller circle. With adhesive tape, glue, or a stapler, attach a double strand of yarn across the middle from edge to edge of the smaller circle, leaving about an inch excess for attaching the handle. Stitch around the inner circle two rows about an inch apart, drawing the circle up to resemble a cup. Breinholt, Chairman, Department of Art Brigham Young University For use with Cultural Refinement Lesson 5—The Necessity of Service Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 John Everett Millais was a precocious child. He was recognized as having great talent at age four. At seven he was drawing amazing likenesses of family and friends. At eleven he was accepted into the Royal Academy as its youngest student and was later elected to membership. Early in his career as an artist he and several friends formed a group known s Pre-Raphaelites, who set principles of painting somewhat contrary to the accepted manner of painting of the time. They believed art should be based upon and be true to nature and represent sincere expression of sincere beliefs and adhere to the gospel of thoroughness. As a result, Millais' work was full was most condemned. One said, "We must protest against sweet, lollipop colours, Taw green fields, and lace-up boots ostentatiously large." In Millais' time, he was a revolutionist and it is chiefly because of his revolutionary works that he lives today. Most creative people seem to have a certain driving force which might be termed a "feeling of destiny"—a conviction that what they are seeking is of worth and importance and they must "get on" with it, which in itself is a service to those who follow. They seem converted to the "rightness" of what they are doing. Perhaps this is what gives the artist direction and a tenacity in spite of obstacles and criticism from others. Anyone out in the forefront runs the risk of being misunderstood. This was true of Millais. If we were to judge his works by present trends in art, he might be considered very conservative, yet during his day he was a revolutionary. "The Blind Girl" is not difficult to understand. It could be said to be true to nature with an obvious message. Try asking a group of people of any age to look at the painting and tell the story. Abstract the story into one word and see how often it will be "service." 689 "SUNDAY AFTERNOON ON THE ISLAND OF LA GRANDE JATTE" by Georges Seurat (1859-1891) French - Courtesy of the Art Institute of Chicago Painting on page 687 Commentary by Floyd E. Breinholt, Chairman, Department of Art Brigham Young University For use with Cultural Refinement Lesson 6—The Power of Work Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting, April 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 When families are united in their work and play, work becomes more meaningful and leisure more enjoyable. A casual observer might say that this painting "La Grande Jatte" by Georges Seurat illustrates-a popular leisure-time activity—strolling in the park. However, as one looks and reflects, he may find that there is much more to it than that. The reality of the subject has been subjected to stringent refining—not necessarily to improve it—but in order to yield its essence. The unessentials have been dropped away leaving only images of incisive clarity. A heat haze blurs the detail and gives a static quality. One feels as if he had captured a moment suspended in time, in which order reigns. Georges Seurat lived at the time Impressionism was at its height. However, he believed that this system of painting was too haphazard, so he developed a systematic method of painting, which was highly intellectual, methodical, and almost scientific in approach. He carefully organized the space on his canvas by using horizontal, vertical, and diagonal lines in perfect balance. Then with careful, almost artificial, precision, he placed the confetti-like, round spots of color next to each other, until his canvas was covered in such a way that the colors, being mixed in the eye of the observer, give a sensation of shimmering vibrancy. He called this method Divisionism. Others have called it Pointillism. This painting was first shown in 1886, and it marked the painter's arrival at a maturity in the use of the method he invented. His departure from the established way of painting, and from the Impressionism of his time, opened the way for later, so-called "Modern" art. Seurat must have worked hard to accomplish what he did at such an early age. (He died at the age of 32.) And, as is the case with many highly creative people, he found his recreation in his work. He said, "Art is harmony—harmony comes from placing, side-by-side, contrasting elements and similar elements in tone, in color, and in line." 690 ROME (Continued from page 672) The last thing on our tours was the ruin of the Colosseum which held 50,000 people. Near the arena there used to be a marble platform with marble thrones for the vestals, senators, and other dignitaries. Above this platform was the emperor's throne under a canopy. The ancient heated baths were the social centers of Rome and there were shops surrounding them for every purpose to please men and women. The Baths were the meeting places of literary men, where lectures were delivered, poems read, and philosophical themes debated. Athletes gave exhibitions there of their skill and strength, musicians showed their talents, and every form of physical improvement was taught. It was cal- © culated that 62,000 people could have bathed at any hour in the public baths in Rome. Many noted works of art were in these areas. We saw the famous "Spanish Steps" before we left and a street with magnolia trees on either side just about to bloom. We learned that Rome is a little farther north than the city of New York, and we reluctantly left the magnificence of this amazing city and hoped that some day our road would lead us back to Rome. He hesitated and, even at that early age, I caught the struggle of an artist's life especially in an isolated community. I did not heed his advice, as the urge to express in paint, plus early exposure to good art, held me forever. My most precious recollections were in Alfred Lambourne's modest studio on North Main Street, where I sat in the bay window on some rainy days and listened breathlessly to his true tales of pioneer days and the lonely beauty of the plains as the pioneers made their tortuous trail to this unknown land. He was a mystic and poet, as was his pioneer father, John Lambourne, and his descriptions of his research into space, the stars and the "music of the spheres" he had actually heard, held me spellbound. He instinctively knew about matters not of this earth, and was host to celebrities and Eastern men of thought in his modest studio—all seeking, as man will seek forever, his own destiny; as Paul Gauguin asked in one of his famous last paintings, "Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?" I am grateful indeed to my parents and the circumstances surrounding the unique cultural life of this then-isolated community in the mountains, on the edge of the desert and the inland sea. If one does not have the advantages of being surrounded with artists in his own family, there is a renaissance of art the world over and good art is available in city galleries and even in small communities. Traveling exhibits, art schools, and art books are plentiful where one can learn and discern a good work of art and truly determine what he likes when the time comes to add a painting or a piece of sculpture to his valued possessions. If I could be given a wish for beauty and contentment, I would choose a good work of art to live by. But the shine was soon gone when a handful of sand lit on her head and sifted through the golden curls. Angie looked around to find who had thrown the sand. Standing behind her were three Japanese children about her own age. Their dark slanted eyes looked strange to her. Angie hadn't seen anyone with eyes like theirs back in Salt Lake City where she used to live. The children's ebony hair hung straight down and was chopped off right below their ears. "Hi! What's your name?" chirped five-year-old Angie, who was happy to see someone to play with. The Japanese children didn't answer but stepped into Angie's sandbox and began sifting the sand through their fingers. The three started talking to one another with sounds that Angie couldn't understand. 694 THE UNIVERSAL LANGUAGE Ardean T. Loertscher "Tl get you some buckets," declared Angie, as she jumped up and ran into the garage. In a few seconds she reappeared with an armful of brightly colored tin buckets and shovels, and some tablespoons she had borrowed from the kitchen. The Japanese children grinned and giggled as they each received their allotted playthings from Angie. One little girl, whom the others called Keiko, tenderly caressed Angie's bare white legs which emerged from the ruffled bottom of her pink sunsuit. The girl seemed to marvel at the skin that was at least two shades lighter than her own. Large mountains and valleys began to take form in the sand pile as the foursome repeatedly filled and emptied their buckets. Aminiature car was buried and uncovered. Ribbons of roads, made by tractors, steam shovels, and trucks, wound around the mountains and through the valleys. "Let's make a farm," cried Angie. "My uncle has a farm. I'll go get some cows." The screen door banged behind her as she skipped into the house. She was greeted with "ohs" and "ahs" when she returned with a plastic bag full of horses, cows, chickens, ducks, pigs, sheep, dogs, and cats. The girl named Keiko fingered a cow and repeated a strange word Angie couldn't understand. "No, it's a cow," Angie corrected. But Keiko continued to say the strange word. Not being able to quite understand what this meant, Angie decided to build a field for the cows. She ran to the tall maple tree which stood at the end of the long back yard. There she picked up dry twigs and sticks. When she had all her chubby hands could carry, she returned to the sand pile. One by one, she pushed the ends of the sticks into the sand next to each other. Her three playmates joined her in the task, and soon an area about a foot in diameter was encircled by the fence. "The ducks need a pond to swim in," declared Angie as she ran for the sprinkler hose. She tugged the hose to the sand pile and carefully placed it in a ravine. Back she ran to the water tap on the side of the house. FIRST DAY OF The Universal Language As the water came on full force, the end of the hose flipped up, drenching the make-believe land in an unexpected shower. The three Japanese friends were also caught in the sudden sprinkle, but screams of delight and laughter escaped their mouths as the water cooled their skin. Just then the sound of a car in the driveway drew their attention. "That's my Daddy," revealed Angie. '"He's a mission president." Angie ran to greet the tall man 'who stepped out of the car. "Daddy, comelook at my farm," she coaxed. "My! You're a dirty, wet girl! You better come in the house and get cleaned up for dinner," replied her father. "Who were your friends in the sand pile?" her father asked when they reached the bathroom. "T don't know their names," Angie replied. "Can you understand them?" he asked. "No, they talk funny," she declared rather puzzled. "Isn't it hard to play if you can't understand them?" he continued. Angie's face darkened for an instant, but ht right back up again as she replied: "But Daddy, we all laugh the same." Doxey Lesson 99— Government and Laws (Reading Assignment: Doctrine and Covenants, Section 134) Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, December 1969 Southern Hemisphere: May 1970 OBJECTIVE: The Latter-day Saint woman seeks to uphold the law and work within the law in seeking any desired change. INTRODUCTION Latter-day Saints are known as loyal citizens of the countries in which they live. About eighteen months after The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints was organized, the Lord commanded his people not to break the law of the land, for if they kept the laws of God there would be no reason for breaking the laws of the land. (D&C 58:21-22.) Before this time, instructions were given to the authorities of the Church that in cases of infractions of the moral law, the guilty should be delivered up to the law of the land. (D&C 42: 84-87.) Later, in two revelations, the saints came to know that the Constitution of the United States was an inspired document and that they should uphold it. (D&C 98:4-7; 101: 76-80.) 704 PROPHECY FULFILLED An incident in American political history involving the Prophet Joseph Smith and Stephen A. Douglas, a political figure, emphasized the point that the Lord respects his people when they conform to his laws and to the laws of the land. The prophecy also affirms the truth that Joseph Smith enjoyed the _ prophetic gift. (B. H. Roberts, New Witnesses for God, Vol. 1, pp. 304- 13.) On May 18, 1843, the Prophet gave the following prophecy to and about Stephen A. Douglas, a little known judge in Illinois at that time: Judge, you will aspire to the Presidency of the United States; and if you ever turn your hand against me or the Latter-day Saints, you will feel the weight of the hand of the Almighty upon you; and you will live to see and know that I have testified the truth to you; for the conversation of this day will stick to you through life. (/bid., p. 305.) By 1857 Judge Douglas, United States Senator from the State of Illinois and then aspirant to the presidency of the United States, delivered a speech in which he alleged that the Mormons in Utah Territory were disloyal to the federal government and that they incited Indian tribes against that government. He then referred to the saints as a "pestiferous, disgusting cancer which is gnawing into the very vitals of the body politic. It must be cut out by the roots, and seared over by' the red hot iron of stern and unflinching law." (Ibid., p. 308.) Although Senator Douglas knew the Latter-day Saint people as a law-abiding people and knew about their persecutions in Missouri, he disregarded the voice of prophecy and, in the presidential election of 1860, was defeated by the Republican candidate,. Abraham Lincoln. DOCTRINE AND COVENANTS—1835 When the Church sought to print a compilation of the revelations received by Joseph Smith by 1833, a mob destroyed the - printing press and_ practically all of the printed material. (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints, Vol. 1, p. 390 [called Documentary History of the Church, hereafter referred to as. DHC].) Consequently, the Book of Commandments was never available to the members of the Church, except for a very few copies. Lesson Department On August 17, 1839, a general assembly of the Church met to agree on publishing a second compilation to be known as the Doctrine and Covenants. The priesthood members _present testified to the truth of the revelations. Oliver Cowdery read an article entitled "Governments and. Laws in General." The article was approved and ordered printed in the volume. (DHC, Vol. 2, pp. 243-47.) In order to present the truth concerning the Church's belief about law, because of accusations that it did not uphold the law, it was felt necessary to prepare this article. "QUR OPINION" It was printed in the 1835 edition of the Doctrine and Covenants and appears as Section 134 in the current edition. The following preamble to the article is not a part of Section 134: That our belief with regard to earthly governments and laws in general may not be misinterpreted nor misunderstood, we have thought proper to present at the close of this volume our opinion concerning the same. (D&C 134 introduction.) This article is an "opinion" and not a revelation, and therefore "does not hold the same place in the doctrines of the Church as do the revelations." (Hyrum M. Smith and Janne M. Sjodahl, Doctrine and Covenants Commentary, 1965, p. 852.) On the other hand, Section 134 was presented to the Church assembled in 1835 and several times since that year as binding upon the members of the Church. 705 September 1969 The laws that now govern the nations of the earth will be supplanted by laws instituted by the Savior when he takes his place to reign as King of kings. (Ibid., pp. 204-05; D&C 38:21-22.) GOD-ORDAINED GOVERNMENTS The Lord raised up men to formulate the Constitution of the United States that principles of freedom might be exercised in this promised land. Only in this kind of political climate could The Church of Jesus Christ be established in the last days. The land of America was kept hid from the nations that this land might indeed be a place where divine prophecies might be fulfilled. (Ezra Taft Benson, Conference Report, October 1961, p. 69.) The perfect form of government was instituted in the days of Adam, but later the sons of men rebelled against these principles of righteousness. (Moses 5:12-13.) Although Section 134 suggests that governments were instituted for the benefit of men, it is evident that all governments are not in this category. (D&C 134:1.) The Lord does not originate laws contrary to eternal principles such as free agency. As Elder Erastus Snow said, all forms of government are bettern than none at all in that order is maintained by governments though some of them may not be the best forms. (Journal of Discourses, Vol. 22, p. 151.) Nonetheless, God controls the nations though he is not the originator of those governments. (Brigham Young, 706 6, p. 342.) of Discourses, STANDARD OF JUDGMENT The governments set up by men serve a purpose in the eternal plan by requiring men to govern their lives according to law. (D&C 76:111; 134:1.) The Prophet Joseph Smith said: He [God] will award judgment or mercy to all nations according to their several deserts, their means of obtaining intelligence, the laws by which they are governed, the facilities afforded them of obtaining correct information, and His inscrutable designs in relation to the human family.... (DHC, Vol. 4, p. 596.) This statement is recognized to be true when one realizes that God is the author of righteousness and that, woven in the various laws of the nations, there are laws which are also found in the gospel of Jesus Christ. (Stephen L Richards, Conference Report, October 1923, p. 47.) Also, there are many laws which are contrary to righteous principles. The framers of laws and governments are held accountable for their acts in relation to them, both in making and in administering them. (Smith and Sjodahl, Doctrine and Covenants Commentary, 1965, pp. 852-53; D&C 134:1, 6.) SECTION 134 By 1835, when Section 134 of the Doctrine and Covenants was prepared, the saints had suffered persecution, loss of property and lives, and their freedom of religious belief had Journal Vol. been challenged. It is understandable why they would want their own beliefs concerning law and governments made known. This section might be divided into the following parts: (1) basic rights, (2) governments and officials, (3) religious societies and beliefs, and (4) noninterference in the rights of others. BASIC RIGHTS After the statement that men are accountable to the governments under which they live, man's fundamental rights are stated in these words: We believe that no government can exist in peace, except such laws are framed and held inviolate as will secure to each individual the free exercise of conscience, the right and _ control of property and the protection - of life. (D&C 134:2.) President David O. McKay has called attention to the fact that "there is innate in man a feeling that will rebel against tyranny." (Deseret News, Church Section, January 2, 1952, p. 3.) Men have come up from oppression to overthrow coercive governments. The Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States are examples of the declared rights of men and the protection afforded. Where there is an infringement of these basic rights, the following belief is expressed: We believe that men should appeal to the civil law for redress of all wrongs and grievances, where personal abuse is inflicted or the right of property or character infringed, where such laws exist as will protect the same; but we believe that all men are justified in defending themselves, their friends, and Lesson Department property, and the government, from the unlawful assaults and encroachments of all persons in times of exigency, where immediate appeal cannot be made to the laws, and relief afforded. (D&C 134: 11.) Class Discussion Under _ today's conditions, what can we do to help preserve the three basic rights mentioned in D&C 134:2? GOVERNMENTS AND OFFICIALS Latter-day Saints during this dispensation, and especially during the time of Joseph Smith, have had many unfortunate experiences with government officials who had not upheld the constitutional rights of the saints. The following verse points out the obligation of civil magistrates upholding the law of the land in their decisions: We believe that all governments necessarily require civil officers and magistrates to enforce the laws of the same; and that such as will administer the law in equity and justice should be sought for and upheld by the voice of the people if a republic, or the will of the sovereign. We believe that all men are bound to sustain and uphold the respective governments in which they reside, while protected in their inherent and inalienable rights by the laws of such governments; and that sedition and rebellion are unbecoming every citizen thus protected, and should be punished accordingly; and that all governments have a right to enact such laws as in their own judgments are best calculated to secure the public interest; at the same time, however, holding sacred the freedom of conscience. (D&C 134:3, 5.) In an earlier revelation the saints were counseled to uphold wise and honest men in public office; otherwise, evil would result. (D&C 92:8-10.) It may not 707 September 1969 always be possible to determine between the wise and the unwise, but the Lord has given some standards by which to make decisions about principles' or political issues. Laws which deny men their agency (D&C 98:4-8) and those which permit them to do evil should be changed. (Moro. 7:14-19.) Class Discussion What measures should a people take to insure that their liberties are held inviolate? The history of the Church provides the answer. Despite the plunderings, mobbings, acts of rapine, and loss of property and lives, the saints followed the counsel expressed in D&C 134:11. By divine commandment the Prophet Joseph Smith appealed to the President of the United States and the Congress for redress of crimes committed against them in Missouri. (D&C 101: 81-95; Joseph Fielding Smith, Essentials in Church History, pp. 287-94.) One is reminded that the Lord counseled his saints who had been driven from Jackson County, Missouri, in 1833 and 1834 that they were not to fight for the redemption of Zion, but that he would, in his time, fight their battles. (D&C 105:14-15.) BREAKERS OF THE LAW Those who break the law should be punished according to the seriousness of the offense. Governments have the right to regulate their societies for the preservation of peace and order. Latter-day Saints are enjoined to bring offenders against the law to justice. (D&C 134:8.) They should also sustain the 708 law enforcement arms of government that all might have justice. Class Discussion Do we as Latter-day Saint women by example encourage our children to uphold the duly appointed officers of the law? RELIGIOUS SOCIETIES AND BELIEFS Eleven years after Section 134 was written, the Prophet Joseph Smith wrote the Articles of Faith. The eleventh article is as follows: "We claim the privilege of worshiping Almighty God according to the dictates of our own conscience, and allow all men the same privilege, let them worship how, where, or what they may." This same statement of belief lies at the basis of what is contained in verse 4 of Section 134. The privilege of religious worship is the right of every man, provided it does not infringe upon the rights and liberties of others. Equally so, Latter-day Saints believe that government does not have the right to prescribe rules of worship, nor dictate forms for public or private devotion. (D&C 134:4, 7.) There should not be favoritism shown for one religion over another. (D&C 134:9.) The following principles were given by the First Presidency of the Church: We declare that from principle and policy, we favor: The absolute separation of church and state; No domination of the state by the church; No church interference with the functions of the state; No state interference with the functions of the church, or with the free exercise of religion; The absolute freedom of the individual from the domination of ecclesiastical authority in political affairs; The equality of all churches before the law. ("An address, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to the World," Conference Report, April 1907, p. 14.) EXCOMMUNICATION AND DISFELLOWSHIP The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints maintains that religious societies have the right to deal with their members for disorderly conduct, but the punishment should not extend to taking their property or jeopardizing their lives. The penalties for misconduct in the Church are excommunication and disfellowship. (D&C 134:10.) To be disfellowshiped means that the person remains a member of the Church, but he is limited in what he may do. He may attend meetings, but he may not participate in the activities of the Church. Excommunication removes one from the records of the Church and thus he loses all of the privileges of Church membership. There are three offenses for which one may be punished: (1) the breaking of the moral law, (2) deliberate disobedience to _ the regulations of the Church, and (3) incorrect interpretation of doctrine when the correct teachings have been explained and the person is unwilling to accept them. (John A. Widtsoe, Priesthood and Church Government, 1954, p. 209.). IMPLEMENTATION Not long after The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Lesson Department was organized, a conference of the Church adopted a set of principles regarding governments and Laws in general. (D&C 134.) Since then the members of the Church have accepted these beliefs as binding upon themselves. To indicate the consistency and application of that early document to the present, the following statement from President David O. McKay is given:. I repeat that no greater immediate responsibility rests upon members of the Church, upon all citizens of the Republic and of neighboring Republics than to protect the freedom vouchsafed by the Constitution of the United States. Let us, by exercising our privileges under the Constitution— (1) Preserve our right to worship God according to the dictates of our conscience, (2) Preserve the right to work when and where we choose. No free man should be compelled to pay tribute in order to realize this God-given privilege. Read in the Doctrine and Covenants this statement: "... It is not right that any man should be in bondage one to another." (D&C 101:79.) (3) Feel free to plan and to reap without the handicap of bureaucratic interference. (4) Devote our time, means, and life if necessary, to hold inviolate those laws which will secure to each individual the free exercise of conscience, the right and control of property, and the protection of life. To sum up this whole question: In these days of uncertainty and unrest, liberty-loving people's greatest responsibility and paramount duty is to preserve and proclaim the freedom of the individual, his relationship to Deity, and... The necessity of obedience to the principles of the gospel of Jesus Christ—only thus will mankind find peace and happiness. (Conference Report, April 1950, p. 37.) 709 r VISITING TEACHER MESSAGE — Truths to Live By (Correlated With the Family Home Evening Manual, 1968-69) Message 3—The Compassion of Jesus Alice Colton Smith Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, December 1969 Southern Hemisphere: May 1970 OBJECTIVE: To emphasize that Jesus' compassionate acts are a standard for us all.... Benjamin Franklin, the well-known exponent of common sense in all practical affairs, made the following comment: "Think what you do when you run into debt; you give to another power over your liberty." Our Church leaders have had no hesitancy in admonishing us to keep out of debt. Following are some of their instructions: The Prophet Joseph Smith: Let thy hand never fail to hand out that thou owest while it is yet within thy grasp to do so.... (Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, p. 317.) President Brigham Young:. Be prompt in everything, and especially to pay your debts. (Brigham Young, Journal of Discourses, Vol. 14, p. 279 [hereafter referred to as JD].) Also: It is an old saying that a woman can throw out of the window with a spoon as fast as a man can throw into the door with a shovel; but a good housekeeper will be saving and economical, and teach her children to be good housekeepers, and how to take care of everything that is put in their charge... (JD, Vol. 12, p. 195.) President John Taylor: We are told to pay our debts... To keep out of debt and meet our obligations day by day. (JD, Vol. 20, p. 103.) President Joseph F. Smith: "Get out of debt now... And let your income hereafter always be greater than your expenses." That is the only safe way to be independent... The advice of Benjamin Franklin should ever stand clearly before you: "Pay as you go." (The Improvement Era, Nov. 1938, pp. 668, 673.) President George Albert Smith: We have been taught by those whom the Lord has raised up to instruct. Us 712 that we should live within our income, that we should not spend as rapidly, and certainly not more rapidly, than we can earn the money that comes into our hands, to take care of ourselves and our families. (Church News, August 8, 1959, p. 2.) A THREAT TO FAMILY HAPPINESS AND SOLIDARITY It is common knowledge that more family problems and difficulties stem from the mismanagement of financial affairs than from any other source. In an address given during the 136th Semi-Annual General Conference, John H. Vandenberg, the Presiding Bishop of the Church, said: Unwarrantable indebtedness is one of the curses of this day and age. It causes many people to live their lives in bondage. The lure of buying on time under the ''easy payment plan" too often puts the millstone around the neck of the purchaser; and when once in the credit rut, it is very hard to get out... When a family finds itself too far in debt, the atmosphere of discouragement enters the home, relationships become tense, tempers become short, and marital trouble begins to erupt. To meet the indebtedness, the mother may frequently leave her children to themselves while she finds employment out of the home. Irregularities in the home follow: service to God is disregarded, tithing is neglected, prayers become less frequent, persons begin to feel separated and apart from God and church.... (Conference Report, Oct. 1966, p. 66.) WHY DO WE GO IN DEBT? The most common reasons for serious financial problems which result in family indebtedness are: 1. Lack of careful and adequate planning. A. Careless, unplanned day-to-day spending. 2. Spending in excess of the income. 3. Failure to establish future, long-range goals. A. No reserves for future expenditures. B. Lack of incentive as a curb to spending. 4. Emotional immaturity—lack of selfdiscipline. A. Allowing wants to take precedence over needs. B. Buying impulsively and heedlessly. C. Demanding unwarranted luxuries. 5. Too much installment buying. 6. Overuse of credit cards. 7. Unexpected illness requiring hospital and doctor care. 8. Loss of employment. HOW CAN WE AVOID DEBT? 1. We can avoid going into debt by first eliminating whenever possible the foregoing reasons for it. 2. We should become informed in regard to wise buying and spending. (Consult previous "Homemaking" discussion.) 3. We should avoid so-called easy credit plans. Lesson Department 4. We should make sure that credit cards are used only when they fit into our planned spending. CONCLUSION We, the homemakers, are responsible to a large degree for the expenditure of the family funds. When we mismanage our financial affairs and allow ourselves to go into debt, we place upon the balance wheel on one side the unjustified fulfillment of immediate wants and _ desires and on the other side the peace of mind of our husbands and the happiness of the entire family. By following the advice of our leaders and by planning with our family members a wise program of spending and saving, we can avoid financial problems that could end in debt and disaster. SOCIAL RELATIONS—Immortality and Eternal Life Lesson 3—The Upward Reach Alberta H. Christensen (Reference: Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, Selections from the Writings and Messages of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Melchizedek Priesthood Course of Study, 1969-70, Lessons 20 and 22.) Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, December 1969 Southern: Hemisphere: May 1970 OBJECTIVE: To illustrate that all may enjoy man's material progress but our spiritual achievements must be individually attained. INTRODUCTION ce a man's reach should exceed his grasp, Or what's a heaven for?" wrote Robert Browning in "Andrea del Sarto." This idea—the reach of man for that which is beyond his present grasp, the goal yet to be obtained—is central to this lesson. Nothing identifies with the 713 September 1969 inherent upward reach of man as does the gospel of Jesus Christ. It is the cause of his being earthborn, it is the road by which he may ascend higher and _ higher through endless time. Whether he accepts all of its divine principles or not, he is the recipient of the essential blessing of immortality that gives him opportunity for his endless upward reach. This lesson, which will be used in December in the Northern Hemisphere, will discuss (1) our efforts to triumph over the limitations of the physical laws that we encounter in everyday living and (2) our inherent desire to go beyond our present toward a higher spiritual self. It will speak briefly of Christmas as an occasion for motivating love, compassion, and charity for others. It will use a long excerpt from an impressive writing by President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. Entitled "The Upward Reach" and statements from other Melchizedek Priesthood course of study lessons, as indicated. THE UPWARD REACH This lesson primarily is one of relationships—of relationships one to another and of our individual relationship to our Heavenly Father, for man does not walk alone as he reaches out from himself and upward through life experiences. Class Participation—Questions and Discussion Statements 1. What does the phrase "upward reach of man" suggest to you? 2. How does this affect you individually? 3. If it means that you individually are reaching toward a goal that is 714 higher than your present state, then the important thing is that the moving be upward toward that goal. 4. It means that you are not a finished product today, and since you are not, how should this affect your attitude toward: a. Yourself b. Your children c. Your neighbor d. Your class leader e. The writer of the lesson? 5. Do you think mothers often may discourage children by expecting finished-product perfection too soon? President Clark states: The days of our infancy and early childhood are filled with a growing awareness of time, space, gravity, the elements, and _ bodily well being; and thence to the grave is a constant struggle to overcome the handicaps, the inhibitions and limitations, imposed by these physical incidents of our being. To the gaining of the experiences of mastering them must be added the experiences having to do with making the biological part of man articulate and the cultivation and interchange of thought. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 22.) Class Participation Read the following statement by President Clark. Discuss it briefly, keeping in mind our present efforts to understand the peoples of the world. The nearer comes the conquest of these [the cultivation and interchange of thought], the nearer come men together, and the nearer men approach one another, the nearer comes the universal brotherhood of men and their ultimate perfection. (Ibid.) Question How important is man's struggle to triumph over such obstacles as time, space, disease, and the elements to his general upward reach? Discuss. WITNESS THE CONQUEST In the following quoted ex- cerpt we trace through vivid description the efforts of man to conquer and to utilize the forces that would restrict him, as President Clark takes us swiftly through the ages: Of House From the shelter of a tree or cave, through the lean-to, the log hut, the adobe house, to the giant structure of steel, concrete, and glass, housing a city within its four walls; Of Road... From the lone foot path in the forest, through the dirt road, the dust and mud of the city street, the paved sidewalk, the paved thoroughfare, to the great concrete ribbon spanning a continent; Of Transportation and Communication... From the pack of a few pounds on a man's back, through the oxcart, the horse and buggy, to the railroad with its thousands of tons, the autotruck; from the fleetest runner through the pony express, the fast mail train, to the airplane traveling half as fast as the earth revolves on its axis [1940]; Of Voice... From the shout that, with fair air, carried a few hundred feet, through the telephone linking cities, to the radio carrying the voice round the globe with the speed of light (we have yet to reach the speed of thought); And— Word of Man... From the passing down of story and song by word of mouth, through the invention of written characters, the writing by hand on bulky scrolls of parchment, on rushes, on paper, then to the printing press with its plain black letters, Of Art... Through woodcuts, steel engravings, lithographs, photogravures, and gorgeous pages in natural colors; Of Medical Skill... From the mangled, gangrenous broken leg demanding a life, through amputation with hideous pain without anesthetic, to the most refined and delicate painless operation upon the very seat of the mind itself—all these but indicate man's Lesson Department conquest of his inhibitions and limitations.... However stable or unstable, however complete or incomplete these conquests may be, they mark human progress—how great relatively we may not measure for we do not know the ultimate. But man seems to have come great distances. But these conquests of energy and force, which make human progress, add to human comfort and well being, increase knowledge and quicken intelligence, and, above all (and this the end of it all), promote human happiness, for the ancient prophet declared, "... Men are that they might have joy." (Ibid.) Class Discussion In the light of the foregoing description of human conquest discuss the following statements: Happiness comes in proportion as we lift ourselves beyond the reach of the penalty of earth law; and _perfection comes nearer with happiness. (Ibid.) An ancient psalmist sang, "The law is the truth." Equate this statement with the performing of a miracle. As we make these truths our own, so perfection approaches. It was by his perfect knowledge of truth... That Jesus turned water into wine, multiplied the loaves and fishes, escaped from the threatening mob on the edge of the cliff at Nazareth and again within the temple walls at Jerusalem, that took him into the room with closed windows and doors to visit the fearsome, questioning, doubting apostles, indeed that brought him forth from the tomb the first fruits of the resurrection. ([bid.) NOT BY THE MATERIAL ALONE For Class Discussion 1. Why are many individuals not content with conquest over the material things only? 2. In your opinion, what is one major difference between the conquest over material things and conquest over the intellectual and spiritual limitations? 715 September 1969 President Clark points out a very important difference. He states: But the things already spoken of {mastery over the physical limitations] only lead out toward perfection but not to it, for perfection may not be reached by mastery over the material things alone. Perfection means also the subjugation of the intellectual and spiritual limitations and inhibitions which are incident to the flesh. But there is an essential and fundamental difference between conquest and achievement in the physical and in the spiritual world. One need not do the works of Morse or Edison or Marconi in order fully to enjoy and use the telegraph, the telephone, the gramophone, or the radio; nor need one do the works of the Wrights in order to enjoy and use the airplane. The most ignorant and depraved of men may use all these things for his own purposes, to serve his own ends, good or bad, for the benefit or injury of others, as fully as they who made them. So likewise it is with the works of the great artists, sculptors, musicians, dramatists, and men of letters. Save only the creative joy which those alone who make may know, these masterpieces may be fully understood, appreciated, and enjoyed by any one without doing the works of the creator. But it is not so with the things of the spirit. ([bid.) THINGS OF THE SPIRIT Class Discussion 1. What do "things of the spirit" mean to you? 2. Enumerate several specific things. President Clark makes this clarification, referring to things of the spirit: One must do the works of Elijah if one would know his joy, have part in his blessings, share his glory, exercise his power and authority, and do the things he did. And surely the power to bring rain to a famine stricken land, to call down fire from heaven, 716 to cause the starving widow's barrel of meal not to waste, her cruse of oil not to fail, to restore to life her dead son, to declare the past and foretell the future—surely these things are beyond compare; they may not be valued, nor purchased, nor hired; they are beyond price. Here the works and the use are companions that never part. (Ibid.) Save for the atoning sacrifice of the Son and the doing of certain initiatory rites for the dead, (and even these must be accepted and adopted by the dead) nothing can be vicariously done, in matters of the spirit, by one for another. (Ibid.) The truths stated and illustrated by President Clark are important to this lesson and of vital importance to our individual lives, even to the relationships in the home, in the neighborhood, wherever individuals live together. Numerous situations illustrate the fact that for full development of that which we consider spiritual, a relationship with others is essential. Let us name a few of the qualities that we must develop within ourselves if we are to grow spiritually. Our spiritual guidance comes from the Father and his Son, whose life exemplified that perfection for which we strive. Class Questions 1. What are some of the spiritual attributes which Jesus possessed that we are striving to develop? 2. Do the qualities you have suggested involve human relationships? Discuss. 3. Do not love, compassion, unselfishness, service, forgiveness apply to human relationships in every woman's life? If they do, then surely we need one another in order to grow spiritually. Discuss briefly. FUNDAMENTAL TO CHRISTIANITY Although we may thus assist one another to grow in spirituality, it is fundamental to Christianity that each individual is responsible for his own life, his own upward reach, his own soul. A mother's faith and unwavering testimony belong to her, my neighbor's readiness to forgive does not make of me a forgiving person. Each must earn these blessings for herself. President Clark states: Thus every person shall make his own mind [as to] what his life shall be. None shall make it for him. Whether he will be satisfied with that part of salvation which pertains to the physical world, or whether he shall go on and add to this the salvation and exaltation of the spiritual universe, is for his own choice.... For him indeed who would conquer the flesh for the blessings of the spirit, there is a joy awaiting which exceeds all power of description.. (Ibid.) OF OUR BETTER SELVES As we travel the upward road toward those higher goals for which we reach there may. Be periods of accelerated growth. Certain individuals, special situations, and occasions may motivate us to a better performance than usual, to wider horizons of thought, where we may understand what we have never known before. These we should not forget. These we should cherish always. Christmas can be one of these occasions. During the kindly yuleLesson Department tide, we reach out beyond ourselves with compassion for others, motivated to a generosity of thought and deed. In this season of good will the lonely, the poor, the forgotten become our individual concern. If we will close our ears to the sounding brass and the tinkling cymbal of material things we may hear wise voices reminding us not to seek for the riches of earth. Voices saying such as this: After all, this existence of ours here is temporary. It is smaller than a drop in the ocean, as compared with eternity. We were before we came here; we are here; and we shall be after we go hence. This life is but one tiny line in this vast extension of existence. Do not forget,... The goodness and the mercy and the kindness of the Savior. Do not forget the blessings which the Gospel has for you. Do not overlook the joy of the spirit, the joy which comes from living as the Savior has taught us to live.. Seek after the treasures of the spirit, seek after the riches of goodness and mercy and righteous living. Go always after those things which are good.... Discard the dross, cast it aside, trample it underfoot; cherish always and guard that which is beautiful in your lives. (Ibid., lesson 20.) Such counsel is for the upward reach of man.
