BEY? ® When one gives evidence as a witness in court, he may either make a solemn declaration or affirmation, or give evidence under oath. In the latter case, if he does not tell the truth he may be charged with perjury. When one bears testimony to the truth of the gospel he also makes a solemn declaration or affirmation, but the source of his knowledge is not the same as that upon which he depends as a witness in court. It may have little or nothing to do with the five senses. In fact, a real testimony of the gospel, a testimony that God is real and personal and that Jesus of Nazareth is his Son, results from revelation and is a serious and sacred matter. In a court of law, hearsay, or secondhand evidence is not admissable regardless of the integrity of the witness submitting it. He must confine his evidence to what he personally knows to be true. While all members of the Church should respect, support, and heed the teachings of the Authorities of the Church, no one should accept a statement and base his testimony upon it, no matter who makes it, until he _ has, under mature examination, found it to be true and worth- 724 while; then his logical deductions may be confirmed by the spirit of revelation to his spirit because real conversion must come from within. By the same token, members of the Church should not become disillusioned and throw the Church overboard because they have not satisfied themselves concerning every principle of the gospel. All blessings from God come as a result of obedience to the laws upon which they are predicated. This rule, or law, applies to the acquisition of a testimony of the gospel or any related subject. Any accountable person can gain a testimony if he will obey the laws upon which the receipt of such knowledge is predicated. But here, as elsewhere, there are certain prerequisites, which may be listed roughly as follows: 1. The seeker must desire to know the truth of the gospel or whatever is involved in his quest. 2. He must study and learn everything possible with relation to the matter involved. In John 5:39 we read: "Search the scriptures; for in them ye think ye have eternal life." And we are directed in the Doctrine and Covenants 1:37 to "Search these commandments." 3. The applicant must practice the principles and truths which he learns and bring his life into harmony with them. The Savior said: "My doctrine is not mine, but his that sent me. If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself." (John 7:16, 17.) 4. He must constantly pray to the Father and exercise faith that the truth will be manifested by revelation through the Holy Ghost. Moroni tells us that by the power of the Holy Ghost ye may know the truth of all things. (Moroni 10:3-5.) When the Apostle Paul answered Christ's question as to who he, the Savior, was, he had the spirit of revelation, and Jesus said to him: "Blessed art thou, Simon Barjona: for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven." (Matt. 16:17.) This bears out the claim that direct and personal revelation is available to men if they will learn the necessary prerequisites and conform their lives thereto. In speaking or writing to memTestimony bers of the Relief Society one is addressing. The builders of the homes of our communities and of the Church. Every home has a spirit and that spirit will depend in large measure upon the testimony which the mother has of the divinity of the work in which we are engaged. This emphasizes the importance of her gaining a testimony and under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit guide and direct the affairs of the home and the lives of her children, having in mind always the relationship which exists between the Lord and his children. In other words, the mother must have great faith—faith in God, faith in herself and in her companion, and faith in the ultimate triumph of righteousness —a faith which ventures beyond knowledge and by which she may be able to meet the tests of practical life and_ religious experience. She will be guided by intellectual as well as moral imperatives. A mother who has a testimony will, therefore, live a righteous life—one which the children can emulate with safety; the kind of life which is inspired and directed by the Holy Ghost, whose companionship she will constantly. Seek. Of course the knowledge which the mother gains in her search for a testimony will be most helpful in her presiding over her home. But that knowledge must be observed and incorporated into the daily life of those concerned. He who knows the precepts and neglects to obey them is like one who lights a candle in the darkness and then closes his eyes. 725 October 1969 A house is not a home unless it contains food and fire for the mind and spirit as well as for the body. In order to supply that food and fire the maker of the home must have the ingredients which include and depend upon the strength of the testimony of both father and mother. The Apostle Peter gave us a list of virtues in II Peter 1: 5-7: And beside this, giving all diligence, add to your faith virtue; And to virtue knowledge; and to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godliness; and to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity. Alma bears testimony as follows: And this is not all. Do ye not suppose that I know of these things myself? Behold, I testify unto you that I do know that these things whereof I have spoken are true. And how do ye suppose that I know of their surety? Behold, I say unto you they are made known unto me by the Holy Spirit of God. Behold, I have fasted and prayed many days that I might know these things of myself. And now I do know of myself that they are true; for the Lord God hath made them manifest unto me by his Holy Spirit; and this is the spirit of revelation which is in me. (Alma 5:45-46.) In this age when there are so many broken homes, it is about time to stop building mere houses and begin rebuilding broken homes, and laying foundations upon which future enduring homes may be established. When grandfather and grandmother took each other for better or for worse, when things got worse, as they usually did, the two of them worked it out for the better. Their marriage lasted sixty years or longer be- 726 cause they knew the darkest hour would be only sixty minutes long. Too many today enter marriage with the door of escape wide open and that door leads to the divorce court. The extended freedom which is enjoyed today requires a stabilizing self-control and _ constancy just as branches demand roots. In this complicated age of restlessness and speed we are all oppressed at times with tension and strain. Tension needs tenacity, and strain requires steadfastness. A testimony of the gospel supplies _ spiritual underpinning without which human life leads but to shipwreck. The most effective and lasting impressions of life are made in the home where it is presided over by parents who know and bear testimony that God is real and personal, that Jesus is the Christ and that the gospel has been restored. Testimony is like an arrow shot from a long bow. The force of it depends upon the strength of the hand that draws it. (Bacon.) The Apostle Paul, writing to the Hebrew saints, said: For unto us was the gospel preached, as well as unto them: but the word preached did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in them that heard it. (Hebrews 4:2.) It was said of the Master, when he returned from Nazareth, that he did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief. All the hopes, the horizons, the motives that have been given to men depend upon faith in God. Our convictions are more important than our lives, if those convictions result from revealed testimonies. We need the type of courage, a product of faith, which will enable us to turn triumphantly toward the east at nightfall, with the calm assurance that dawn will surely follow dusk. We must regain and retain that rugged self-confident faith of our pioneer fathers. A torch is given to each of us as we seek to see the road ahead that we might light the lamps of others. This excerpt from the pen of one whose name I do not know is an appeal to all to keep the light of their faith still shining. THE LIGHT OF FAITH When the dark days come and the clouds grow gray All men must brave them as best they may: With never too much repining; And bravest is he, when the shadows fall, Who sees in the gloom of his darkened hall The light of his faith still shining. All great enterprise begins with and takes its first forward step in faith. Our job must be done with faith in the future, because very little of the fruit of one's work shows above the ground during a lifetime. We constantly need the warmth and glow and power of faith which will support and be supported by our testimonies of the gospel. Tennyson said: Faith sees the best that glimmers through the worst; she feels the sun is hid but for a night; she spies the summer through the winter bud; she tastes the fruit before the blossoms fall; she hears the lark within the songless egg; she finds the fountain where they wail "mirage!" Testimony And again: Think not the faith by which the just shall live is a dead creed, a map correct of heaven. Far less a feeling fond and fugitive, a thoughtless gift withdrawn as soon as given. It is an affirmation and an act that bids eternal truth to present fact. Faith is holding reasonable convictions in realms beyond the reach of final demonstration and thrusting out one's life upon those convictions as though they were really true. A testimony of the gospel develops and sustains such faith. Robert Louis Stevenson said: "I believe in the ultimate decency of things and if I woke in hell I should still believe in ite" There are plenty of people to do the possible. You can hire them at one hundred dollars a month. The prizes are for those who perform the impossible. If the thing can be done, experience and skill can do it—if it cannot be done, only faith can do it. Both science and religion rely on faith to inspire each forward step. All divine help depends on the presence of man's faith. Words like these were continually on the lips of the Savior: Be of good comfort, thy faith hath made thee whole. According to your faith be done unto thee as thou wilt. Thy faith hath saved thee. Man's life interpreted and motivated by religious faith is glorious, but shorn of faith's interpretation, life loses its highest meaning and its noblest hopes. Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith let us to the end dare to do our duty.... (Abraham Lincoln) 727 October 1969 Whether on the first of January or on the thirty-first of December, faith is a good word to end on. (Robert Louis Stevenson) Poetry is faith, faith that the converging sides of the pyramid slope to a summit whether we can see it or not. (Ralph Waldo Emerson) With all our science we must face each day as Paul faced his journey to Rome, "not knowing the things that shall befall me there." Paul's continuing and sustaining faith was supported and buttressed by his inspiring testimony. Every member of the Relief Society, every mother in Israel, needs and may obtain a testimony that God lives and that she is a member of a living Church, a_ growing, forwardlooking Church, where new ideas and new ways of doing things predominate their lives and leave no room for littleness of living nor for the paralysis of skeptical doubts in thinking. The testimony of Peter is inspiring as he responds to Christ's question "... Whom say ye that I am?" He said, "Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God." This testimony welled up from an overflowing heart, made humble by his recent denial and made more glorious by his own indomitable spirit. It is this stirring desire to do the will of our Father which caused the pioneers to endure the contumely and reproach of their fellow men and associate themselves voluntarily with the people denominated Latter-day Saints. Or Mormons. The Savior was pleased with Peter's testimony which was revealed to him, not by flesh and blood, but by our Heavenly 728 Father and was evidence of his love and of his unfolding mind as he comprehended the gospel plan. We also pass through valleys of weakness and _ hills of doubt as we attempt to climb the mountains of faith and get a testimony of truth. An abiding and oft repeated testimony of the truth of the gospel, borne by the mothers in the home; is a bulwark not alone to them personally but to their families and to all whose lives they touch. Because of the testimonies of the officers and members of the Relief Society that God is real and personal and their understanding of the relationship of God and man, this world-wide women's organization adopted charity (love) as a slogan. (See 1 Cor. 13.) Said Frank Crane: Conventional charity drops pennies in the beggar's cup, carries bread to the starving, distributes clothing to the naked; real charity, which is another name for love, sets about removing the conditions that make beggary, starvation, and nakedness. Conventional charity plays "Lady Bountiful;" love tres to establish such laws as shall give employment to all so that they need no bounty. Conventional charity piously accepts things as they are, and helps the unfortunate; active love goes to the legislature and changes things. Charity may swat the fly; love impels us to remove the dung-heaps that breed flies. Charity gives quinine in the malarial tropics; love drains the swamps. Charity sendssurgeons and ambulances and trained nurses to the war; brotherly love struggles to secure that internationalism that will prevent war. Charity assumes evil institutions and customs to be a part of Divine Providence, and tearfully works away at taking care of the wreckage; love regards injustice everywhere, custom-buttressed and re- spectable or not, as the work of the devil, and vigorously attacks it. The best part of the human race does not want help, nor favor, nor charity; it wants a fair chance and a square deal. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow said: The little I have seen of the world teaches me to look upon the errors of others in sorrow, not in anger. When I take the history of one poor heart that has sinned and suffered, and think of the struggles and temptations it has passed through, the brief pulsations of joy, the feverish inquietude of hope and fear, the pressure of want, the desertion of friends, I would fain leave the erring soul of my fellow man with him from whose hands it came. Some of us have sometimes, when in presiding positions in the Church, executive positions in business, while practicing law, or commanding men in the army, found it necessary to _ hold trials, make investigations, and pass judgments on our fellow men. Often in such cases when associates or counselors have insisted on microscopic examination of the lives and faults of the accused, I, myself, have been deterred from hasty judgment by imagining a slide film of my own life had been slipped beneath the glass. How often at such times has the "beam" eclipsed the "mote" and the "first stone" been withheld because I could not qualify to cast it. S. E. Kiser imagined that one day in paradise two angels, beaming, strolled along the amber walk that hes beside the streets of gold. They met and gazed into each other's eyes, then dropped their harps, amazed, and stood in mute surprise. Testimony And other angels came, and as they lingered near, heard both exclaim at once, "Say, how did you get here?" Dr. Benjamin Johnson adds, "God, himself, sir, does not propose to judge man until the end of his days, why should we?" And Dante queries, "Oh, mortal men, be wary how you judge." WATCH YOURSELF GO BY Just stand aside and watch yourself go by; Think of yourself as 'he' instead of "TIT". Note closely, as in other men you note, The bag-kneed trousers and the seedy coat. Pick flaws; find fault; forget the man is you, And strive to make your estimate ring true. Confront yourself and look you in the eye, Just stand aside and watch yourself go by. And then, with eyes unveiled to what you loath— To. Sins that with sweet charity you clothe— Back to your self-walled tenement you'll go With tolerance for all who dwell below. The faults of others then will dwarf and shrink. Love's chain grows stronger by one mighty hnk— When you with "he" as substitute for "yp" Have stood aside and watched yourself go by. Relief Society workers should be unwilling to choose between flaming fanaticism and _ sentimental surrender. Let personal conviction and generous tolerance meet and merge. The spirit of testimony makes one tolerant of the weaknesses and mistakes 729 October 1969 of others as it emphasizes the brotherhood of man. A book on tolerance by Phillips Brooks, mentions six brands of tolerance: First, the tolerance of pure indifference. We may be tolerant because we do not care, because the issue at stake does not concern us. Second, the tolerance of policy. We may be tolerant because we think we would lose more than we gain by fighting the man or the measure. Third, the tolerance of helplessness. We may be tolerant because we realize that the enemy holds the field and that resistance will be futile. Fourth, the tolerance of pure respect for man. We may be tolerant because we respect even a man's right to think wrong, because we agree with Voltaire when he wrote to Helvétius, "I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say Te Fifth, the tolerance of spiritual sympathy. We may be tolerant because we feel a spiritual comradeship with the man whose purpose is fine even if his proposition is false. Sixth, the tolerance of an enlarged view of truth. We may be tolerant because we have come to realize that truth is larger than any one man's concept of it, even if we are the one man in question. The first three kinds of tolerance are mean; the last three are magnificent. "True tolerance," says Brooks, "consists in the love of truth and the love of man, each brought to its perfection and living in perfect harmony with one another." But this is no easy achievement. In this age of selfishness and greed, of birth control and barrenness, of easy divorce and broken homes and juvenile delinquency, in this age of cheap amusements, idleness and lack of discipline, it is well to search for basic values, to call attention to the fact that the home is 730 the nation's most fundamental institution and that mothers are the first professors in that character building school. Let us teach the young women of the land that womanhood is glorified by motherhood. A woman who has a testimony of the gospel will meet the demands of home building with poise and dignity. Motherhood is the _ inscription on the gate through which the spirits pass to enter the realm of mortal men, and it will be woman's password for admittance into the highest realms of glory. The Son of God hallowed and glorified that inscription when he bowed through that gate and called a mortal woman, "Mother." How important it is that every mother have a testimony of him and cooperate with him in the continuing work of redemption. President McKay said: Motherhood is the one thing in all the world which most truly exemplifies the God-given virtues of creating and sacrificing. Though it carries the woman close to the brink of death, motherhood also leads her into the very realm of the fountains of life and makes her co-partner with the Creator in bestowing upon eternal spirits mortal life. Artists may make new visions real; poets express thoughts never known before or dress old ones in a more becoming garb; engineers may transform deserts into bounteous fields and fill them with prosperous towns and thriving villages; scientists may discover new elements, and by various combinations thereof create means contributive either to progress or destruction—all these are in a measure revealers of unknown things: but the mother who, in compliance with eternal law, brings into the world an immortal spirit occupies first rank in the realm of creation. (Gospel Ideals, page 656.) All who have received a testimony of the gospel through revelation are authorized, commissioned—required—to teach the gospel under the inspiration of that spirit through which it came. I quote and commend the appeal made by Sister Zina Y. C. Brown in her prose poem, "Woman Exalted:" Daughters of Zion, ye mothers of men, hold fast these gifts of thy calling great, Yesterday is gone, WITH THESE HANDS The canvas of my day is yet empty. And the pallet is clean. My beloveds still slumber— And God awaits my prayer. | offer my hands this day unto their Creator, To fashion a thing of beauty From these virgin hours awaiting color and form. Strike away the temptation to blotch and blurr, Testimony Lest they be lost—these priceless pearls of purity and purpose holy. Know ye not that thy place is at the side, and not below, This companion to whom thou art given of the Lord? Thou woman exalted, thou first to forgive and last to forsake, Thou pnestess, queen, Thank thy God who made thee thus, That thou was born A woman. That the canvas may be vibrant and clean With the work of loving hands. Hands that will comfort, protect and perpetuate. Hands that will discipline and adhere, That the work may form in order and beauty. Hands that will build, give, and guide, Strengthening each fiber of importance, And shunning the rest. When the canvas is completed In detail and deed, May | hopefully seek my Lord again. Then, in humility and with thankfulness, May | ask for his refreshment And begin anew with these hands he has given me. —Mary Jo McEwan 731 Mm Mayola R. Miltenberger Appointed General reasurer The General Presidency of Relief Society is pleased to announce the appointment of Mayola Rogers Miltenberger as General Secretary-Treasurer of Relief Society. Sister Miltenberger has been serving as acting SecretaryTreasurer since June of 1969. Sister Miltenberger brings to this office devotion to the gospel and Relief Society in addition to her fine training and experience. She possesses grace and dignity and endears herself to those with whom she works. She is capable in meeting the requirements of any assignment given her, and finds joy in her work. Sister Miltenberger was named to the General Board in October of 1968. Prior to her appointment as acting Secretary-Treasurer she had rendered valuable service in the field of social service. She was no stranger to Relief Society at the time of her appointment to the Board, for she had served as director of the Relief Society Social Service Program for Arizona. Sister Miltenberger is the daughter of Marion and Leanora Smith Rogers. She was married in 1937 to the late Edwin John Miltenberger. Sister Miltenberger attended Brigham Young University and was graduated from the University of Arizona. She obtained her Master's degree in social work from Tulane University, where she also served as a field instructor. She is a member of the Academy of Social Workers, and a charter member of the National Association of Social Workers. Sister Miltenberger has served as a ward and branch Relief Society president, as MIA president, and as a Sunday School teacher. She is always willing to bear testimony as to the truthfulness of the gospel, and is unselfish in her devotion of time and energy to the work of our Heavenly Father. In her new appointment, she has the love and confidence of the General Presidency and her associates on the General Board. Her service will be a blessing to the sisters and to Relief Society organizations throughout the world. 732 New Members Appointed to The General Board of Relief Society Amy Young Valentine, Provo Thirteenth Ward, East Provo Stake, Utah, is a daughter of Cecile Virginia Skousen and W. LAnn\' ee) |= $f Relief Society G( DV ) Con esc General Announcement The Relief Society General Board is pleased to announce the second contest for Latter-day Saint women in song writing (lyrics and music) to be conducted annually. The purpose of the contest is to encourage creativity in this form of art excellence in the general field of music among the women of the Church. The General Board will be happy to receive entries following this announcement until the closing date of the contest (see below). Name of Contest This contest is to be known as THE RELIEF SOCIETY SONG CONTEST. Dates This year's contest (1969-70) opens with this announcement and closes March 1, 1970. All entries must be postmarked before midnight, March 1, 1970. Prizes Prizes will be awarded as follows: First Prize $100 Second Prize $ 75 If two individuals collaborate on the words and the music, the prize will be awarded as follows: Sixty per cent to the composer and forty per cent to the author. Decision of the judges will be final. Winners will be notified by the General Board and public announcement of the awards will be made in the June 1970, issue of The Relief Society Magazine. The General Board reserves the right to withhold the awarding of prizes if no compositions of sufficient merit are submitted. Rules 1. The contest will be open to all Latter-day Saint women, except members of the Relief Society General Board and employees of the Relief Society General Board. 2. Each contestant may submit one composition only. Duplicate copies of all submissions should be retained by the contestants to insure against loss. 3. The composition is to be submitted in a sealed envelope. No explanatory or pictorial supplementary material should accompany the composition and the sheet(s) upon which the song is written should have no identifying marks or signature upon it (them). Address to: SONG CONTEST Relief Society. Building 76 North Main Street Salt Lake City, Utah 84111 739 October 1969 4. It will not be possible for the General Board to correspond with the contestants regarding individual works. 5. No nom de plumes are to be used. 6. A signed statement is to accompany the "work" certifying: a. The composer is a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The composition is the contestant's original work. That it has never been published. That it is not in the hands of an editor or another person with view to publication. E. That it will not be published nor submitted elsewhere for publication until the contest is decided. 7. Contestants should submit a biography of 150 words, or less, giving essential data regarding themselves and citizenship (for copyright purposes). 8. The music should be unpublished. The Relief Society reserves the right to publish the same and assign the copyright to a publisher on a royalty basis. The royalty will be divided on a fifty-fifty basis between the composer and the Relief Society for two years after publication. Thereafter, the Relief Society will waive its royalty and the fifty per cent royalty shall accrue to the composer. Such royalty shall be ten per cent of the marked selling price. If an author collaborates with a composer a division of the royalties will be made agreeable to both of them. 9. The songs most preferred will express spiritual values. The texts need not be original but must not be subject to copyright. Texts most preferred will sing with natural flow—with a happy placement of vowels for ease of delivery. Tricky effects should be avoided. 10. Manuscripts should be written in ink. Manuscript paper may vary to suit the composer. Generally the size to be preferred is octavo or 9" by 12". 11. Music is to be submitted in clearly written manuscript, in SSA (first soprano, second soprano, and alto) setting. Occasional two or four parts may be used for special effects, as may unison. The accompaniment should be suitable for piano or organ. Each of three parts should be written on separate staves as is generally the case in octavo publication. The writing style and complexity should approximate the type of selections that have been sung by the Singing Mothers at Relief Society General Conferences. Highly contrapuntal and dissonant musical settings are generally too difficult and, except for special effects and contrast, should be avoided. Eloquent phrasing will be considered highly desirable. 12. The recommended performance length is approximately three to five minutes. 13. The winning works will be published and programmed for performance by Singing Mothers choruses. 14. The winning of one Relief Society Song Contest in no way prohibits the contestant from entering and winning another contest in another year, but a contestant who received first prize for two consecutive years must wait for two years before she is eligible to enter the contest again. ICRS Judges All manuscripts will be reviewed by a competant team of judges composed as follows: A representative of the publishing business, a member of the Relief Society General Board Music Committee, two competent directors of choruses, and a recognized composer. 740 SMU Lael J. Littke @ Mama said I shouldn't really count too strongly on being the fairy princess in our fourth grade spring operetta, but I knew I would get the part. After all, hadn't I prayed for it with all the faith in my nine-year-old heart? Just because I had straight brown hair and freckles wasn't any reason why I couldn't be the princess, was it? Mama didn't say anything about the straight hair and freckles, of course, but she did remind me gently that there were eleven other girls in my class who would like to be the princess, but I knew they all expected Lauramae Van Skiver to get the part. Ever since we had all been in the first grade, she had always been the princess. Lauramae didn't know how to spell Mississippi, but no one cared, least of all Lauramae. She had fat blond Sausage curls and blue eyes Shaded by long, curly black lashes. She giggled a lot, but she took dancing lessons and could sing like an angel. It would take practically a miracle for me to get the part when Lauramae was around, but miracles had happened before, hadn't they? My Sunday School teacher said they had when a person's faith was strong enough. The fairy princess got to wear a crown anda white costume with a fluffy skirt all spangled with sequins. She was to carry a glittering wand which, when she waved it, would bring all the flowers to life. Playing that part seemed to me to be the most beautiful thing that could happen in a young girl's life, especially one who had read every book of 741 October 1969 fairy tales in the school library. For months I had worked to get the best grades in our class hoping that Miss Ellerbee would take that into consideration when she assigned the parts. And then, of course, there was the praying. Heavenly Father couldn't possibly ignore a small person who had such a big want that for weeks she had washed dishes and done her piano practicing without being prompted, and who didn't hit her brother even when he took her doll buggy and used it to mix mud in for a fort he was building. | On the day Miss Ellerbee assigned the parts I sat with my eyes closed and my _ hands clasped, knowing she would say, "Jenny Bennett will be our princess," and then I would give the little squeal of surprise I had been practicing. But what Miss Ellerbee said was "The part of the fairy princess will be played by Lauramae Van Skiver." Lauramae didn't even scream with pleasure as any other girl in the class would have done. She had known all along she would be the fairy princess. The squeal I had prepared died in my throat and almost choked me. I wished that it had. What good was it living in a world where people who didn't even care got the best things and where your most fervent prayers went unanswered? I felt betrayed. Next time I went to Sunday School, I thought, I would tell my teacher a thing or two. No, on second thought I wouldn't, because I wasn't going to go any more. Feeling dismally wicked, I half listened as Miss Ellerbee 742 went on to read the rest of the parts. "Daffodil will be played by Ruby Raymond." I waited, not eagerly any more but still with a little curiosity for my name to be called. After all, the flowers had pretty costumes, too, although not as beautiful as the fairy princess. It would be nice to be the rose. "Rose," said Miss Ellerbee, "will be played by Merna Bell. Freddy Hopkins will play the part of Spider." She went on down through the list of flowers, bugs, and birds until she came to the last part. "The part of Toad will be played by Jenny Bennett." I hadn't even thought about being the toad. It was beyond consideration. I hardly heard what else Miss Ellerbee said—something about the toad being just about the most important part in the play since it was the toad who hopped around protecting the lovely flowers from the bugs and birds, and it was the toad to whom the fairy princess said at the end, "Despite your homely appearance, oh, Toad, you have a truly beautiful spirit." I didn't care what Miss Ellerbee said. If you were a toad, who would notice how beautiful your spirit was? On the school bus going home Lauramae Van Skiver sat. By me. "I wish I could be a toad sometime," she said. I knew she was just being nice. Lauramae was always nice. That's why everyone liked her. I didn't like her. I didn't like her at all, with her fat curls and long lashes and nice ways. "You'd make a terrible toad," I said. "Maybe I would," she said, "but it would be fun to try. I always have to be the princess." It just wasn't fair. I wanted to cry right there on the bus, but I managed to wait until it stopped to let my two brothers and me off. Instead of going into the house, I crawled into a clump of lilac bushes and wept. I wished that a bolt of lightning would hit me, and then when I was all fixed up in a white dress in my coffin people would say, "Poor little thing. See how pretty she looks—not like a toad ° at all." I was so involved with my fantasy, which made me. Weep even harder, that I scarcely noticed Mama crawling under the lilacs beside me. "Tom told me you went in here," she said. "I thought maybe something was wrong." "Il have to be the toad," I blurted, fresh tears flooding my face. Mama patted my back and rubbed my head until I stopped bawling. "I wanted so much to be the princess," I sobbed. "And Lauramae would rather be the toad. She really would, Mama." Mama thought about it. "Maybe I could speak to Miss Ellerbee," she said. "Oh, Mama," I cried hopefully, "would you? Please would you?" "Let's think about it," Mama said. "What does the princess do?" "Well, I said, rubbing my nose with my forearm, "she sings five songs all by herself." The Princess Part "You could do that," Mama said. "T really can't sing very well," I said. "I don't know whether I'd dare even if I could." "We could take care of that," Mama said. "Maybe Lauramae could sing backstage and you could just move your mouth." "That would work fine," I agreed. "But what about the dancing? I can't dance." "You could learn some steps." "Or maybe Lauramae could be a dancing toad," I suggested. Mama nodded. "I don't see why not." "Oh, Mama," I said, "the princess gets to wear the prettiest costume you ever saw. It's all spangled and it's got a little short fluffy skirt like a ballet dancer wears." I looked down at my long thin legs with the knobby knees. Mama looked, too. "We could make the skirt clear to the floor," she said gently. October 1969 I had never pictured the fairy princess in a full-length dress. "That wouldn't be quite as pretty, but we could put lots of spangles on it," I said. There was. Still wrong. "Mama," I said, "what about my hair? A princess should have cule: " Mama laughed. "That's no problem. We'll get you a_ permanent." I remembered the last time I had a permanent. My _ hair had stuck straight out in eight inches of frizz. I couldn't imagine a fairy princess with a head of frizz. I looked down again at my knobby knees. "Mama," I said. I cleared my throat so I wouldn't start crying again. "Mama, I wouldn't make a good fairy princess at all. I'd be a mess." Mama was loyal. "You'd be sweet," she said. I shook my head. "Td just look silly. 11 make a better toad." Mama smiled at me. "If someone has curls and can sing, it's easy to make the audience believe you're a fairy princess," she said, "but it takes much more real effort to be a_ believable toad." I thought about that. Sudsomething denly I didn't want to cry any more. "Maybe Lauramae really meant it when she said she'd like to be the toad," I mused. Mama nodded. "Maybe," she said, "but Miss Ellerbee thought you could do it better. You know, if you learn your part well and work very hard, you can make the toad the most interesting character in the whole show." "Will you help me?" I asked, and Mama nodded again. I crawled out of the lilacs and stood up, raising my face to the bright afternoon sunlight. "Tl be the best toad Miss Ellerbee ever saw," I said. "She'll be glad she gave me such a good part." Mama crawled out, too, and stood beside me, smiling down at me. "I just know she will," she said. "Let's go in now and plan your costume." "Let's make it orange with green and purple spots," I said. Oh, there was so much to do. And I would have to remember when I went to Sunday School on Sunday to tell my teacher that sometimes prayers were answered in a much different way than you expected them to be. In the meantime I must practice hopping and speaking in a croaking voice. Poor Lauramae, I thought. She never gets the fun parts. Culp, twenty-seven, of Newport Beach, California, a small blond native of Riga, Latvia, who has lived in America the last twelve years, won the twenty-third annual Powder Puff Derby, women's cross-country - air race, last July. She has two thousand flying hours to her credit and flew from San Diego to Washington in eleven hours and fiftyseven minutes. Mrs. Sharon Sites Adams, whose husband is a sailing instructor, has become the first woman to sail alone the six thousand miles across the Pacific Ocean (from Yokohama, Japan, to San Diego, California). During the 75-day crossing in a 31- foot ketch, the 37-year-old housewife weathered severe gales, lost her rotator (which drags in the water and measures distance), to a shark and was becalmed for one week. Her radio transmitter became inoperative. Letitia Baldridge has been social secretary to Ambassador and Mrs. David Bruce in Paris, to Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce, and to President and Mrs. John F. Kennedy. She became the first woman executive in Tiffany's history, and is currently public relations consultant for Chicago's Merchandise Mart, and for Sears, Roebuck. She is married and is a mother. Mrs. Elaine Whitelaw, director of volunteer services for the National Foundation, said the Rubella vaccine to prevent German Measles, which was licensed in midJune, will soon be administered in the United States to children below ten years of age. Pregnant mothers with rubella have given birth to thousands of deformed children. Mothers will be protected if epidemics are not started by children, so the young will receive the first shots available. Sphere Ramona W. Cannon Jan Armstrong, Joan Aldrin, and Pat Collins, wives of the three astronauts of the Apollo XI Mission, and the spacemen's mothers: Mrs. Stephen Armstrong, Mrs. Edwin Eugene Aldrin, Senior, and Mrs. James Collins, were the focus of interest, sympathy, and prayers of women of the world last July as their husbands and sons flew through boundless space. Humanity waited with almost unbearable suspense until Neil Armstrong planted the first human footprint on the moon, remarking, '"'(One small step for a man, a giant leap for mankind.''We salute these women whose lives and examples have influenced their famous sons and husbands. The women displayed great courage and patience while waiting. He [Jesus] went throughout every city and village, preaching and shewing the glad tidings of the kingdom of God: and the twelve were with him, And certain women... Which ministered unto him of their substance., ''And when much people were gathered together, and were come to him out of every city, he spake by a parable: '"'A sower went out to sow his seed: and as he sowed, some fell by the way side; and it was trodden down, and the fowls-of the air devoured it. '"'And some fell upon a rock; and as soon as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moisture. "And some fell among thorns; and the thorns sprang up with it, and choked it. "And other fell on good ground, and sprang up, and bare fruit an hundredfold...."' (Luke 8:1, 3-8.) This, the first, and adjudged by many most perfect of the parables, was interpreted by its divine Author: Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God. Those by the way side are they that hear; then cometh the devil, and taketh away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved. They on the rock are they, which, when they hear, receive the word with joy; and these have no root, which for a while believe, and in time of temptation fall away. And that which fell among thorns are they, which, when they have heard, go forth, and are choked with cares and riches and pleasures of this life, and bring no fruit to perfection. But that on the good ground are they, which in an honest and good heart, having heard the word, keep it, and bring forth fruit with patience. (Luke 8:11-15.) In this day when evil is rampant, the parable of the sower has particular significance. The ''riches and pleasures of life'' are the temptations the devil uses to draw men's hearts from following after the i Volume 56 October 1969 Number 10 THE GENERAL BOARD Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Miltenberger, Secretary-Treasurer ~~. Aaa 746 commandments of God. Jesus urges his followers to guard against the suggestions of the devil. Not only do these suggestions withhold men from good deeds, but they inspire evil thoughts and draw men to sin. The devil attacks at every point where weakness may lie, and never stops in performing his mission of evil with one kind of temptation alone. We are told to observe the condition of the soil in the story. The seed was the same, whether it fell on good ground or poor. The gospel is the same. It is the extent to which it is received which makes the difference. Some hear the word and embrace it for a brief period. As soon as obstacles appear, their enthusiasm dies as the roots from the seed sown in shallow soil shrivel from lack of nourishment. Some hear the word, but the pursuit of the world's pleasures soon smothers its voice, as the thorns and weeds choke out the burgeoning seed. Some hear the word not at all, it does not penetrate their consciousness, as the seed which falls on ground too hard for it to take root. Some hear the word and it thrives and grows within their souls. They tenderly nurture it, cultivate it, keep it free from weeds and thorns and reap harvests of blessings. Their eternal lives are abundantly good and yield an hundredfold to the harvester. What shall the harvest be? Each individual assures his own harvest. He reaps the consequences of his acts and deeds as time goes by. At the end of his mortal life, the sum of all of his productive years is the great harvest when the good is separated from the bad, as the wheat is separated from the weeds and carefully stored in a granary, and the weeds destroyed. It is from the harvest, from our receptiveness of the seed, the word of God, we will be judged. What shall the harvest be? Blessings or condemnation according ai Leone G. Layton Aleine M. SSSSESSSSRAATS SEPTERESH The General Board of Relief Society announces as of July 18, 1969, the release of ten General Board members who have given valued service to the organization from twenty-nine to five years. Anna B. Hart was called to the General Board in 1940. In her twenty-nine years of service she has endeared herself to sisters throughout the world. Her extensive educational training has resulted in great benefits to Relief Society. Edith S. Elliot has served on the General Board since 1940, during which time she has rendered untiring service for the well-being of Relief Society members. Her sunny disposition and happy approach to her tasks influenced those with whom she has come in contact. Florence J. Madsen came to the General Board in 1941. During her long years of service to Relief Society she has aided the music program in taking giant steps toward becoming the meaningful program it is today. Sister Madsen's musical compositions and her skill in working toward the development of the Singing Mothers program will live forever. Blanche B. Stoddard was appointed to the General Board in 1945, and has rendered outstanding service in aiding Relief Societies throughout the world in following the prescribed policies and practices of Relief Society. Her charming sense of humor has enabled her to achieve a rare rapport with those whom she has served in her twenty-four years of service. Edith P. Backman became a member of the General Board in 1953. Throughout her sixteen years of service she has given unselfish and valuable service in the field of educational programs. Her work in regional conferences has brought many commendations to the General Board. Elna P. Haymond was called to the General Board in 1953. Her service has been characterized by excellent preparation for the many tasks she was called upon to perform. Her dependability has caused her to be called upon for many services. Afton W. Hunt has endeared herself to sisters throughout the world since her appointment to the General Board in 1957. In her twelve years of service on the board she has traveled extensively, and has always been equipped to meet the responsibilities of conference assignments with intelligence and dignity. Elsa T. Peterson as served on the General Board since 1958. In her eleven years as a board member she has demonstrated countless qualities of leadership at regional conferences. Her social experiences and good taste have been invaluable in helping with conference receptions and other social activities. ( 748 General Board Members Released Zola J. McGhie became a member of the General Board in 1962. Her service in the homemaking area of Relief Society and her contributions to the social activities of the Board have made her a valuable asset during her seven years of service. She has willingly fulfilled every assignment that has been given to her. Anne R. Gledhill received her appointment to the General Board in 1964. As a board member she has rendered outstanding service in regional conferences, and has achieved a valuable rapport with those whom she has served. The united love of the Board goes with these sisters for their loyal support of the organization. May the service they have rendered continue to inspire and elevate others to loftier goals, and may Relief Society always be a joy and blessing to them. Watson \ Member, General Board of Relief Society What is more appealing to the appetite than the tantalizing aroma of a casserole brimful of flavor? Simple foods, such as stews and leftovers, take on a new elegance and importance when served as casseroles. One-dish meals require little watching, and with a side serving of salad, bread, and milk, little else is needed for a hearty meal.: Fortunately, casserole recipes are usually quite flexible. Proportions and main ingredients can be varied without diminishing the flavor or quality of the dishes. Happily, in these days of high food prices, less meat may be used, more potatoes, rice, spaghetti, and vegetables may be added for bulk. Either fresh, frozen, or canned foods, depending on their availability or price, may be used. Casseroles are well known as time savers. Provident homemakers find it a good practice to prepare two or more casseroles at one time from like ingredients, one to be cooked for tonight's dinner, the other to be popped into the freezer to be brought out for unexpected company, for dinner on Relief Society day, or to be taken to a sick friend. Preparation for the Sabbath day may be minimized by frequent use of casseroles prepared in advance. Casserole recipes cover a wide range of foods. They may be served in a simple or an elegant manner, as the occasion demands. Why not try some of the following delicious recipes? Or you may wish to concoct some of your own. SEEDTIME AND HARVEST Today as | look from my window at half-bare trees, At crimson and gold, gay-dotting the landscape over, | give grateful thanks to God on bended knees For flowers and fruits, for sun and succulent clover: That 'While the earth remaineth, seedtime and harvest, And cold and heat, and summer and winter, and day And night shall not cease." The owl and the bluebird shall nest. We shall be gladdened alike by the sun's golden ray And storms, be they gentle or wild; that age follows youth, That earth is our home and around it the waters are curled, | \\\="==" And we who are a part of it all, treasure each truth \\ ~""aé AS seasons come and go and light illumines the world. 755 i, —Zara Sabin Black | Walnut "= Gathering, Pauline L. Jensen @ In my childhood, October meant more than blue skies, glorious sunsets and crisp nights when we pulled the wool comforters to our chins and snuggled in dreamy content beneath them. It meant more than the red of sumac and maple leaves; more than the final fling of beauty from the chrysanthemum bushes before winter descended and gently cradled them in sleep. October, in Nebraska, was black walnut gathering time. There, in my early years, black walnuts grew in abundance in the woods of every farm. Tall and straight, the trees stretched along the banks of the turbulent Missouri River. In rows, they formed a windbreak on the side-roads, having been planted, in many instances, by the first settlers of the region. An abundance of trees did not always insure us of an ample supply of the delicious nuts that added a touch of luxury to our simple fare. After the first frost, people came in droves to retrieve each nut that fell along the highways or on the river banks. In the farm woodlands, the squirrels hoarded great stores of them against the long winter months ahead. But farmers were kind, generous people, willing to share their bounty with neighbors and friends, or even strangers. We were fortunate, in that we had relatives living in the country. Invariably, in early October after the first frost, we set aside a day as "Black Walnut Day." The entire clan then gathered at the home of one of the farming members of the group. I remember with what joyous anticipation we looked forward to these affairs. The winey odor of fallen apples met us as we stepped from the car. Chickens preened their feathers in sheltered spots beside the house, and cats squatted in the sun, their eyes glinting in their solemn faces. In the fields, corn shocks stood in wigwam fashion, reminding us that in the not too distant past, true wigwams had stood upon that very soil. The feel and scent that belongs only to October filled the air. This was the typical "Black Walnut" day of my younger ~ years. I recall with nostalgic longing the appetizing fragrance of roasting pork, baking chickens, spicy pies, and hot rolls that we encountered as we opened the door. Because most of my ancestors were of Pennsylvania Dutch extraction, the food conformed to that mode of cooking. And where could one find better? More than the traditional "seven sweets" and "seven sours" graced the enlarged tables. 756 Black Walnut Gathering The children dashed ahead, dogs barking and darting between them. When they reached the grove, they vied with each other in finding the biggest nuts, and filling pails. In no time, it seemed, sacks were full and stood in neat rows, Waiting to be tied and loaded into the waiting wagon. This done, the children clambered aboard, and with much shouting, urged the horses homeward. The older members of the party walked slowly toward the house Savoring scurried about, putting the leftovers from dinner on the table, where each Goodbyes were called, the cars started, and people settled back against the hard cushions. Truly, this black walnut gathering had been one to remember! AUTUMN Autumn has not come for me, Until | see a chestnut tree In all its golden majesty, On some October day. As sunshine's penetrating beams Reach into branches, nature seems Triumphant in the color schemes That glitter, dance, and play. Brilliant hues of gold are fired, And tones of bronze and brown acquired, As amber, saffron, leaves are pyred In breathtaking array. On some October day. —Ruth G. Rothe 757 th,., ri Ath WA, le Of all the season's rare delights, This scene most pleases and excites, And lifts my soul to unknown heights, Make Your Own Bat ys - Look Grace Diane Jessen Every child treasures the stories, the pictures and mementos that tell of him alone. When these bits are bound together under one cover that can expand with the years as he grows and learns, they become doubly precious. You can make a book for your baby (or a grandchild or a friend) that will be more cherished than any book purchased in a store, because a bit of your love, your personality and creativity will remain stamped onto the pages forever. This book will be less expensive in terms of dollars and cents, but more precious to the one who receives it because you make it just for him. The following directions tell how you can make a basic baby book. You may wish to make many changes or additions to fit your own ideas, and, of course, many pages can be added as the child grows. MATERIALS NEEDED First, purchase these materials from genealogical supplies: One inexpensive '"'Book of Remembrance"' cover. (These cost about 50¢ and are available in different colors and designs.) One personal record page One personal health record page One pedigree chart One portrait pedigree chart One dozen sheets of plain heavy bond paper. (This has prepunched holes as do the other genealogy pages.) Assemble your old greeting cards, appropriate pictures from magazines, a few packages of baby and flower seals, or'a package of baby gift-wrapping paper. These items can be used as you desire to add decorative touches to the pages or you may prefer to draw your own if you have artistic talent. You will need a fine felt-tip pen in a bright color for writing page headings and also a bottle of glue or rubber cement. PROCEDURE Begin by using one of the heavy plain sheets for the inside cover page. Use a stencil or write as neatly as possible "This is the story of" followed by a blank line if the book is for an unnamed baby. Write in the name in large, attractive letters if you know it. Trim the page with flowers, birds, pictures, or whatever appeals to you, but make the name the focal point of the page. Page two is the personal record sheet, trimmed, if desired, with tiny flowers in the upper margin. Under the heading "Important Events," mother may wish to write such details of baby's birth as his measurements, attending physician, and time of arrival. Page three is the personal health record which may be decorated similar to page two. 758 Make Your Own Baby's Book Page four is the pedigree chart with the title "My Family Tree" added at the top of the page. Using colored pencils, sketch in the outline of a large tree which nearly fills the page from top to bottom. Very lightly fill in the coloring with pencil where desired. This will add background to the page. But will not obscure the names and dates when they are added later. Page five is made from the plain heavy bond paper and is divided down the middle by a wavy line, a short straight line or other design. It need not extend from the top to the bottom of the page, but only four five or six inches in the center. Choose one type of dividing mark and use it on all the divided pages throughout the book. Entitle one section "Visitors" and the other "Gifts." Add any pictures or trim that you consider appropriate. Page six is also divided into two sections. These are entitled 'First Foods" and "Favorites." Page seven is for "My Development" and may contain subheadings such as "First Smile," "Sat Up Alone," "First Word," "First Steps," and others. Page eight can be divided three ways and labeled "My Birthdays" with subheadings for "First," "Second," and "Third." Page nine is for "My First Christmas" and "Second" and "Third." Additional pages may be added later for other birthdays and Christmases. You may choose to devote a whole page to just one birthday and include snapshots of it. Page ten is divided into two sections which are labeled "Travels" and "Teachers." Page eleven is for "Mother's Notes" with one corner set aside for information on "My First Haircut." A small envelope can be glued here to hold a lock of baby's hair. Page twelve contains a space for "My Birth Announcement" and "My Footprints." Page thirteen is entitled "Birth and Blessing Certificates." Page fourteen is for "Cards and Clippings." The heavy bond paper is sturdy enough to glue these items on satisfactorily, but, if you prefer, you may purchase sheets of plastic film which fit over these pages. Then the certificates will stay in place without being glued and will be protected from dust and fingerprints as well. Page fifteen is for the portrait pedigree, and is followed by a blank page entitled "Snapshots." These pages are sufficient for a basic book for baby. If you are making one for your own baby, you can assemble the materials and take them along when you go to the hospital. Then you can spend those lonely leisure hours after baby arrives in finishing his book just the way you want it. As your child starts to school, you may wish to add a page for each year including a picture of him. On his twelfth birthday, you can present this record to him and let him have the opportunity of keeping it up to date. He may wish to copy some of your genealogical pages of his ancestry to include in his book. If your child shows a desire to expand and continue the book, you could give him a more durable and permanent cover for it for another birthday. In this way, his "baby book" can grow with him and provide a cherished record of all his life. 759 a. RtyyTityit ty Nancy D. F. Tuddenham Katherine, Northern Territory, Australia, lways Granny, never )J5, Sister, just Granny. A She was Granny to all of us, bless her. An Islander from the Torres Straits, brown of skin and great of heart. Loving her large family, all relatives included, and loved and respected by them. As her name implies, she was not young in years, but was young in spirit. Once we wanted something different for entertainment for a conference. What? Then came the answer — Granny knew Island dances, she could teach us how to do them. So, Granny did, much to our enjoyment and her own. We would sit on the floor, four or five white sisters, three or four native sisters, with Granny in front of us. 760 She would sing the song, and we would try and write down the words phonetically, then we would try to sing them. Why ree roh, ah why ree ree roh, Cor mah tee, cor mah tee, Why ree roh, ah why ree ree roh, Cor mah tee, cor mah tee, Ah kiapee kiapee kiapee Eoh ra coh roh kiapee oh Gh Gh Gh Coh roh, Ah kiapee kiapee kiapee Coh ra coh roh oh oh Gh oh oh coh roh. Then she would show us the movements. As we tried, we must have looked very funny. Granny's ample form would shake with laughter. "No! T'is way, watch me!" Aggie, her daughter-in-law, would start the beat again, using a couple of knives on a chopping board. "One two tree go!" And we would try again, very often ending up _ helpless with laughter ourselves, as we strove to attain the grace and rhythm of the dance. Eventually we could manage. Porma was best at learning the movements; Dot, best at learning the words; the rest of us got through somehow. If we couldn't master the words, we sang the tune, if neither—we made believe. Granny would always tell us "Don't watch me—look at peoples out t'ere." But try as we would, we had to watch her, or get lost. Her great patience won through, though. Then with our coconut leaf skirts, paper leis around our necks, floral dresses, colored rags at our ankles, and pretty scarves tied to our wrists, we were on. Granny stole the show—as she should. The energy she put into each dance, sitting down, or standing up, singing with all her might, was something to be seen. With the last breathless "Herp!" she would bring us to a stop. Granny would be laughing with, it seemed to be, the sheer joy of living. Incidentally, we were asked to do these dances quite a few times. Granny—with her wonderful testimony of the gospel, and her great faith in and love for her Heavenly Father. Many a testimony meeting Granny there has not been a dry eye in the chapel, as she has given her testimony in her English, which made it all the more poignant, because she would not get the words she wanted to use. Her greatest joy was her son and his family steadily growing in strength in the gospel, and her most ardent prayers were for the one who had left the fold, and the ones who would not enter. Granny—who poured out her love on all and sundry, a kiss and a hug for everyone. Her crinkly gray hair pulled back to a bunch at the back, very often with an hibiscus flower stuck into it. Her wide—I must admit—toothless grin that was wonderful. She was proud—as any Islander. Proud that two of her grandsons were on a_ building mission. Proud of the priesthood they and her son held, the positions her daughter-in-law and granddaughter held—the unity there was in the family. Still trying to "larn 'im English more better," so she could "understan' more better t' gospel." An enigma in the branch, and a well-loved one. Whose nimble fingers could do the loveliest embroidery, make _ the prettiest leis? Who always had a smile and a cheery word, even when her heart or her body was aching? Who loved everyone, and whom everyone loved. Who? Our Granny. XS 761 October 1969 Mary Roseltha Fuller Burnett, Ben Lomond South Stake, Ogden, Utah, seldom experiences an idle moment. If she is not cooking or baking, she is sewing or quilting, all of which she does very well. Her rolls melt in your mouth, and she designs her own quilts, having completed more than 150, along with 100 pair of embroidered pillowcases. Everyone in her ward looks forward to receiving a telephone call from Sister Burnett on her birthday, an assignment she faithfully and happily fulfills for the bishop. She has served in the presidency of Relief Society and in the other auxiliaries, and has been beloved as a teacher in all of the Church organizations. Sister Burnett has a large family tree, consisting of thirteen children, forty-one grandchildren, ninety great-grandchildren, and six great-great-grandchildren. Q q tee asia' ~ desl Eva Elizabeth Harmon Gledhill, Riverside Stake, Salt Lake City, Utah, has made more quilts than she has time to count. In one year, at the age of seventy-six, she completed thirty large quilts alone, and had pieced the tops for five more. She intends that each of her forty-five grandchildren and twenty-six great-grandchildren will have one of her quilts. She has nine children. Sister Gledhill has been a faithful Relief Society visiting teacher for sixty years and is still teaching. She has also served as Relief Society secretary, and, when as Magazine representative for seven years, her ward was on the Honor Roll. She has served in the presidencies and has taught many years in the other auxiliaries. 762 HZEART ROOM FOR HOME | Alice Morrey Bailey Chapter 5 SYNOPSIS: Several major changes have taken place in the Freeman family as a direct result of Kim, the father, and Mary Ann, the mother, bringing Kim's father from his lovely little home in Mayville, Utah, to Los Angeles to care for him after hospitalization for a fractured hip. Mary Ann has had to resign her teaching position to care for him, even though she has been supporting their son, Tommy, in his last year of college, and their daughter, Rosemary, has expected her to stand the expense of her coming wedding to Cary Marks. Rosemary, who has previously said she had no intention of working, applies for Mary Ann's teaching position, where she has been substituting, and gets it. Tommy blandly accepts a scholarship which has been available to him for the last two quarters. Nevertheless, the family budget is still strained, with Mary Ann feeling the brunt of it. ® For a moment Mary Ann was shocked, even frightened, at the command in Kim's voice. "What's mine is yours, don't you know that, honey?" he went on. "You know what there is to spend. Go ahead and spend it." That was right. She did know how much there was to spend, but it was practically all spent by the time Kim got it. If only they had stayed in their smaller home, which was paid for! But it had seemed the only thing to do, to turn it in on a bigger place as the family grew. Four bedrooms had not been too much, with the children coming often, sometimes for overnight visits. A swimming pool and a double 763 October 1969 garage had seemed necessities at the time, and they were still in use, but the payments were high and seemed endless, with ten more years to go on their mortgage. Taxes were as high as modest rent by themselves. And there was still Christmas coming. "Mother, I had no idea how easy it is for money to slip through your fingers," said Rosemary. "I thought I was wealthy when I got my pay check, but it is nearly gone and nothing saved for my wedding." This was a good lesson for Rosemary to learn before her marriage, thought Mary Ann, but she said nothing. Let Rosemary do her own thinking. And Rosemary did. The next afternoon she called Tommy to help her unload a piece of furniture from the trunk of the car. "Where in the world did you get that antique?" he asked. "It is antique, isn't it?" said Rosemary, her eyes shining. "A solid walnut night stand, and I got it for six dollars at an auction. 'm going to strip and refinish it. One of the other teachers told me how, and Cary is going to help me." oe oe grandfather wheeled his walker near and looked at it. "T declare!" he said. "I have its exact mate at home. She bought it when we were first married." "Grandfather! Do you really?" "I have, really, and if you like it you may have it." Rosemary threw her arms ecstatically around her grandfather and kissed him. When Kim got home an hour 764 later he brought a checkbook for Mary Ann. "Joint account," he said. "And, Mary Ann, I hit the boss up for some overtime I heard him talking about and he says fine. Time and a half until Christmas. It will help us over the hump." "Are you sure, Kim? Can you - stand it? You come home dead tired every night, and it will be like having two jobs." "Why not?" Kim said. "Look how long you ran this house and taught school to boot. Any woman who works outside her home has two jobs, really. Don't think I didn't notice the strain of it on you. A man should be stronger than a woman, more able to work long hours." "Kim, you're the most wonderful man in the world," Mary Ann said, and meant it. That was all right for a temporary measure, but not for always, and it wasn't the final answer. Maybe, after the children were gone, things would even out or they would find some other answer, but this would do for now. Christmas was wonderful, with all the children home for Christmas Eve, the little ones performing in turn, singing the carols, playing their amateur, and not so amateur pieces on the piano and other instruments. Grandfather Freeman sat and listened, unashamedly wiping his eyes from the steady outpouring of happy tears to see his grandchildren and _greatgrandchildren all under one joyous roof, the progeny of his only son, Kim. "T don't know as you need snow for Christmas," he said. "T guess they did without it in Bethlehem when Christ was born." Grandfather Freeman was not the only one to feel sentimental at this time of celebration. It was a last Christmas in some other ways, the last time they would be together for the occasion before Rosemary and Cary would be married. Goodness knows where Tommy would be by another Christmas. He was already getting tentative offers, so many that it was a matter of choice for him. Kim and Mary Ann had reason to be proud of their whole family.
