Doxey (Reading Assignment: Doctrine and Covenants, Section 135.) Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 OBJECTIVE: The Latter-day Saint woman strives to strengthen her testimony that Joseph Smith is a Prophet and that The Church of Jesus Christ was restored through him. INTRODUCTION One of the inspired documents of the latter days was written by President John Taylor at the time he was a member of the Council of the Twelve. (D&C 1844 ed.; Doctrine and Covenants Commentary, Hyrum M. Smith and Janne M. Sjodahl, Rev. Ed., p. 855.) During the remainder of this year, we shall have an opportunity to consider the great truths found in that scripture, Doctrine and Covenants, Section 135. When a man speaks or writes by the Holy Ghost, it becomes scripture—the will, mind, word, and voice of the Lord, "and the power of God unto salvation." (D&C 68:4-5.) When imbued with the Spirit of the Lord a person can know the _ truth uttered by that Spint. In this manner the truth is revealed and known by the honest in heart. Ultimately, this is the final test of religious truth. (D&C 50:19- 22.) Measured by this standard, the member of the Church may know that Elder Taylor was under the inspiration of the Holy Ghost when he _ penned the document about the martyrdom of Joseph and his brother Hyrum Smith. (D&C, Section 135.) By his' apostolic calling Elder Taylor was qualified for this work and, also, because he and Elder Willard Richards, later to be a Counselor to President Brigham Young, were with the martyred brothers on June 27, 1844, at Carthage Jail, Illinois. 777 October 1969 JOSEPH SMITH EVALUATED President John Taylor as guided by the Spirit wrote the following about Joseph Smith: Joseph Smith, the Prophet and Seer of the Lord, has done more, save Jesus only, for the salvation of men in this world, than any other man that ever lived in it.... (D&C 135:3.) Centuries before Joseph Smith ° was born, Joseph, who was sold into captivity by his brothers, foresaw that the seer of the latter days should be named after him and that his father's name would be Joseph. (2 Ne. 3:15.) Of significance in this prophecy is the Lord's statement about Joseph Smith's work and his appraisal of his faithfulness: And I will give unto him a commandment that he shall do none other work, save the work which I shall command him. And I will make him great in mine eyes; for he shall do my work. (2 Ne. 3:8.) It was the testimony of Joseph of Egypt that his descendant of the latter days would attain an esteemed position in mortal life, for:... A seer shall the Lord my God raise up, who shall be a choice seer unto the fruit of my loins. Yea, Joseph truly said: Thus saith the Lord unto me: A choice seer will I raise up out of the fruit of thy loins; and he shall be esteemed highly among the fruit of thy loins. Ahd unto him will I give commandment that he shall do a work for the fruit of thy loins, his brethren, which shail be of great worth unto them, even to the bringing of them to the knowledge of the covenants which I have made with thy fathers. (2 Ne. 3:6-7.) (Italics added.) The Prophet Joseph Smith knew that as other prophets were foreordained to their callings, so also he received a divine 778 calling before he was born. On one occasion he said: I suppose that I was ordained to 'this very office in that Grand Council. (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 6, p. 364 [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereafter referred to as DHC].) Class Discussion Support your belief in the doctrine of foreordination to callings in this life. GREATNESS AMONG THE PROPHETS The inspired evaluation of Joseph Smith that he has done more, except Jesus, for the salvation of men in this world raises a question as to the position of other prophets of God. Each prophet has attained greatness as he has fulfilled his calling. Special recognition, for example, has been given to the prophet Isaiah about whom Nephi said his soul delighted in his words. (2 Ne. 25:5.) The resurrected Savior told the Nephites on this continent that "... Great are the words of Isaiah." (3 Ne. 23:1.) Why were Isaiah's words great? Primarily, because he foresaw events of the dispensation of the fulness of times. (Isa. 2: 1-4; 29.) His greatness as a prophet is also evident because he served faithfully the people of his own generation. Another Old 'Testament prophet Ezekiel was great because he also fulfilled his calling in his day, as well as to foretell events of the future concerning the last days. (Ezek. 37:15-28.) NEW TESTAMENT PROPHETS Peter, John, and Paul ful- filled their missions in honor to the people of the meridian dispensation. Also, each one of them was permitted to see the greatest dispensation, that of the last days. (Acts 3:19-21; Rev. 14:6-7; Eph. 1:9-10.) Although all of the works of the former-day prophets are not known to us, we can see wherein they were great. Their personal ministry was confined, as in the case of Joseph Smith, to a relatively few people, but their influence has been felt through their writings and the significance of their acts in this mortal state. Admittedly, it is difficult to place one prophet above another, for each performs his work in a particular situation. Therefore, one might say that the "greatest" prophet to a people is the living prophet. The principal reason for this belief is due to the opportunity for the living prophet to present solutions to the problems of his day through divine guidance. The prophets who have succeeded Joseph Smith have each met the particular need of his day; so it was with the ancient prophets. JOSEPH SMITH'S GREATNESS Obviously, a prophet must be judged in relation to the time in which he lives. If we believe that Joseph Smith has done more, save Jesus only, for the salvation of men in this world, upon what basis may we say it? Bear in mind that it is said that Joseph Smith did a greater work for the salvation of men in this world. This statement rules out consideration of Adam, certainly one of the Lesson Department greatest of prophets, for his work involved the _ premortal state, and will involve the future. (Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, p. 157; D&C 88: 110-15.) President John Taylor apparently had in mind Joseph Smith's accomplishments during mortal life. It was not that he was greater than any other person in the plan of salvation, but only that his greatness was reflected in his mortal ministry. What then of Joseph Smith? By virtue of his relationship with other dispensations, and _ the place of the dispensation ushered in by the Prophet Joseph, we shall discover the reasons for his greatness. Our dispensation is the final period in which God will conclude his work for the salvation of men. In addition, it is to contain the truths revealed in past dispensations. This fact was spoken of by both Peter and Paul as the restoration of all things, spoken of by the prophets since the world began. (Acts 3:19-21.) Paul said this period of time would bring together all things God had revealed, consequently, it would be known as the "fulness of times." (Eph. 1:9-10.) Questions for Discussion Because we have the privilege of coming to earth during this final period for the salvation of men, what special responsibilities are ours? What would characterize this dispensation? Not only would this work involve the salvation of the living but also the dead. It was necessary that the Savior offer his atonement for man and go 779 October 1969 into the spirit world to initiate the preaching of the gospel to those who died without a knowledge of it. (1 Peter 3:18-20; D&C 128:5.) As far as is known, little work was performed for the dead during the time of the apostles. Few references appear in the New Testament regarding it. (1 Cor. 15:29; Heb. 11:39-40.) As far as the salvation of man is concerned, Joseph Smith's period was to include on a large scale benefits for the dead as well as the living. Class Discussion Why would a Latter-day Saint believe that Joseph Smith has done more for the salvation of men in this world, save Jesus only, than any other man that has ever lived in it? (D&C 135:3.) A REMARKABLE PREDICTION In Joseph Smith's own account of a visit to him by the Angel Moroni, at the age of seventeen, Joseph Smith said that Moroni said:... God had a work for me to do; and that my name should be had for good and evil among all nations, kindreds, and tongues, or that it should be both good and evil spoken of among all people. (Pearl of Great Price, Joseph Smith 2:33.) The fulfillment of this divine prediction was realized in Joseph Smith's life and continues to be fulfilled. Great men have been lauded and condemned by their contemporaries. Abraham Lincoln was denounced by many who thought he was unjust and illiterate, while others considered him a great man of destiny. The same may be said of Joseph Smith. To the unrighteous and prejudiced, he was a 780 subject for persecution. But to his faithful followers he was God's anointed seer. Many, not of his own Church, however, also saw his greatness. One of these wrote for the New York Herald from Nauvoo, Illinois, the home of the saints, this personal description of the Prophet: Joseph Smith, the President of the Church, Prophet, Seer and Revelator, is thirty-six years of age, six feet high in pumps, weighing two hundred and twelve pounds. He is a man of the highest order of talents, and great independence of character, firm in his integrity, and devoted to his religion; in one word he is a man per se as President Tyler would say. As a public speaker, he is bold, powerful, and convincing— possessing both the suaviter in modo and the fortiter in re; as a leader, wise and prudent, yet fearless; as a military commander, brave and determined; and, as a citizen, worthy, affable, and kind— bland in his manners, and noble of bearing. (March 19, 1842.) Concerning the work being donein Nauvoo by the Latter-day Saints, a correspondent of this same newspaper wrote that the priests and philosophers of the day could well take a lesson from Joseph Smith. Of the Prophet it was said he seemed to have... Hit the nail exactly on the head, by uniting faith and _ practice—fancy and fact—religion and _ philosophy— heaven and earth, so as to form the term of a new religious civilization, bound together in love and tolerance—in industry and energy—that may _ revolutionize the whole earth one of these days. (January 19, 1842.) FURTHER EVALUATION In support of the evaluation of Joseph Smith as discussed in this lesson, President Taylor gave the following: To seal the testimony of this book and the Book of Mormon, we announce the martyrdom of Joseph Smith the Prophet, and Hyrum Smith the Patriarch. (D&C 135:1.) He lived great, and he died great in the eyes of God and his people; and like most of the Lord's anointed in ancient times, has sealed his mission and _ his works with his own blood; and so has his brother Hyrum. In life they were not divided, and in death they were not separated! (D&C 135:3.) Does the death and testimony of these two prophets affect the salvation of men in this world? An answer to this question involves an understanding of what President Joseph Fielding Smith, of the First Presidency and President of the Council of the Twelve, has termed the divine law of witnesses. (Doctrine of Salvation Vol. 1, pp. 203-28.) This law was stated by Paul as: In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established. (2 Cor. 13:1.) If we had a perfect record of each dispensation, we would know that there has been more than one witness to testify for the Lord. Methuselah, grandfather of Noah, and Lamech, father of Noah, were righteous men who witnessed with Noah in _ his dispensation. In the Mosaic dispensation, Moses and his brother Aaron served in a similar capacity. We have a much more complete account of the divine law of witnesses in the meridian dispensation. In addition to Jesus, his Father testified of the divine Sonship of the Savior upon several occasions. (John 5:30-33; 8:14-19; 12:26-30; Matt. 3: 15-17.) The twelve apostles were also witnesses, and of these Peter, Lesson Department James, and John received a special witness when they heard the Father's voice and _ conversed with Moses and Elijah. (Matt. 17:1-8.) In our own dispensation there were many witnesses to testify of the Lord. Among these testators was Oliver Cowdery, who served with Joseph Smith as a witness of the restoration of the keys of the priesthood. (D&C 13; 27:12-13; 110.) The Three Special Witnesses to The Book of Mormon and also the Eight Witnesses may also be mentioned as God's witnesses to his truth in the last days. A TESTIMONY SEALED In a special way, however, the principle of witnesses was applied in the martyrdom of Joseph and Hyrum Smith. Hyrum was not only the Patriarch to the Church but also Assistant President of the Church, having taken the place of Oliver Cowdery. The divine law of witnesses is expressed in the New Testament as: For where a testament is, there must also of necessity be the death of the testator. For a testament is of force after men are dead: otherwise it is of no strength at all while the testator liveth. (Heb. 9:16-17.) After the martyrdom of these prophets, the Lord revealed to Brigham Young that Joseph Smith had sealed his testimony with his blood "... That he might be honored and the wicked might be condemned." (D&C 136:39.) Class Discussion How has the sealing of the martyrs' 781 October 1969 testimony affected the salvation of men in this world? NON-LDS EVALUATION In the spring of 1844, Josiah Quincy, mayor of Boston and a non-Latter-day Saint, visited the Prophet in the city of Nauvoo. He later published his observations as follows: It is by no means improbable that some future textbook for the use of generations yet unborn will contain a question something like this: What historical American of the nineteenth century has exerted the most powerful influence upon the destinies of his countrymen? And it is by no means impossible that the answer to the interrogatory may be thus written: 'Joseph Smith, the Mormon Prophet.'... The wonderful influence which this founder of a religion exerted and still exerts, throws him into relief before us, not as a rogue to be criminated but as a phenomenon to be explained.... Joseph Smith, claiming to be an inspired teacher, faced adversity such as few men have ever attained, and, finally, forty-three days after I saw him, went cheerfully to a martyr's death. Josiah Quincy concluded his observations by saying: Born in the lowest ranks of poverty, without book-learning and with the homeliest of all human names, he had made himself at the age of thirty-nine a power upon the earth. Of the multitudinous family of Smith, none had so won human hearts and shaped human lives as this Joseph. His_ influence, whether for good or for evil, is potent today, and the end is not yet. I have endeavored to give the details of my visit to the Mormon prophet with absolute accuracy. If the reader does not know just what to make of Joseph Smith, I cannot help him out of the difficulty. I myself stand helpless before the puzzle. (Conference Report, April 1930, pp. 190-92; Figures of the Past by Josiah Quincy, University Press, John Wilson And Sons, Cambridge, Copyrighted 1883.) IMPLEMENTATION Biblical prophets foretold the restoration of the gospel and The Church of Jesus Christ with its priesthood powers. To initiate this work, the Lord raised up Joseph Smith, Jr., foretold by the Old Testament prophet, Joseph of Egypt, as recorded in The Book of Mormon. It was said he would perform the work of salvation appointed him as a choice seer in the Lord's eyes. This modern Prophet was destined to lead the greatest dispensation of the gospel, for he would perform a work for the salvation of the dead as well as the living. His period of time would see the culmination of all of God's work on this earth for the salvation of men. Mighty in its scope and marvelous in its impact upon the souls of men, the work of the dispensation of the fulness of times would eclipse all other gospel periods. Latter-day Saints believe that "Joseph Smith, the Prophet and Seer of the Lord has done more, save Jesus only, for the salvation of men in this world, than any other man that ever lived in it." CEBHIO 782 VISITING TEACHER MESSAGE — Truths to Live By (Correlated With the Family Home Evening Manual, 1968-69) Message 4—Labor for That Which Perisheth Not Alice Colton Smith Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 OBJECTIVE: To remember that throughout one's life one makes eternal choices. When you were little did you read the fairy tales, the legends, and the myths that told of kings and queens, of castles, palaces, and feasts? Did you then dress up in your mother's old dress, make a crown of paper or flowers, and play that you were a queen? Didn't that seem the epitome of all that you could ever want? Was some of that make-believe stardust still clinging to you when you read Mosiah 28:10 and discovered that "... King Mosiah had no one to confer the kingdom upon, for there was not any of his sons who would accept of the kingdom."? Then as you read further, didn't the castles and palaces fade as you saw the king's sons, mighty in faith, humble in spirit, persuasive in teaching the gospel, bring many souls into the kingdom of God? You remembered, "And now, if your joy will be great with one soul that you have brought unto me into the kingdom of my Father, how great will be your joy if you should bring many souls unto me!" (D&C 18:16.) Have you ever secretly sympathized with the very rich ruler who having kept the commandments of Moses came to Jesus and asked, "... Good Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?" (Luke 18:18.) Jesus answered him, "... Yet lackest thou one thing: sell all thou hast, and distribute unto the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come, follow me." (Luke 18:22.) And when Jesus saw that he could not, he said, "... How hardly shall they that have riches enter into the kingdom of God!" (Luke 18:24.) Have you thought how difficult it would be to sell all you have and give to the poor? The great prophet-leader Nephi had a devoted, faithful brother Jacob who, while on earth, lived worthy to see his Redeemer. This younger prophet taught, "Wherefore, do not spend money for that which is of no worth, nor your labor for that which cannot satisfy... Feast upon that which perisheth not, neither can be corrupted...." (2 Nephi 9:51.) 783 October 1969 By. Joining the Church we have made the first great choice in this life of "that which perisheth not." Each day, each week we make new choices that will determine our future joy or sorrow. Let us consider some of these important decisions: 1. Do we expand our capacity for love and compassion by continually searching to find new ways to help others? 2. Do we follow Jacob's teaching and spend our money for that which perisheth not? 3. Do we labor to increase our knowledge, our faith, and our understanding of others? 4. Do we grow in self-discipline so that our anger is schooled, our charity increased, our. Peaceful efforts extended, our enemies forgiven and loved? 5. Do we "... Visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and... Keep... [ourselves] unspotted from the world."? (James 1:27.) 6. Do we plan and live our lives so that we will endure to the end? The good we choose perisheth not. HOMEMAKING—Development Through Homemaking Education Woman's Role in Family Preparedness Discussion 4— "She Considereth a Field and Buyeth It: With the Fruit of Her Hands She Planteth a Vineyard."' (Prov. 31:16) Celestia J. Taylor Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 OBJECTIVE: To point out the woman's — in planning and managing a successful family budget. INTRODUCTION A woman's role as a successful homemaker means more than being a loving companion to her husband and a devoted mother to their children; it also means working with her husband in the management of a well-ordered home. It means helping to establish a pattern of living conducive to the best interests of the family members who dwell in 784 that home. This pattern of living recognizes the goals and objectives that are vital to its well-being. A wise homemaker knows that these goals involve careful planning and management of the family resources. She also knows that this can be best accomplished through the use of a family budget worked out to fit their own special needs, interests, and _ desires. Unless we who are the homemakers are aware of our responsibility in the planning and managing of a_ successful family budget, we will not be able to solve the financial problems which inevitably arise in every household. We need to develop in our family members an understanding of their individual responsibilities by letting them share in the planning and formulating of the budget. We need to show them what it costs the family to live and why it is necessary to set up a plan of procedure whereby we can reach our goals and objectives. OUR PLAN OF PROCEDURE In the homemaking discussion printed in The Relief Society Magazine, October 1966, we learned that in planning any budget, certain procedures usually apply to most families. 1. Estimating family income. With our husbands we should make an appraisal of the family income, which will include take-home pay from wages, regular salary, commissions, and parttime earnings, as well as any revenue from pensions, rental income, dividends, interest, or any additional income which might be forthcoming. 2. Calculating fixed expenditures. We should make our family members aware that there are certain expenditures which must be paid regularly— monthly, quarterly, semiannually, or annually—and that these are fixed or obligatory expenses which take precedence over others. The hst of fixed expenditures should include tithing and other Church contributions, taxes, housing payments, insurance, and debt. 3. Planning daily expenditures, including incidentals. As housewives we should know that day-to-day Lesson Department living costs offer many opportunities to practice wise spending. Such expenditures include those made fo food, household services, clothing, automobile and other transportation, medical care, personal allowances, family recreation and cultural development, and such variables as differing localities, climates, and nationalities might add to or take from the list 4. Planning savings and emergency funds. We must be aware that every family should make some provision for saving in their financial plan if they are to achieve a sense of security When possible, it should be large enough to cover both emergency funds and long-term goals such as education, missions, vacations, retirement, and other desired attainments. We can help our families to see the wisdom of establishing a regular savings plan, even though it means the renouncing of some immediate desires. Many budget experts warn against trying to be too detailed and penny-counting, a practice which tends to discourage longterm persistence. A too-complicated budget is quickly abandoned. CONCLUSION Wise planning and conscientious effort on the part of all members of the family are required to formulate and carry out a successful family budget plan, but it is the homemakers—the mothers and wives—who really put the plan into action. We can be sure that our husbands will be enthusiastic in their approval and that the other family members will be willing to cooperate. Once it is accomplished, it will bring the income, expenditures, and savings of the family into balance and will result in blessings of lasting benefit and fulfillment to all its members. 785 October 1969 APPLICATION The "Simple Monthly Budget Plan" below might be a helpful teaching aid for each sister to fill out for her own confidential use with her family. (This is a reprint from The Relief Society Magazine, October 1966, pp. 788-89.) Lesson Department March through December are recorded the same as January and February. In the beginning a daily record should be kept and the totals recorded in the form. (A looseleaf notebook will serve the purpose.) Most banks and insurance companies provide free budget forms for the asking. Christensen (Reference: Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, Selections from the Writings and Messages of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Melchizedek Priesthood Course of Study, 1969-70, Lesson 23.) Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 OBJECTIVE: To emphasize the value of work in meeting the requirements of happiness and of divine admonition. INTRODUCTION Having been introduced to President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. (lesson 1, The Relief Society 78 Magazine, July 1967), we know of his general attitude toward work. We know that he believed in the value of work, that he was introduced to responsibility at an early age and that he liked to work. This lesson develops the idea that to work is following divine admonition, that it is a practical necessity, a privilege, and that it may become an _ enjoyable activity. The general theme applies to all—man, woman, and child. Discussion in this lesson, however, will generally be focused toward work within the home and will focus upon the mother's specific position in introducing the children to one of the great challenges of life. REMEMBER THE STORY Do you remember the story of "The Little Ren Hen'? One version narrates that: One day the Little Red Hen was scratching in the farmyard when she found a grain of wheat. She asked, '"'Who will help me plant this wheat?" "Not I," said the duck. "Not I," said the cat. "Not I," said the dog. "All right, I will do it myself," said the Little Red Hen. Then she asked successively: "Who will help me cut the wheat?" "Who will help me knead and bake the bread?" To each of these questions she received the same negative reply. When the loaf was baked, savory, and brown, she then asked, "Who will help me eat the bread?" "T will, " said the duck. "T will," said the cat. "T will," said the dog. The story concludes with this rhyme: Lazy folks must hungry go For they would not help me sow, Neither would they help me reap They had rather rest and sleep. All alone I baked the bread, Lazy folks should not be fed. 787 October 1969 Question for Brief Discussion How would you define work? An international dictionary defines work as "exertion or effort directed to produce or accomplish something." With this definition in mind, the duck, the cat, and the dog, were justified in considering the tasks required to produce the loaf of bread as work. And in the story they did not want to work. This story implies that eating the loaf was less effort or, at least, a more desirable activity. This nursery story obviously tries to teach children the idea that work is important and that each one should assume some responsibility in producing the good things of life. What mother has not observed, with amazement, the amount of exuberant energy expended by her children playing jump-therope or the various running and hiding games, who, only a few moments earlier, said they were too tired to sweep out the garage or to wash the dishes? Questions 1. What makes the difference? 2. How important is the mother's attitude in forming the children's reaction to "work" activities? 3. How will knowing that willingness to work and liking to work are characteristics of maturity help a mother teach her children to work? 4. How will this influence her own attitude toward what might otherwise be considered irksome, monotonous housework? How may a mother teach children to see that opportunities for service to others and for personal satisfactions are endless for those who are willing to work? On 788 OLD AS TIME Eden's gate was no sooner closed than man's earthly work began, for Adam was now introduced to the idea that he must work all the days of his earthly life. Among other things spoken by the Lord to Adam are these words: By the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, until thou shalt return unto the ground....(Moses 4:25.) Since thorns and thistles were to be natural obstacles, the implication is that providing the necessities of life from the earth would not be an easy task. Nor has it been throughout the centuries. In calling our attention to this statement of the Lord, President Clark states, "I believe that we are here to work, and I believe there is no escape from it." (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 23.) Being able to direct personal effort toward the achievement of definite goals other than to obtain food and shelter is a characteristic distinguishing the life of man from that of the lower animals. The English poet Milton pays tribute to man and to work in the following poem from "'Paradise Lost": When Adam thus to Eve: "Fair consort, the hour Of night, and all things now retire to rest, Mind us of like repose; since God hath set Labour and rest, as day and night, to men Successive; and the timely dew of sleep, Now falling with soft slumbrous weight, inclines: Our eyelids: long other creatures all day Rove idle unemployed, and less need rest; Man hath his daily work of body or of mind Appointed, which declares his dignity, And the regard of Heaven on all his ways; While other animals inactive range, And of their doings God takes no account. Of the ways of men the Lord does take account and he has counseled us as to the spending of our precious days and years. A person who will not work, providing he is physically and mentally able to work, may rightly be termed an idler and the Lord has given, in our day, a direct commandment regarding idleness. In the Doctrine and Covenants we read: Now, I, the Lord, am not well pleased with the inhabitants of Zion, for there are idlers among them; and their children are also growing up in wickedness; they also seek not earnestly the riches of eternity, but their eyes are full of greediness. These things ought not to be, and must be done away from among them... (D&C 68:31-32.) INDISPENSABLE IN COLONIZATION How important is work to the world in which we live? How rewarding can it be to individuals and to groups? President Clark speaks of work as indispensable to pioneer life and cites the struggles of the early members of the Church. From lesson 23 of the 1969-70 Melchizedeck Priesthood course of study we quote from an address given in 1960: A hundred years ago armed mobs plundered, burned, and murdered us. I speak without heartburning or malice and with full charity. Three times we were driven by force Lesson Department of arms from our homes, and all our property that we could not carry on our backs or in our wagons was taken from us. When ninety-five years ago our Prophet-leader was slain by an unrestrained local mob and we_ began our westward march over plain and mountain under that genius in leadership, Brigham Young, we moved under our own power, without subsidy, without loan, wished on our way only by the maledictions of those who drove us out from our homes and then appropriated, without payment for it, the property they forced us to leave behind. Arriving in the valleys of the mountains, we planted all our wheat, with enough flour to last only to harvest; our nearest food supply was one thousand miles away, reached only by ox teams; thousands of others were on the way to join us. A pest of locusts came, devouring everything on their way. Famine raised its gaunt frame. Then came the miracle of the gulls, the crops were saved, starvation was beaten back—a miracle as real as any that aided the ancient Israel in her escape from the bondage of Egypt. But even then we lived on short rations of the simplest foods, eked out by wild roots dug from the hillsides. So we struggled on against want and misery; toil and hardship were with us daily. But the Church survived; the people prospered. Character endured intact. We took care of our own poor. In times of scarcity neighbors helped one another. Time and time again, we _ passed through the fiery furnace; we came out of it each time, refined, with the dross burned away, re-inspirited, sanctified. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 23.) Experiences, in many ways similar, were encountered by other groups colonizing western America. In fact, pioneering life at all times has taxed the resourcefulness of the people and has required all individuals to work individually and cooperatively in order to survive. Out of their combined efforts, com- 789 October 1969 munities have been built, states and nations have evolved. Class Participation Consider pioneer conditions, briefly. Discuss the need and the willingness to work in order to survive in contrast to the trend toward idleness in times of plenty.. WORLD OF DISCOVERY For the individual, work may be a door opening into fields more vast than the mind of man has yet envisioned. Though faith may be the great motivator, work is the spade of discovery, for it is work that makes the dream materialize. An _ intelligent person cannot work in any capacity without learning. To work is to discover. It is through individual effort and application that new vistas are glimpsed, horizons widened, and the ability to accomplish enlarged. Examples of what work has produced and the possibilities of future accomplishment are breathtaking. Class Participation Discuss the following personal statements: 1. I stand in awe when I consider how much intelligent effort goes into producing even one of the innumerable commodities we use in the home, the school, and the shop, from simple electrical and manual appliances to such complex mechanism as is found in the computer or the satellites that man has made to orbit into space. 2. The libraries of the world, taken collectively, house billions of books. They did not create themselves. They are the product of intellectual effort and of manual skill. I am grateful to all the individuals who have been involved in their production. I am a student, and, as I view the 790 stacks of books before me, I realize that books contain much of the best that man has thought and said. I know that ideas and facts contained in them can be mine only if I put forth personal effort to make them mine. At best, only a fraction of the knowledge contained will be transferred to me, a thought which spurs me to better use of my time. 3. The innumerable yards of fabric which one sees in a fabric store are evidence of work already accomplished. Without further labor they constitute mere yardage. With additional work of merchant, designer, and seamstress, the world may be clothed. (Other examples may be suggested.) WORK, AN AID TO EMOTIONAL HEALTH Glen C. Beeley, director of a well-recognized arts and craft institution, has some important things to say about work and a woman's emotional world. She believes that work, especially creative work, can and does perform miracles in the lives of unhappy, frustrated, and even, physically handicapped women. She states: I wish you could see the transformations I see in people. I believe that individuals cannot be truly happy unless they are constructively busy. Although some individuals are more inherently creative, everyone can be creative who is willing to work. Many people naturally find creative ways of expressing themselves and of usefully using their available time. Others, less naturally creative, need to be led to creativity, and, thus, to happiness. They need to feel that they can do things with their hands. This assurance and this accomplishment lead to a degree of creative experimentation and of mental exploration. They think of new or different ways of making the same article. But [concludes the director] it is not the articles of art or of usefulness that are really important, it is what creative work does for the individual. This is most rewarding. Individuals (including older people) should and do sense a personal growth from giving of themselves to others and to objectives. Thus they develop a fineness within themselves and a sensibility to the fineness in others. They learn to appreciate what others also are doing and can do. They need to feel, and they do, that they can, figuratively, "Sail their own ships." The foregoing comments regarding arts and crafts, generally, refer to leisure time activity, although professional status and specific occupations may and sometimes are the result. Many women make special effort to enroll in such classes. They find personal satisfaction in creativity as do women who engage in the homemaking activities of Relief Society. What may we say of the necessary, daily tasks of the homemaker? How useful is this work? How important is the attitude of the wife or mother in relation to this part of the world's work? RELEVANT TO WORK Many thought-evoking statements have been made regarding the need for and the important results of work. From the following statements, select for discussion as you desire and as time may permit: Lesson Department When I go into my garden with a spade, and dig a bed, I feel such an exhilaration and health that I discover that I have been defrauding myself all this time in letting others do for me what I should have done with my own hands. —Ralph Waldo Emerson Idleness and pride tax with a heavier hand than kings and parliaments. —Benjamin Franklin Sucess is better when it's harder to achieve. —Aristotle Things may come to those who wait, but only the things left by those who hustle. —Abraham Lincoln I have no secret of success but hard work. —Edward Turner As an author, people often say to me, "So you write books!" I reply, "No, I rewrite books." Little can they know how much rewriting an author must do. —Anon Work is next to genius. —J. Reuben Clark, Jr. You cannot be successful at anything and waste your time. —dJ. Reuben Clark, Jr. For Home Doing Implement this lesson by appraising your own attitude toward work. Ask yourself, "Am I depriving myself of specific satisfactions and blessings because I am unwilling to work sufficiently hard to obtain them?" If so, select one needed task, and work! Thomas There is no more sure tie between friends than when they are united in their objects and wishes. —Cicero Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting, January 1970 Southern Hemisphere: May 1970 OBJECTIVE: To show that those who can communicate can work together, and those who can work together make civilization possible. ART "Advice to a Young Artist'' by Honoré Daumier (1808-1879) French, National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C., Gift of Duncan Phillips. Painting reproduced in the June 1969 Relief Society Magazine, page 447. Commentary on art selection by Floyd E. Breinholt, Chairman, Department of Art, Brigham Young University. Honoré Daumier at the age of seven decided to be an artist. To gain background for his chosen field, he frequented the poorer quarters of Paris and haunted the corridors of the Louvre. He studied Rembrandt and Michelangelo, nature, and the manners and customs of his period. Although he is better known as a lithographer and political cartoonist, it has been said that he was one of the greatest painters of the 19th century. Daumier expressed very deep feelings in a spirit of satire and ridicule. His caricatures are without hatred or spite, although they are biting. There is a direct simplicity in the expressions of what he saw and felt. All of his work has social significance. His art was and still is a very direct means of communication of ideas, a universal language. Artists today use art for propaganda purposes just as Daumier did in his time. The painting, ''Advice to a Young Artist,' is perhaps more mild than many of his works. This is not a portrait of any two particular people but more a generalization of a typical situation in the world of work. We can all learn from others who go before us, especially if they are willing to share their knowledge with us. In this very commonplace idea, expressed in a simple, earthy manner, one senses a certain kinship between the artist and the common working man, a certain reality that makes the commonplace beautiful when stripped to the bare essentials. None of his works is pretty. All tinsel and glitter have been left out and only simple truth remains. Perhaps this is why many have placed Daumier in the school of realism. All of his works, full of compassion for the downtrodden, are attempts at communicating the unvarnished truth as he saw it. As in all great art, Daumier in his work gives us not merely a photographic likeness of his subject but an interpretation of it in which he communicates what he knows, thinks, and feels. 792 t{NTRODUCTORY COMMENTS From childhood, many of us have heard that "sticks and stones may break my bones but names can never hurt me." A far more accurate assessment of reality is given in the Apocrypha when we are reminded that "the stroke of the whip maketh marks in the flesh, but the stroke of the tongue breaketh the bones." Most physical pain is less excruciating than having someone we love and_ respect speak harshly to us. To feel unloved or unwanted is often more crippling than physical impairment. Perhaps modern _ research rightly emphasizes the role of communication in_ establishing positive human relationships. Such communication need not be in words—how rarely are our deepest feelings easily translated in speech—but we must use words to discuss non-verbal communication, so the importance of language in communication cannot be minimized. To concede this, however, is not to admit that the basic problem in poor communication is failure to convey information clearly. If this is assumed, we focus our attention so totally on methods of communication that we risk losing ends in means. Although it has been popular to assert recently that the medium we use is an integral part of the message we are trying to convey, it probably needs to be said also that an Insignificant message belittles any medium that carries it. The word communication originally suggested sharing Lesson Department or making common an idea or an experience. If the idea we want to share can touch a positive chord in another's' background, the chances for successful communication are immeasurably increased. It is when we try to get through to those who do not share our ideals and values that we have extreme difficulty. It is probably not very accurate to speak of a "communication problem" under such circumstances, lest we assume that we need to refine our method rather than examine our beliefs. The selections we have chosen for this lesson make less effort to examine procedures than to assess results. "THE SECRET HEART" In the beginning poem "The Secret Heart" by Robert P. Tristram Coffin the father is hardly conscious of how deeply he is revealing his: love to a half-awake child. But the youngster's identification with his father is so total that he has no difficulty in interpreting the look on his parent's face. As the next to the last couplet suggests, the moment of illumination was not long, but it was enough to light ''all about." The result of such a reassuring insight has been a lifetime of happy memories which are symbolized by a brief vision of his father's "secret heart." The tone of this tender poem helps us understand how prepared the boy was for his revelation. The real impact of this moment depends very little on the situation, even though it yields a symbol that is a memora- 793 October 1969 ble one. The kind of fatherson devotion that is evident here inevitably finds its expression. Question for Discussion Why is unqualified devotion difficult to hide? Comment on some of the less obvious ways in which we communicate our identification with that which we love. "ANOTHER APRIL" In "Another April" by Jesse Stuart we touch briefly on a number of communicative levels. The boy understands his childlike grandfather as only a child could. If his youthful candor is disconcerting, he sees without the restraints which experience imposes, and _ he reacts freely and openly, if also superficially. In the relationships of mother and child there are hints that the young boy understands far more than his simple conversation would suggest and that the mother senses this. Her relationship to her father is now a mildly ambiguous one: she must be both mother and daughter. She doesn't let her practical need to care for him destroy her sensitivity to what he has been to her and still is. The grandfather's relationship with the natural world he had seemed to control totally as a young man has become more passive, but possibly more discriminating. In the terrapin, the old man has a natural counterpart, a checkpoint in his renewed intercourse with the world which is the more precious because it can no longer be taken for granted. 794 Question for Discussion The grandfather seems to have established meaningful relationships with everyone and everything in this story. Why has he been so successful? FROM "THE AUTOCRAT OF THE BREAKFAST TABLE" In this short essay Oliver Wendell Holmes helps us see that "full" communication may not be "good" communication. If we try to share sacred feelings with those who are not prepared to respect them, we may lend ourselves to grievous exploitation. A man or a woman is often as vulnerable as an open wound to a marriage partner. In our awareness of the totality of relationship that a good marriage demands, we must also be aware that there is no other human relationship that should ask so much. Letting down restraints in an attempt to understand associates is neither an automatic route to self-enlightenment or a guarantee of better inter-personal relationships. Limits of taste and self-respect should inhibit the intimacies we share. Confession is not a shortcut to that communication which is earned by trust, rooted in similar commitment, and justified by joint responsibility. Question for Discussion Why are we tempted to give keys to our "side-doors" to those who might not use them appropriately? "CAN YOU GET ALONG WITH YOUR IN-LAWS?" In his popular version of a careful research study, "Can You Get Along With Your In-Laws?" Edward Fales provides persuasive evidence that all communication problems with inlaws appear to yield to loving acceptance by all concerned. The lists of "do's'" and "don'ts" he provides are obviously the result of much experience, but, as he himself suggests, the "one greatest lesson" in the Cornell survey he is reporting on is that people who refused to think of their relatives as "in-laws" but only as "members of our family" were able to establish warm, happy relationships with them. Question for Discussion How can we prepare our own sons and daughters to realize that, in marrying, they marry a family as well as a person? "MARK TWAIN'S FAMILY LETTERS" The letters exchanged by Mark Twain and his wife, Livy, are dificult to match in all literature for tender concern and sensitivity to one another. Each almost aches with the desire to understand and help. Mark found it difficult to believe, and Livy was often embarrassed by his lack of taste. She helped him on both counts, some modern critics notwithstanding. Mark aided a gently spoiled child, who took herself very seriously, turn into a resourceful, stimulating woman. In these remarkable letters there is not only growth but a truly notable desire on the part of both to match that ideal that each has of the other. It Lesson Department is comforting to see how effective words, lovingly chosen, can be in encouraging personal development and fostering marital harmony. Excerpts from two letters follow: My dear, dear Livy: November 28, 1868 I do love, love, love you, Livy! My whole being is permeated, is renewed, is leavened with this love, and with every breath I draw its noble influence makes of me a better man. And I shall yet be worthy of your priceless love, Livy. It is the glad task of my life—it is the purest ambition and the most exalted that ever I have known, and I shall never, never swerve from the path it has marked out for me... Mark had early found that Livy was careless in her spelling. Up to this point he hadn't teased her about it, but he can't resist in talking to her about his sister: My sister is a good woman, familiar with grief, though bearing it bravely & giving no sign upon the surface; & she is kind-hearted, void of folly or vanity, perfectly unacquainted with deceit or dissimulation, diffident about her own faults, & slow to discover those of others. She isn't such a gem as you; (by a long shot) & neither is any other woman, but then she is a very, very excellent woman anyway. You'll like her, Livy— she don't seem to spell worth a cent. You see she spells cow with a K. And she has spelled "tripped" with only one p, & she puts only one t in "delighted," & only two s's in "expression," I can stand those little blunders well enough, but I do hate to see anybody spell John with a G. I look upon that as perfectly awful. I notice that you always spell John with a G.—Now forgive me, Livy, darling—you know I wouldn't poke fun at you to save a man's life if I thought it would wound you. I don't care a straw how you spell, Livy dear—I hardly ever notice when you make a mistake—& bless you I am just as proud of you as if you could 795 October 1969 beat the Unabridged dictionary spelling. It would be a pity indeed if I presumed to criticize your spelling—I who am sown as thick with faults as you are with merits, & shining virtues, & beautiful traits of character; & yet you have found it in your heart to take me just as I am & lift me up & bless me with your priceless love—I never can be your critic, my loved and honored Livy. Question for Discussion How much do you think the repeated assertions of love by Mark Twain and his wife actually contributed to that love? With "Neighbor Rosicky" we conclude our discussion of communication on a_ highly encouraging note. As the ideals and values of the characters in this fine story come together, effective communication flourishes. Although, Anton Rosicky and his wife, Mary, have worked out most of their adjustments before this account begins, the series of flashbacks, by which part of this story is told, lets us see some of the circumstances that aided their developing unity. It is important to note that years of marriage have not blunted the Rosickys' sensitivity to each other's whims: Anton caters to his wife's sweet tooth, and she has something hot ready for him when he returns from town. Real marital harmony, however, is not built on indulgence. Shared principle is at the base of the Rosickys' strength. Perhaps this is best exemplified in the scene near the end of section two. As the creamery agent tries to persuade them to sell him their cream, Mrs. Rosicky declares emphatically that 796 she would rather "put some color into my children's faces than put money into the bank." The agent merely turns to Mr. Rosicky to get the real decision, knowing that it is usually the husband's word that really counts among the newly emigrated families with whom he does business. "I guess we'll do like she says," said Rosicky. The developing relationship of Polly to her father-in-law is possibly the key to this story. Here we have concentrated many of the forces that are supposed to block real communication: Polly is not a recent immigrant; Rosicky is. Rosicky is old; Polly is young. Polly is gregarious, Rosicky is not. Polly is a daughter-in-law. It takes a rather dramatic crisis to reveal the depth of Rosicky's understanding of and love for Polly and her own "tender heart." In the few minutes that Rosicky and his daughter-in-law share during his heart attack, all barriers that had seemed to inhibit communication between them are swept away. In realizing how much her father-inlaw loves her, Polly tells him of her expected, child before letting anyone else know. In finding out how tender and capable Polly is, Rosicky sees through the facade of sophistication she had erected between them and knows that she will be the kind of wife Rudolph needs. Question for Discussion Why is Rosicky so effective in bringing out the best in everyone he meets? Like to do grape juice — but hate the mess? BRISTLECONE PINE You, Bristlecone! You made it! Alone on the rim of sky You defy danger. Bent under lightning lash Nothing can break you. | know your kin: People grizzled and old, Glorious and tough, centrated juice with a minimum of effort and absolutely no mess. —Joanna Brown.. Rejected manuscripts will be retained for six months only. The Magazine is not responsible for unsolicited manuscripts. 803 If It's Right We Can Do It President Belle S. Spafford [Address Delivered at the General Session of the Relief Society Annual General Conference, October 1, 1969] @ It has been said that "we look back in order that we may go better forward." Today I would like to turn back the pages of history for a few moments to the year 1842—twelve years after the organization of the Church; the year in which Relief Society was founded in Nauvoo, I[llinois, through revelation given by the Lord to the Prophet Joseph Smith. According to research done by Fay Tarlock, the Honorable John Tyler, an able and independent Whig from Virginia, was President of the United States. It was the day of Stephen A. Douglas, a fiery orator and leading political figure and, at that time, a friend of the Mormons. It was the day when Abraham Lincoln, a promising young lawyer from Illinois and a rising politician, was looking forward to his marriage to the charming and ambitious Mary Todd. It was the year of the establishment of the 804 se | 4 i boundary line between the United States and Canada, a line that has defined territory, but never restricted neighborliness. Nauvoo was a western frontier town, a part of a vast new America reaching ever further out to the West. Oregon and California were exciting words, although as yet no wagon train had passed beyond the Rockies. The city of Nauvoo was only three years old, but it was a thriving city with sturdy twostory houses of brick and frame, with churches and stores, and a university. The rising structure of a temple enlisted with rare dedication the interest and the labors of the populace. At the busy harbor of the river's bend, boats from down the river came to anchor, bringing hundreds of converts from the Old World. It was at this growing, happy period of time for the saints that the Prophet Joseph Smith, on March 17, in meeting assembled with Elders John Taylor andWillard Richards and eighteen sisters, uttered these "long to be remembered words" that initiated a new day for Latter-day Saint women and, indeed, for all womankind: I now declare this Society organized with president and counselors, etc., according to parliamentary usages—and all who shall hereafter be admitted to this Society must be free from censure and be received by vote. (A Centenary of Relief Society, page 15.) Elder John Taylor addressed the assembly on that memorable occasion, saying that he "rejoiced to see the institution organized according to the law of Heaven." The law of heaven is divine law. In this, Relief Society differs from all other woman's organizations of the world. (I use the term "woman" as defined in the dictionary, meaning "mature females."') On the eventful day of the Society's founding, an open Bible lay on the pulpit of the historic room. The following words were found written on a scrap of paper lying on the open Bible: "Oh, Lord, help our widows and fatherless children! So mote it be, Amen. With the sword and the word of truth defend thou them, so mote it be!_ Amen." With gratitude and dedication, the members of the newly formed Society moved into the work defined for it and as guided by the Prophet, defending the widows and fatherless children, nursing the sick, finding employment for those with such need, feeding the hungry, comforting the sorrowing, clothing the naked. At the same time, the young organization looked to the rightIf It's Right We Can Do It eousness of the individual lives of the sisters, and the Prophet admonished the sisters with regard to their duties to their husbands. Counselor Whitney cautioned the sisters "to avoid all evil, even the appearance of evil." She urged them to "pray for one another that they might succeed in the work before them and have wisdom given them in all their pursuits." (A Centenary of Relief Society, page 16.) The Prophet instructed them: Let this Society teach women how to behave towards their husbands, to treat them with mildness and affection. When a man is borne down with trouble, when he is perplexed with care and difficulty, if he can meet a smile instead of an argument or a murmur—if he can meet with mildness, it will calm down his soul and soothe his feelings; when the mind is going to despair, it needs a solace of affection and kindness. (A Centenary of Relief Society, page 16.) The prayers of the sisters were answered and their efforts were blessed. The Prophet, meeting with them in the summer of 1842, said, "I have come here to bless you. The Society have done well: their principles are to practice holiness. God loves you, and your prayers in my behalf shall avail much..." (A Centenary of Relief Society, page 17.) Following the Nauvoo period, the sisters in true companionship with the priesthood entered upon the path of religious empirefounding in the heart of the Rocky Mountains, and they 'were vigorous in the promotion of righteousness according to revealed truth. Their teachings were not merely admonitions, they were continuous Christian practice. 805 November 1969 As we look back over their labors, even to the present time, a divinely guided drama of selfless service unfolds, revealing the strength of the sisters born of faith and testimony, and the power of the organization as it functions according to the law of heaven. A small sampling of activities will serve to illustrate the obedience, the intensity of devotion, the spirit of love and service that characterized efforts and led to almost unbelievable accomplishment. In September 1876, President Brigham Young gave to Sister Emmeline B. Wells the mission of leading the sisters in grain saving. Sister Wells, in a report to the members in 1915, said: "We began that very year, and though we were laughed at, we did buy grain—the Relief Society did; I did not do it myself—the Relief Society gave money and grain was bought that year...." (The Relief Society Magazine, February 1915, page 48.) The sisters garnered in the fields, sold Sunday eggs, quilts, rag carpeting, and other products of their hands to acquire the grain, disposed to do so because the spirit of the gospel bade them accept the mission in loving obedience to their great prophet, President Brigham Young. In February 1915, when Sister Wells was eighty-seven years old, prophetic tribute was paid to her by Sister Annie Wells Cannon and published in The Relief Society Magazine, from which I quote:... Ho doubt, she will be able to see clearly through the devastating wars which are now raging in Europe, that 806 the mission which was given her, so many years ago, was not in vain. Many. Starving mothers will be rescued, no doubt, through the faithful integrity of President Emmeline B. Wells and her associated sisters in this Society, in saving grain for famine need. (The Relief Society Magazine, February 1915, page 50.) On August 18, during World War I, President Clarissa Smith Williams, writing in The Relief Society Magazine, gave evidence of the fulfillment of this prediction as follows: The Relief Society has turned over to the United States Government [at a price set by it] over two hundred thousand bushels of wheat... How proud we are to perform this service for our suffering and glorious cause. Our hearts and prayers go with the gifts which we have laid upon the altar of our country. (A Centenary of Relief Society, page 72.) Today, as a praiseworthy symbol of the continuing blessing of the wheat program, there rises toward the heavens on Welfare Square a great grain elevator filled with Relief Society wheat stored against a day of need— obtained through the investment in wheat of money paid the Society by the Government in the day of war. An impressive demonstration of the unselfish spirit of sisterhood within the Society comes to us in the action of the sisters at the cessation of hostilities of World War II. A letter from a president of one of the European Missions to the Church Welfare Committee graphically described the urgent need of the people of Europe for soap. In the letter a strong appeal was made for help. The Welfare Program had but one soap plant which could in no measure meet the request. Soap at the commercial markets was rationed and only available through the use of coupons issued by the Government to individuals. Being notified of the need through the General Presidency, with the approval of the First Presidency, compassion touched the hearts of Relief Society sisters who rallied to the call for help. In ninety selected stakes of the Church in Zion, the sisters drew from their home supplies precious bars of soap. (Only bar soap could be shipped abroad.) Within a period of one week the local Relief Societies had been notified of the need, the soap was collected, and over 50,000 bars were on their way to Europe—an almost unbelievable response to share with those about whom they cared. Individual women were generous to be sure, but how helpless each would have been without the power of the Society to notify of need, to inspire, to organize, and direct the activity. At the same period, more than a carload of beautiful new quilts, on hand in the local Relief Societies, was donated to the suffering people of Europe. These, too, were collected and shipped in a period of a little over one week. In a report I made to the National -Council of Women in New York City at that time on war services of Relief Society, I mentioned the number of quilts that Relief Society had sent to Europe. Following my report, the President of the Free Czechoslovakian Women, an escapee to United States from that invaded country and a former Deputy-Mayor of Prague, rose and said, (and I quote from my notes): "Mrs. Spafford's report is overly modest and has dealt only with figures." Then If It's Right We Can Do It she explained that as DeputyMayor she had been assigned by her government to oversee the distribution of commodities from the United States. The quilts were not to be reserved exclusively for the Mormons. She concluded by saying, (again I quote from my notes): "They [the quilts] were new and beautiful. They not only warmed cold bodies, but brought sunshine to wintered spirits. They were gifts of understanding love." There is one other story I wish to tell. A sister, president of a small branch Relief Society of Mexican sisters in Salt Lake City, sat in this historic Tabernacle and heard a_ plan _ proposed whereby the sisters were to raise one-half million dollars for a Relief Society headquarters building. Each local Society was to be responsible for seeing that every one of its members was represented by a $5 contribution. That dutiful Mexican president had great feelings of trepidation because of the magnitude of the undertaking. But strong in testimony her response came: "I don't know how we can do it. My sisters are poor. Yet, President McKay is listening. The First Presidency has authorized it. If these Brethren authorize it, it is right. If it is right, we can do it!" And do it, they did. This Mexican Branch was the first to submit its money, soon to be followed by full contributions from the other sisters of Relief Society. More than one-half million dollars was contributed in a oneyear period. The Relief Society Building stands today a monument to the faith and labors of the sisters. 807 November 1969 Recorded in the minutes of the General Board is an address given March 17, 1914, in the Assembly Hall by President Joseph F. Smith from which I quote: When rightly wielded, governed and directed, I think the influence of this great organization in the Church is, without doubt, the most cogent and the most powerful of any other single organization of the Church, for this reason, it is not confined to three, nor to twelve, nor to seven nor any other definite small number of people, but it extends to the outermost borders of the Church and in every part of the Church. In every live branch of the Church the Relief Society is found, and it is found there for good.... Its work is good, and its power for uplifting, for comforting, and for sustaining the cause of Zion, I think, is most potent.... Where on earth should we look for good, for the spirit of truth, for sincerity, for divine love, for patience and longsuffering and forgiveness and endurance and charity and every other blessed thing, if we do not look for it in the organizations that develop the mothers and the daughters of Zion. What power you possess, my beloved sisters, in the exercise of your duties, in the performance of your callings... Powers... That you may wield among the people of God and among any people among whom you may be permitted to associate.... What a mighty, what a great and powerful organization is the organization of the Relief Society of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and what responsibilities rest upon them! Not only the responsibility of being capable yourselves of sustaining the spirit of the organization to which you belong and of maintaining its rights, and of performing your duties in it in a temporal way; you have also the responsibility resting upon you to impart... Knowledge, wisdom and understanding... To all others with whom you may come in contact..... Today we stand fortified in meeting the requirements of this troubled period of time by the size, the greatness, and the power of 808 our organization, and by the worthy and glorious accomplishments of the past. Also today we have unusually choice women. I have met with Relief Society sisters in many parts of the world. I have felt the power of their faith. I have seen striking evidence of their testimonies. I have noted the; zeal and dedication with which they work. I have watched, almost: in amazement, the quality of their r leadership. I have partaken of the sweetness and humility of their spirits. I have rejoiced in the beauty and refinement of their lives. Three hundred and twenty-five thousand such women, working through the medium of Relief Society under priesthood direction, fortified by the glorious accomplishments of the past are indeed favorably positioned successfully to deal with problems and meet the special needs of today, difficult though they may be. Strength is ours, greater perhaps than any of us comprehend. Today is not an easy, comfortable period of time. More changes and scientific advancements have taken place in the last fifty years than in any comparable period of time in history. Change and scientific advancement call for continuous adjustments in our way of life. These must be made with wisdom and in a way that will preserve the enduring values of life. Relief Society must rise as a power in helping mothers to do this. Relief Society must worthily meet the emergent special hu- | manitarian needs of today as did our Sisters of the past. At the same time, it must be constant in its efforts to strengthen the moral and spiritual values of our homes, so much in jeopardy today. It must train mothers to maintain well-managed, peaceful homes that draw family members to them even against the most appealing and glittering community enticements. It must create in mothers a recognition of the fundamental values of close companionship with their children. It is vital leisurely to spend time with our children. Relief Society must guide mothers in the firm and wise direction of young lives, and in maintaining the God-ordained relationships with husbands. It must strengthen community virtues, as directed by the Prophet Joseph Smith, through fortifying the sisters against the dangers of declining moral standards, and the relaxed attitudes toward the importance of sexual purity. It must safeguard mothers against the taint of some of the presentday, so-called religious attitudes, If it's Right We Can Do It through effectively teaching the beauties and truths of the gospel. The task before us is great, but it is not beyond our successful accomplishment. We bear in mind the words of the president of that small Mexican Branch Relief Society, "If the Presiding Brethren approved it, it is right. If it is right, we can do it." The Lord is mindful of his Relief Society. I am sure he loves the sisters of today even as he loved the sisters of Nauvoo and he will bless and make fruitful our efforts. I bear testimony to the divine mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith, to the divine birth of Relief Society, and to the inspired guidance that comes to it from God's prophets. I am humbly grateful for my membership in the Church and for my membership in Relief Society. When all else is gone in life, the blessings of this membership will remain for they are eternal.
