Sharp [Address Delivered at the General Session of the Relief Society Annual General Conference, October 1, 1969] @ Should we ask the sisters in the Tabernacle what is the motto of Relief Society, I feel sure we would all answer "Charity Never Faileth." We are told by Paul: Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal. And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and, though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing. (I Cor. 13:1-2.) Could we then say that the basic characteristic of an individual striving for exaltation should be charity, which Moroni defines as "... The pure love of Christ." The Savior taught us that the first and second great commandments are love of God and love of neighbor. When the sisters assembled at the invitation of the Prophet Joseph Smith on March 17, 1842 810 to be organized under the priesthood, there was some difference of opinion as to what the organization should be named, but there was no difference as to its purpose. The brethren present seemed to incline to the name benevolent, but the sisters preferred the name relief, and so it was named The Female Relief Society of Nauvoo. The idea of charity was fundamental in its concept. The Prophet Joseph declared: This is a charitable Society, and according to your natures; it is natural for females to have feelings of charity and benevolence. You are now placed in a situation in which you can act according to those sympathies which God has planted in your bosoms. (DHC IV, 605.) Relief Society today offers all Latter-day Saint women a situation in which they can act according to those sympathies which God has planted in their bosoms. In passing we might remind the sisters of the Church, however, that nearly half of the Latter-day Saint women are not taking advantage of that situation. This is unfortunate. Relief Society members, however, are grasping the opportunity to express their feelings of charity and benevolence. No call made on Relief Society for benevolence goes unanswered. Recently in a small gathering, one of the sisters remarked on the great number of women in her stake who were being left widows. She concluded, "They surely must need a lot of good men on the other side." Sister Spafford spoke up quickly, "They ~ need a lot of good women here— Relief Society women. In this disturbed world, fine, good, charitable women are needed or what would happen to the world?" We do need charitable women throughout the world and in our wards and branches. As individual Relief Society members we may fittingly question ourselves as to the extent of our personal charity. Should the Savior come tomorrow, would we all feel that we truly represented our motto "Charity Never Faileth'? If we do not feel satisfied with our accomplishments (and who ever does?) the four gospels and 3 Nephi give us innumerable examples of the charity of the Savior. He helps us to acquire characteristics we lack to minister to needs in a spirit of charity. We need to search out our true motives for in exercising charity it is not only the deed, but more important the intent. Christ did not judge: to the "The Greatest of These"' sinning woman he said, "Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more." (John 8:11.) To Martha, overly busy with many things, he said, "But one thing is needful: and Mary hath chosen that good part, which shall not be taken away from her." (Luke 10:42.) To one puffed up with her own importance, he says "... Whosoever will be great among you, shall be your minister: And whosoever of you will be the chiefest, shall be servant of all." (Mark 10:43-44.) The Savior was long-suffering and kind in his hour of deep anguish and loneliness. He longed to have his three beloved disciples watch and pray with him during his agony in Gethsemane. Not once, nor twice, but three times he returned where they were, only to find them asleep. Even an angel came and_ strengthened him, but the human companionship failed him. With the greatest charity Christ only said, "Sleep on now, and take your rest: it is enough, the hour is come...." (Mark 14:41.) Whatever aspects of our characters need strengthening, we will find help to improve through prayer and study of the scrip- — tures. Then as beloved Relief Society gives us the opportunity to act according to the sympathies God has planted in our bosoms, we will not only perform the outward act but it will be accompanied by the inward grace. I pray each Relief Society member in the coming year may learn the truth "And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity." (I Cor. 13:13.) 811 The Spiritual Value of Homemaking Counselor LouiseW Madsen [Address Delivered at the General Session of the Relief Society Annual General Conference, October 1, 1969] ® On a dull gray day in Paris in October 1822, John Howard Payne found himself completely, unutterably homesick. Alone in his room he could think of nothing but his home in East Hampton on Long Island. Memories flooded his mind and while the mood was upon him he wrote the immortal "Home, Sweet Home." Into the song he poured his aching loneliness, the longings of his heart for the scenes of his boyhood, the remembering of his family, his assurance that his mother was thinking of him, his father missing him, and the beauty of his home world. *Mid pleasures and palaces though we may roam, Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home. The song was set to music by Sir Henry Rowley Bishop from a tune Payne had heard sung by an Italian peasant girl. It was sung in the Covent Garden Theater in \ 812 London in the first act of a play he wrote, "Clari, or, the Maid of Milan." As famous Maria Tree sang the song, her eyes filled with tears, her voice choked with emotion, and the whole audience responded with hushed attention and tears. "Home, Sweet Home" became one of the most famous songs in all the world. It has been translated into many languages, sung in almost every land. On the night of December 17, 1850, Jenny Lind, "the Swedish Nightingale," sang for one of the most distinguished audiences ever seen in a concert hall in the United States. President Fillmore, Daniel Webster, Henry Clay, General Scott, and others were in attendance. Daniel Webster rose at the end of the concert, and bowed to the singer in public tribute to her great voice. She smiled and then turned to face a gentle, white-haired man seated in the audience, John Howard Payne. Without taking her eyes from his face, the incomparable Jenny sang as if to him alone, "Home, Sweet Home." Profoundly moved, as people always were, the great audience heard and many wept openly. For 145 years this song has had great influence upon those who love their homes and cherish their family ties. This story is related by Lillian Watson in her "Light From Many Lamps," and serves to illustrate the appeal of home. The very word home has inspired poets to write about its glories, its simple joys, its place as a haven of security. Home has been the subject of many a painter's canvas, the basis of sociologists' lectures, of philosophers' treatises, of writers' essays, of politicians' preachments, and is a basis of the teachings of great religious leaders. One such inspired leader has assured us that the perfect homes on earth have their pattern in the heavens. With the home receiving such universal acclaim, can one doubt the spiritual values of homemaking? Can one question the wisdom of the Father in giving to his daughters the role of homemaker? Would one really wish it to be otherwise? No doubt the greatest spiritual value to be found in homemaking is to fulfill the desire of our Father in heaven to have his spirit children come to earth to choice homes. He entrusts to the care of earthly parents his sons and daughters to be reared in accordance with his commandments. As co-creator with God of the bodies of mortals, mothers are especially blessed with the opporThe Spiritual Value of Homemaking tunity to make homes worthy of the spirits which have come from the presence of God. A home wherein dwells the priesthood of God in an honored and respected position is a worthy home. When the father assumes his position of leadership, upheld by the mother, the children learn by example the full meaning of priesthood as a glorious gift from the Father to his sons. When the mother reigns as a queen in her home, companion-counselor to her husband, the children learn the full meaning of the equality of the gifts of a loving and wise Father to his sons and to his daughters. The spiritual value of love in the home is beyond measure, its influence so far-reaching as to stagger the imagination, its presence as necessary as life itself. Love is so many things—shown in sO Many ways. The homemaker shows love in the care of her home, in its cleanliness, order, and lack of confusion. Order is a law of heaven and is a necessary aspect of the pattern after which earthly homes are built. One cannot imagine anything unclean nor disorderly in heaven. The wise homemaker instills pride of home in her family to the extent that all contribute to order. The homemaker shows love in her sensitivity to the needs of others. She is so attuned to the souls of her husband and children that she becomes aware of their needs and, to the best of her ability, fulfills them. This virtue of sensitivity must be consciously nurtured. It is partly unselfishness; it is greatly thoughtfulness; it is mainly a mother's expression 813 November 1969 of love. Sensitivity to others' needs results in compassionate service to them. The homemaker shows love in. Awareness of the need to make her home a haven of security where each family member has complete confidence that he is loved for himself, and recognized as an individual. One's own special self is unique and must be so understood by those who love him, his abilities fostered, his talents encouraged, and his ambitions aided. Each family member must bask in the sunlight of approval as often as is good for him. The homemaker makes the climate for growth, establishes the atmosphere for culture, and provides the tools for refinement. Discipline is a spiritual value to be wisely administered by the homemaker. Happy people, useful citizens, dedicated Church workers come from homes where selfcontrol and righteousness are a part of their upbringing. To be taught obedience becomes a blessing throughout life. The homemaker has unceasing chances to teach, to guide, to lead. She must take advantage of her own learning opportunities to prepare herself. The spiritual value of lessons learned at home is shown in the character of those who hear and are taught. The children we are given are not only our children, they are God's as well. We should teach and train them as our Heavenly Father would have us do. The Spirit of the Lord will not always contend with man. We have long been urged to look to our homes. Church leaders continuously teach the necessity of well-ordered homes and endeavor to help us to know how to make our homes right. The responsibilities and duties of parents are fully described, the duties of children are beautifully defined, the words of the Lord are concisely interpreted. It remains for us to heed and act accordingly. Nothing else is of greater importance. May all of us as homemakers inspire our families to love their "Home, Sweet Home." ERRATUM Through an inadvertency the word Paul was used in the place of Peter in President Hugh B. Brown's article "Testimony," page 725, The Relief Society Magazine, October 1969. (Reference Matthew 16:17). The sentence, should read: When the Apostle Peter answered Christ's question as to who he, the Savior, was, he had the spirit of revelation, and Jesus said to him: Blessed art thou Simon Barjona: for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven." 814 IN MEMORIAM Elder John Longden Assistant to the Council of the Twelve November4, 1898-August 30, 1969 @ Elder John Longden, Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, passed away August 30, 1969 in Salt Lake City, Utah. He had served as an Assistant to the Twelve since 1951. During that time he fulfilled many important callings for the Church, and he endeared himself to members throughout the world. Elder Longden was born in Oldham, Lancashire, England, on November 4, 1898, the son of Thomas J. And Lizetta Taylor Longden. The family emigrated to the United States and Salt Lake City ten years later. Elder Longden was graduated from LDS Business College and attended the University of Utah. He served as a missionary in the Central States Mission. Elder Longden had a successful business career. At the time of his retirement he was area manager for National Electric Products Corporation. Interested in music and dramatic arts, Elder Longden studied voice and dramatics. He was well-known throughout the area as a gifted singer. He gave freely of his talent, singing at Church services, weddings, funerals, and other gatherings. In 1924 Elder Longden married LaRue Carr in the Salt Lake Temple. They had three daughters, Mrs. Grant (Gail) Hickman, and Mrs. Loren C. (Sharon) Dunn. The first daughter, Helen Margaret, died in childhood. There are three grandsons and five granddaughters. Elder Longden was always devoted to the gospel and served in several MIA superintendencies, as bishop, and as high councilman in two stakes, and on the General Church Welfare Committee prior to his call as a General Authority. As a General Authority, he served on the General Priesthood Committee and several youth committees. At the time of his death he was supervising all stakes and missions in the British Isles. Previously he had supervised missions in the South Pacific, Australia, and New Zealand. The General Board and Relief Society members in all stakes and missions of the Church extend heartfelt sympathy to the family of Elder Longden and to his many friends. He has left a heritage in faith and dedication to the gospel for others to follow. 815 REPORT AND OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS President Belle S. Spafford [Delivered at the Officers Meeting of the Relief Society Annual General Conference, October 1, 1969] @ Once again it becomes my duty to present to you a brief report of the status of Relief Society, together with a few General Board instructions and recommendations. The latest available figures are those from the 1967-68 annual report, since the 1968-69 reports were not due in the General Board Office until September 20 and, of course, are not audited and compiled as yet. In order to make the information somewhat more current, growth figures for the previous year will be used in estimating present conditions. Precise figures will be available to you when the compiled report for the fiscal year is published in a forthcoming issue of The Relief Society Magazine. GENERAL BOARD We mourn the loss, by death of two valiant and eminently capable members: Evon W. Peterson, General Secretary-Treasurer, and Mildred B. Eyring. STAKE AND MISSION RELIEF SOCIETIES With the growth of the Church, the number of stake and mission Relief Society organizations has grown. There were as 816 of September 1968, 462 stake and 74 mission Relief Society organizations, with 328 mission districts and more than 6,500 ward and branch Societies. MEMBERSHIP For the past several years there has been consistent growth in membership, but there still remain far too many Latter-day Saint women not enrolled who need Relief Society. We, therefore, appeal to officers and members alike to intensify their efforts in enrolling new members. The membership appeals are almost endless. There are, in reality, few women who cannot be reached by. One or the other of these. Estimating the membership | growth for 1968-69 to be the same as for the previous fiscal year (or 11,000), there is now a total membership of 322,500. Of this number 3,500 are non-Latterday Saints. Each year we receive gratifying reports of nonLatter-day Saint Relief Society members becoming _ baptized members of the Church. ATTENDANCE It is our conviction that there are comparatively few enrolled members who do not attend some meetings during the year. We must recognize that under certain circumstances a sister may be unable to attend regardless of her desire to do so; for example, personal or family illness may interfere, or the infirmities of age or the hazards of winter roads where distances to the meeting place require car travel. Nonetheless, attendance is) a continuing concern and _ ward presidents should be urged to do all in their power to interest women in regular attendance and to help make it possible for them to attend. Second session Relief Societies are a boon to countless women, as are well-managed nurseries for mothers with young children. COMPASSIONATE SERVICES The General Board requests that great emphasis be placed upon the compassionate service program which is fundamental in the accomplishment of the purposes of the Society and which, according to the reports, seems to be somewhat on a plateau insofar as volume is concerned. Today's troubled, costly, and insecure world, with its measure of tragedy in the lives of many faithful sisters and good families, -calls upon us deeply to understand our responsibilities in this area, and to respond to needs with readiness, competency, and love. It is our opinion that days care of the sick, which declined by more than 5,000 eight-hour days in 1967-68, have not taken any Significant upturn during the 1968-69 year. We suggest that you Report and Official Instructions exercise watchcare so that Relief Society will not falter where this service is needed in the home. — _ Figures on visits to the sick also have remained somewhat constant—between 395,000 and 400,- 000—as have the number of hours of other compassionate services, which were approximately 750,- 000 hours. Let us be sensitive to all such needs. We particularly call your attention to the desirability of Relief Society presidencies calling on a family at the time of a death and making available to it, if desired, the services of the Society in connection with the funeral. We estimate that 1,000 bodies were dressed for burial during the 1968-69 year, and assistance including the providing of food was given in connection with more than 12,000 funerals. Such service is usually welcomed and is comforting and helpful. At times, our sisters need to be reminded of the value of going the second mile in rendering voluntary humanitarian service as individuals—on their own. I call attention to an important program which is proving of value in our Latter-day Saint hospitals. I refer to the hospital Volunteer Auxiliary program, sometimes referred to as the "Pink Lady" program. We encourage sisters who have time, health, and an aptitude for service in a hospital setting, where there is a variety of work situations, to contact your local Latter-day Saint hospitals. Full information will be readily given you. We commend the stakes who have participated in the Red Cross Home Nurse Training programs. Approximately 5,426 wo- 817 November 1969 men have completed this course, made available to them through the cooperative efforts of the American Red Cross and the Relief Society. CHURCH WELFARE Relief Society sisters consistently support the Church Welfare Program with ward presidents having made approximately 100,000 family visits under the direction. Of their respective bishops, and 94,000 other contacts during the past year. Relief Society members contributed during the year 756,000 hours on Church Welfare projects. VISITING TEACHING It is estimated that there were close to 54%, million visits made to homes during the 1968-69 fiscal year by more than 148,000 visiting teachers. We increasingly see their value as an aid to the bishop in ascertaining cases of temporal need among worthy Latter-day Saint families and also as an aid to him through the Home Teachers in reactivating inactive members. Visiting teachers are a great asset to Relief Society itself in bringing women who are enrolled into membership and _ activity. The visiting teaching program has value in fellowshiping new converts to the Church, most of whom soon make excellent visiting teachers themselves, thus enlarging our reservoir of teachers. Let us aim to enlarge our visiting teaching program and continually improve the quality of the visit and attendance at the visiting teacher meeting, as well as the quality of the confidential report to the ward president. 818 COURSES OF STUDY The spiritual living lessons for the forthcoming season conclude the course based on the Doctrine and Covenants. It is expected that by the time this course is concluded in May 1970, members will have thoughtfully read the entire Doctrine and Covenants in order that they may enjoy fully the spirit of this book of scripture, increase their knowledge and understanding of the _ revealed truths contained in the revelations, and be guided by them in their day-to-day activities. Visiting teaching messages correlate with the Family Home Evening Manual and are designed to renew our faith and guide us as we meet life from day to day. The social relations lessons for the coming year are based again upon the writings of the late President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., and are correlated with the Melchizedek Priesthood course of study. The cultural refinement course will stress the individual and human values as seen through literature, art, and music, widening the scope by emphasizing a woman's responsibilities in community life and the world in which she lives. LESSONS FOR THE USE OF LAMANITE WARDS AND BRANCHES The General Board is pleased to announce that special lessons for Lamanite Relief Societies are now ready for distribution. This new set of Lamanite lessons has been prepared so as to fit into any standard three-ring binder. The set is wrapped in cellophane and includes sheets of visual aids fol- lowing each lesson. The cost for a set is $3 postpaid. They are to be ordered from the office of the General Board. HOMEMAKING Exclusive of the homemaking discussions that are prepared by the General Board, activities for the homemaking meeting are planned by the local Relief Societies with the General Board setting the purposes of the meeting and giving general guidelines. It is the rule of the stake and mission district board to suggest, display, and demonstrate suitable items which might be produced, or demonstrations which appropriately might be conducted. This year's estimate of number of items produced is in excess of 14, million. This was over and above the countless recorded homemaking demonstrations and other helpful homemaking activities. MUSIC We are delighted to report the increasing interest and general improvement in the music program. We now have over 3,600 local Singing Mothers choruses, with 52,000 singers participating. Special concerts are being held with a high degree of success. - SONG CONTEST Results of the Song Contest were excellent. There were 223 entries. Both the first and second award-winning numbers will be heard during this conference— the first award number in the General Session, and the second in this morning's session. These numbers will be published and Report and Official Instructions will be available for purchase at the music stores. We are indebted to our former board member, Sister Cleone Eccles, for the inspiration and the financial means which led to the establishment of the contest. THE RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE It is with gratitude that we acknowledge the tireless and competent service of more than 7,000 sisters whose callings as Magazine representatives are so important to the organization and to the sisters as individuals. The present circulation is 285, 000 (7,000 Spanish). In November 1957, the subscription price was set at $2. Through rigid editing and publishing economies, and by virtue of the labors of the sisters in obtaining subscriptions, we have been able to maintain the $2 subscription price for twelve years. It is with genuine regret that, regardless of our efforts to continue the $2 subscription price, it has become necessary to increase it to $2.50 for the twelve issues per year. This price change becomes effective January 1, and applies to all subscriptions, including renewals, which start with the January 1970 issue of the Magazine or any month thereafter. Subscriptions beginning with September, October, November, or December 1969 issues will be at the $2 price. Subscriptions for one year at a time only will be accepted. Publication of the award-winning poems and short stories in the Poetry and Short Story Contests, respectively, has brought interest and enrichment to the publication. This year there were 469 entries in the Poetry Contest and eighty-six in the Short Story Contest. We call your attention to the excellence of these awardwinning works, published in the April 1969 Magazine. The influence of Relief Society can be a potent one in helping the Lamanite mother to lift the standards in her home and to make her home a center where the gospel is taught and lived—a place of order, attractiveness, and peace. Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judaea... There came wise men from the east... Saying... We have seen his star... And are come to worship him. (Matthew 2:1-2.) @ To the wise men of the east, whose search took them over mountains and deserts to the hills of Judaea, the star was a sign of the birth -of Jesus, but they were looking, also, for a greater brightness, a more glorious illumination. With the Savior's birth, the plan of salvation was given again to the earth ''for it pleased the Father that in him should all fulness dwell."' We, too, in our time and place, have seen the star, but have we participated in its full radiance? To each and all of us there comes a spiritual search for an application in our own lives of the message of Christmas. Beset with many interests and urgent responsibilities, some of us who know the meaning of the star may have difficulty in realizing its enduring splendor. In a multiplicity of demands, we dwell among seemingly urgent details—how shall the home be decorated? We ask. How can we provide for all the names on the Christmas lists? Have we reciprocated all the greeting cards? All the pleasing elements of our observance have their place in providing joy and warmth and beauty—in uniting the family on a memorable occasion. And yet the transcendent meaning of Christmas is neither gain nor giving of material objects. When the Savior was born, the world, having lost much of the gospel belief and observance, was veiled in spiritual darkness—a darkness greater than the shadows on the hills roundabout. The darkness was a lack of assurance of life beyond the time of earth and a knowledge of a previous habitation—a lack of direction and purpose for the pathway between birth and the next estate. The birth of the Savior signified the divine gift of a restoration and a promise of life everlasting through the mission of the Savior, who ''ascended up on high... And gave gifts unto men." (Ephesians 4:8.) Volume 56 November 1969 Number 11 THE GENERAL BOARD Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Miltenberger, SecretaryTreasurer 822 Editorial Thus Christmas for us and for our children should be a searching for identification with the teachings of the Savior—to become doers of the word and to exemplify our belief. In every era of time the conversion of faith into appropriate action has been a blessing to those who have found the way to achieve it. A certain man in a pioneer village believed that the Savior's instructions to care for the widow and the orphan applied to him. He had little besides his own strength to give, but he owned some desert hills thickly overgrown with juniper and pinion pine. Each year in the week before Christmas he loaded his wagon with the logs which had fallen and hauled them many miles to the town and delivered the wood to the widows who were unable to provide warm homes for their children. In the long miles of travel by night, sometimes beneath a clear constellation of stars, sometimes in a white blizzard, his journeys continued. Some who received his gifts may have wondered if he had seen the Christmas star. Long remembered gifts may be small in monetary value, but their enduring compensation may last as long as years continue. In a time when this century was one-quarter old, a family which had ordered its Christmas gifts by catalog and had not received them, was isolated at Christmas time by a drifting blizzard. They had a fireplace and a fire, some honey candy, and some popped corn for decorating a small fir tree. There were no other gifts. The father, late at night, had been delayed at the sheep camp, and the mother and the children waited. Finally, the door was opened and the father came in carrying a small stray lamb in his arms. In the firelight the children and the lamb found a deep and warm contentment, and later, as was fitting for the time and place, the mother read from the book of Luke ''and there were in the same country shepherds abiding in the field..." Not one of that Christmas family circle could forget, through all their lives, the occasion and its meaning. Perhaps, even in this time of many beckonings and numerous pathways, we may still find some interval of devotion—some space of time in which all the family may turn again towards a more lasting ChristLeone G. C. s to the Field, oe v2 Relief Society Magazine Subscription Price to Be Increased it is with genuine regret we announce at this time that regardless of our efforts to continue The Relief Society Magazine at its present $2.00 subscription price, it now becomes necessary for us to increase it to $2.50 for the twelve issues per year. (There will be no change at this time in the subscription price of the Spanish edition.) This price change becomes effective January 1, 1970 and applies to all subscriptions including renewals which start with the January 1970 issue of the Magazine or any month thereafter. Subscriptions beginning in September, October, November, or December 1969, or renewals beginning in these months will be at the $2.00 price. Subscriptions for one year at a time only will be accepted. Increases in the costs of labor, printing, paper, and postage force this step upon us. Presidents, we urge you fully to explain this action to ward and branch presidencies and to enlist their support in making certain that the number of subscriptions does not decline either for the sake of the organization or for the sake of the sisters who need the Magazine's instructions, guidance, and influence. We suggest that ward presidents take a few moments of time in the regular Relief Society meeting to call attention to some feature of the Magazine, thus creating interest in it and deepened appreciation for it. Jean Roberts clasped her hands excitedly, as her eyes took in every detail of the picturesque cottage. The weather-worn stone, the small latticed windows framed with climbing ivy, and the cowled chimney sitting slightly askew upon the low roof. "Dad, Mum, can we explore?" "Let's go in. Quick." "T'll bet a witch once lived there." "Boys, simmer down, it's not going to disappear." Their father laughed at the excited faces in the back of the car. "We have the key," he continued, "and we can go and look at the cottage, but that dog stays put." "That dog" breathed heavily and a long pink tongue reached out for Steve's ear. "No, Trub, you can't get out, you would 826 only get into mischief." Steven spoke sternly. The dog gave a resigned sigh as they stepped from the car, and laying his head on his paws, gazed with mournful eyes at the departing family. Jean opened the gate, and the three older boys hustled through, nearly bowling each other over. Steve, following, carrying baby James, laughed. "There's plenty of garden. They will certainly enjoy living here if we decide to buy," he said. "My mind is nearly made up," replied Jean, picturing crisp white net behind the latticed panes. "There may be dry rot, woodworm, and medieval plumbing," Steve warned her. The path to the front door was overgrown with weeds, and the once trim lawns' were scattered with daisies and buttercups, while a few pansies grew harmoniously with the wild clover. Steve approached the door with the key as the boys came bounding back. "Dad, there's a_ tree big enough to hold a swing," John, the eldest of the three, gasped, his eyes bright with anticipation. "We could have a pet rabbit, couldn't we?" asked Pete the younger one, while Martin, whose physique belied his appetite, said, "And there're some apple trees and blackberry bushes. Oh, boy!" Jean and Steve laughed as he went on, "We might even be able to grow our own peas." "And you'd go nibbling them all." John poked him with a grubby finger. "Come on.. Chaps, let's see what's inside." Inside the low-ceilinged house, old oak beams ran the length of the downstairs rooms. These lovely old beams are thirsty for polish, Jean thought, and my brass ornaments will look most attractive. Chintz covers and drapes... I have furnished and redecorated already! Reluctantly she brought her thoughts back to the present. A large lounge led to an even larger stone-floored kitchen, and a narrow stairway reached to the upper floor. There they found three bedrooms, one being slightly larger than the other two. A small room under the eaves reached by a _ wall ladder completed the layout of the cottage. "Well?" Steve asked inquiringly, "what do you think of it? Would you be happy here? It will mean making new friends Trouble and More Trouble he went on, shouldn't be too and neighbours," "but that difficult." "A small town will be a big change from the city," Jean replied, "but I think the garden itself is well worth moving for. I know the boys will enjoy living here, and I'm sure Trub will like it, too," she added. "T'm sure he will" Steve said dryly, "if he doesn't decide to take a liking to anyone's hens. That dog! He's still as headstrong as a puppy. How did those boys talk me into keeping him?" "Well, I think he needs to relax and have more freedom." Jean tried to defend the dog. "IT don't suppose we should have kept him, but the boys did want a pet." "Pest is the word," Steve answered grimly, "I don't know about a cat having nine lives, but that dog certainly leads a charmed life the trouble he gets into." He broke into a wry grin. "He's certainly aptly named." Tub had been with them for nearly a year. He had followed one of the boys home, a longhaired, mournful-eyed dog of doubtful parentage, and after making the usual inquiries and finding no owner, the dog had become part of the family. The boys had wanted to name him Butch, but after the escapades of the first few weeks, with Steve repeating, "That dog is nothing but trouble," they decided to call him Trouble, shortened to Trub. "Well that's that." Steve surveyed the ring of expectant faces as they all converged in the tiny hall. Gradually the bright summer colors deepened to the mellow tints of autumn, and the family settled down in their new home. Trub had been wildly excited when introduced to his new home. He had run around inspecting every tree in sight, hurtling through the house like a miniature tornado, skidding on the polished floors. Finally he had settled in an untidy heap on the hearth rug, his exploration completed. The older boys had quickly made new friends, while Jean's bright disposition came to good use, and she was soon on friendly terms with the occupants of nearly every house on the road. One person, however, always answered her kindly greeting with a grunt and never smiled. An upright, elderly gentleman, the retired Colonel Watkins, Trouble and More Trouble lived further along the road, and seemed very brusque. Jean often wondered about him, living alone and so unfriendly. He didn't even have a smile for young James in his push chair, until one day when Trub took a turn in the events. "Mum!" "Well, why was he angry?" Jean inquired. "I hope you weren't rude?" "Oh, no," Martin answered firmly, "he asked me why I wanted to look in his garden, and I answered and said very politely, 'I'm just looking for Trouble,' and he said that I was a naughty impur... "Qh, dear," Jean sighed, not knowing whether to laugh or cry. "I will have to go and explain, and if the poor man is ill, Il] see if he needs any help." "T'll play with James while you go," offered Martin. "Thank you, dear." Jean hurried out and down the road B29 November 1969 to the home of Colonel Watkins. He answered her knock, looking just as ill as Martin had said, his military bearing gone and his blue eyes clouded. After making apologies and explanations on Martin's behalf, Jean went on, "I wondered if I could get you anything? My son said that you are ill." "No, thank you. I can manage," he answered gruffly. "Well maybe I could send you some lunch over with one of my boys?" Jean asked hesitantly, "or some hot lemon? You look as if you have caught flu." "Oh, you might as well come in," he said grudgingly, holding the door open for her, and followed her in to sink into a deep chair by the low fire. "Must apologize," he grunted. "My daily woman is ill. Tried to do a bit but had to give up. Flu, as you said." Jean took off her coat and began to tidy up, softened as she glanced at the old man. He seemed more human today, all the fire gone out of him. "T must go now." She roused him gently. "Ill send some broth over. Try to take some, it will make you feel better, and I'll call around later." Next morning John and Martin accompanied Jean to visit the colonel. As John cleaned out the old-fashioned hearth, Martin chopped sticks outside to light the fire. Jean tidied up and dusted while the old man watched. "T had ason," he said suddenly. Jean turned as John looked up. "Is he grown up now, Sir?" he asked. 830 her eyes - "No," answered the colonel sadly, "he was killed during the last war. He was only twentytwo, and the shock made my wife so ill she died not long after. He was our only child." "Oh, my dear, I am sorry." Jean went and knelt by the chair, suddenly understanding the colonel's sternness and apparent dislike of children. He was nursing a broken heart. "What he must have suffered, living alone all these years," Jean told Steve that evening, "gradually being left all alone with his grief. I'm not surprised he became grim and hard." Within a few days all the family were visiting the colonel, including Trub, who, most of the time, hked to lie with just the tip of his nose upon the old man's slipper. "You see he wasn't really our dog," Martin went on. "He just came one day and stayed. He didn't have anyone to love him so we adopted him." The colonel laughed. "I'm sure you never could have bought such a handsome looking creature. He would have been far too expensive." "Mum, I have an idea." John turned suddenly to his mother. "Why don't we adopt Colonel Watkins as our Grandpa, if he will let us? We have only one and he lives a long way from us, and the colonel is all alone." They all looked at the old man inquiringly. To This Day" @ Today is the most wonderful day of your life! Today is the day that you can do marvelous things! We cannot change what happened yesterday. We do not know what tomorrow will bring, but today is a gift to us from Heavenly Father! Let us make the most of this gift. Today we can teach our children and make them happy. Today we can be real neighbors and worthwhile friends. Today we can study and learn to do new things. We must stop regretting the things that happened yesterday. We cannot change any part of the day that is gone, yet, how many of us there are, who, like Lot's wife, turn to pillars of salt when we look back. In our case the pillars of salt are salt tears, whether they are shed actually, or whether we weep inwardly in our regret. All the tears in the world will not change the past, yet if we should spend the energy and the thought and the pain that we spend on vain regret in making the present all that we can make it, what a happy future ours would be! Stop regretting. If you are regretting lost opportunities of learning, start learning now. If you are mourning about something you did not accomplish, start working and planning something you can accomplish now. Some of the greatest books have been written, some of the finest paintings painted, some of the most wonderful inventions worked out by people well along in years, or seriously handicapped, or both. Milton was past fifty and blind when he sat down to complete his world famous epic. Benjamin Franklin was past fifty when he started the study of science and philosophy. Michelangelo said, "Yet I am learning," when he was past seventy. He finished the huge painting called the "Last Judgment" in the Sistine Chapel when he was sixty-six and was working on his plans for St. Peter's Church when he was a very old man. He died at eighty-nine. Tennyson wrote his favorite poem, "Crossing the Bar" when he was eight-one. We can always do something worthwhile, no matter what our age or condition. If you are feeling sorry because you have hurt someone's feelings, apologize and forget it, and then start doing something that will make that person unusually happy. There is the familiar story about the man who was branded with a cruel ST in his forehead. He was a sheep thief. He devoted the rest of his life to making restitution for his sin. Years later when someone asked what those letters on the forehead stood for, a man answered, "I don't know, but I think it must stand for saint, for he is surely a saint!" If we have done some wrong in the past, we can do many good things if we "Look to this day." 833 Edythe K. Watson Member, ® The Christmas season is just around the corner, bringing with it excitement, happiness, memories, traditions, caring, sharing, loving, and gift giving. What a lovely custom the giving of gifts can be, how beautiful the event it symbolizes, but are we somehow losing sight of its true significance? Unfortunately for some people, Christmas with its gift giving has become a time of frustration, of mental, physical, and financial strain, rather than a joyous time of family fun, traditions, peace, and good will. Gifts of themselves are not important, it is the desire to give that counts. Christmas should be a time to think of others, to draw close to friends 834 General Board of Relief Society ard family, to be mindful of those less fortunate than we, to give of our selves. Are we as mothers making lasting lovely memories for our children, establishing traditions, by teaching them by precept and example the joy of giving of themselves? My husband remembers with pleasure and a tear in his eye the thrill he felt as a young boy sharing gifts from his mother's lovely kitchen, carrying in his little red wagon bottled fruit, jams, jellies, fruitcake or homemade breads to the needy in his neighborhood. Our children contend that the happiest Christmas they remember was the year we joined with my sister's family in preparing Christmas carols; then, following Church service on Christmas Eve, going to the homes of neighbors, family, friends, and some who were homebound, caroling our hearts out. Our children do not remember the gifts they received that year, but they do remember the joy of giving of themselves. One mother's gifts to her family are beautiful hand-knit Christmas socks, every one with the name of a family member boldly knitted into its heading. A priceless gift, a treasured tradition. The mother made the first socks many years ago when her oldest children were tiny tots. Each year as her family has grown she has added another sock to the crochet yarn cord on which they hang Mothers Make Memories together atop the mantle. Now they include the names of grandchildren, sons, and daughtersin-law. The socks range from those used for twenty-five years to bright new ones, to be hung for the first time this year. This tradition has welded this family together. Whether a family member is serving in the mission field, in the armed forces, away at college, or just living too far from home to join the family at Christmas time, they always know that they are being remembered and missed, as their sock is lovingly placed on the family cord for the Christmas season. Most every mother appreciates gifts which have been prepared or made especially for her and her family—a loaf of stollen bread for Christmas morning breakfast, a favorite dessert set in hollydecorated paper cups, a plate of choice cookies, a holiday salad, a popcorn cake, or special handmade gifts from family members or dear friends. There are so many lovely yet simple and inexpensive items, which can be made for Christmas giving. The little family of a young friend are sure that Christmas is near when the handmade Christmas pillow cases are found on their freshly made beds as they turn down their covers. Such fun for the children, yet so simple to make from a few yards of Christmas design yardage. Children love to be remembered. Since Christmas means so much to children why not try some of the following ideas? They cost little but the pleasure they give cannot be measured. Y Id @PProximately 2 Sp cinnamon doz 837 Madonna Keepsakes | Florence G. Butler esorsnespee sii a ey # I well remember the first issue of The Relief Society Magazine I received back in December 1953. My subscription came as a wedding gift from my mother and on the cover was a reproduction of the Madonna, a painting by Roberto Feruzzi. I did not know it then, but it was the beginning of a fascinating interest in Madonna paintings. I must have been on my way home from Relief Society meeting a few months later, because I had that same December issue in my arms as I passed through the checkout stand at the grocery store. I still remember the delight of the clerk who saw the Magazine and exclaimed, "Oh, may I see that, please?" She gazed at it tenderly and then remarked, "We had that painting in our home when I was growing up. It's very dear to me." I feigned delight to match hers and hoped she would not notice how embarrassed I was. I had scarcely even noticed the cover. When I returned home I sat down and took a good look at the picture. I did not readily realize how that particular picture could mean so much to anyone. But I was determined to 838 let it mean something to me just so that I could share her emotion and appreciation, if only in part. I resolved to pay more attention to paintings. The following December another Madonna _ reproduction appeared. This time it was the world famous "Sistine Madonna" by Raphael, and while I did not recognize it, I had at least heard of it, Each year thereafter, I eagerly awaited the December issue of the Magazine and privately worried that the editors might decide to discontinue the tradition for which I was developing such affection. Fortunately, they did not. With the exception of a picture of the new Relief Society Building which appeared in 1956, and certainly deserved the priority it received, the art prints continued. | By 1961,,1 had begun collecting not only the Madonnas which were featured on December issue covers, but other reproductions of this universally popular subject. I am both pleased and proud that of the fifteen reproductions I prize most, eleven are from the December covers of The Relief Society Magazine. Each has a distinctive personality that has enriched my life. There seems to be no end to the pleasure they provide. To Feruzzi I am indebted for my attraction to this special field of art. I am especially fond of his choice of model for his painting. Of all the Madonnas I have seen, this is the one I find most convincing. Her angelic expression as she gazes upward is a prayer in itself and I am reminded of the scripture, "But Mary kept all of these things, and pondered them in her heart." (Luke 2:19.) Also, I love the way Feruzzi has positioned the child, sleeping against the mother's shoulder. This popular version was repeated in 1962 in color, and I doubt I shall ever grow tired of it. A print in monochrome which has endeared itself to me is Murillo's "Mother and Child," which appeared in 1955. Bartolomé Esteban Murillo was a Spanish painter of the seventeenth century. He holds a kind of record in that three of his religious paintings have been featured on Magazine covers since I began observing. I am partial to each one. "The Virgin and Child" which appeared in 1960 shows a mother of exquisite skin and fairness. "Adoration of the Shepherds" which was used in 1966 captures on canvas that thrilling emotion which tiny inMadonna Keepsakes fants inspire. One has the feeling that the baby has just been bathed and is so soft and sweet! Of all the infants depicted, this is the one I wish most to pick up and hold. At the same time, there is an aura of holiness that keeps me at a distance. "The Rest on the Flight into Egypt," by Gerard David, the 1958 December cover was the first reproduction to appear in full color. And what an exciting combination of contrasts! I think the lithographer must have been very pleased with the results of this screening. I don't know how it compares with the original, but the reproduction is a masterpiece in its own right. Mary's dress is regal blue with a red sleeve and skirt just showing. Her head covering is a subtle shade of gray that looks purple in the shadows of the folds. She is holding a bunch of grapes for the Child Jesus. Fra Filippo Lippi, whose "Madonna and Child" was used in December 1959 is of interest to me because of the number of Madonna scenes in one version or another I have encountered by this gifted artist. He was the first in Italian art to picture the Madonna in the form of a young and attractive Florentine woman. The _ particular "Madonna and Child" used on the 1959 cover is part of the Samuel H. Kress Collection which hangs in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D. C. For a long time I searched encyclopedias and art books to determine who had painted a particularly appealing "Madonna and Child" on a Christmas card I received which bore no in- 839 November 1969 scription. One day as I was scanning back issues of The Relief Society Magazine to see which paintings had been used in the past, I discovered the very identity I was seeking. A painting by Dolci, "Virgin and Child" was a Magazine cover in 1961 and the similarities startled me —the same classic features and exquisite hands, the same peace and glow. I am certain that it is the same model on each. Dolci catches a mood of adoration on the Virgin's part that is unique. Another painting I would love to see in the original is the "Madonna and Child" by Crivelli, December cover for 1965. I have two copies of this print and each is very different from the other both in textural effect and shading. I have no idea which is closer to the original. Crivelli is supposed to have contrived a type of devotional picture which is never mistaken for the work of another. At the same time, his use of tempera medium —powdered colors tempered, or held in solution by the yolk of eggs has never been surpassed. This is a method which calls for a very precise touch and does not lend itself to easy corrections. When properly applied there results a brilliancy of color impossible to obtain in oil. With indescribable patience, Crivelli delicately stroked his surfaces into embossed patterns which resemble the vetreous effects of enamelware. Curiously enough, I have been to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, where the Crivelli is part of the Jules S. Bache Collection. Perhaps I have already seen the Crivelli! 840 But this of course was before I began collecting Madonnas. How much better equipped I will be the next time having lived with my _ reproductions. Being able to recognize artists and paintings adds a_ special dimension to one's life. "Vierge a la Grappe," by Pierre Mignard which arrived just this past December came as a kind of Christmas bonus because, for the first time, I was able to identify the picture without having to look inside for the title and artist. However, the pleasurable shock of recognition was only a fringe benefit. The greater joy was the realization that this copy was mine to keep, to contemplate, explore, and study. Great painting to be enjoyed must be seen again and again. One need not be a scholar to become sensitive to paintings. He need only be willing to devote time, attention, and feelings. And for this, one needs frequent opportunities to see paintings. Ideally, we would all like to see or even own originals, but this is usually out of the question. "In default of originals," said Thomas Craven, editor of A Treasury of Modern Masterpieces, "there is but one consolation—the print—preferably the color print." He dreamed of a day when paintings would be as popular, and prints would circulate as freely as magazines. How pleased I think he would be to see a display of Relief Society Magazine December covers with reproductions which have circulated as part of the Magazine! In addition, these reproductions are potential missionary tools. Being familiar with and in- formed about these masterpieces may be just the conversation piece I will need someday as I attempt to make friends with a nonmember. Suppose I had _ been resourceful enough to give that grocery clerk my copy back in 1953? How nice it would be if I had made it a practice to keep in touch and share with her the Madonnas which followed. Or why not a full year's subscripMORTAL SEEDS Memories flow into my consciousness Like wheat falling on the threshing-floor, One on one, yet each in singleness Containing life with power to restore Vigor, strength, and beauty. Once again | hear of life as from a silent tongue, Madonna Keepsakes tion? It might have been the beginning of a conversion. Whenever you are tempted to throw away back issues of The Relief Society Magazine, I hope you will be reminded of the October 1967 cultural refinement lesson and "be wise in your choice of discards."* *From "A Courageous Letter," Out of the Best Books, Volume 3, page 11. It speaks of fields with ripened waving grain, Where youth and age both work and play among Ever-blooming flowers. Sorrows smile As you hold my hand and touch my cheek. Loved memories, please, stay with me awhile. Oh, diary of my heart, remember, speak, Let me glean from memory's golden field Mortal seeds, that bring eternal yield. —Margaret B. Cox 841 November 1969 Lora Ann Gifford Christensen, Springdale, Utah, Zion Park Stake, has been sewing and making lovely articles of handwork since she was twelve years old. Much of the clothing she has sewed has been created through her own ingenuity. She makes patterns herself. Her most recent undertakings have been making miniature and regular sized hats for tourists. She has averaged making twenty quilts a year for more than twenty-five years. Her family of eleven children, thirty-six grandchildren, and twenty-eight great-grandchildren have received many items of clothing and quilts from her. She is a generous and faithful Relief Society member, and still is an active visiting: 4, ro a as wwil S Ina Wilson Hummell, St. George Stake, Utah, has filled the lives and homes of those close to her with many lovely handmade articles, ranging from exquisite quilts to delightful children's toys. She has a talent for painting, and makes the faces of dolls and other toys truly come to life. Sister Hummel is the mother of five children and there are nine grandchildren to add to her joy. All of them are appreciative of her talents, but more so of her wonderful spirit and the things she teaches them. She has served as a counselor in the district Relief Society in Missouri and Arkansas, and is serving as a faithful visiting teacher. Her greatest delight is to be living near a temple where she may join with her husband in doing temple work. 842 KEART ROOM FOR HOME Alice Morrey Bailey Chapter 6 SYNOPSIS: Several major changes have taken place in the Freeman family as a direct result of the parents, Kim and Mary Ann, bringing Kim's aged father to their home in Los Angeles to care for him after an accident which has broken his hip. Kim has promised his father that the lovely homestead in Mayville, Utah, will not be sold, as Kim's sisters wished to do in order to put their father in a rest home for the aged. Mary Ann has had to resign her teaching position, halving the family income. However, it has been a time of growth for them all. They hope Grandfather Freeman will be weaned away from his home in Utah. ® Emily's letter to her father had a profound effect on him. After going to bed without dinner he pushed most of his breakfast aside. "Dad, you must eat more than that to keep up your strength. You can't exercise without nourishment." "I know, Mary Ann. And I have to keep up my exercise or I won't be able to take care of things when I get home, will ~ "Indeed you won't," said Mary Ann with a heartiness she did not feel. It was plain Father Freeman had not relinquished his hope of going back to Mayville and living alone, a rank impossibility. Yet he did little or no practicing in walking that day, and his mind was on home. "They can't sell it out from under me in any way, can they?" By "they" he meant his daughters, Francine Grady and Emily Dodd. "Not a way in the world," assured Mary Ann. "Don't give it another thought. Kim would 843 November 1969 not let them if there was. He promised you, remember, that it would never be sold in his lifetime or in yours." But that night Kim broached the subject to Mary Ann himself. "Funny thing happened today. My boss asked about Dad's place in Mayville. He wants to buy it." "What in the world for?" asked Mary Ann, astonished. "T've talked quite a bit about it—not selling it, just describing it—how pretty it is, the stone house, the seclusion, the garden and the cow—just talk through the noon hour, we men telling about our boyhood. About a month ago he picked up interest. He nearly fell over when I told him how low the taxes were. Today he out and out asked to buy it." "Of course you told him it is not for sale," said Mary Ann, a little fear edging her heart— a fear that was not alone for her father-in-law. "Of course!" "What does he want it for?" "To retire in. He's past retirement age, and I didn't think he needed to, owning his own business as he does, but he says he has enough to live modestly and is tired of working. Anyhow, he could turn the business over to his son. Mayville sounds good to him, and I guess it is my fault, the way I have talked it up." As if to confirm the conversation there was a letter from Francine. "... An odd thing is happening here. People from California are buying up every old place they can get to retire in. Jensens sold 844 their place with their house on it for fifteen hundred dollars. Of course it needs fixing up, but these people are glad to get it. They say they can't afford to retire in California, the taxes are too high, and some of them just want to live in small towns. It might be a good chance, Dad, if you want to sell your place. Now, I'm not urging you, remember. I just thought I'd mention it." "T am not selling the place!" said her father, agitated and almost angry. "Why do they keep talking about it?" Mary Ann noticed a fine tremor in his hands and the pulse that beat heavily in his throat, and her heart ached for him. "T don't think Francine means anything, Dad," she said calmly, to calm him down. "You don't have to sell it. Kim won't let anything happen to it." Plosemary had come in to hear the conversation and she flew to hug her grandfather. "That sweet place? Never! Mother! Dad! Everybody! The most wonderful thing has happened. Just wait until I show you." She unwrapped a parcel done up in wrapping paper and tissue that was crumpled from previous use. Several pieces of very tarnished silver issued from it. "Where did you get that junk?" said Tommy, coming in. "Junk?" cried Rosemary. "That's sterling silver,. Tommy Freeman." "Well, where did you get it?" "From a loan shark." "You've got to be kidding!" said Tommy inelegantly. "T'm not, and I'm so excited. It happened this way. You know how I want sterling silver and how expensive it is. Well, I was Passing this loan place down on Broadway and here was a sign in the window about sterling silver. I went in and it was fabulous. Everything, guns, guitars, jewelry, Sewing machines— all jumbled in together. I asked about the silver and he showed it to me—some heavy Swedish stuff with a crude design, and I was disappointed. It was not a pattern I could use at all, and there were only eight place settings. Getting the other four would be practically impossible, so I was disappointed and about to go. Then I asked him if he had any more sterling and he said some, but not full sets of anything, and he took me upstairs. He had lots of odds and ends and I looked at them all. Then I saw this!" It was a very ornate pattern built around a solid shaft, and So tarnished it was hard to appreciate it. Rosemary had raced for the silver polish and was at work on one of the forks. They all watched with intense interest as the beauty of the piece came forth, the satin finish of the shaft, the ornate pattern jumping to bold relief by her polishing of the high parts. "You leave the tarnish in the low parts," explained Rosemary. "It adds richness." "But there are only three Place settings and a few pieces," objected Mary Ann. "The serving spoons and the Sugar shell and the butter server," said Rosemary. "But it is a good American company and a retired pattern. [ can add to Heart Room for Home it indefinitely, and I got it for less than half price! I'm going to every loan place in town." "It is brand new," observed Mary Ann. "Some little bride registered for it, and when hard times came she had to pawn it and then couldn't redeem it." "I don't want to think of that," said Rosemary. "It was meant for me, and [']] have more of it. Now, Tommy, what's with you?" Mary Ann hadn't noticed until then how subdued Tommy seemed. "I met my girl and I know her name. It is Lisbeth King." "Classy!" Pronounced Rosemary. "How did you meet her?" "She dropped a book leaving class and I picked it up for her. It was the first time she looked into my eyes. She said thank you—very warmly." "And then?" prompted Rosemary. "And then I made a dumb fool of myself. I said: 'Will you Marry me?' " "You didn't! Any girl would think that terribly romantic. What did she Say?" "She turned all iceberg. If looks could kill! She said: 'I beg your pardon!' like a duchess." "Did you expect her to gush? At least she is no easy pick-up." "It's worse than that. She's engaged. She has a diamond the size of a hen's egg." "Oh, Tommy! I'm sorry. Too bad for it to end that way!" I t was a relief to Tommy's parents, listening in. Maybe next time Tommy would go at it a little more rationally, now that he had done a right-about 845 November 1969 face in his attitude toward marrying. "Kind? Who said anything about it ending? Just makes it tougher on me, that's all." Rosemary shrugged. 'More power to you, brother." The let-down after the Christmas holidays was an ebb-time for them all. James and Carol moved to Hawaii, visiting them only once more to say good-bye. "What about my wedding?" said Rosemary. "I want you back for that." "We'll be here. We'll fly. Really, we're not much farther away than we were. We expect to see you as often." It didn't seem the same to Mary Ann and Kim, especially as Dick signed a contract to teach at Church College in Hawaii and he and Jennefer were going to move there as soon as school was out. "Not before Tommy's graduation and your wedding, though, Rosemary, dear." eJ anuary and February were dismal with rain and Father Freeman complained that everything was damp all the time, even the towels and sheets, and it was not like him to complain, as _ he was normally very appreciative of everything and sought the good in all. "It may be cold in Utah, but it is dry and warm in the house. This cold may not be low in temperature, but it cuts to the bone." "Youre getting thinner, Dad," said Mary Ann. "You're worrying too much, and you must eat more." He agreed, but ate less and less and his walking diminished. 846 His eyes had a faraway look and it was always mountainward. Kim and Mary Ann held many worried conversations. About him. They took him to the doctor they had first consulted on his arrival in Los Angles, Dr. Judd. "Physically he is no worse than when I first saw him," said Dr. Judd. "It takes a year or more for the bone to heal and put on strength, no matter how you look at it. His mental attitude is dragging him down and can become serious if he won't eat well. You'll have to distract him, make him happy." The family turned handsprings to distract him to no avail. "T don't think I'll go," he said when Tommy and his father were getting ready for priesthood meeting, and later in the week, when it came their regular temple night, he told Kim and Mary Ann to go without him. "Pll be all right with Tommy here. I don't feel up to it." Rosemary haunted the loan shops without finding any more of her silver, so the edge of the first find was dulling. "They all say the same: they don't keep it when it becomes saleable, when the redemption time lapses. They sell it to some man who takes it off their hands. He picks up practically all the silver on the coast." "What does he do with it?" asked Mary Ann. "It must be for sale. Why don't you contact him?" "Nobody knows his address. They just say he comes a couple of times a week. I couldn't hope to catch him, but I did leave a note with one of the dealers. Father FreeMan's door had been Open and he heard the whole Conversation. 847 November 1969 He was weeping impotent tears when Mary Ann went to tuck him in for the night. "Tt's all my fault," he said. "An old man ought to die when he gets this old, and be a bother to no one." "Kim!" called Mary Ann, concerned, and Kim came. It took their combined efforts to assure Father Freeman that they were not in immediate danger of eviction, and _ that they loved him above and beyond the mere thought of money, and that it was right for him to be with them. "How happy do you think we could be enjoying even wealth, if we knew you were unhappy in an old people's home?" "You knew all the time I couldn't go home in the spring, didn't you, Kim? After that we'll take our vacation and take you home for a visit." "T didn't want it to be a visit," Kim's father said, but he was calmed down enough to go to sleep. Kim had no more than reached home the following Monday, which was the first day of March, than the doorbell rang. Kim's boss was on the doorstep. They admitted him wonderingly, but of course cordially. "T came to meet your father," he said, and Father Freeman looked up in surprise from his wheel chair, which he had reverted to using. "Mr. Shelton, I am most pleased to meet you," Father Freeman responded courteously. "My son has many fine things to say of you." "Good! Good!" said Mr. Shelton brusquely. "Did he tell you I want to buy your place in Utah? I believe in coming right to the point." Father Freeman looked at him in bewilderment, and then at Kim. "Kim," he finally said, "is this your idea?" (To be continued) ON DOORS CLOSING AND OPENING A new door does not always open wide Immediately when the familiar door clicks Shut; and so one stands lost, inside The unfamiliar loneness till the pricks Of shutters on the retina adjust And shadows form in new dimensions like Or unlike what is gone. The question: must One hurdle forward, seek another dike To satisfy this need that one be used, Or stand and wait, slowly gathering strength Until reason rises, unconfused And in perspective; and we learn at length That doors within the mind must open first Before the heart accepts a new sunburst. —Mabel Jones Gabbott 848 FROM THE FIELD All material submitted for publication in this department should be sent through the stake Relief Society presidents, or mission Relief Society supervisors. One annual submission will be accepted, as space permits, from each stake and mission of the Church. All submissions must be received within two months of the event described. Submissions should be addressed to the Editorial Department, Relief Society Magazine, Salt Lake City, Utah 84111. Relief Society Activities Gooding Stake (Idaho) Relief Society Presents "An Evening of Art," April 25, 1969 Barbara Durfee, President, Gooding Stake Relief Society, reports: ''Members of the stake board donned lovely long formals to help make our 'Evening of Art' a memorable occasion. The theme for the event was 'Mother Makes Her Home a Place of Heavenly Beauty.' We tried to include every phase of Relief Society in our presentations. Music included four lovely numbers by the Singing Mothers. A dramatization 'To Hearken and to Obey' was presented. Homemaking skills were represented in a fashion show narrated by Shirley Haslem, and in displays showing each room of the home: how to decorate it, or useful suggestions regarding its use. Cultural refinement was represented by an art display of original works by the sisters and a booklet of original poems was given as a favor. An original piano solo was presented by Jeanette Thornock. The Magazine and visiting teaching departments each had impressive displays.: "We received many lovely compliments on the evening, and we received much loyal help and cooperation from the ward officers and members."' 849 November 1969 Mexico City North Stake Celebrates Anniversary of Relief Society March 17, 1969 Sister Estrada, a ward president, cutting the Relief Society birthday cake; the gentleman standing behind her is Agricol Lozano, Stake President; to his left is the Stake Relief Society President Lucrecia Juarez de Suarez, and on his right are the ward Relief Society presidents. Sister Suarez reports: '"'Our stake celebrated the birthday of Relief Society by remembering our pioneer sisters. As Sister Estrada cut the cake, she gave a brief narration about the pioneers. The dress she is wearing in the picture belonged to a great-aunt of her husband. The Singing Mothers performed and all the ward presidents were honored. The large cake was enjoyed by all." Cascade Stake (Washington) Holds Annual Relief Society Day May 19, 1969 Mabel M. Collins, President, Cascade Stake Relief Society, reports: ''Three hundred sisters of the Cascade Stake enjoyed a program, luncheon, displays, and a sewing demonstration at our annual Relief Society day. The program honored the visiting teachers of the stake. The dramatization, 'To Hearken and to Obey,' by Luacine C. Fox was presented. "A lovely floral arrangement made by Helen Barton, stake Secretary-Treasurer was presented to the ward with the highest percentage of visiting teaching throughout the year. Following the program, a luncheon was served. Beside her plate, each sister found a pattern for a 'Happy Coat' and a list of sewing hints. "The fashion show was presented by women from the ward Relief Societies. Marilyn Haymond, stake cultural refinement class leader, gave the narration to a background of soft music."'
