Doxey (Reading Assignment: Doctrine and Covenants, Section 135.) Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 OBJECTIVE: The Latter-day Saint woman, knowing that The Book of Mormon was translated by the Prophet Joseph Smith through the power of God, gains increased faith in Jesus Christ as her Savior. INTRODUCTION One of Joseph Smith's contributions to the salvation of men in this world was the bringing forth of "... The Book of Mormon, which he translated by the gift and power of God...." (D&C 135:3.) The Book of Mormon, translated from gold plates received from the resurrected Moroni, an ancient American prophet, is a condensed history of people from the old world who were divinely directed to America. The first of these peoples was the Jaredites from the Tower of Babel. (The Book of Ether.) Toward the end of their existence, a colony of Israelites, under the leadership of the prophet Lehi, came from Jerusalem about 600 B. C. In time the Israelites divided into two factions known as Nephites and Lamanites, the former being white and the: latter becoming dark-skinned. Another group, known as Mulekites, came from Palestine about the time of the overthrow of the kingdom of Judah in 589 B. C. A merger of this people, with other inhabitants of the land occurred several 857 November 1969 centuries after Lehi's colony landed in what is now America. (Omni 12:22.) Prophets of God taught principles of salvation to The Book of Mormon people, warning them of temporal and spiritual destruction if they became unrighteous. The predictions of the prophets were literally fulfilled. The Jaredites destroyed themselves by civil war, and the Nephites were later swept off the earth by the Lamanites. North and South American Indian tribes of today are probably descendants of the Lamanites. PURPOSES OF THE BOOK OF MORMON Moronirecordedsome purposes of The Book of Mormon as follows: (1) to show unto the house of Israel what the Lord has done for their fathers, (2) to inform latter-day Israel of the covenants of the Lord that they might not be cast off forever, and (3) "... To the convincing of the Jew and Gentile that Jesus is the Christ, the Eternal God...." (Title page, Book of Mormon.) The Book of Mormon prophet Nephi saw in vision other ways in which this book of scripture would be of utmost value to people in the last days. First, it would constitute another witness with the Bible that God's purposes would be fulfilled in behalf of his covenanted people. (2 Ne. 29:8.) Second, it would establish the truth of the Bible. (1 Ne. 13:40.) Class Discussion If you were to select the most important purpose of the coming forth of The Book of Mormon, which one would it be? 858 THE BIBLE AND THE BOOK OF MORMON Not only does The Book of Mormon witness to the truth of the Bible, but the Bible testifies to the truth of the Nephite record. This testimony came to many Bible prophets who were inspired to prophesy concerning The Book of Mormon. Ezekiel foresaw that the "stick of Judah" (Bible) would in the last days be joined with the "stick of Ephraim" or "Joseph" (Book of Mormon) when the gathering of Israel would take place. These two records of different continents would be one in bringing people to an acceptance of Jesus Christ as their Savior. (Ezek. 37:16-21.) Significant among the prophecies regarding The Book of Mormon is the one recorded in chapter 29 of Isaiah. A "book," or the writings of a people who should speak from the dust, would be ".. Delivered to him that is not learned...." (Joseph Smith.) The words of the book, however, would be taken "... To one that is learned...." (Prof. Charles Anthon), who would fulfill Isaiah's prophecy that he could not read a sealed book. (vs. 11-12.) The "book" would be in the world and then the Holy Land would ".. Be turned into a fruitful field...." (v. 17.) The Bible and The Book of Mormon testify of each other as God's people recorded scripture on the eastern and western continents. Class Discussion What does it mean to you that the Bible testifies of The Book of Mormon? CONTRIBUTIONS OF THE BOOK OF MORMON The Book of Mormon shows men the way to salvation in the following three ways: 1. It imparts a knowledge of the true gospel of Jesus Christ. 2. It proclaims the reality of the resurrection of Jesus Christ and of the future life for all men. 3. It assists men to live the gospel plan by witnessing to them, by the power of the Holy Ghost, that the book is true. THE BOOK IMPARTS KNOWLEDGE The Prophet Joseph Smith gave the following evaluation of The Book of Mormon:. I told the brethren [Twelve Apostles] that the Book of Mormon was the most correct of any book on earth, and the keystone of our religion, and a man would get nearer to God by abiding by its precepts, than by any other book. (Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, compiled by Joseph Fielding Smith, p. 194.) The Three Witnesses to the truth of this book testified that it had been "... Translated by the gift and power of God...." and that "... We know of a surety that the work is true." (The Book of Mormon, The Testimony of Three Witnesses, Oliver Cowdery, David Whitmer, and Martin Harris.) The Lord revealed that The Book of Mormon contains the fulness of the gospel of Jesus Christ. (D&C 20:9; 27:5.) What is the gospel? It is the principles, doctrines, and ordinances revealed from God for the salvation of those who will accept them. The Book of Mormon contains the fulness of the gospel because it is a record of God's dealings with a people who had the gospel Lesson Department fulness and because it records what men must do to gain salvation. A brief summary of some fundamental Book of Mormon doctrines, found in the Doctrine and Covenants is as follows: (1) The existence, eternal nature, and creative power of God. (2) The creation of man in God's image and likeness. (3) Man should love, serve, and worship the only living and true God and no other being. (4) The fall of man came by transgression of God's commandments. (5) Because of the fall, Christ's sacrifice was made as foretold in scriptures. (6) Jesus, though tempted, was sinless. (7) Jesus was crucified, resurrected, and ascended into heaven. (8) Salvation in the kingdom of God is dependent upon acceptance of the gospel and endurance in faith to the end. (9) Salvation is for faithful believers who lived before as well as during and after the earthly ministry of Jesus. (10) The "... Father, Son, and Holy Ghost are one God, infinite and eternal, without end." (D&C 20:28.) (11) Justification and sanctification through the grace of Jesus Christ are just and true. (12) Man may fall from grace and depart from God. (D&C 20:17-34.) CLARIFICATION OF GOSPEL TRUTHS The Book of Mormon adds to our understanding of Bible teachings. The following Beatitudes from Jesus' discourse to the Nephites compared with the rendition in the Bible are examples. First read the verses without the italicized words as given in the Bible and then the entire verse as it appears in The Book of Mormon. 859 November 1969 Yea, blessed are the poor in spirit who come unto me, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. (3 Ne. 12:3; c. F. Matt. 5:3.) (emphasis added) And blessed are all they who do hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled with the Holy Ghost. (3 Ne. 12:6; c. F. Matt. 5:6.) (emphasis added) Class Discussion Do you know of other clarifications of truths from The Book of Mormon? PROPHECIES OF THE LAST DAYS The condition of the apostate religious world is clearly depicted in prophecy, a condition which will eventually bring great destruction at the time of the second coming of Christ. (2 Ne. 28.) The role of the house of Israel in the last days as an instrument in bringing about God's purposes for man, and the gathering of the Jewish people to the Holy Land are other parts of these events. (2 Ne. 30:2-10; 3 Ne. 20:29-36; 1 Ne. 22:1-12:) THE REALITY OF THE FUTURE LIFE Class Discussion What is the principal message of The Book of Mormon for the people of today? The title page of The Book of Mormon states that it is to convince every man that Jesus is the Christ, the Eternal God. What does this mean? Essentially, it means that Jesus Christ is divine, the literal Son of God, who has provided the means through his atonement that man may be saved. It also provides the answer to the principal need of the world today—a faith in the reality of the future existence. The Book of Mormon stands as a 860 witness of the divinity of Jesus Christ as the Being who made it possible for all people to be resurrected from the dead. Moroni, the last historian-prophet of the Nephite nation, having died about 1500 years before, came to the Prophet Joseph Smith as a resurrected being. Of him, the Prophet wrote: Moroni, the person who deposited the plates, from whence the Book of Mormon was translated, in a hill in Manchester, Ontario County, New York, being dead, and raised again therefrom, appeared unto me.... (Elders' Journal, Far West, Mo., July 1838.) Nephite prophets upon the American continent were inspired to witness to the continued conscious existence of man. The spirit world or the place where the departed dead live as conscious, living beings, prior to the resurrection, is described and attested to. Alma testifies that at death the spirit enters the world of spirits where the righteous enter paradise and the wicked are in prison. Happiness is the reward of those who have accepted the atonement of Christ, while those who chose evil works are in a state of sorrow because of their iniquity. (Alma 40:11-14.) The last testimony of the prophet Moroni was that at death his spirit would "... Rest in the paradise of God, until my spirit and body shall again reunite...." (Moroni 10:34.) The resurrection of Jesus, as the first to receive this blessing on this earth, is related in The Book of Mormon. His dramatic appearance to the Nephites begins with the people hearing a voice from heaven which pierced them to the center, causing their hearts to burn. They heard these words: Behold my Beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased, in whom I have glorified my name—hear ye him. (3 Ne. 11:7.) They saw a man descending out of heaven, clothed in a white robe, who said: Behold, I am Jesus Christ, whom the prophets testified shall come into the world. And behold, I am the light and the life of the world; and I have drunk out of that bitter cup which the Father hath. Given me, and have glorified the Father in taking upon me the sins of the world, in the which I have suffered the will of the Father in all things from the beginning. (3 Ne. 11:10-11.) Thereafter, the multitude felt the prints of the nails in his hands and the wound in his side, witnessing the reality of his resurrection with flesh and bones. Man lives as a spirit entity at death awaiting the resurrection of his body and a uniting with his spirit never to be divided again in death. This message the world needs today. Unbelief in the reality of life after death does not alter the truth. Class Discussion Discuss the ways in which The Book of Mormon is a testator of the reality of the future life. A POWER FOR SALVATION The greatest evidence of religious truth is the knowledge which comes through the Holy Ghost. This power not only affects the mind but also the heart. The process of testimony is the Spirit speaking to man's spirit. The impression of the Spirit upon man's soul is so powerful that the knowledge continues as long as the person is worthy. Lesson Department To seal the validity of The Book of Mormon for those to whom this record would come, the prophet Moroni gave the following promise: And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost. And by the power of the Holy Ghost ye may know the truth of all things. (Moroni 10:4-5.) The fulfillment of this promise is known to thousands of members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The Savior promised that if one would accept his doctrine, he would know of its truth. (John 7:16-17.) The Holy Ghost has operated in the lives of those who seek diligently as they strive to keep the commandments. Discuss The testimony of the truth from the Holy Ghost is more powerful in a person's life than a vision. THE BOOK OF MORMON AND SALVATION What place does the testimony of The Book of Mormon have in one's personal salvation? The answer to this question is found both in the scriptures and in the lives of hundreds of thousands of people. Basically, when one learns by the power of the Holy Ghost that the Book of Mormon is true, he also receives the knowledge that Jesus Christ lives as an immortal and resurrected being. (Moroni 10:7.) 861 November 1969 Class Discussion In view of the contents of this lesson, why would you believe that The Book of Mormon contributes to the evaluation of Joseph Smith, namely, that he had done "more, save Jesus only, for the salyation of men in this world, than any other man that ever lived in it'? IMPLEMENTATION The Book of Mormon stands as a convincing witness that Joseph Smith is a prophet of God. Not only do its teachings bear testimony of the gospel of Jesus Christ, but they impress their divinity by the spirit which accompanies scripture. There is power in truth which the spiritually minded recognize. (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 6, p. 273 [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereafter referred to as DHC}.) The Book of Mormon is a powerful book. It convinces men of the truth of the gospel of Jesus Christ through its clarification of the doctrines and ordinances which save. Great truths that affect the intellect and the heart are found throughout its pages. The Book of Mormon is a witness for Jesus Christ as the literal Son of God who was the firstborn from the dead. Not only does it attest to his divinity and resurrection, but to the truth PRECIOUS JEWEL 862 that all men shall receive their bodies again never to be separated in death. Faith in the reality of this experience—conscious existence forever, eternally—is the present need of an unbelieving world. The Book of Mormon is in the world for this express purpose—a testifier. This divine record has stood the test of time and will continue to stand as a bulwark of strength for those who have learned from its pages eternal truth by which they guide their lives. Above all else, this book of scripture has instilled faith in God and in his Son Jesus Christ. The Holy Ghost has borne testimony of the truth of The Book of Mormon, making it one of the greatest of all books in influencing the lives of people. They have endured hardships, trials, and great difficulties because the Spirit has continued to motivate them through the truths of this ancient record. All men may know the truth for themselves. To know what the Lord requires of man and then to apply that knowledge from the scriptures is a rewarding experience for the faithful. Elder John A. Widtsoe expressed it this way: The degree of faith possessed by any man depends not upon the extent of his knowledge, but upon the certainty of his knowledge, which leads to the proper use of his knowledge.... (John A. Widtsoe, Joseph Smith, p. 163.) Life has Many facets, Like a fine-cut diamond, And in its heart the sparkling fire Is love. —Vesta N. Fairbairn VISITING TEACHER MESSAGE — Truths to Live By (Correlated With the Family Home Evening Manual, 1968-69) Message 5—Weak Things May Become Strong Alice Colton Smith Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 OBJECTIVE: To understand that by overcoming our weaknesses we can become strong. Tall, slim, and beautiful at eighteen, she gazed discontentedly at her mother. "I don't have any special gift," she complained. "T have only weaknesses." Have you shared, with this teenager, an overwhelming sense of inadequacy? When you wanted to make a musical instrument sing, have you ever struck a wrong note? When you wanted to share a particularly radiant sunset have you responded less than eloquently with, "It's beautiful," having no words to match your emotion? Have you wished that you were more able? In such moments of inadequacy it helps to remember, among others, Moroni, Moses, and Paul. Moroni fearing the mockery of the Gentiles "... Because of awkwardness of our [his] hands" (Ether 12:24) complained, "... When we write we behold our weakness, and stumble because of the placing of our words...." (Ether 12:25.) The Lord answered him saying, "I give unto men weakness that they may be humble; and my grace is sufficient for all men that humble themselves before me; for if they humble themselves before me, and have faith in me, then will I make weak things become strong unto them." (Ether 12:27.) As we read the later words of Moroni, we know the truth of God's promise, because Moroni expressed some of the greatest concepts given to man. The Apostle Paul whose magnificent gospel teachings make up the great bulk of the apostolic writings of the New Testament said: And lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure. For this thing I besought the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me. And he said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for my strength is made perfect in weakness. Most gladly therefore will I rather glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me. Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses for Christ's sake: for when I am weak, then am I strong. (II Cor. 12:7-10.) 863 November 1969 Moses said unto the Lord, "... I am not eloquent... But I am slow of speech, and of a slow tongue. And the Lord said unto him.... I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt say." (Exodus 4:10-12.) The great promise of the Lord is to all of us. We grow through struggle. If we humble ourselves and have faith, our weaknesses will help us to grow strong. HOMEMAKING—Development Through Homemaking Education Woman's Role in Family Preparedness 'Discussion 5—''She... Worketh Willingly With Her Hands." (Prov. 31:13) Celestia J. Taylor Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 OBJECTIVE: To alert the Latter-day Saint woman to the wisdom of preparing for family security through home storage of foods. INTRODUCTION The people of our Latter-day Saint communities are accustomed to the idea of home food storage. Ever since our greatgrandparents entered these valleys of the mountains, we have been planting gardens, reaping rich harvests, and storing the grains, fruits, and vegetables which they have yielded, to supply us with food for the winter months. Few of our parents would have felt secure if they had not known that their shelves were well stocked with jars of home-canned fruits and vegetables and that their supply of sugar, flour, and other staples was complete.. Many of us, together with our Church members in other parts of the world, are still cognizant of 864 the need for family preparedness and are able to look with pride on our shelves of delicious jams, jellies, pickles, and bottled fruits of every kind and our cupboards and pantries supplied with all the necessities for the year ahead. Some of us, on the other hand, have forsaken these traditions and have accustomed ourselves to the convenience of the corner grocery store and are living from week to week with little or no regard for the future. We need to remind ourselves that a supply of food in our homes may be much more valuable than money under emergency conditions when food might be difficult to obtain or in the event of misfortune such as accident or loss of health which could result in loss of employment. WHAT FOODS SHALL WE STORE? Requirements of people and storage conditions in different areas and countries are so varied that the preparation of a list of what to store would not be practical. Any good plan for a year's food supply should be based on a good plan for a daily food supply. It is most desirable to store those foods which are normally used by the family. It is recommended that we eat the stored supplies and replace them as we use them on a rotation basis. The saying "store what you eat and eat what you store" is a wise and practical one. It is not wise to store a quantity of food that the family does not normally eat or that is not acceptable in the regular family food pattern. DETERMINING OUR FOOD NEEDS There are several factors which govern the needs of a family and determine the kinds and amounts of food to be stored. Because of this, our Church leaders have in their wisdom left the details of food storage to each individual family to work out for itself. Our needs, then, will vary according to our family's particular tastes, situation, and circumstances, as determined by (1) the climate in which we live; (2) the size of the family; (3) the ages of the family members; (4) the occupations and physical activities of the members; (5) the likes and dislikes of the family; and (6) any special diet problems within the family. MEETING THE COST OF FOOD STORAGE Probably the most significant reason why many of our people Lesson Department do not have a reserve of food supplies and other provisions is that they think they cannot afford it. It is true that many families are not in a position to purchase a ear's supply in addition to their daily needs, but there are ways by which, with careful planning and systematic procedures, this can be accomplished. 1. By home canning and buying in season. 2. By over-purchasing. It is suggested that when we do our marketing we "over-purchase" at least ten percent on storable foods that the family ordinarily uses. By careful planning this practice will not upset the budget but can actually be absorbed as part of the weekly purchasing allotment. This additional supply should be designated as storage food and should be used in rotation as new stocks are purchased. Are we willing to curb our appetites for luxury items and nonessentials long enough to build up our supply from what we save? 3. By taking advantage of food sales. If we watch the markets and take advantage of reliable food sales, we can buy food at reduced prices without sacrificing quality. A WELL-BALANCED FOOD SUPPLY A well-balanced diet should come first in any kind of food planning, since the health of the family members is influenced more by the food they eat than by any other factor. Any wise homemaker is aware of the nutritional requirements of a good basic food plan. But just as it is neither wise nor feasible to work out any over-all food storage plan, neither is it possible to suggest a nutritional plan that would satisfy every family's needs. In a general way, however, all of the suggestions that have been given could be modified and 865 November 1969 adapted to fill every family's nutritional needs. The following classes of foods for storage will supply the basic nutritional needs. 1. Staples—Wheat, beans, rice, sugar or honey, salt, and vitamins. 2. Dehydrated foods—Eggs, milk, fruit, and vegetables. These augment the staples. 3. Canned foods—Fish, meats, nuts, juices, etc. (These require rotation if not used after a year's time). 4. Water. It is suggested that every family keep on hand a supply of water in addition to that stored in home tanks. Emptied fruit bottles should be filled with water and sterilized. Chlorinated water may be safely stored also. CONCLUSION The success of any food storage plan will depend, in large measure, upon our attitude toward it. When we, the mothers and homemakers, can see the wisdom of having a good food storage program, and the foresight and ingenuity to carry it through, there is no doubt that our families will respond enthusiastically and that its success will be assured. SOCIAL RELATIONS—Immortality and Eternal Life Lesson 5—Be of Good Cheer Alberta H. Christensen (Reference:! Mmortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, Selections from the Writings and Messages of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Melchizedek Priesthood Course of Study, 1969-70, lessons 29, 36, and 45.) Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 OBJECTIVE: To remind the Latter-day Saint woman that the gospel of Christ brings a message of gladness to her home. INTRODUCTION "Lift up your head and be of good cheer...." (3 Ne. 1:13.) These are words of the Lord spoken to Nephi, son of Nephi, in an hour of great. Need. It was a crucial, faith-testing time for those Nephites who had kept faith with the beliefs and traditions of their fathers, for there were 866 many among them who began to say that the time had passed for the prophecies of Samuel to be fulfilled. Nephi, with head bowed in earnest prayer, cried mightily unto the Lord in behalf of the believers. He was in critical need of divine assurance, for there had been a day set apart whereon all who believed in the prophets would be destroyed unless the sign of the Savior's birth was given. These words came in answer to his humble prayer for that assurance: Lift up your head and be of good cheer; for behold, the time is at hand, and on this night shall the sign be given, and on the morrow come I into the world, to show unto the world that I will fulfill all that which I have caused to be spoken by the mouth of my holy prophets. (3 Ne. 1:13.) This scripture leads us into the general subject of this discussion. While there is no single lesson in the current Melchizedek Priesthood course of study considering this theme specifically, there are many comments and statements in the lessons which are relevant and affirm the fact that we individually and the Church membership collectively have many blessings for which we should be grateful and which warrant our being of good cheer. Throughout the lesson these two questions will be uppermost in mind: 1. How may the words of the Lord "be of good cheer" apply to the Latter-day Saint woman in her home? 2. In a world beset with problems and sin, what should make the Latter-day Saint people, as a collective group, be of good cheer? Class Question How would you answer the foregoing two questions at this point in the class discussion? PROPHECY FULFILLED Nephi must have lifted his head toward heaven in indescribable joy, his faith rewarded in the knowledge that on the morrow, in Lesson Department the city of David as foretold by prophecy, the Christ child would be born. How great must have been the gratitude of all the believers when, at the going down of the sun, there was no darkness and when a new star appeared in the heavens! Approximately three decades later the risen Lord appeared in person to the more righteous of the Nephites. Perhaps no scripture which we have is more spiritually impressive than that which records his brief ministry among them. The healing of the sick, blessing of little children, the calling of the twelve disciples with commission and authority to perform all necessary ordinances therewith—surely here was reason for optimism, for increased faith for the people collectively as well as individually. FOR THE INDIVIDUAL: HERE AND NOW Class Discussion Questions 1. What does being "of good cheer" mean to you? An international English dictionary defines "cheer" as that which gives comfort, gladness, encouragement, joy. 2. With this definition in mind, how important to family relationships is an atmosphere of gladness or good cheer within the home? 3. In your opinion who is most responsible for setting the tone of emotional atmosphere in the home? Discuss briefly. 4. What may a mother do to maintain an atmosphere of good cheer within the home? Name several things. 5. In what ways may the happy, positive attitude of one woman influence a neighborhood? A number of women were asked to name one specific thing or circumstance of a religious nature or otherwise which could inject a feeling of good cheer into 867 November 1969 an otherwise unhappy atmosphere. Their replies follow: 1. I suppose you might say that I am a fair-weather bird. Sunshine—just plain sunshine breaking through dark clouds can do more for my emotional attitude than almost anything. 2. I love people and I am always moved emotionally by the loyalty of friends. If I am discouraged or in an unhappy attitude of mind, the good wishes of a friend who has faith in me can lift me almost immediately into a happier mental climate. 3. The laughter of little children is a precious, contagious thing. It is to me the very essence of good cheer. 4. To observe a mother act with great courage although struggling against difficult obstacles fills me with admiration. But it also causes me to evaluate my own blessings. Invariably I am lifted from a state of apathy or selfpity to one of cheerful gratitude. 5. To be loved by someone is to me the great source of comfort and joy. That someone may be husband, child, parent, or a friend. 6. I believe that personal prayer has a greater influence upon my emotional attitude than anything else. Regardless of the situation or the depth of my discouragement, when I rise from my knees the world looks brighter. 7. To see or hear of one of our children performing in accord with the ideals and teachings of our home gives me a special lift of spirit. 8. Very simple things give me pleasure. Just watch me receiving a compliment or wearing a new dress! 9. To give of oneself by way of kindly service to others brings a special kind of personal satisfaction. This service always fills me with a sense of wellbeing and gladness. 10. To overcome a personal weakness and to be aware of a certain inner growth which results give me an indescribable feeling of joy. THE COLLECTIVE GROUP: HERE AND NOW As members of the Church to which we belong we may rightly be of good cheer. In spite of problems and individual human errors, 868 we may be happy and grateful because: 1. The Church operates through the delegated authority of the priesthood of God. Does any other church today have this? 2. We witness the miracle of change that the gospel brings into the lives of individuals. 3. We see the willingness of dedicated members of the Church to serve wherever and whenever called. 4. We know that the missionary program throughout the world is increasingly successful. 5. We observe an increased interest in genealogical research and temple work. 6. We see that material resources make possible the building of temples and churches throughout the world. More may be added. Discuss briefly. INTO A DARKNESS President Clark, who made an intensive study of the Christian Church from its beginning years to the present, refers to the time after the passing of the apostles of Christ when bickerings, jealousies, strife, and contentions grew among the people. This dissension, growing in _ intensity, developed within a few generations into what we know as the Great Apostasy. A relevant excerpt by a Professor of Church History, Free Church College, Glasgow, Scotland, is used by President Clark in lesson 29 of the current Melchizedek Priesthood course of study. In the words of Dr. Islay Burns, we read: It is the year 101 of the Christian era. The last of the apostles is just dead. The rich evening radiance which in his solitary ministry had for thirty years lingered on the earth when all his companions were gone, has at last passed away, and the dark night settles down again. The age of inspiration is over,— That peerless century which began with the birth of Christ, and closed with the death of John—and the course of the ages descends once more to the ordinary level of common time. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 29.) OUT OF THAT DARKNESS For the better part of two millenniums men groped about, spiritually stumbling one over the other, vainly seeking even a spark of spiritual light, until, on that beautiful spring morning, a century and a third ago [1954], a pillar of light above the brightness of the noonday sun gradually fell from the heavens till it enveloped a young boy in the woods praying mightily for spiritual light. As he looked up he saw two personages standing in the light above him, the Father and the Son: the morning of the Dispensation of the Fullness of Times had come, breaking the darkness of the long generations of spiritual night. As in the creation light was to replace darkness, day was to follow night. (Jbid.,) The foregoing important happening is included in this particular lesson because out of that darkness came light for which the whole earth has cause and eternally shall have cause, to be gratefully glad. BECAUSE OF OUR BELIEF In various lessons of the current Melchizedek Priesthood course of study, President Clark speaks of situations and principles which give him hope and encouragement—beliefs for which he is grateful. They should make glad the hearts of all who believe. Speaking of the final judgment he states: I believe that in his [God's] justice and mercy he will give us the maximum reward for our acts, give us all that he can give; and in the reverse, I believe that he will impose upon us the minimum penalty which it is possible for him to impose. (Ibid., lesson 36.) It is a glorious thing to me to think of the freedom which we may have from Lesson Department the power of the evil one if we but live righteously in Christ Jesus. ([bid.) In an article entitled "Our Priceless Special Blessings"' written in 1954, President Clark reminds us of blessings we may take too much for granted. Years ago [he begins], I heard of a statement from a nonmember banker of the city, which has always impressed me. He is reported to have said, and of course this in jest, that Mormons have six senses: the five the ordinary mortals have and a sixth that enables him to believe Mormonism. I am more grateful than I can express for that sixth sense. All down through the ages there have been great bodies of humanity who could not believe the gospel. We are blessed that we know that life is purposeful. [Not all peoples of the world believe this.] We are blessed that we know that before we came we had an existence. We are blessed to know that we came to this earth which was created for the purpose of giving us the experiences of mortality. We are blessed that we know that if we observe and keep the commandments of the Lord that our salvation and exaltation is assured. That is part of the sixth sense which we have. We are blessed in that we believe in God, a Personage who has manifested himself in our day, in the great vision of all time.... We are blessed with that testimony, that the Son was in the image of the Father, and that we also are created in his image. That is part of our blessing. We are blessed that God not only spoke in ancient times, but that he also speaks today and has spoken, speaks with all of the definiteness and the specifications that he spoke to Israel at Mount Sinai. He does not speak alone in parables as he taught some of the multitudes.... He speaks definitely, I repeat, that all can understand. We are blessed in the faith that we have, the living, active faith which not alone inspires us to live as we should, but which gives us power and strength. Our people have defined faith as the moving cause of all action. Faith is not trust, 869 November 1969 faith is a living, and I think an intelligent, force, through which God himself performs his great work. We are blessed that, along with that faith, we have the priesthood, the Holy Priesthood of God.... We are blessed, I was going to say, beyond all, in our knowledge, our testimony, our witness that Jesus is the Christ. And what a responsibility that knowledge brings to us that he came to earth a sacrifice to answer for the Fall of Adam. How that was brought about, the Lord has not revealed. I am not sure that if he revealed it we finite minds could understand it. We are blessed with a knowledge that just as all down through history men and women have gone astray, so we know that the Church set up by the Christ and by the Apostles who followed him was not long upon the earth. A few centuries and it had become corrupt. It became an apostate church. This is our witness; this is our testimony. That blessing is one of the blessings that goes with our belief in Mormonism. Surely, mankind never was in a more distressed and uncertain condition than today, the day in which we live. Shall we say that God has stopped his voice, has closed his ears to our prayers, that he no longer cares for or loves us? Rationally, the conclusion to that question that he has would be absurd. So in this day of ours, a little over a hundred years ago, God came, he and his Son, Jesus Christ, and opened up through the Prophet Joseph Smith this last Dispensation of the Fulness of Times. We Mormons are blessed with a testimony and a witness of that. We are also blessed with a testimony and a witness that not only did the powers and the authority come to Joseph but he passed them on down, and today President McKay, as_ prophet, seer, and revelator, stands for the Church as the mouthpiece of God, and when he speaks through the inspiration of the Lord, as he will when he speaks to the Church, he proclaims what the Lord would have us know today. (Ibid., Lesson 45.) IN CONCLUSION Sometimes we overlook the affirmative, gladsome aspect of the gospel in relation to our everyday lives. The gospel is one of optimism, of hope, of glad tidings, of eternal progress. A thoughtful consideration of its principles will reveal that there is a rewarding, promised blessing, whether so stated or not, in all divine commandments. These blessings are inherent in obedience to the law. Perhaps the greatest of these is embraced in the statement of the Father to Moses, 'For behold, this is my work and my glory— to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man." (Moses 1:39.) Surely this, in essence, is saying to each individual of earth: "Lift up your head and be of good cheer" for the vexations of the flesh, the trials and anxieties of earth life are transitory, they are of brief duration, death is not the end of existence, immortality is assured and eternal life is attainable to all who will live the required commandments.... Men are, that they might have joy. (2 Ne. 2:25.) For Home Doing Help yourself and your family to a home atmosphere of good cheer by reminding yourself and your family of the many blessings of the gospel and of the wonders of life. A 870 CULTURAL REFINEMENT Ideals of Womanhood in Relation to Home and the Family Lesson 4—The Place of Entertainment Dr. Bruce B. Clark Textbook: Out of the Best Books, Volume 5 Community Responsibility, Section Four by Bruce B. Clark and Robert K. Thomas "Any pleasure which keeps the heart from God will be fatal to the soul."' —Richard Fuller Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting, February 1970 Southern Hemisphere: June 1970 OBJECTIVE; To show that there is a valid place for entertainment and pleasure in life but that these should always be in good taste and in accordance with Church standards. MUSIC The Telephone, a ''mini-opera'' by Gian Carlo Menotti (1911- born) ) American (italianCommentary on musical selection by Clawson Cannon, Assistant Dean of College of Fine Arts, Brigham Young University. The Webster New World Dictionary states that the word "entertain implies planned amusement or diversion, often with some intellectual appeal." For the past thousand years in the western world, many musical compositions have been written specifically to entertain. Among these especially composed to this end is the opera, introduced in the culturally and musically sophisticated courts of Italy at the turn of the seventeenth century. Certainly the little opera by Gian Carlo Menotti, The Telephone, is an excellent vehicle for providing a few minutes of entertainment to all who hear it. This little opera should appeal to those whose activities are being interrupted by the ringing of the telephone, usually for the most frivolous matters. INTRODUCTION TO LITERATURE LESSON There is a long tradition among some churches, going back through centuries of medieval Christianity, which assumes that God is not pleased when people enjoy themselves with the pleasures of this world. Under such a philosophy money is regarded as evil, love between men and women is thought of as_ tainted with sin, art and recreation are looked upon' with — suspicion. 871 November 1969 Through centuries of history some churches have banned dancing and drama as forbidden evils, some have legislated that their religious leaders must not marry, and some have prescribed heavy, drab clothing as the only dress suitable to express religious devotion. Philosophically a whole intellectual movement known as asceticism flourished for centuries advocating strict self-denial as a means of spiritual self-discipline. Severe "mortifications of the flesh" were practiced, apparently under the supposition that God is somehow pleased with human self-punishment. This is not, however, the position of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The Church believes that God wants people to be happy and enjoy themselves, in this life as well as in the life to come. "... Men are, that they might have joy" (2 Ne. 2:25) is one of the great principles expressed in The Book of Mormon. Money sometimes does promote evil but need not do so if used for good purposes. Love between men and women sanctified by marriage provides genuine happiness. Art and recreation when in good taste abundantly enrich life and are in harmony with the fulness of the gospel plan. The key words in the preceding sentence are "when in good taste." From the beginning The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints has not only permitted but actually sponsored extensive programs in music, drama, dance, literature, and athletics. Always, however, emphasis has been upon encouraging refinement, wholesomeness, and good taste. 872 Discuss the term "good taste." What does it include? What are the limitations? Reading, as millions of readers know, provides an inexhaustible and wonderfully varied storehouse of entertainment. In addition to all of the aesthetic values of literature and all its rich insights into people, ideas, and problems we should never forget that one of its great and valid functions is to entertain. We live in a world of pressures and problems. How wonderful that we can draw upon literature for the relaxation and delight it provides in addition to its many other values! From Aristophanes in ancient Greek times to writers such as E. B. White, James Thurber, and Al Capp in our own century, every era has had its great humorists. Thousands of delightful stories, novels, poems, dramas, and essays are available to illustrate the rich entertainment literature can provide. In the five preceding years, and this year, too, we have studied "serious" literature concerned with problems, values, ideals, etc. Now in this one lesson we want to emphasize the power of literature to entertain. The lesson consists of the following fourselections: (1) Stephen Vincent Benét's short story "The Devil and Daniel Webster," (2) Ring Lardner's short story "Haircut," (3) "Baker's Blue-Jay Yarn" as excerpted from A Tramp Abroad by Mark Twain, and (4) a discussion of and brief excerpts from the essays of Charles Lamb. Since each of the four selections is too long to print in this Magazine, they will need to be studied from the textbook. All four selections are also available in many libraries throughout the world if readers do not have access to the textbook. "THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER" This, the longest of the four selections, is an excellent example of literature at its entertaining best—delightful, compelling, clever, yet also very wholesome, and rich with meaning. Cleverness of some kind can be found in almost every sentence, making the story great fun when read silently and even greater fun when read aloud. Why was the story written? First, to eulogize Daniel Webster, making him emerge out of the pages of history as a vivid folkhero of America—courageous, dynamic, idealistic, eloquent, and bigger-than-life in the Paul Bunyan tradition. Second, to glorify the American ideal of freedom and human dignity—the beautiful dream of America. Third, simply to delight the reader, to entertain as literature and literature alone can do. Some works of literature live primarily through their message. Some live primarily through their power to entertain. When we have important meaning combined with wonderful entertainment, as in this story, then we have a great story. Because "The Devil and Daniel Webster" illustrates so excellently this combination of delightful entertainment and wholesome meaning it has been chosen as the feature selection in this lesson on the place of entertainment in our lives. When discussing the Lesson Department story the class leader should emphasize both of these aspects. The beautiful section of seriousness near the end when Daniel Webster talks about ideals of freedom and about the dignity and glory of mankind is one of the finest passages Benét ever wrote. Note, for example, this paragraph describing Daniel Webster's speech to the jury in defense of Jabez Stone: He started off in a low voice, though you could hear every word. They say he could call on the harps of the blessed when he chose. And this was just as simple and easy aS a man could talk. But he didn't start out by condemning or reviling. He was talking about the things that make a country a country and a man a man. And he began with the simple things that everybody's known and felt —the freshness of a fine morning when you're young, and the taste of food when you're hungry, and the new day that's every day when you're a child. He took them up and he turned them in his hands. They were good things for any man. But without freedom they sickened. And when he talked of those enslaved, and the sorrows of slavery, his voice got like a big bell. He talked of the early days of America and the men who had made those days. It wasn't a spreadeagle speech, but he made you see it. He admitted all the wrong that had ever been done. But he showed how, out of the wrong and the right, the suffering and the starvations, something new had come. And everybody had played a part in it, even the traitors. The next two paragraphs are also beautifully meaningful. Then the story returns for the last three pages to a lighter tone and one of the most interesting endings to be found in the literature of America. "HAIRCUT" This is included in this lesson for two reasons: first, simply be- 873 November 1969 cause it is such an_ excellent story, and second, because it shows how fun can become evil if itis had at the expense of other people. Although the story is written very cleverly, providing amusement all the way through, most readers will realize that underneath the entertainment the author has a serious purpose: to show how twisted and cruel humor can be when it causes other people to suffer. "Haircut" is the story of a barber who talks in an uninterrupted stream of words all the time he is whacking off the hair of a stranger who has come to the barber shop. The barber talks mostly of a man in the town named Jim Kendall who recently was killed in a hunting "accident." Although the barber repeatedly refers to Jim as a man with a great sense of humor, just bubbling over with the fun of playing practical jokes on other people, we gradually realize that Jim's sense of humor is terribly perverted. He laughs loudly at the embarrassment and suffering of other people, especially when he can cause the embarrassment and suffering himself —such things as sending anonymous postal cards to men asking them where their wives were when they were out of town the other day or sending a feebleminded boy to get a left-handed monkey wrench. The man is really twisted and cruel instead of funny in his sense of "humor." And the barber is hardly better. Although perhaps not quite so cruel as Jim, the barber apparently is even more stupid because he doesn't even comprehend all that is going on. In fact, one of the best things about the story 874 as a work of art is that it is written so skillfully that the barber tells a story he doesn't understand in such a way that the reader fully understands. As a story "Haircut" is clever and entertaining, however, humor is never really humor if it must be had at the cost of ridicule or injury to someone else. As our children learn in Primary, "Fun is not fun unless it's fun for everyone." And in adult words, "Entertainment that is not uplifting can turn thoughtless indulgence into real degradation." ""'BAKER'S BLUE-JAY YARN" This delightful excerpt from Mark Twain's A Tramp Abroad is also included mostly as an illustration of the wholesome entertainment that literature can give. Mark Twain, one of our great masters of style and humor, describes animals that can talk. Perhaps space will permit just a couple of paragraphs as samples of his unique style and humor: There's more to a blue-jay than any other creature. He has got more moods and more different kinds of feelings than other creatures; and, mind you, whatever a blue-jay feels, he can put into language. And no mere commonplace language, either, but rattling, out-and-outbook-talk—and bristling with metaphor, too—just bristling! And as for command of language—why, you never see a blue-jay stuck for a word. No man ever did. They just boil out of him! And another thing: I've noticed a good deal, and there's no bird, or cow, or anything that uses as good grammar as a blue-jay. You may say a cat uses good grammar. Well, a cat does—but you let a cat get excited, once; you let a cat get to pulling fur with another cat on a shed, nights, and you'll hear grammar that will give you the lock jaw. Ignorant people think it's the noise which fighting cats make that is so aggravating, but it ain't so; it's the sickening grammar they use. Now I've never heard a jay use bad grammar but very seldom; and when they do, they are as ashamed as a human; they shut right down and leave. You may call a jay a bird. Well, so he is, in a measure—because he's got feathers on him, and don't belong to no church, perhaps; but otherwise he is just as much a human as you be. And I'll tell you for why. A jay's gifts, and instincts, and feelings, and interests, cover the whole ground. A jay hasn't got any more principle than a Congressman. A jay will lie, a jay will steal, a jay will deceive, a jay will betray; and four times out of five, a jay will go back on his solemnest promise. The sacredness of an obligation is a thing which you can't cram into no blue-jay's head. Now, on top of all this, there's another thing: a jay can outswear any gentleman in the mines. You think a cat can swear. Well, a cat can; but you give a blue-jay a subject that calls for his reserve powers, and where is your cat? Don't talk to me —I know too much about this thing. And there's yet another thing; in the one little particular of scolding—just good, clean, out-and-out scolding—a blue-jay can lay over anything, human or divine. Yes, sir, a jay is everything that a man is. A jay can cry, a jay can laugh, a jay can feel shame, a jay can reason and plan and discuss, a jay likes gossip and scandal, a jay has got a sense of humor, a jay knows when he is an ass just as well as you do— maybe better. If a jay ain't human, he better take in his sign that's all. CHARLES LAMB AND THE INFORMAL ESSAY Although space does not permit the printing of a complete essay by Lamb it would be unfair to end this lesson on entertainment without making at least a few comments on the writer who is probably the most delightful essayist English letters has ever produced —Charles Lamb (1775-1834). For all who will take the time to discover Lamb with his inimitable style and ineffable charm, hours Lesson Department of leisurely, delightful reading are guaranteed. In spite of a good deal of tragedy in his personal life and of drudgery in his professional life, Lamb had a sense of humor that bubbled up in all that he said and wrote. As he plays up and down the whole scale of humor we feel his humanity, his genial warmth, the endless charm of his prose style, and the range of his keen, curious mind. Although he has a great deal to say on a wonderful variety of subjects his chief aim is to entertain, not to instruct or persuade. And entertain he surely does, captivating readers with the magic charm of his matchless style in almost every paragraph that he wrote. Sometimes in his essays he is serious. For example, in "Dream Children" he lovingly talks about the children he yearns for but never had. In "Old China," one of the loveliest of his essays, he reminisces about his youth when possessions were scanty but joys were spontaneous and dreams were free. And in "Modern Gallantry" he regrets that men tend to be more gallant with young or wealthy women than with women who are homely or poor or old. Men should treat all women with the same gallantry, he feels —just because they are women and men are their protectors. As a brief sample of Lamb's exquisite style, we print the opening lines of "A Chapter on Ears:" I have no ear.— Mistake me not reader,—nor imagine that I am by nature destitute of those exterior twin appendages, hanging ornaments, and (architecturally speaking) handsome volutes to the human capital. 875 November 1969 Better my mother had never borne me. I am, I think, rather delicately than copiously provided with those conduits; and I feel no disposition to envy the mule for his plenty, or the mole for her exactness, in those ingenious labyrinthine inlets—those indispensable side-intelligencers.... When therefore I say that I have no ear, you will understand me to mean— for music. CONCLUSION In the foregoing discussion and selections it is the objective of this lesson to point out that entertainment in the form of good, wholesome humor has a valid place in our lives. While the very word "humor" has meant different things to different centuries, it is never destructive or malicious. As Louis Untermeyer has written, "It does not fly to assault the mind, but laughs its way into the heart. Humor is healing, wholesome, recreative, and rejuvenating." (From "A 'Treasury of Laughter," selected and edited by Louis Untermeyer.) Thought for Discussion Define "humor." Discuss some of the principles which govern it. How does it differ from wit or satire?
