Brown Of the First Presidency (Address delivered at the General Session of Relief Society Annual General Conference, October 1, 1969.] @ My dear sisters of the Relief Society of the Church, it is an honor and a privilege to be asked - to participate in the programs of this general conference. It is hoped that we may define and delineate some of the distinguishing characteristics of this great organization whose motto, as you have heard, is charity, and, may I add, whose slogan is service., President David O. McKay would be here if he could. I am sure if he could have been given the choice of which session of the general conference he would attend, if he could only attend one, he would choose to attend this session. His spirit is with you, his heart is with you, and he sends his love and his greetings. Religion has too often spent a large proportion of its effort on doings apart from the real business of life. One of life's problems is to establish a deep understand- 884 ing of man's relationship to his fellow men. When that relation- 'ship is faulty, men are not living in the just, helpful, and cooperative fellowship which the Savior enjoined. On every hand we see an appalling human need awaiting the harness of religious power and zeal. One of mankind's most insistent needs is the interpretation of religion in terms of service. Let us go back for instruction to the Hebrew Prophet Micah: Wherewith shall I come before the Lord, and bow myself before the high God? Shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old? Will the Lord be pleased with thousands of rams, or with ten thousands of rivers of oil? Shall I give my firstborn for my transgression, the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul? He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the Lord require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, _ and to walk humbly with thy God? (Micah 6:6-8.) Man's curious ability to keep divine relationships in one compartment of life and human relationships in another is wrong. They belong together. And in the Relief Society they are together. For the Relief Society knows no division of our obligations to God and to his children. Too much of religion's driving power remains unharnessed to the needs that lie all about us. The Prophet Isaiah spoke directly to this subject when he said, Wash you, make you clean; put away the evil of your doings from before mine eyes; cease to do evil; Learn to do well; seek judgment, relieve the oppressed.... (Isaiah 1:16-17.) Fortunately, in the lives of many people, piety really does involve goodness, and faith involves justice, and worship, humaneness, and their life with God has a definite connection with their daily relationships. It makes them better home folk, better friends, neighbors, and citizens. The prayer of Charles Kingsley could well become a part of our daily worship. He said, "Guide me, teach me, strengthen me till I become such a person as thou wouldst have me be, pure and gentle, trustful and rightminded, brave and able, courteous and generous, dutiful and useful." That sounds to me like a Relief Society prayer. Religious life should inspire practical goodness and daily usefulness. God dwells in the hearts of the human family as well as in temples. The Lord said through the Prophet Hosea, "... I desired — mercy, and not sacrifice; and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings." (Hosea 6:6.) Service The Savior, while he lived among men, in order to emphasize the meaning of service, ate with the ceremonially unclean, transgressed the law of the Sabbath in the interest of human helpfulness, and gave his life as a service to mankind. Jesus emphasized the truth that God is not primarily in the Church, but in the midst of the needy, sinning, failing yet aspiring humanity. Paraphrasing Henry Ward Beecher, religion means work. The battle of religion, like all other battles, means peril, blows given, but blows taken as well. Religion means transformation. Dr. Wilford Grenfell, the Lincoln of Labrador, with whom I was briefly associated during the First World War, made the statement, 'Whether we, our neighbor, or God is the judge, absolutely the only value of our religious life to ourselves or to anyone else is what it fits us for, and enables and inspires us to do." Every man's religion should have practical issue, not merely emotional responsiveness which delights in hearing the gospel, but lacks diligence in living it. We must remember that religion is action, not diction. Let us pray that God will deliver us from our dullness of conscience, from a feeble sense of duty, from thoughtless disregard of others, and from all half-heartedness in our work. The Hebrew prophets had a supreme abhorrence of what they called "unmoral" religion, and the Master shared their conviction. He pilloried the Pharisees in everlasting scorn. Their petti- 885 December 1969 ness, their quibbling, their false emphasis, their bigotry, and the uncharitableness of their lives, their lack of forthright honesty, aroused his indignation. Their religion made them worse, not better. To the Master, religion meant graciousness and magnanimity, self-forgetfulness and self-denial, high purpose and deep joy in the ministry, boundless brotherhood and love blocked by no ingratitude or sin. There was inexhaustible goodwill in all of his teachings, and he emphasized over and over again the need and blessing of service— outgoing service to all those whose lives we touch. No one can doubt the central place which service held in the life of the Savior, as it is referred to in the parable of the Good Samaritan or in that other solemn utterance where the standing of the dead before the throne of God depended upon whether they had fed the hungry, clothed the naked, given drink to the thirsty, and visited the imprisoned and the sick. He said of himself, "... The Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many." (Matthew 20:28.) He that is greatest among you should not call himself a disciple of the Master until he possesses the spirit and knows the meaning of service. An aged and industrious Relief Society worker once said, "There's a lot of room in heaven, but there's no place to sit down!" Today we are confronted with many social evils—we have war, poverty, disease, ignorance, vice —all of which have become com- 886 monplace in the modern world. One-third of the population of the globe, nominally Christian, has seemingly failed to realize the full meaning of Christianity. Religion must not become an isolated and uninfluential afterthought. On Sundays, when the banks and stores are closed and the rest of life is still, when the finer forces stir within us, we go in company with our family and friends to the Church for formal worship. This is good. But when it is over, we too often close the door on that experience and return to the routine and mundane affairs of life. The Relief Society, and all the members thereof, are, or should be, willingly harnessed to the task of serving their fellow men. And this is a continuing obligation and a continuing benediction. Strictly speaking, our worshiping assemblies on the Sabbath day should not be called "church service' for church _ service should begin on Monday morning and last all through the week. Church service is helpfulness to people. Public worship is but preparation for that helpfulness. Ours should be a life of ministry amidst the dust and din of daily business. The Hebrew prophets directed their scorn against the religious trivialities of their day and the Savior scorned the quibbling minds that tithed mint, anise and cummin, yet neglected the weightier matters of the law. With the experience of two world wars behind us, and now the hapless war on foreign soil, thoughtful men are coming to realize that some things which were once deemed important are really of small account. We must somehow get rid of our ante-bellum concepts and address ourselves to the stupendous task of making over the shattered world preparatory to the millennium, when the battered and broken lives of the unfortunate and the sinful can be reclaimed; when our social life, its business,. Its statecraft, its international relationships can be transformed by the renewing of men. With so much work to be done, so much action on many fronts, we cannot afford to ride theological hobbies or be obsessed with favorite fashions in religious phylacteries, else we shall miss the main issue of the gospel. He who travels widely and observes carefully is impressed by the spiritual desolation of millions of men who live near expensive churches but are impressed and disillusioned by the frivolous futility of much that is called religion. It becomes, in fact, a ghastly mockery. When we think of the One who came to seek and to save those who were lost, and when we observe the apathy or, at best, the fitful interest in other than outward appearance, when we become concerned only with our meetinghouses, our tabernacles, and temples, let us look about us and see the millions who are not affected thereby. We should resolve to reach out our hands and save them from the inferno toward which they are moving, and we should concentrate all our energies on the united effort to rescue some, at least, of them whom Christ came to save. Too many men accept religion, profess to love it, and cleave unto it, not from many unselfish moService tives but solely because of an inward peace, a quieted conscience, and the radiant hope which they, themselves, get from it. Religion then becomes not a stimulus but a sedative. It is used not as an inspiration to service, but as a substitute for service. We too often have mystical experiences of the spiritual, and a peaceful sense of being pardoned by God and reconciled with him, as we purr and primp in the shade of public praise. Religion reaches such men only on their receptive side. They are yielding to the lure of selfishness. The Master and his disciples referred often to the tendency among their followers to become hearers of the word rather than doers. The Savior said, And every one that heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, which built his house upon the sand.... (Matthew 7:26.) And Paul wrote that not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law. While we live, we should try to make each day a year so far as beauty, nobility, and a warm sense of brotherhood are concerned. In a time when there is so much cruelty abroad, we must generate the oxygen of love to keep the soul of the world still breathing. Religion should summon all of us to deepen the quality of life as compensation for diminution of its quantity, to treasure each other in the recognition that we do not know how long we shall have each other, to make life strong and brave and beautiful is our answer to the inexorable approach of the forces of death 887 December 1969 abroad in the world. We must make up for the threatened brevity of life by heightening the intensity of life. Our very understanding of each other can serve to deepen life even when we cannot lengthen it. The mission of the Relief 5ociety, and it is discharging this obligation admirably, is to establish in the hearts of men and women a love that involves unselfishness, willing sacrifice, mutual forbearance, absolute fidelity, boundless devotion. There is a drawing power in love. You can feel it just as surely as you can feel heat or cold. "I will draw all men unto me," said Jesus. Whenever you come into the presence of a loving heart, if you are in tune, you will feel the heavenly power and will be drawn by the magnetism of love. Service is included in, and is a product of love. So long as we love, we serve. "Not what we give but what we share, for the gift without the giver is bare," said Sir Launfal. And James Russell Lowell said, "All the beautiful sentiments in the world weigh less than a single lovely action." And from Sir Walter Scott, "It is greater to do a kind deed than to write a novel." Let this ever be our prayer as we labor in Relief Society: "Help us, O Lord, to find those who need us." Too many are comfortable in the luxury of their self-approval as they listen with receptiveness to the consolations which come from those who hear the gospel message. Let everyone get under the load of responsibility, and realize that every doctrine has its 888 associated duty, that every truth has its task. The gospel when the Master first proclaimed it, was not intended _ primarily for preaching—it was intended for action. Surely there is a challenge to all Christians who look about them and see the appalling sin, the haggard want, the infuriating oppression which befall millions of our fellow men—for every one of whom the Savior died. Lord, we cannot serve thee as did Martha in those days, But we can seek and find thee in a thousand other ways. The poor, the hungry, and the weary cry out ceaselessly, And every home, if filled with love, can be a Bethany. The: inevitable expression of real Christianity is a life of sacrificial service. No man can truly assimilate Christianity by impression alone, there must be expression as well. MY LAMP I met a stranger in the night, whose lamp had ceased to shine, I paused and let him light his lamp from mine. A tempest sprang up later on, and shook the world about, And when the wind was gone, my lamp was out. But back came to me the stranger—his lamp was glowing fine; He held the precious flame and lighted mine. I want to congratulate the President and her Counselors on their magnificant addresses this afternoon and I am humble in being asked to follow them. Surely we have no greater preachers of the gospel than you members of the Relief Society. We want you to know that we love, admire, support and depend upon you for the work of the gospel of Jesus Christ. It seems to me that the Relief Society is really the backbone of the Church. For that I humbly thank God, and being a married man, I know what it is to have the woman standing beside you, upholding and defending you and encouraging you when you are up against real problems. May all of us be inspired to seize the torch and hold it high, remembering that we may from one candle light a thousand others without diminishing our own. May our lives be given to charity and service and thus may Service we become real servants of the Master. Thank you for permitting me to participate briefly, and may God's choicest blessings be with your General Presidency, the General Board, with your stake and ward, mission, branch officers and teachers, and with all the members of the Relief Society throughout the world. O God, bless and sanctify the efforts of our sisters upon whom we depend so completely for their help and for their inspiration. We thank you so very much and pray God's blessing upon you in the name of Jesus Christ, Amen. INVENTORY: A SNOWBALL TREE Soon the year will end and | shall take An inventory of all blessings sent My way. For future scantier years I'll make A special note of how the snowball bent Its thick-leafed branches toward my kitchen sink; How leaf-green newness turned to blossomed snow And lush cool shade, and lingered then, | think, Long past the scheduled time for leaves to go, Lingered while the sun poured red and rust And amber gold through once-green leaf-veins. Day After day | gloried in them, thinking they must Fall soon. For all things earthy go the way Of transient growth and bloom and then to dust. Only the memories of their beauty stay; Today my snowball tree, etched in frost, Adds to this blessing and will not be lost. —Mabel Jones Gabbott 889 ® Elder Marvin J. Ashton, for- 'mer first assistant in the YMMIA general superintendency was sustained as an Assistant to the Council of the Twelve at the Friday afternoon session of the 139th Semi-Annual General Conference of the Church. Prior to his appointment, Elder Ashton had served eleven years in the YMMIA general superintendency and ten years on the general board of that organization. While in the superintendency he gave supervision to the MIA activities in music, dance, drama, speech, and athletics. He had much influence in developing the Church athletic program into what it is today. He also has served as senior president of the 315th Quorum of Seventy. Only a week prior to his appointment as a General Authority, Elder Ashton had been appointed managing director of the Unified Social Services Committee, a new committee to function under direction of the Church Priesthood Correlation Committee. This committee will include the principal youth and child services of the Church: the Youth Guidance Program, the Relief Society Social Services, and the Indian Student Placement Program. Elder Ashton was born in Salt Lake City, May 6, 1915, a son of 890 Marvin O. And Rae J. Ashton. He attended Salt Lake City schools and was graduated from the University of Utah with a degree in business administration. Elder Ashton helped establish his reputation as a crusader for youth when, as a Utah State Senator from 1957-1961, he spearheaded legislation for improvement of statewide juvenile detention facilities. He serves on various committees for the betterment of youth, and has given long service to the Boy Scouts of America. He holds the organization's highest awards, and serves on a national committee. Elder Ashton served a mission to England, and has traveled world-wide as a speaker, directing most of his efforts toward the youth. In 1940 he was married to Norma Berntson in the Salt Lake Temple. They are the parents of four children: John, Jonne Ashton Wheadon, Stephen, and Janice. Sister Ashton is a member of the General Board of Relief Society. SOFT WHITE SNOW AND EVERGREENS PHOTO BY ERIC M. SANFORD A SNOWY MORNING The snow sneaked in on us last night On downy, padded feet. So still it is as flakes float down All muffled in the street. The cars creep past like shrouded ghosts. No children shout aloud. The sky above is quiet, too; One massive, great gray cloud. How peaceful and serene earth lies Under its coverlet of white. That softly, silently drifted down During the tranquil night. —Lucy W. Jones a0 Pyne ny aan?; The Relief Society Annual General Conference 1969 Mayola R. Miltenberger General Secretary-Treasurer @ "The fields of compassion have not all been plowed...." said Elder Bruce R. McConkie as he addressed the opening session of the 1969 Annual General Conference of the Relief Society held October 1 and 2 in Salt Lake City. A colorful assembly of Relief Society women from various parts of the world heard revered priesthood and Relief Society leaders in numerous sessions give words of comfort and faith, of admonition and instruction to the Society. "Religion must not become an isolated and uninfluential afterthought," but its "driving power must be harnessed" in order that the "needs of today be met." So 892 This group of Lamanite Singing Mothers performed in the Presidencies Department of the Annual Relief Society General Conference, October 2, 1969. Their singing was under the arrangement of Margaret E. Dahl, Supervisor, Northern Indian Mission Relief Society. Spoke President Hugh B. Brown in the General Session of the conference. President Joseph Fielding Smith, Elder Mark E. Petersen, and Elder Marion G. Romney gave inspiring addresses urging women to use their powers (as women) to better the world, to strengthen their homes, to encourage their husbands; to place their confidence in the priesthood, to teach their sons to understand and honor their priesthood, and to "save souls" as they were originally instructed to do by the Prophet Joseph Smith. The messages of the priesthood leaders and those of the Relief Society General Presidency and The Relief Society Annual General Conference 1969 other participants of the conference together with the moving, and, at times, ethereal music rendered by Singing Mothers choruses combined to make this conference, according to many, the "best ever." New emphasis was given to excellence in music by the rendition of an _ hour-long choral presentation together with a narration during the Stake Board session in the Tabernacle. The combined Singing Mothers choruses of the Cottonwood, Mill Creek, Murray, and Wilford Regions, under the _ brilliant musicianship of Sister Ellen N. Barnes of the General Board, provided the conference with a new dimension in this phase of Relief Society work. The chorus was 'accompanied by Roy M. Darley, a Tabernacle organist. The galaxy of nine departmental meetings held simultaneously produced ideas designed to assist in the various facets of Relief Society work. These meetings sparkled with exciting homemaking displays, original dramatizations set to specially composed music, with cogent addresses, visual aids, and demonstrations. The Official Instructions issued by President Belle S. Spafford, who presided at all major sessions, were given as guidelines for the governing of the world Society. President Spafford also challenged the women by her stirring address, "If It Is Right, We Can Do It." She said, "The task before us is great but it is not beyond our successful accomplishment." In her address Counselor Marianne C. Sharp reminded the women that "Charity Never Faileth," and Counselor Louise W. Madsen spoke of the "Spiritual Values of Homemaking." Against beautiful settings in the Relief Society Building and Parley's Stake Center women gathered the evening of October lst personally to meet the Relief Society Presidency and members of the General Board. There they partook of refreshments and exchanged greetings during the annual reception honoring the visiting sisters. The unifying of womenkind into a world sisterhood—a goal of Relief Society—was particuly underscored by the attendance of a large group of Lamanite Relief Society sisters from the Northern Indian Mission. Sisters from cities with different sounding names such as Pago Pago and Sao Paulo mingled with those from Anaheim, Idaho Falls, Snowflake, Kansas City, and Kalamazoo. Surnames like Red Wolf, Jack Rabbit, Fadmausili, Gonzales, and Jones, smiled, embraced, and communed as "sisters" do. When the conference closed at 4 p. M. Thursday, October 2, there seemed to be an eagerness to apply what had been seen and heard. The sisters returned to their homes with the words of President Hugh B. Brown ringing in their ears: "... The mission of Relief Society is to establish in the hearts of... Women a love that involves unselfishness, willing sacrifice, mutual forbearance, absolute fidelity, and dauntless devotion." 893 @ The howling wind made the tall old house rock and creak. It came down the _ stovepipe blowing puffs of smoke into the room from the big pot-bellied stove. The windows were rattling, and Mama was stuffing rags into the cracks to hold back the snow. I ran to her and held onto her skirt. Sternly she told me to let go so she could move around. She stopped for. A minute, scraped frost from the glass pane, looked out, then started to cry. Mama cried a lot these cold winter days. Papa said she was just homesick, but I knew better, for I heard them talking after they put me to bed. "There's no use in staying in this God-forsaken place," Mama said, "now that you have sold the cattle, we can go back to Southern Utah, and live like other people!" "T am not leaving the land I took in as part payment on the cattle," Papa said, "besides Canada is a coming country, already the land is fast being taken by homesteaders." 894 pa " Lila L. Ae I did not know what a Godforsaken, place was, or what homesteaders were, but I thought it must have something to do with all the snow and ice piling up outside, and something terrible - would happen to us as it did to the people in the Bible, when God did not like them. It was dark when Papa and the boys came in, stomping the snow from their. Boots and clothes. Mama lit the lamp, and started supper. "Is it time to put the nails in the wall for the stockings?" I asked Mama. "Yes, get your brothers to put them in behind the kitchen stove, so the things Santa puts in them won't freeze," Mama said looking at Papa. "Do you think Santa Claus can get through the deep snow?" I whispered to my big brother. "Sure," he said, "Mr. Taylor at the post office says he always gets through. Sometimes the mailman brings things for him." I ran to get the stockings, and started hanging them on the nails, but as I reached far over to the last nail my hand slipped and I touched the back of the hot stove. I let out a scream. Papa picked me up, and started soothing me. Mama did not say a word. She just reached for the Magic Bag from the top of the cupboard, took me from Papa, put salve that smelled of camphor on my burned arm, and wrapped a clean white cloth around it. She dried my eyes, kissed my cheek, and put me in the big rocker. "You'll be all right now," she said with a smile. "Just think about it being Christmas Eve, and Santa coming." Somehow it did not hurt any longer, and I almost fell asleep as I smelled the loaves of brown bread Mama was taking from the oven, and watched her dish up hot stew for our supper. The house did not creak any longer, and after supper my brothers rubbed the frost off the window so we could see the deep snow glistening in the moonlight. Papa said the storm was over, and Mama said, "After three days it is about time or we will all be buried alive!" We had just settled down to story reading when the knock came at the door. Papa opened it, and a big man in a fur coat and hat came in. He was covered with snow, and icicles hung from his eyebrows and mustache. "IT am Mr. Armstrong," he said, "my wife needs help, and I can't get through those drifts to Kimball to get Mrs. Talbot in time. I heard that your wife has had training with the sick, Mama and the Magic Bag so I came to ask her to help us." Mr. Armstrong was all out of breath when he had finished. Papa tried to take his coat and hat, but he said, "No, there is not time, I must get back." Mama took down the Magic Bag, opened it to check the medicine inside, then I followed her into the bedroom and watched while she combed her long black hair. She whirled it round and round, then pinned it in a big bob on top of her head. She put on a clean white apron and let me kneel beside her while she said her prayers. Papa helped her into his big fur coat, he put Lorin's overshoes on her feet. She put a wool fascinator scarf around her head, then followed Mr. Armstrong into the cold frosty night. I cried myself to sleep when Papa put me to bed. It was sad not to have Mama home when Santa Claus was coming. The room was still dark when I woke up and saw the light shining through the curtain over the doorway. I jumped out of bed and ran into the big room that was kitchen, boys' bedroom, and living room for our family. A blast of cold air came in the door with Mama and Mr. Armstrong. They were both covered with snow. Mama said the horse could not pull them and the buggy through the deep drifts and they had to get out and walk. She looked tired and pale. Papa helped her off with the big coat. In my excitement at seeing Mama I had forgotten about Santa and the stockings. Then the boys jumped out of bed, and we went to look behind the stove. Santa had got through. The boys 895 December 1969 had skates, and standing beneath my stocking was a pretty RedRiding doll. But I lost interest in the doll when I heard Mr. Armstrong say that Mama had given them a beautiful baby boy for Christmas! The rest of the day I played with my doll, but kept looking at the Magic Bag on top of the cupboard in hopes another Christmas baby would come out. We ate our dinner of roast beef, mashed potatoes, and creamed carrots, topped off with Mama's suet pudding and sauce, which we could hardly choke down after Mama told us there would be no Christmas dinner at the Armstrongs, just potatoes, cabbage, and an egg if the hens laid enough. The early snow and freezing had covered their crop before it could be cut and threshed. After the boys had washed the dishes for Mama, Papa brought around the horses and sleigh to take Mama to see how Mrs. Armstrong and the baby were getting along, and we all went with them. The horses lunged through the deep snow, sending snowballs from their hoofs back into the sleigh. We laughed when the drifts were so high the sleigh bounced over the top, jarring us when it hit bottom. We arrived at the Armstrong house that looked like two boxes put together with a lean-to porch in between. Papa tied the horses and we followed Mama into one of the boxes. I looked at the other door, and just knew it must be the stable. The side we went in was a kitchen where four children sat with their coats on, huddled around the stove. "You better keep your coats on," the oldest boy said, "there's not enough wood to keep both stoves going, and Mama and the baby must be kept warm. Papa has gone over to an old shed to find more wood." Mama told me to take off my hood and mittens. But when I pulled off my mittens out came the two red apples I had carried clenched in my fists and they G rolled on the floor. I was afraid Mama would scold—but she just smiled as I picked them up and give them to the two little girls. Mama took the kettle from the stove and the Magic Bag and left for the stable. I helped the two girls cut out paper dolls from a catalog, and my two brothers played marbles with the two Armstrong boys. | Papa came in carrying a big box. He took out Mama's big roaster and put it in the oven, then piled wood in the stove and a few chunks of coal. Soon Mama came to the door and told us we could come see the baby. When we went through the other door it wasn't a stable, but a big bedroom. The baby was in a cradle made of a wooden box, not a manger. He had a red face, but no halo on his head as it shows the Christmas Baby in the Bible stories! Then we left for home and the setting sun made the white world and clouds look pink. Mama said, "This has been a beautiful Christmas day." And we sang "Jingle Bells" to the sound of the squeaking sleigh runners cutting the crisp snow. When we arrived home Mama and I took off our wraps, my brother Ray brought in the coal, and Papa built up a warm fire. "What's for supper, Mama?" Lorin asked. "Oh, we can make sandwiches from the roast beef left from dinner," she said. "T don't think we can," Papa said, "I took it and the gravy to the Armstrongs. But we can have the rest of the suet pudding and sauce." Mama and the Magic Bag "No, we can't," Mama said, "T took that to Mrs. Armstrong." "Well, boys, let's have some of the nuts and candy from your stockings,' Papa said, "because it won't matter if they do spoil our appetites now." "We can't give you any from our stockings, Papa, we took them to the Armstrong children," Ray said. Everyone laughed, and we made jokes and riddles while we ate our supper of bread and milk. From then on if anything was lost, we would ask, "Did you take it to the Armstrongs?" Mama never cried by the window any longer, she was too busy making carbolic salve, camphorated oil, liniment, and canker medicine from the recipes Grandpa Pugh had brought across the plains with him in the Magic Black Bag. They had been given to him by his Welsh ancestors, and given to Mama when she left for Canada. Mama always said she found a magic recipe for happiness in the Magic Bag that Christmas Eve, and she often told it to us: A lot of faith, with a lot of work will make everything turn out right. And never feel sorry for yourself—there is always someone in the world with more miseries than your own. All winter she went through blizzards, rain, winds, and floods to help children with croup, pneumonia, and broken bones. She left babies for ranch women, women on lonely homesteads, and women across the boundary line on the Indian reservation. Through it all she had a smile, time to tell us stories, and time to sing. 897 EDITORIAL The 139th Semi-Annual Conference of the Church @ The 139th Semi-Annual Conference of the Church was held in the Tabernacle in Salt Lake City, Utah, the 3d, 4th, and 5th of October 1969, in a time of harvest in the mountain valleys, and in a spirit of gratitude and rejoicing for the everlasting gospel. By ships of the sea and by planes of the air, by train, by bus, and in private cars, the saints journeyed to the place of gathering. Many walked from nearby homes, and all who attended the meetings heard the words of salvation, authentic and inspiring as in other times and other places since the glorious restoration and organization of the Church in these latter days. From many lands and many nations, from the continents and the islands of the sea came the members of the Church to be comforted, renewed, blessed, and directed. The Tabernacle was filled to overflowing and other thousands heard the addresses and the uplifting music in the Assembly Hall and in the Salt Palace nearby. Foreign visitors were privileged to hear the proceedings by direct translation. By radio and television, other thousands in many parts of the world participated in a renewed dedication of their lives to spiritual ideals and a devotion to service and brotherhood in their daily lives. In addition to the Tabernacle Choir, three other choruses sang during the meetings: The Brigham Young University Combined Chorus, the Singing Mothers from Cottonwood, Mill Creek, Murray, and Wilford regions; and the MIA Girls Centennial Chorus. President David O. McKay, from his nearby home, presided at all the conference sessions, and the meetings were conducted by President Hugh B. Brown, President Nathan Eldon Tanner, President Joseph Fielding Smith, and President Alvin R. Dyer of the First Presidency. President Thorpe B. Isaacson was in his place during the conference. Elder Marvin J. Ashton, former First Assistant YMMIA Superintendent, was sustained as an Assistant to the Council of the Volume 56 December 1969 Number 12 THE GENERAL BOARD Belle S. Spafford, President Marianne C. Sharp, First Counselor Louise W. Madsen, Second Counselor Mayola R. Miltenberger, SecretaryTreasurer 898 Editorial Twelve. Words of appreciation and abiding love for Elder John Longden, an Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, who passed away in August, were expressed by General Authorities and by many others who missed the presence of a beloved leader and inspired counselor. In his opening address, delivered by his son Robert R. McKay, President David O. McKay spoke of the astronauts and their journey into the realms of outer space, saying ''Members of the Church have always known through revelation of the numberless creations of God.". Although God has created the universe and all therein, ''man is the jewel of God." This is just another way of saying that the earth was created for man and not man for the earth. God gave to man part of his divinity. He gave man the power of choice, and no other creature in the world has it. So he placed upon the individual the obligation of conducting himself as an eternal being. You cannot think of any greater gift that could come to a man or woman than the freedom of choice. You alone are responsible, and by wielding and exercising that freedom of choice, you grow in character, you grow in intelligence, you approach divinity, and eventually may achieve that high exaltation. That is a great obligation. Very few people appreciate it. The roads are clearly marked—one offering animal existence, the other life abundant.... In his closing address, read by his son Robert, President McKay expressed his love for the saints in all the world, admonishing them to righteousness, and testifying of his own great faith:! Wish to emphasize the fact that this great conference has testified to the hundreds of thousands listening in from all over the world that God lives, and furthermore that Jesus is his Beloved Son, the Savior of the world. We have also testified to the world that man is not living for himself, that his selfish desires should be overcome and controlled, and that he should render service to others.... 1 am grateful for and pray that God will continue to direct and bless our General Authorities who have inspired us with their messages during the sessions of this great conference. Singing Mothers of Los Angeles Area to Present Christmas Program Over National Broadcasting Corporation Radio On Monday evening, December 22, 1969 at 7:05 p. M. Barnes of the General Board of Relief Society will conduct the Singing Mothers from Los Angeles, South Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Inglewood, and Huntington Park Stakes, assisted by Renee Sheranian Goates, harpist, and Melva Niles Barborka and Linda Hallett soprano soloists, with Jacqueline Young as accompanist. C Mrs. Shirley Temple Black, former famous and beloved child actress of moving pictures, has been appointed one of the ten United States delegates to the United Nations General Assembly. She will specialize in environmental and_ social problems, particularly air pollution and water problems, and on an earnest effort to further peace and human brotherhood. Miss Carolyn Dunn, a member of the Sunday School General Board of the Church, has been named director of Consumers and Customers Services for Armour Company, the large meat-packing organization of Chicago. She has been an associate professor of foods and nutrition for the Utah State University, and also a newspaper columnist, with, in addition, a daily television program. Miss Eileen Roberta Donovan, one of two United States women ambassadors, took up her post as envoy to Barbados recently. She was consul-general in the country 1960-55, then spent four years as director of the State Department's Office of Caribbean Affairs before her ambassadorial appointment. The only other present U. S. Woman ambassador is Carol Laise, the envoy to Nepal. Tatzumbie DuPea, a Piute Indian born in Lone Pine, California, recently celebrated her 120th birthday and was congratulated by President Nixon and many California Officials. She is thought to be the oldest woman in the United States and has been truthfully called the oldest Californian, the oldest actress, and the oldest mother. Her Piute name means "Beautiful Star.'' She has spent more than thirty years in the ''movies'' and is a veteran of some forty films.. Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon Mrs. Antoinette Concello has been a circus performer since 1929 when she joined a flying trapeze act. She retired for a time when her son was young, but now that he is in law school, she has reinvested her valuable experience to further the future of the circus and now serves Barnum and Bailey Circus as director of the aerial ballet. Women Pilots in the United States number seventy who hold air transport ratings from the Federal Aviation Administration. Approximately another 1700 hold commercial licenses, while an additional 500 are licensed flight instructors. The airlines do not hire women as air transport pilots. Mrs. Roxa Wright, Woman's Day needlework editor and herself a needlework designer, collected for the New York Hallmark Gallery's spring exhibit of America's needlework: past and present, many rare and breath-takingly beautiful items. Some, lent by museums and historical collections date from early eighteenth century. Embroidery, appliqué, elaborate petit-point, crochet, all kinds of handwork embellished utilitarian objects, and clothes demonstrate touchingly the skills of many countries and a depth and breadth of aesthetic feelings. Mrs. Lois Arnow and Mrs. Mary B. Kadesch are ''plant librarians" at the University of Utah Herbarium, a plant reference library. The library furnishes information on many species of plants, identifies poisonous plants, edible and non-edible plants, and supplies data for medical research, as well as aiding air pollution experts and police officers and others in the identification of narcotic specimens. 901 Ruth C. Ikerman utting the bright red ribbon to tie the holly paper covered box holding Christmas tree shaped cookies, my friend remarked to me: "It used to be that Christmas was a day. Now. Christmas is a season." We reflected together on these words as we continued wrapping gifts for a committee to take to anumber of senior citizens in our area. As I reached for the box of silver stars to fasten the foil paper, I remembered back to the silver star on top of the community Christmas tree when I was small. How eagerly we anticipated the surprises of that wonderful day of Christmas, living fully for one joyous day, remembering it for a whole year. In that moment of remembrance, I was glad that Christmas has been extended into an abundantly full season. How rich in friendship and fellowship and sharing is all the year because of active participation in a season of Christmas. Trading of news and recipes is part of the Christmas season. One of the richest gifts I ever received for my kitchen came from a friend who lives in a convalescent home for the aged. She took time to copy from her re- 902 tired missionary friends, who lived there, the various recipes from countries where they had served. Just a step away from comparing recipes to the art of learning how to decorate differently for the Christmas season. Greenery and shrubbery which seem so familiar they are almost prosaic take on new luster when sprayed with gold or silver paint. Men who have never made an artistic design in their lives find it an absorbing hobby to see what they can do with the humble tumbleweed to turn it into a miniature Christmas tree. Closely allied to this discovery of new talents in decorating is that of learning to express tastes through gift wrapping of packages. None of us can excel at everything, and if we decide we do not like to make fancy bows, we can learn to tie with red string or yarn, while the season of Christmas gives us a chance to try out our skills. This is an opportunity for husband and wife to learn to work together in new ways, perhaps in painting a little red wagon, or enameling tins to hold cookies. Anyway I still have this dream and I rouse myself to think of my Grandfather Cheever and the day we talked about petunias. Grandfather had an amazing garden, but the flowers in it were not for picking. Children could look at the blossoms, smell them, enjoy them, but never pick them. No one ever took the trouble to explain to us children that Grandfather was a nurseryman and that the beautiful flowers yielded seeds only when they were left on the vine, so we thought Grandfather liked flowers more than people and that he was, perhaps, just a. Little bit selfish. One day Grandfather found me shaking the gate with all my strength and crying. He gave me a grayish peppermint from his pocket and invited me to walk with him in the garden. This was an unusual invitation. Grandfather was very old, at least he seemed so to me. When I heard the Bible stories about Noah and Methuselah I always thought of Grandfather. I knew that he had been older than was usual on the frontier when he married my grandmother and Mother was their tenth child. I thought he didn't like children, but perhaps that was wrong because once before when I had been left behind he had asked me if I could count to a hundred. I had already learned the system. I could count into the billions and trillions. As I remember it, he begged me to stop counting before I got even to a thousand. This day he suggested a walk in the garden before I could say, "Nine hundred and ninety-nine." We walked down a row of radiant snapdragons. Carefully he pinched off one little face and holding it between his thumb and forefinger he showed me how it could open and close its mouth. "Let's pick some," I suggested hopefully, and his answer was just a shake of his head. He pointed with his cane and we moved over to the cinnamon pinks—I can still smell them. In another part of the garden I admired the stock and the phlox. I don't know at what point in our walk I began to beg constantly to be allowed to pick at least one flower. Perhaps I had been tempted by the peonies which Grandfather raised mostly for funerals, or by the sticky stemmed moss roses. Voice calling, "Wait 904 Petunias Are Flowers, Too Finally when we passed the petunia border Grandfather said, "These are petunias. You may pick one of them." He guided my hand so that the petunia came up by the root. Then, together we went up to the house and, sitting on a bench near the kitchen door, we leaned our backs against the sun-warmed adobe wall. He took the petunia from my hand and I wasn't sorry. It had never been very pretty and already it had begun to droop. With all the beautiful flowers in the garden, why pick a petunia? Starting with the roots, brown and hair-like, he told me that children drink from a cup but plants must drink from the earth through those fine threads, that flowers need water; without it they would die of thirst. And they need minerals. Minerals in the soil are dissolved in the water that is drawn up through the ordinary looking roots. Then he gently touched the leaves. He told me that leaves are much more wonderful than they look. If the sun is shining on the leaf and there is water coming down the tiny pipe system—Grandfather's gnarled, shaking finger followed the vein system in the leaf—the leaf can make food. Actually out of nothing but water and sunlight these tiny green factories can produce something that wasn't there before. This wasn't like making bread of flour and yeast and water, Grandfather said. This was one of the two greatest miracles in nature and I knew by the awe in his voice that he thought of it as one of God's miracles. Then he had me look into the flower and he showed me where the seeds would grow and why they would develop there. As he talked to me of the second miracle he showed me the stamen and the pistil. Though I am sure he didn't explain the entire mystery of reproduction, he still let me know that even flowers need both a father and mother. That was a wonderful afternoon with Grandfather's quiet voice telling me so many things that I had never heard before. He put the flower back into my hands and said, "I know you would rather have picked a rose or a peony. Petunias tell us more about life and they: are flowers, too." Our visit was over. He went into the house to sit in his favorite platform rocker with the crocheted antimacassar. I went back to my vigil by the front gate. I don't know what adventure I missed that afternoon when Vera and Bob left me behind; but I'm sure that I wouldn't trade that hour with Grandfather Cheever for anything. He knew as he led me through the garden that being with him wasn't like having gone with Vera and Bob. In his quiet way he told me that second choices are "petunias" and that they are flowers, too. So I've gone through life picking flowers and quite a few of them have been petunias. I hoped to be a concert artist, so I'm a teacher. I'd love to write deep novels that would win international attention, so I write simple things. I'd like to be wrapped in mink, so I'm collared in muskrat. And yet every petunia I've picked has brought me more joy than the rose I might have had. Though I have never bowed to the roar of "bravo, bravo," from an excited audience, my students have at times called me blessed. I'm far from a Nobel Prize winner in literature, but one third grader after finishing one of my books wrote me, "Those were great guys. I'm going to grow up to be like them." I wanted sons and I have two daughters—but what loving, considerate, wonderful daughters! Each of them has brought me a grown-up son that I didn't have the responsibility of rearing; and one of them shares with me three enchanting grandsons. And so I sleep and dream that an impassable high board fence and locked gate are between me and what I want from life. But even as I dream I recognize that it is a dream and I can rouse myself and remember Grandfather showing me the wonders of a simple flower. Every time I want one thing and get another I say to myself, "This must be a petunia." And I wait for it to turn into a miracle. 905 Chapter 7 @ No man likes to antagonize his employer, but Kim was in a cold rage at Mr. Shelton's coming to his home and offering to buy Kim's father's beloved family homestead in Utah. His impact on the family was there—Rosemary's right-about face from dependence to independence, Tommy's own, even the change of Mary Ann from a fashionable working woman to a homemaker, and Kim's emergence as the real head of the household. All because they had brought Kim's father to live with them instead of selling his beloved homestead and putting him in a home for the aged. Tommy was fair. He showed how this might not work for some families. He outlined his parents' dilemma— the unfinished payments on the mortgage, the upkeep of a too large home when the children were gone. Tommy offered no solution, and Mary Ann wished he would. He was merely the scientific observer, and said it would be interesting to see the drama played out to the end, with a satisfactory solution for them all, or failure, and that it deserved further study. There was no time to think of either alternative just now, but both hovered over Kim and Mary Ann like dark-winged birds. The thesis was done and approved barely in time for Tommy's flight to Washington and the symposium, where he made a brilliant presentation of his paper, according to the Dean. It would be published in the fall and included in the Society's Proceedings of the Thirty-Fifth Annual Symposium. The newspapers picked it up as a "Revolutionary Solution to the Care of the Aged," and featured it. "About as revolutionary as 910 Methuselah," drily. Several offers of professorships at various colleges came of it, and Tommy was invited to submit a proposal to a scientific foundation for a sizeable grant to support further research on it. Lizbeth was at the airport to meet him and she looked at him with respect. Mary Ann noted she was not wearing her engagement ring. This was just an interlude, for they went back to the bridal showers for Rosemary given by her friends, the trousseau tea at the Freeman home, with the excited female relatives, and some of the male ones, coming and going, then exclaiming over her matched outfits of clothing, her linens and_ silver, everything beautiful for a bride. Her ivory white satin wedding dress was sheathed in her closet, her accompanying temple _ clothing pressed and packed into a small white case. Rosemary, with her mother's help, had not missed a detail to make her wedding perfect. It was Rosemary who drew the family's attention to her grandfather. "T don't remember hearing him speak a word in three weeks," she said. "And he looks sad and frail. I so wanted him at my wedding, but not if it will be too much for him. Grandpa's all right, isn't he?" Her father looked suddenly frightened, and guilt swept over Mary Ann. There was no doubt she had neglected her father-incommented Kim law in the excitement and hubbub in the last few weeks, doing only what was necessary for him and leaving the rest to Kim. But Kim had been kept on the run from the minute he got home until he could no longer see, fixing up the place for the wedding. "Grandfather, you are coming with us to the temple, aren't you? You promised, remember?" "What's that, Rosemary?" her grandfather answered, dragging his gaze from its faraway place. His eyes burned unnaturally bright in his pale face, and his clothes looked like a half-filled sack, he was so thin. His white hair, usually so well-kept, and his shaggy white eyebrows, looked slightly wild. "You promised to come to my wedding in the temple. Are you able?" "If I promised, darling, I will come. I always keep a promise." They took him with misgivings, and then the day was out of their hands—the wedding breakfast and the last minute preparations for the reception that night. He went to his room "to rest" he said, and when it came time for the reception he made his excuses that he was too tired to join them. Mary Ann fixed a supper tray and took it in. The wedding reception was a highlight for their family, the hundreds of guests from the ward, from Kim's work, from Mary Ann's and the children's associations coming and going was a kaleidoscope of loveliness. One of Kim's friends from work was most impressed with their home, their yard and gardens, the swimming pool, now dramatized at their best by the event. "Kim, you plutocrat! I had no idea you lived in a place like this." Heart Room for Home This pleased Kim, of course, and he murmured something about its being adequate for the family. "We never would have bought so big a place for ourselves—but the children." "Yes, the children. We've got seven of them, you know, and they are bulging the walls out of our place. We'd sure like to have an outlay like this." "How would you like this one?" Kim asked jokingly. "Are you serious?" demanded his co-worker. "Oh, could we?" abetted. His' wife A: long last the affair was over, the last guest gone, the bride and groom having changed quickly and departed in a decorated car trailing old shoes and peppered with rice. Tommy, Lisbeth's hand in his, had also gone, borrowing the little car and tucking her in. There was no mistaking the stars in her eyes, nor the love in his. Barbara, Jennefer, Heidi, and Carol and their husbands, aided by all the children who were still on their feet, were retrieving tissue paper from Rosemary's room, where the gifts had been unwrapped, and were on the patio putting the gifts away. "Let's check on your father," said Mary Ann. The supper tray was still on the little table beside his bed, untouched, and Kim's father was on the floor, where he had obviously fallen in an effort to reach the bathroom, because he had been nauseated. Kim was terrified. "My father is dying!" he said. Looking to the east, | see the church spire, beautiful and tall, Reaching toward God. Inviting us to reach also, and find him, Ever willing to help us in our upward climb. Beyond the spire to the east, the magnificent Wasatch Mountains, Rising in their stately beauty and majesty, Standing tall as protecting warriors, overlooking our lovely valley. As | turn my gaze westward, | find the guarding Oquirrhs, With their array of towers and blinking lights As ever present as those on the east. Surrounded by nature's barriers, our valley is serene and wonderful Filled with loving friends and neighbors Who feel the love of Christ in their hearts and homes. We are thankful for the Christmas season, the beautiful lights, trees, and carols, Reminding us again of the light brought into this world By the birth of Jesus Christ. May we ever feel the warmth and security of peaceful homes in a beautiful vatley And be able to feel this love for others Expressed in the celebration of Christmas. —Marcella H. AISLE OF CHRISTMAS TREES COURTESY HAROLD H. BENNETT, PRESIDENT TRANSPARENCY BY J M. HESLOP Celebrating Christmas Without Going Into Debt Mary E. Bergman In the early years of our marriage the available money for Christmas expenditures was scarce. After listening to friends expound on the pitfalls of charge accounts that would take months to pay off, lavish gifts to children that seldom pleased them for more than a few weeks, and fancy holiday parties, I realized that it would be most advantageous to fall back on my own resources, Often, the innocence of childhood can be changed into selfishness by parents who are unable to withstand the onslaught of hardsell tactics employed at Christmas time. Our gifts to Cathy that year totaled an expenditure of fifty-nine cents, but required hours of time and preparation. She was delighted, and her enjoyment of our homemade toys led me to believe that I had stumbled on a precious secret. Throughout the years, my children and I have learned together the satisfaction of counters filled with delicious home-baked goodies, Amid the pleasant aromas in our home, we stitched "God Bless Our Home" samplers, for each adult on our list, and we made stuffed toys of all varieties for the children, and a boxful to be sent to the Primary Children's Hospital. For the entire holiday season, we become absorbed in sewing, gluing, baking, molding salt clay, painting, building, and so on. Mark, being a normal energetic boy, doesn't always adapt to these quiet occupations. One afternoon while Cathy and I were engrossed in a project, I gave Mark a bowl of vegetables to chop for homemade soup that was bubbling on the stove. He was fascinated by the process of putting raw materials into the kettle and afterward being able to savor the taste of the resulting soup. Thereafter he became the official soup maker, starting from scratch and doing the entire project himself. We poured this soup into decorated quart jars to be delivered to various people. HESLOP Working With Knit Fabrics Myrene T. Alvord O) Available on the market today are lovely knit fabrics for home sewing. Knit fabrics can be purchased by the tube or the yard. Many are like sweater material, although made by machine. Knowing a few tricks in handling these materials can open up a whole new world of fashion. One of the professional touches you can add to your outfit is to edge it with embroidery and/or crocheting. To be most effective, this should be done from the same yarn as your sweater is knit from. To do this, you must unravel yarn from your tube, which requires patience and know-how. Most knit tubes are made from four separate strands of wool or yarn, each of which has been machine locked. These must be unraveled into four separate balls. Never cut the tubing to unravel the yarn. At the top of most tubes (not the ribbing end) there is a rough edge which you must pick through before you reach the regular yarn. After this top edge has been carefully picked off, unravel one strand all around the tube and lay the small ball aside. Pick up the next until you have four small balls of yarn. Then pick up the first ball and repeat this process until you have enough yarn for the work you wish to do. (continued on page 934) 925 Something Different For Your Home Arrangements by Florence G. The gold angel and scented candle symbolized the season. Such arrangements can be made easily by purchasing a certain product from a floral shop, putting it in the bottom of the vase or bowl, soaking it with water, and arranging the flowers to suit one's taste. Swedish Lucia Queen and Attendants ( Each year in the Swedish Branch of the Church in Salt Lake City, Utah, the Lucia festival is held. In Sweden this is known as Little Christmas, and is held on the 13th of December, the longest night of the year in Scandinavia. Lucia means Festival of Light, and is symbolic of the triumph over darkness. The Lucia Queen is the Queen of Light, and spreads cheer and light throughout the villages, with the help of her attendants. The candles are of course symbolic, and this crown is imported from Sweden. Part of the festival includes a parade through the building, and lovely music. Following the celebration, there are refreshments and a visit from Saint Nicholas. 927 Swedish Cookery For Christmas Darlene C. Dedekind Member, General Board of Relief Society O A typical Swedish holiday meal would be aptly termed a feast. Many varieties of seafood make up the first course. This is followed by baked ham and red cabbage, which is followed by meat balls and various kinds of cheeses. The main course of the meal is Lutfisk, a _ traditional Swedish dish served with potatoes and a white sauce. Lutfisk is available in package form in many import stores. Rice pudding is the popular dessert for such a feast, and there are several interesting customs surrounding it. Among these is that one almond is included in the recipe, and the person who gets this will be married within the year. This person is not to tell 928 MODEL NANCY ANN JOHANSSON Swedish cookery for Christmas that he or she has it, but the excitement runs so high among the single girls, it is nearly impossible to keep it a secret. Before eating the rice pudding, each person is supposed to say a little rhyme he or she has made up, then light a candle. The first candle that burns down indicates that person has been naughty during the year. Following the feast, Santa Claus generally appears and the delightful festivities of Christmas begin. The straw animals in the picture are traditional Swedish decorations. SWEDISH MEAT BALLS 1 Ib. Ground beef 1 tsp. Nutmeg or % tsp. Allspice ¥ ¢. Fine bread crumbs 2 tbsp. Shortening 1 egg 2 tbsp. CHRISTMAS TREASURE CHESTS (continued from page 923) JEWEL CASE FOR A LADY Materials needed 1 box of your choice either old or new, with or without drawers Y, pint gesso (a type of Latex paint) 1 pint satin finish lacquer (20 minutes drying time) small tubes artists' oil color in desired shade plus white Dutch gold (gold leafing sheets) gold leaf size and antiquing glaze old-fashioned print lace medallions and trim (new or antique) Step 1. Select box (remove any knobs on the box) a. If old finish, sand to smoothness ready for new finish. B. If new wood, sand lightly, apply 1 coat of lacquer to seal the wood. Step 2. Apply lace using a good quality glue. Move lace around until you have a pleasing design. Step 3. Apply several coats of gesso. The purpose is to fully permeate the lace and make it hard enough not to absorb further coats of finish. Be sure to dry thoroughly between coats. Step 4. Apply color. A high grade satin finish lacquer that takes about 20 minutes to dry is best. Mix with artist's oil paints to the desired shade. Prepare sufficient paint to cover the surface at least four times. Apply two to three coats to whole box, lace and all, allowing time for thorough drying between each coat. Step 5. Following directions for gold leafing, apply gold to lace area. When size is almost dry (about 40 minutes) apply the gold leaf and make no attempt to remove the loose excess gold until dry (overnight). Next day remove extra gold with a clean dry brush, seal with one coat of lacquer, smooth the edges of gilt area with a light touch-up of color. Step 6. The print selected is cut to fit the area and carefully glued into place, being careful to squeeze out any air bubbles from under the paper (I used only the center from an 8 x 10 print and cut it to fit the round section). When glue is thoroughly dry apply multiple coats of lacquer to picture face. Since this picture was bordered with lace, forming a dike, I was able almost to puddle the lacquer and let it dry overnight. 931 December 1969 CHRISTMAS TREASURE CHESTS (continued from page 931) Step 7. Antiquing glaze. Select a color that will blend well with primary color. Apply a thick coat and let it partially dry. Then, using rubber gloves and paper towels or cheesecloth, wipe off the glaze. Be careful not to take too much off. Use a "dry brush" effect on the flat surfaces to leave a thin coat of glaze over entire surface (except for gold and center of print) thus toning down the base color. Step 8. Final step glaze is a turpentine base, hence lacquer will cut it even if it is dry. Apply a little clear lacquer to the gold where you want to lift the glaze off and leave a shine. Wipe clean. You have created a very feminine beautiful jewel case, something which requires small interesting drawer pulls. If you can buy them in your area so much the better, but if you must improvise, try small screw-in picture hangers and no one will know the difference.. Follow the same steps for the tissue box. Use a paper maché box that just fits over the new style tissue box. The flowers are fabric artificial flowers dipped in resin containing just a pinch of gold powder and then are hung head down to dry. As a finishing touch, cut off stems of flowers and glue in place with a good quality airplane type glue. MAKE SOMETHING HANDSOME FOR THE MAN IN YOUR LIFE How about a decorative chest where he can store his treasures? Items Needed box available at craft stores with '/,-inch lowered surface in lid. Hinges, clasp. Plastic mold, and resin from craft supply house gold leaf (Dutch gold) Y, pint satin finish lacquer (20 minutes drying time) in artist's colors—mix to color of lightest shade in wood. ¥, pint wood tone glaze. Decals of coats of arms or drawings of same. Step 1. Cast three plastic "carvings" according to resin instructions and place level in a well-ventilated room to cure. (We will make him think the decals are carved of wood.) Be sure to use paper containers and discardable mixers. Be prepared for the strong smell which accompanies the curing period. Step 2. Arrange plastic sections on box lid. If they don't quite fit, use a file to smooth them. Sand off any sharp edges and glue in_place. Step 3. Seal exposed sections with lacquer. When dry, apply gold leaf to these areas. Dry completely and seal with clear lacquer. Step 4. Mix lacquer with oil colors to shade of lightest wood color. Paint plastic sections two to three coats. Step 5. Apply decals or glue prints to gold leaf surface. Be sure air bubbles are squeezed out from under the designs. Dry, and seal with clear lacquer. Step 6. Apply wood tone glaze liberally to whole surface. When partly dry, use rubber gloves and cheesecloth or paper towels to wipe off glaze. On plastic areas wipe back and forth leaving glaze streaked over high relief areas to give effect of wood grain. In exposed sections carefully reveal just the designs through the glaze. Let dry. Step 7. Lacquer will lift the glaze even when dry, so if you want more shine to the gold areas, use it lightly to remove glaze from edges around design. Apply hinges and clasp and line box with velvet.. 932 A Thing of Beauty is a Joy A THING OF BEAUTY IS A JOY—Candles of Elegance (continued from page 919) lighted with the results of this interesting and rewarding project that many additional ones were made to be given as Christmas gifts. INSTRUCTIONS FOR WOOD STAINED CANDLESTICK 1-inch paint brush soft cloths wood stain antique glaze Apply stain with small soft cloth, allow to stand for 45 minutes. ENAMELED CANDLESTICKS 1 small can enamel paint in color of your choice 1 1-inch brush Apply several coats, allow sufficient time between each coat to dry thoroughly. Sand lightly between each coat. Remove Pencil ang cut 2nds of tasse| Celebrating Christmas Without Going into Debt CELEBRATING CHRISTMAS WITHOUT GOING INTO DEBT (continued from page 918) Finding the names of people who might not have a pleasant Christmas, and sharing with them, has brought unspeakable joy and insight to our family. Time after time my children have demonstrated unselfishness, and have put other people's happiness before their own desires. Such times make a parent's heart burst with pride. To develop fully a child's imagination, toys should be interchangeable. Therefore, a truck should not look too much like a truck. It should quickly convert to a bus, fire engine, moving van, or any other four-wheeled conveyance. With this in mind, Tom, my husband, has built ride-in box carts that have served every imaginable purpose. He has cut blocks in all sizes and shapes, built work benches, bulletin boards, and other household accessories. My contributions include stuffed animals, rag dolls, bean bag toys, special dresses or costumes, hand puppets, and similar items. Our children's accomplishments show real imagination, and they improve continually. Celebrating Christmas this way means burning the midnight oil every night for weeks. It means tolerating horrible messes from cookie decorating, salt clay, and other projects. Projects are in various stages of completion and must be stored everywhere. Boxes of scraps, spools, detergent and bleach bottles, pop bottle caps, and numerous other things are stacked high in storage, awaiting time for construction. The ironing doesn't always get done, and the house seems to be in utter chaos, and Christmas morning finds us physically exhausted, but spiritually refreshed. We strive to remember the true meaning of Christmas, and to give thanks for the birth of the Savior, together, as a family united. INTRODUCTION The Doctrine and Covenants gives direction to the fulfilling of the Lord's promises unto the ancient prophets. The importance of this book in the plan of salvation was given at the November 1831, conference of the Church, in the following words of the Prophet Joseph Smith:... Being the foundation of the Church in these last days, and a benefit to the world, showing that the keys of: the mysteries of the kingdom of our Savior are again entrusted to man; and the riches of eternity within the compass of those who are willing to live by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God—therefore the conference voted that they prize the revelations to be worth to the Church the riches of the whole earth, speaking temporally. 938 In appreciation for the books of scripture received from the Lord by that time, the following was also indicated by that conference: The great benefits to the world which result from the Book of Mormon and the revelations which the Lord has seen fit in His infinite wisdom to grant unto us for our salvation, and for the salvation of all that will believe, were duly appreciated.... (Joseph Smith, History of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 1, pp. 235-36 [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereafter referred to as DHC}.) THE PLAINNESS OF THE GOSPEL That man might escape the judgments of the last days and also the more enduring judgment of the future life, the Lord has given the plan of salvation anew in plainness and simplicity. Elder Harold B. Lee of the Council of the Twelve, suggested the following four things to be done to prepare a people for the second coming of Christ: They should be taught: (1) the personality and nature of God and his Son, Jesus Christ, (2) the divinity of the mission of Jesus as_ the Savior, (3) the necessity of being cleansed and purified and sanctified to be made worthy to receive the Lord, and (4) acceptance of the divine mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith. (Conference Report, October 1956, pp. 61-62.) The Doctrine and Covenants makes a significant contribution to our understanding of these truths. Latter-day Saints do not worship Joseph Smith, but they believe that he received revelations from God to perform a work which is greater than any other's except that of Jesus Christ. (D&C 135:3.) Missionaries of the Church teach investigators of the gospel to pray that the Holy Ghost will testify to them that Joseph Smith is a prophet of God, that the workestablished by him, under divine guidance, is God's plan. When a person learns by the Spirit that God has restored his Church and gospel through Joseph Smith, then he is prepared to accept all of the restored gospel. The convert's knowledge may not be extensive, but by the testimony of the Spirit he knows the fundamental truth that The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints is the "... Only true and living church upon the face of the whole earth...." (D&C 1:30.) God sent his holy angels to Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery to confer upon them the Aaronic and Melchizedek Priesthoods so that saving ordinances could be performed by men holding the priesthood, which ordinances would be accepted by God. (D&C 27:7-8, 12-13.) The Doctrine and Covenants not only contributes information on the restoration of God's authority, but it also affirms the fact that without this authority the ordinances of salvation are invalid. (D&C 20:18-20; 84: 18-22.) In several other ways the Doctrine and Covenants attests to the divine mission of Joseph Smith. Detailed information on 942 Church organization and government is a unique contribution to the validity of this mission. (D&C 1:35; 49:24-25; 87; 130:12-13.) The Doctrine and Covenants contributes to the salvation of man by reaffirming and clarifying doctrines which are obscure or fragmentary in the Bible. Outstanding are the revelations concerning man's nature, the purpose of his life on earth, and of his future. It affirms that man is a child of God, born of divine Parents in a premortal world. (D&C 76:24; 93:29.) The Doctrine and Covenants reveals that by the spirit and the body becoming a soul in mortality, the resurrection through the atonement is assured, and through obedience to the principles of the gospel, man may receive a fulness of joy. (D&C 88:15-16; 93; 76:58-60; 132:20-21; 93:33-34.) Among some of the unique teachings of this book of scripture are tithing and the Word of Wisdom. (D&C 89; 119.) It is learned from these revelations that men may reach the divine destiny of godhood by obedience to gospel principles and ordinances, including marriage for eternity. (D&C 131:1-4; 132:15-21.) Class Discussion How do the four points given by Elder Lee to prepare a people for the second coming of Christ explain the fact that Joseph Smith contributed to the salvation of men in this world? REALITY OF THE FUTURE LIFE The third major way in which the modern revelations contribute to the salvation of men in this world, is their attestation to the truth that man lives beyond the grave. They do this in two ways: (1) by testifying to the reality of the resurrection, and (2) by the testimonies of men who have seen the resurrected Christ. Man will be resurrected with a body of flesh and bones, never to experience death again. (D&C 88:27-32, 96:102; 130:18.) In addition to considerable light being given on man's resurrection, specific information is given concerning the appearance of resurrected beings in our day. (D&C 27:5, 7-8, 12-13; 110; 128: 19-21.) Thus, further enlightenment is given concerning messages from, or the appearance of, individuals who have lived upon the earth, died, and then have been raised to immortal life. In the Doctrine and Covenants three persons testify to a sight-knowledge of the Savior. Joseph Smith, Oliver Cowdery, and Sidney Rigdon beheld the resurrected Lord. The first two were in the Kirtland Temple, on April 3, 1836, when they saw the glorified Lord. (D&C 110:1- 10.) Joseph Smith and Sidney Rigdon beheld God, Jesus Christ, and angels in vision at Hiram, Lesson Department Ohio, on February 16, 1832. (D&C 76:19-24.) Class Discussion How does the Doctrine and Covenants contribute to man's salvation by giving evidence to the reality of life after death? IMPLEMENTATION The Doctrine and Covenants was given by the Lord for this generation. Its message is intended to save people from their sins and to exalt them in the celestial kingdom. When one considers the great truths of salvation found in this book of scripture, he is impelled to exclaim that it is truly of God. In the words of President Wilford Woodruff:. We have the Book of Doctrine and Covenants, our Testament, which contains the most glorious, godlike, solemn and eternal truths ever recorded within the lids of a book on the earth. (Journal of Discourses 22:331.) Joseph Smith was the mortal instrument, under divine guidance, to bring forth this book of revelations. Blessings come not only by acquiring the understanding of doctrines and principles through study, but also by faith. (D&C 88:118.) POETIC URGE What is this flashing inside me?
