Jorgensen 943 VISITING TEACHER MESSAGE — Truths to Live By (Correlated With the Family Home Evening Manual, 1968-69) Message 6—Faith in Christ Alice Colton Smith Northern Hemisphere: First Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 OBJECTIVE: To know that faith needs constant nourishment. He was the ideal to many: tall, handsome, eloquent, and congenial. A mighty speaker, he persuaded many to join the Church. Then one day, someone else was given a position that many thought would be his. Gradually a sour note crept into his conversations. He grew less and less active in the Church. Long before he died the mighty voice no longer thundered of faith in God. The warm personality became an unhappy critic. His influence dwindled until most people forgot that he had ever been a great leader in his community. Many are the reasons for lost faith in God. Each has its subtle poison. 'T'o avoid such loss, faith, like all knowledge, must be constantly renewed and expanded. How do we nourish faith? How do we keep it alive, vibrant with spiritual health? For many, faith is buffeted by winds of doubt as well as attacked by subtle poisons. How do we protect ourselves against such evils? Who can explain this better than Alma who once worked so hard to destroy faith? 944 In a beautiful simile, Alma graphically explains faith's pattern of growth. His message of hope comparing faith to a seed begins by strengthening us with the knowledge that "... God is merciful unto all who believe on his name...." (Al. 32:22.) This seed is enriched by humility and watered by the desire to believe. Faith is fed by open-mindedness and the search for truth. One must then exert oneself— in the words of Alma— "awake and arouse your faculties....." (Al. 32:27.) In our day of scientific interest, out of the past Alma invites us to experiment in_ seeking faith. What are the steps in this experiment? 1. We must pray with a sincere heart. Unbelief has no place. No researcher finds an answer if he makes up his mind before he begins that he will not find it. 2. We must study. "Search the scriptures; for in them ye think ye have eternal life: and they are they which testify of me" (John 5:39) counseled Jesus. 3. We must be long-suffering. A dedicated scientist pursues truth regard- less of obstacles, differences of opinion, or long years of effort. 4. We must be patient. Research scientists spend long hours in planning, work, analysis, and evaluation. 5. We must be diligent. The solution of difficulties requires perseverance. How can we know when the experiment is producing favorable results? There is a swelling sensation within us. The soul is enlarged. The understanding is enlightened. The knowledge that Lesson Department here is something good floods the soul. Alma said that the fruit of all this effort "... Is sweet above all that is sweet, and... White above all that is white, yea, and pure above all that is pure; and ye shall feast upon this fruit even until ye are filled, that ye hunger not, neither shall ye thirst." (Al. 32:42.) Without nourishment faith dies. Properly fed it is "... A tree springing up unto everlasting life." (Al. 32:41.) HOMEMAKING—Development Through Homemaking Education Woman's Role in Family Preparedness Discussion 6—''She Is Not Afraid of the Snow for Her Household: For All Her Household Are Clothed With Scarlet." (Prov. 31:21) Celestia J. Taylor Northern Hemisphere: Second Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 OBJECTIVE: To alert the Latter-day Saint woman to the wisdom of preparing for family security through home storage of basic items other than food. INTRODUCTION If a family is to be self-sustaining over a period of at least a year ahead, provision must be made for other physical needs in addition to that of food. It is satisfying and rewarding to know the security of having a_ supply of food in the house, but with it we should not lose sight of the other basic needs. Food alone will not suffice if the family is cold, without sufficient clothing, or improperly housed. The sanitary and healthful needs of the family should also be taken into consideration if we are adequately to protect our families from sickness and want. OUR CLOTHING NEEDS One of the most important of the physical needs in our family preparedness program is that of clothing. To supply our family with clothing for a year ahead is not so difficult as it may appear to be. Certainly, it will not entail a_ significant stretching of our budget because, in many cases, we will find that we already have a very good 945 December 1969 start toward that year's supply. We should take inventory of the present wardrobe of each family member to determine what is needed and then proceed to complete the wardrobe needs as we are able to. We should make our clothing purchases 'with the idea in mind of long-term wear, especially in such things as outer clothing and footwear. As in all our expenditures, the methods of wise buying and spending should be followed. We should be aware of good buys on yardage and have some on hand. Very often money can be saved by doing our Own sewing. We should shop the clothing sales in the early autumn months and during the post-Christmas season. As much as fifty per cent can be saved on staple items of clothing which various members of the family will need during the year. There are many items for sale which are not subject to style changes and which will be appropriate for not only one but several years. Included with regular clothing should be ample bed clothes— Sheets, pillow cases, blankets, and quilts. Nothing is quite so uncomfortable as trying to sleep in an unheated room with inadequate bedding. In the event of a shutoff of gas or electricity or both—ample bedding is a safeguard and a protection. HOW SHALL WE KEEP WARM? We should make sure, to begin with, that our homes are insulated as fully as possible in the walls as well as the windows. Our fuel bills can be reduced considerably by taking such precautions. 946 Some kind of auxiliary heating should be available in case of power shortage in electricity and gas. 1. A fireplace is a convenient asset. 2. A year's supply of fuel is advisable. - Bottled or canned heat can be stored for emergency cooking where a stove ls not possible. PRECAUTIONS FOR FAMILY HEALTH AND WELL-BEING We need to feel assured that our family's health will not be jeopardized in the event of personal or national disaster. We should look ahead and invest in regular physical and dental examinations as a preventive measure against medical emergencies in the year ahead. It would also be wise to have on hand medical literature that will help under all conditions. Satisfactory bandages can be prepared from clean Sheeting material if they are rolled and then sterilized for twenty minutes in a 150° to 175° oven. They should then be carefully packed to keep in sterile condition. SUGGESTED LIST OF STORAGE ITEMS OTHER THAN FOOD soaps (hand and laundry) cleansers toilet and other tissue paper towels and napkins paper plates and cups tooth paste and brushes shampoo matches needles and pins thread and buttons Scissors candles hammer, axe, and saw nails and screws flashlight and batteries can and bottle openers clean cloths pencils and paper personal items of other kinds This list could be added to or deleted as circumstances might warrant. Many of these items are already a part of a family's permanent equipment. CONCLUSION We can rest securely when we Lesson Department know that the needs of our family will be met in the event of an emergency that might cut off our source of supply. We will be happy in the knowledge that we have followed the advice of our leaders in preparing our homes and families for whatever hes ahead. SOCIAL RELATIONS—Immortality and Eternal Life pce — — —- Lesson 6—A Position of Honor Alberta H. Christensen (Reference: Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, Selections from the Writings and Messages of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. Melchizedek Priesthood Course of Study, 1969-70, Lessons 1-5.) Northern Hemisphere: Third Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: August 1970 OBJECTIVE: To point out that the role of woman is essential to the eternal plan of creation and that she therefore occupies a position of honor. INTRODUCTION In lessons 1 through 5 of the current Melchizedek Priesthood course of study, President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. Speaks with great understanding and appreciation of the important role of woman in the eternal plan of creation. He discusses the home, children, and the responsibilities of homemaking. Relief Society members, generally, are familiar with the essential teachings of the gospel relative to the importance of the woman-role. There are, however, occasions when a woman may ask in all honesty, "Is my role as a woman really important? If so, how important?" This lesson will, of necessity, be generally theological for the priesthood lessons with which it correlates are doctrinal in nature and we shall quote much from President Clark's addresses. All Latter-day Saint women should know why and how essential their contribution is to the purposes of the Lord. ESSENTIALS TO CONSIDER _In order to discuss, fully, the position of the woman in the eternal plan, a review of funda- 947 December 1969 mental facts generally familiar may be encouraging to all women and give assurance to the woman in doubt. Certain truths given to us through accepted scripture, follow: 1. At the great pre-earth council in heaven, two plans for creating and peopling the earth were presented: (a) Satan's plan, which would destroy the agency of man, would insure redemption to every soul but it would prevent all growth and _ progress which are the results of overcoming obstacles. (b) The plan proposed by the Only Begotten and accepted by a majority of the spirit children of the Father, would leave man his free agency, thus giving him the opportunity to advance in wisdom and knowledge and_ righteousness by overcoming error and sin. The plan of the Only Begotten, which was accepted, included the creation of an earth upon which these spirit children might dwell during a period of earth life. We read of this truth in the Book of Abraham, "We will go down, for there is space there, and we will take of these materials, and we will make an earth whereon these may dwell." (Abr. 3:24.) According to the scriptural sequence, the earth was created in six creative periods. Abraham records the creation of man, which was directed by the Only Begotten, in these words: And the Gods formed man from the dust of the ground, and took his spirit (that is, the man's spirit), and put it into him; and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul. (Abr. 5:7.) The Lord planted a garden, recorded as the Garden of Eden, in which he planted two special, fateful trees— the tree of life and the tree of knowledge of good and evil. He gave specific commandments to Adam about the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. Further scripture records: And I, the Lord God, took the man, and put him into the Garden of Eden, to dress it, and to keep it. 948 And out of the ground I, the Lord God, formed every beast of the field, and every fowl of the air; and commanded that they should come unto Adam, to see what he would call them; and they were also living souls; for I, God, breathed into them the breath of life, and commanded that whatsoever Adam called every living creature, that should be the name thereof.... But as for Adam, there was not found an help meet for him. (Moses 3:15, 19-20.). We read that all things were created spiritually before they were created temporally. Just how the creation was accomplished the scriptures do not tell us. Such information would, in fact, be of little importance to this lesson. It is important to note that:. Up to this point all that had been accomplished, according to the scriptures, had been done by the priesthood, also that Adam was alone in the Garden of Eden, for there was no helpmeet for him. (See the foregoing scripture.) President Clark suggests that perhaps Adam may have recalled ".. The eternal truth of motherhood," so beautifully voiced by Eliza R. Snow in her great poem: In the heavens are parents single? No; the thought makes reason stare! Truth is reason, truth eternal Tells me I've a mother there. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 3.). We recall that God gave Adam and Eve this commandment: "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth...."' (Moses 2:28.) Upon fulfillment of this great command, so given, depended the whole plan of the great council in heaven, because those who kept their "first estate" must have opportunity to come to earth to obtain mortal bodies that they might be proved in this "second estate... To see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them... And they who keep their second estate shall have glory added upon their heads for ever and ever." (Abr. 3:25-26.) To provide mortal bodies and a mortal life and experience for the waiting spirits was the very purpose of the creation. Yet, notwithstanding the great powers of the Priesthood which he held, Adam was powerless to g0 forward by himself, to the providing of earthly tabernacles for the spirits eager to enter into their "second estate...." Adam alone, no matter what his priesthood, could not bring this about. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 3.) Our first earthly parents began an earthly family unit of which President Clark speaks in the following paragraph, as he pictures the possible, ultimate destiny of the righteous earthly family: Thus every earthly family unit that ls properly begun by a marriage in a House of the Lord, performed by one having authority thereto, has within its reach this infinite opportunity of eventually becoming creators after eternities of schooling and preparation, they have the infinite opportunity of heading another celestial family, which means the power and opportunity of creating worlds and peopling them. This is the supreme work, the very highest glory of which God has told us. Even its appreciative contemplation is almost beyond our finite reach. (Ibid., lesson 1.) (See also, Joseph Smith, History of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Vol. 5, Pp. 391 [commonly called Documentary History of the Church; hereinafter referred to as DHC}.) There are the essential facts which form the basis for our understanding of the significance of the role of woman in the eternity of life. Questions 1. How may a review of these essential facts, assure women that they hold a position of importance in this the "second estate"? Discuss. Lesson Department 2. Do you think that women who do not believe in a pre-existent life may find it difficult to cultivate an assurance of general importance in life? If so, why? Discuss. 3. What must we do to keep our "second estate"? INTO THE GARDEN From a word picture of the Garden of Eden and of our first mortal parents, Adam and Eve, we quote the following from President Clark: So came Eve, an helpmeet to the priesthood mission of Adam—Eve the last created being in the creation of the world, without whom the whole creation of the world and all that was in the world would have been in vain and the purposes of God have come to naught. Receiving her, Adam took her in her purity, took her, radiant and divinely fair, into the Garden he had dressed and kept for her, into the bridal home he had built, into the Garden that from then till now has been the symbol of heaven on earth, there to begin together their earthly life, that was finally to bring opportunity for salvation and exaltation to the untold myriads of spirits then waiting for the mortal tabernacles these two were to make it possible for them to possess. The Only Begotten had fashioned the world, had filled it with beautiful flowers and lofty forests, with grasses and grains, and multitudes of living creatures, Adam had had some part in this. But the key to the glorious arch of temporal, earthly creation for man was still missing. So Eve came to build, to organize, through the power of the Father, the bodies of mortal man, to be a creator of bodies under the faculties given her by the Priesthood of God, so that God's design and the Great Plan might meet fruition. This was her calling; this was her blessing, bestowed by the priesthood. This is the place of our wives and of our mothers in the Eternal Plan. They are not the bearers of the priesthood; they are not charged with carrying out the duties and functions of the priesthood; nor are they laden with its responsibilities; 949 December 1969 they are builders and organizers under its power, and partakers of its blessings, possessing the complement of the priesthood powers and possessing a function as divinely called, as eternally important in its place as the priesthood itself. The crowning glory of motherhood came to the daughters of Eve, when, in Bethlehem, there was born to Mary of Nazareth a mortal, the Christ child, begotten of the Father. (Immortality and Eternal Life, Vol. 2, lesson 3.) TO KEEP IN MIND Thus, for the woman who may wonder about her opportunity to make a worthwhile contribution, we repeat that righteous motherhood is fulfilling "... A function as divinely called, as eternally important in its place as the priesthood itself." (Ibid.) A teaching which has been expressed many times in Relief Society lessons, also is repeated here. Not all wives are mothers; not all adult women in the Church are wives, often from no fault of their own. Relevant to this situation President Joseph Fielding Smith states: Now, just one more thought: You good sisters, who are single and alone, do not fear, do not feel that blessings are going to be withheld from you. You are not under any obligation or necessity of accepting some proposal that comes to you which is distasteful for fear you will come under condemnation. If in your hearts you feel that the gospel is true and would under proper conditions receive these ordinances and sealing blessings in the temple of the Lord, and that is your faith and your hope and your desire, and that does not come to you now, the Lord will make it up, and you shall be blessed—for no blessing shall be withheld. The Lord will judge you according to the desires of your hearts when blessings are withheld, and he is not going to condemn you for that which you cannot help. (Joseph Fielding Smith, Elijah the Prophet and His Mission, p. 51.) 950 FOR THE "SECOND ESTATE" President Clark speaks of the ideal Latter-day Saint home where parents fulfill their responsibilities in righteousness. He impressively visualizes the return of the mothers from their earthly missions into the presence of the Father of all, to give account of their stewardship. The picture he projects is a glorious goal to which all Latter-day Saint mothers would do well to keep in mind. When the souls shall return to the presence of the Father of all, the worthy mothers will be there to welcome their worthy children; and with humble pride born of righteous achievement, they will reverently bow and humbly speak: Father, we come back to thee with the righteous souls whose earthly bodies thou lettest us to build, "bone of our bone, flesh of our flesh," all to thine everlasting honor and glory and to our blessing and exaltation forever. Blessed were our wombs, for they bore children, even as thou didst command, in the image of thine Only Begotten, who is in the image of thee. Great is the joy of this the end of our labors, for these souls have been saved with eternal life. Blessed were we in our example set, for thou gavest us the power to live worthily; in the teaching of thy children, thou didst give us a goodly measure of wisdom. Blessed were we in our understanding, for thou didst cause the Holy Ghost to enlighten our minds. Blessed were we in our living, for thou didst give us patience and kindliness, and forgiving natures, with charity and unbounded love. Blessed were we that thou didst send these spirits to the bodies which we by thy power fashioned, for they were choice spirits. Blessed were we in their companionship, for they were loving and kind, respectful and obedient to us. Thomas "'Humblest service done by willing and discerning souls is glory."' —George Eliot Northern Hemisphere: Fourth Meeting, March 1970 Southern Hemisphere: July 1970 OBJECTIVE: To emphasize that service makes a citizen out of an inhabitant and a community out of a town. ART 'The Blind Girl'' by John Everett Millais (1829-1896) English (September 1969 Relief Society Magazine, p. 688.) Commentary on art selection by Floyd E. Breinholt, Chairman, Department of Art, Brigham Young University. (September 1969 Relief Society Magazine, p. 689.) What do you think of when you see this picture? "The Blind Girl' is not difficult to understand. It could be said to be true to nature with an obvious message. Try asking a group of people of any age to look at the painting and tell the story. Abstract the story into one word and see how often it will be "service." John Everett Millais was a precocious child. He was recognized as having great talent at age four. At seven he was drawing amazing likenesses of family and friends. At eleven he was accepted into the Royal Academy as its youngest student and was later elected to membership. Early in his career as an artist he and several friends formed a group known as Pre-Raphaelites, who set principles of painting somewhat contrary to the accepted manner of painting of the time. They believed art should be based upon and be true to nature and represent sincere expression of sincere beliefs and adhere to the gospel of thoroughness. As a result, Millais' work was full of detail, yet there was nothing harsh. The details were absorbed in the whole truth without detracting from the complete, satisfying beauty of the canvas. As is so often the case, he was severely criticized by the critics of his time. His most enduring work, "The Blind Girl," has proved to be one for which he was most condemned. One said, '""'We must protest against sweet, lollipop colours, raw green fields, and lace-up boots ostentaciously large." In Millais' time, he was a revolutionist and it is chiefly because of his revolutionary works that he lives today.... 952 INTRODUCTORY COMMENTS A woman may live in a particular neighborhood without identifying with it, but her most casual act of service to that neighborhood—if no more than soliciting the block in which she lives in behalf of a philanthropic fund —gives coherence and _ special meaning to an area and often helps set an attitude toward the larger whole of which her neighborhood is part. We can't serve and remain totally unconcerned —as anyone knows who has tried to recruit volunteers to canvas for worthy causes—however, it is difficult to find prospective helpers whose vision of their contribution is not bounded by the walls of their house and the fences of their yard. This is not to question the priority of home. But it does suggest that seeing one's home in context can prepare one to be more effective in every sense; for the happy, developing family is part of a neighborhood, a city, a country. The opening selections in this section on service, therefore, focus on an expanded view of the individual. "SONG OF MYSELF"' BY WALT WHITMAN In volume two of Out of the Best Books we presented two poems by Walt Whitman and a brief biographical sketch. The stanzas we include in this section are from the work which is most characteristic of him—JLeaves of Grass. What Whitman has to say to most of us in this poem is not to be afraid to enjoy life and to expand that capacity to its fulness. Lesson Department Only if we are keenly alive to that going on about us will we be able to serve at our highest capacity. In the final section which we reprint from Whitman's "Song of Myself," he stresses the insights which recognition of our common humanity can bring to us: These are really the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands, they are not original with me, If they are not yours as much as mine they are nothing, or next to nothing, If they are not the riddle and the untying of the riddle they are nothing, If they are not just as close as they are distant they are nothing. This is the grass that grows wherever the land is and the water is, This the common air that bathes the globe. "TO FIGHT ALOUD" BY EMILY DICKINSON Whitman's identification with everything—both good and bad— needs the corrective of Emily Dickinson's discipline in "To Fight Aloud." To fight aloud is very brave, But gallanter, I know, Who charge within the bosom, The cavalry of woe. Who win, and nations do not see, Who fall, and none observe, Whose dying eyes no country Regards with Patriot Love. We trust, in plumed procession, For such the angels go, Rank after rank, with even feet And uniforms of snow. For someone committed to the gospel, Whitman's total identification is not sufficiently discriminating. We need to be aware of the world that surrounds us, but we are not content to accept its degradation as well as its exaltation. Awareness should not imply justification. 953 December 1969 Miss Dickinson's poem is a fine example of discriminating awareness in considering human potential. She suggests that only if our view of ourself transcends earthly concerns are we ready to see our divine possibilities. "A WREATH FOR MISS TOTTEN" BY HORTENSE CALISHER In "A Wreath for Miss Totten" we encounter the selflessness which "To Fight Aloud" praised. This story may have a school setting but it is not so much a story of education as it is a revelation of that capacity and determination to help young people grow that distinguishes those who truly teach, whether in the school or the home. As the writer of this touching story recalls, there was little, if any, recognition of the total effort Miss Totten was expending for Mooley Davis. Perhaps the principal was sensitive to the result of her labor, but few of the children seemed lastingly impressed. The writer is not at all sure that Mooley herself attended Miss Totten's furneral. The fact that her actions did have a permanent effect on at least one of her students, who was only indirectly involved, has little relevance to the actions themselves. Miss Totten wasn't working for recognition; one has the feeling that she didn't expect gratitude. Service, for her, was as natural as breathing and as little thought about. Question for Discussion If, as the scriptures tell us, we find our lives in losing them, how might Miss Totten have found hers? 954 "CONCORD HYMN" BY RALPH WALDO EMERSON A monument to the Minute Men who fought the British troops at Concord in 1775 was set up in the middle 1830's on a piece of land which had been presented to the town by one of Ralph Waldo Emerson's §forbears. Although Emerson himself could not be present for the dedication of the monument on the Fourth of July, 1837, the hymn he had composed for the event was sung by a choir to the tune of "Old Hundred." Although this poem has been so widely reprinted that its opening stanza is one of the best known in American poetry, its final lines are almost forgotten. It needs to be seen in its entirety if it is to be fully appreciated: By the rude bridge that arched the flood, Their flag to April's breeze unfurled, Here once the embattled farmers stood And fired the shot heard round the world. The foe long since in silence slept; Alike the conqueror silent sleeps; And Time the ruined bridge has swept Down the dark stream which seaward creeps. On this green bank, by this soft stream, We set today a votive stone; That memory may their deed redeem, When, like our sires, our sons are gone. Spirit, that made those heroes dare To die, and leave their children free, Bid Time and Nature gently spare The shaft we raise to them and thee. The shot was not "heard round the world" because a few loosely organized men engaged in a skirmish with those they thought of as oppressors. History is full of defiant deeds in support of causes, and the Colonists in America appear to have been under the mildest of yokes. It is the attitude of those who were willing to die that Emerson would have us remember. In mutually shared devotion to _ principles which seemed to them to be violated, they ceased being Colonists and became Americans. Note, in the final stanza, that the memorial is not simply to the men who die or to the circumstances surrounding their sacrifice; it is also to the "spirit" which prompted them to serve their country nobly. Question for Discussion How might the same "spirit" Emerson talks of prompt us to serve our country today? "AIRMAN'S LETTER" Among the personal belongings of a young Royal Air Force pilot in a bomber squadron, who was killed in execution of his duty, was a letter to his mother, to be sent to her if he were killed. The letter was sent to the bereaved mother by the young officer's station commander, who asked for permission to publish it anonymously. The permission was granted. The anonymous "Airman's Letter" is a more current example of the dedication Emerson discusses in "Concord Hymn." At a time when clamorous voices are being raised against the draft of young men to serve their country, the clear, comCOMMUNICATION Lesson Department mitted voice of this British airman is reassuring. "MOTHER OF COMPTONS" BY MILTON S. MAYER "THE STORY OF JEPHTHAH'S DAUGHTER''—Judges, Chapter 11. The final two selections in this section, 'Mother of Comptons" and "The Story of Jephthah's Daughter," illustrate lives given over to Christian service. Mrs. Compton is explicit in citing the Bible as the source of the direction she' and her husband provided for their children. The nameless daughter of Jephthah simply takes for granted the sacredness of her father's promise to the Lord. Mrs. Compton is not playing at being a wife and mother; and she is not viewing her roles here so narrowly that she cannot be an inspiration whenever she needs to be. Jephthah's daughter would like to be a mother in Israel but she is quite prepared to accept the role that her father has imposed on her. In the totality of their commitment, both Mrs. Compton and Jephthah's daughter face the consequences of their belief with confidence and serenity. Question for discussion 1. Mrs. Compton lives for what she believes. 2. Jephthah's daughter dies for what she accepts. 3. What are the special problems which each type of service requires? When stress and strain are rife, And harsh words would be easiest to say, Replace taut lines of doubt or bitterness, With quiet threads of thoughtful understanding. —Ruth G. Have the Sweetest Holidays " Holiday Cookies BON BON COOKIES 1 tbsp. Vanilla % cup soft butter 1% cups flour % cup sifted U and | Y tsp. Salt Powdered Sugar Heat oven to 350° (moderate). Mix butter, sugar, vanilla. Blend in flour and salt thoroughly with hand. Add food coloring, if desired. Wrap level tbsp. Dough around filling. Bake 1" apart on ungreased baking sheet 12 to 15 minutes, until set but not brown. Dip tops of warm cookies in icing Decorate. Makes 20 to 25 cookies CHOCOLATE DOUGH: Add 1 square unsweetened chocolate (1-0z.) melted. BROWN SUGAR DOUGH: Use 2 cup brown sugar (packed) in place of powdered sugar. ICING: Mix 1 cup sifted U and | Powdered Sugar, 2 tbsp. Cream, 1 tsp. Vanilla. Add food coloring. For Chocolate: Add 1 sq. Unsweetened (1-0z.) melted, and use % cup cream. FILLING: 1. Wrap a cherry, date, nut, chocolate piece, etc. In Bon Bon Cookie dough—white (or tinted), chocolate, or brown sugar. Or make the center itself of dough, mixed with chopped nuts or dates, etc. — then wrap. 2. Dip in icing after baking. You can vary your icings, chocolate, white, and assorted colors. 3.
